HPL.question: It takes about __________ minutes for the cones and __________ minutes for the rods to achieve maximum sensitivity.

According to Rasmussen’s SRK model:
The __________ mode involves execution of actions based on __________ which have been learned.
Deep-seated tiredness caused by continuous exposure to jet-lag is a characteristic of:
The purpose of the __________ is to carry air from the nose or mouth to the lungs.
Blood pressure is measured in __________ of mercury.
Slight imperfections in the curvature of the cornea or the lens...is a description of:
Blood pressure is lowest at __________.
The normal cardiac output is approximately __________ litres per minute.
Air sickness is caused by a disagreement between accelerations sensed by the __________ system and accelerations and orientation detected by the __________.
__________ is the inability to focus on near objects.
A progressive narrowing of the coronary arteries can cause shortness of breath and chest pain when exercising. This condition is known as:
For a person seated (at rest) the time of useful consciousness is: 30 to 90 seconds at __________ ft.
__________ vision is obtained because of the very slight difference in the perspective between one eye and the other.
The __________ pumps blood around the body.
The 5 stages of sleep includes: Stage 2: __________ sleep.
Dark adaptation causes increased sensitivity and __________ the threshold for detecting stimuli.
When hyperventilation occurs the blood's:
The accepted time zone adjustment technique states that: For less than 24 hrs in the new zone __________.
choices: take a long sleep on arrival
take a short nap immediately and a longer sleep before the next duty period

HPL.question: Conductive deafness is caused by problems in the __________ ear.
The amount of oxygen attached to __________ is measured by the blood oxygen saturation level. It is about 98% for a normal healthy human.
Cones used for colour vision are concentrated around the __________ part of the retina, called the __________ .
The 1 of the 3 physiological thresholds for hypoxia is: __________ threshold 22 000 ft.
Cones are __________ light sensitive than rods.
In normal operations, cabin altitude in a pressurised aircraft never exceeds 8000 ft. This protects crew and passengers against hypoxia and __________.
The vestibular apparatus detects __________.
Presbyopia:
choices: is common over the age of 50.
is partial visual loss due to pressure changes in the eye.
is caused by long-termed exposure to stimuli over 90 dB.
is usually treated by surgical replacement of the lens and is compatible with flying.
HPL.answer: is common over the age of 50.

HPL.question: The contraction and relaxation of the ciliary muscle which changes the shape, and thus focal length, of the lens is known as:
The 1 of the 3 physiological thresholds for hypoxia is: __________ threshold 10 000 to 12 000 ft.
When deprived of sleep, the individual builds up a __________ which can only be satisfied by one or more longer periods of sleep to catch up.
The middle ear contains 3 small bones which conduct vibrations via the oval window to the __________ in the inner ear.
The term "circadian rhythm" describes the:
choices: biological cycle controlled by a 24-hour internal clock in the brain that regulates behavioural and physiological changes.
physiological state in which there is a decreased capacity to perform cognitive tasks and an increased variability in performance.
period of impaired cognitive performance and reduced vigilance following awakening from a regular sleep episode.
natural drive to sleep that increases as the day progresses, and which also affects the ability to sustain attention.
HPL.answer: biological cycle controlled by a 24-hour internal clock in the brain that regulates behavioural and physiological changes.

HPL.question: __________ reduces the chances of developing coronary disease because it: strengthens the heart muscle, improves circulation, increases the number of red blood cells, improves blood flow and reduces blood pressure.
Which of the following may cause hyperventilation?
choices: A sudden decrease in the cabin pressure altitude.

HPL.question: How much does the barometric pressure decrease at 18000 ft in comparison to the mean sea level?
In dark conditions the neurons in the retina gradually become physiologically more sensitive to stimuli. This is known as __________ __________.
TUC (Time of Useful Consciousness) is:
choices: the time after pressure loss until decompression sickness sets in.
the time before becoming unconscious at a sudden pressure loss.
measured from the moment at which an individual starts being exposed to hypoxia and death.
the length of time during which an individual can act with both mental and physical efficiency after pressure loss.
HPL.answer: the length of time during which an individual can act with both mental and physical efficiency after pressure loss.

HPL.question: For a person seated (at rest) the time of useful consciousness is: 15 to 20 seconds at __________ ft.
The threat is then examined in detail by turning your head and eyes to focus the object on the __________.
What can cause a coronary disease that may then lead to angina pectoris and myocardial infarction?
choices: A partial or complete blockage of coronary arteries.
An abnormality of the cardiac valves.
A congenital malformation of the coronary veins.
HPL.answer: A partial or complete blockage of coronary arteries.

HPL.question: The __________ carry oxygenated blood from the heart to organs and tissues.
Excessively low blood pressure is known as __________. It can cause dizziness, shortness of breath, fainting and, in extreme cases, coma.
Damage to the __________, caused by high-energy blue or UV light can be reduced or avoided by using sunglasses.
__________ is age-related hearing loss.
In monocular vision __________ depth perception isn’t possible.
For a normal, young, healthy adult, systolic pressure is about __________ mm Hg and diastolic pressure is about __________ mm Hg.
The 5 stages of sleep includes: Stage 5: __________ sleep.
The 5 stages of sleep includes: Stage 4: __________ sleep.
As a result of hypoxia, the short-term memory begins to be affected above an altitude of about __________ ft.
Which of the following blood pressure conditions can disqualify a pilot from obtaining a medical clearance to fly?
The 1 of the 3 physiological thresholds for hypoxia is: Reaction threshold __________ ft
__________ is the body condition in which there is insufficient oxygen to support the metabolism of the tissues.
__________ sunglasses must not be used because they make the polarised cockpit display units unreadable.
The condition in which sensory signals trigger progressively smaller responses in the brain is known as sensory __________.
The period of time available to an individual after being deprived of oxygen in which s/he is still aware of his or her environment and capable of controlling his or her actions, is a description of:
Sensory __________ is a decrease in the physiological response as the result of repeated exposure to a stimulus.
__________ travel results in significantly greater circadian dysrhythmia.
The resolving power of the retina, i.e. the ability to discern small details, is described by the term:
Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Photopic Vision is the same as Peripheral Vision.
Scotopic Vision is vision through the operation of the Cones.
Scotopic Vision is vision through the operation of the Rods.
Scotopic Vision is the same as Photopic Vision.
HPL.answer: Scotopic Vision is vision through the operation of the Rods.

HPL.question: Air is drawn into the lungs by the action of the diaphragm muscle...This is a description of:
Age-related long sightedness caused by a reduction in the elasticity of the lens is a description of:
__________ drive the urge to breathe in.
The heart and blood are essential for transporting oxygen around the body and carrying __________ back to the lungs.
Complete the following statement: During an approach with thunderstorms in the vicinity... This is a/an (1 ) __ and it can be (2) __ by a proper briefing.
The __________ nerve carries sensory information from the retina to the visual cortex.
Throughout the night, we cycle progressively through the sleep stages, repeating the cycle at a steadily __________ rate.
Excessively high blood pressure is known as __________. ...
During normal respiration the blood's __________ level determines the rate of respiration.
The REM sleeper is sleeping __________ than in other phases of sleep.
The __________ carry de-oxygenated blood from the organs and tissues.
In-ear headphones __________ capable of producing damaging levels of sound.
The danger to a pilot of becoming habituated to a stimulus, is that:
choices: It may result in hypo vigilance
It may trigger inappropriate alarm responses.
You may become dependent on it.

HPL.question: The __________ is the organ responsible for translating fluid vibrations into electrical signals which are then sent to the brain via the auditory nerve.
What is the most significant factor for causing strokes?
__________ vision is relatively poor at night.
Hypertension may be correctable with drugs and by addressing the root causes. Hypertension is a major risk factor for __________.
The __________ is the central part of the retina and is most densely packed with cones.
Visual acuity is highest in:
Which of the following accurately describes the 'sensory threshold'?
choices: The level above which the intensity of a stimulus is sufficient to generate a response in the organism.
The level at which the senses can generate autonomic reflexes.
An effect where sensory signals trigger progressively smaller responses in the brain.
A decrease in the physiological response as the result of repeated exposure to a stimulus.
HPL.answer: The level above which the intensity of a stimulus is sufficient to generate a response in the organism.

HPL.question: Are pilots allowed to wear contact lenses? If yes, which type of contact lenses are permitted?
choices: Yes, only bifocal contact lenses and contact lenses correcting for near vision are acceptable.
Yes, any type of contact lenses is allowed..., as long as a spare set of similarly correcting spectacles is carried.
Yes, contact lenses may be used as long as they are for distant vision, monofocal, and non-tinted.
The use of contact lenses is not permitted.
HPL.answer: Yes, contact lenses may be used as long as they are for distant vision, monofocal, and non-tinted.

HPL.question: The highest level of human error and poorest performance occur when the individual tries to work during __________.
An inability to focus on distant objects requires a concave corrective lens to brings the lens’ point of focus onto the retina. This is a description of:
Systolic blood pressure is the pressure measured when the heart muscle __________.
With increasing cabin altitude, the blood oxygen saturation level holds approximately constant until about 7000 ft. Thereafter it __________.
For a normal, healthy adult of average age, 1 hour of quality sleep allows for how many hours of activity?
The volume percentage of the gases in ambient air __________ at which conventional aircraft operate.
The body's internal clock, is brought into line with the 24-hour day by zeitgebers (cues). The most important of the cues is __________.
__________ vision is one-eyed vision, lacking stereoscopic cues.
Which of the following options is one of the difference between cones and rods in the eye?
choices: Rods have high visual acuity while cones observe colours.
Cones are more sensitive to colours than rods.
Cones are more sensitive to light than rods.
Most of the rods are in the fovea and most cones are in the outside area.
HPL.answer: Cones are more sensitive to colours than rods.

HPL.question: The __________ contracts and expands rapidly to control the amount of light entering the eye.
EASA believes that, __________ has the most significant implication for sleep.
At night you should look __________ at very dim objects to make them out.
Diastolic blood pressure is the pressure measured when the heart muscle is __________.
Free running circadian rhythms normally have a cycle of approximately:
The most common cause of anaemic hypoxia is __________ poisoning or an insufficient amount of haemoglobin in the red blood cells.
Noise induced hearing loss (NIHL) can be caused by prolonged exposure to loud noise levels greater than __________ dB, or a single exposure to an extremely loud noise.
In accelerated flight (positive or negative g) the __________ detect linear accelerations caused by g, as well as any component of acceleration caused by gravity.
In such cases, a __________ corrective lens is used to move the point of focus forward on to the retina.
Cardiac output is defined as:
choices: Systolic blood pressure x stroke volume.

HPL.question: Sensory __________ lasts much longer than sensory __________ because it isn’t dependent upon short-term physiological changes.
For a person seated (at rest) the time of useful consciousness is: __________ min at 20 000 ft.
The semi-circular canals contain fluid which moves when subjected to a __________ acceleration.
What is true regarding hypotension and/or hypertension?
choices: Both conditions are harmless and therefore are NOT assessed during a pilot's medical.
Having hypertension or hypotension may disqualify a pilot from obtaining medical clearance.
Both conditions are related to the respiratory system.
Hypotension WITHOUT symptoms can disqualify a pilot from obtaining medical clearance.
HPL.answer: Having hypertension or hypotension may disqualify a pilot from obtaining medical clearance.

HPL.question: Sensory habituation takes place in the:
Rods embedded in the retina detect __________ .
Rods are concentrated more densely in the __________ part of the retina.
The __________ is a natural body cycle which prepares the body, depending on the time of day, for rest or action and for fasting or feeding...
The 5 stages of sleep includes: Stage 1: __________.
The purpose of the __________ is to absorb oxygen from inspired air.
__________ hypoxia is caused by a reduced ability of the blood to carry oxygen.
The highly sensitive motion-detection capability of __________ vision serves to catch your attention.
The normal pulse rate for an adult at rest is about __________ beats per minute. (As a whole number).
In __________ vision, depth perception is achieved by only taking cues from: colour, contrast, relative size and relative motion.
Glaucoma is due to:
choices: damage to the eyeball due to high altitude.
an increase in pressure of the liquid within the eye.
a drop in pressure of the liquid around the eye.
HPL.answer: an increase in pressure of the liquid within the eye.

HPL.question: The rate and depth of respiration is controlled by sensing the level of __________ in the blood stream.
__________ hypoxia is caused by low saturation levels of oxygen in the blood.
The accepted time zone adjustment technique states that: For 24 hrs in the new zone __________.
choices: sleep as much as you can
take a short nap immediately and a longer sleep before the next duty period
HPL.answer: take a short nap immediately and a longer sleep before the next duty period

HPL.question: Which of the following greatly increase the oxygen-carrying capability of the red blood cells?
A pilot is planned for a full week on duty with reduced periods of rest. What is the consequence of this?
A complete blockage of a coronary artery which causes intense chest pain... is a description of:
The accepted time zone adjustment technique states that: For more than 24hrs in new zone __________.
choices: take a short nap immediately and a longer sleep before the next duty period
take a long sleep on arrival

HPL.question: The 5 stages of sleep includes: Stage 3: __________ sleep
Hyperventilation causes
choices: an excess of carbon dioxide in the blood
a reduction of carbon dioxide in the blood
HPL.answer: a reduction of carbon dioxide in the blood

HPL.question: If cabin pressurisation is lost: immediately don your oxygen mask; make an emergency __________ and land asap.
__________ is a condition in which the individual suffers from a lack of haemoglobin or lack of red blood cells, or both.
The circadian rhythm operates on an ‘internal clock’ which has a period of approximately:
The __________ and lens together focus light coming into the eye onto the retina.
__________ is the state of breathing faster and/or deeper than is necessary for the body’s current demand for oxygen.
__________ is the word used to describe the initiation, direction and energisation of human behaviour.
What are the two inputs to a simple model of stress?
choices: The ease of achieving the task and its usefulness in the scheme of things.
The value of the task overall and its usefulness in the scheme of things.
The perceived demand of the task to the pilot and the pilot's perceived ability to complete the task.
The value of the task to the pilot and what the pilot can get out of it.
HPL.answer: The perceived demand of the task to the pilot and the pilot's perceived ability to complete the task.

HPL.question: A __________ is an intentional deviation from what is known to be the correct action.
1 of the 3 phases of acquiring a skill is: The __________ phase, in which you consciously identify and develop the component parts of the skill.
A countermeasure against ineffective monitoring of automation is to revert to a __________ level of automation, so that the pilot becomes more involved and in-the-loop.
High levels of stress may result in high levels of ___________.
Working (short-term) memory capacity can be increased by the technique of __________ information.
A faulty interaction between a pilot and an air traffic controller, for example incorrectly hearing a radio frequency change is a type of:
Mental models, once created, __________ .
choices: are usually flexible and susceptible to change
often become very rigid and unsusceptible to change
HPL.answer: often become very rigid and unsusceptible to change

HPL.question: A sequence of interdependent errors whose effects are cumulative is the most common cause of aircraft accidents (rather than isolated, individual errors). This is a description of:
A false sense of orientation caused by the fact that the vestibular system interprets positive g as ‘down’ is the primary reason why the following, so-called, sense is so dangerous:

A human error associated with automation includes: Loss of __________ awareness: caused by failure to monitor mode changes suitably quickly, or lack of understanding about modes and sequences of modes.
Informal, often unstated, rules that groups develop to convey expectations about appropriate behaviour is a description of:
Forgetting or failing to carry out a required action is called an __________.

A series of defences (analogous to walls) are put in place to interrupt potential accident chains. Holes in the walls can align. When they do, they open an accident trajectory pathway through all the walls. This is a description of:

An aircraft departs for a VFR flight. The route involves a descent into mountainous terrain. En-route an instrument fails, which makes it more difficult to fly without visual reference, and the weather deteriorates to IMC. The pilot continues to attempt to fly under VFR but crashes into the mountains. What type of error best characterises this accident scenario?
High workload situations such as __________ require multiple rapid actions, and thus carry a risk of insufficient attention being paid to all the necessary tasks because of channelling of attention.
A human error associated with automation includes: __________ concentration, characterised by focusing on just one element of the information displays.
Which of the following characteristics apply to short-term memory?
choices: It is stable and insensitive to disturbances
It is limited in time and unlimited in size.
It is unlimited in time and limited in size.
It is limited in time and size.
HPL.answer: It is limited in time and size.

HPL.question: The GAS results in: ___________ heart rate; increased respiration rate; increased muscle tension; __________ production of saliva; loss of appetite; high level of alertness; increased energy levels.
A conflict between people is an example of:
What are the main advantages that the human possesses over those of a machine in the decision making process?
choices: The ability to analyse and memorise.
The ability to analyse and compare.
The ability to reach the most advantageous option from a number of choices.

HPL.question: Side-by-side seating on the flight deck __________ the quality of interpersonal communication.
A permanent or temporary inability to recall or even recognise events that were previously firmly stored in memory is a description of:
A helpful process in which the crew members communicate with each other and share information and tasks, is a description of:
Misinterpreting the size of human figures in an 'Ames Room' is an example of the brain trying to maintain __________ constancy.
Which of the following is a symptom of human overload on a flight deck?
choices: During the cruise stage of flight and in good weather, making an error when executing a normal procedure.
During the cruise stage of a long flight, in VMC, missing out one or more steps when executing a normal procedure.
During an emergency procedure, concentrating on one task and ignoring other information.
HPL.answer: During an emergency procedure, concentrating on one task and ignoring other information.

HPL.question: The best countermeasure against illusions in IMC is to use your __________ to help you to correct your mental model.
The faulty interaction between a pilot and a procedure, for example incorrectly reading from a checklist, is a type of:
The physiological response to stress (the 'fight or flight' response) is a description of:
Physical Stress takes place when:
choices: outside conditions put a strain upon the homeostatic mechanisms of the body.
the brain can no longer cope due to either quantitative or qualitative overload.
overload of the neurones in the nervous system.
the perceived demand is greater than the perceived ability.
HPL.answer: outside conditions put a strain upon the homeostatic mechanisms of the body.

HPL.question: It __________ possible to maintain at least straight, level and unaccelerated flight in cloud using just the seat of the pant's sense.
Having interrupted the Captain for a sound reason, the co-pilot should:
choices: Never interrupt his/her Captain at a critical stage of flight.
Ensure there is no ATC traffic on the radio that may be causing a possible distraction before continuing.
Repeat the interruption twice so that the Captain's attention is focussed on the new information.
Remind him/her of his/her last action before the interruption.
HPL.answer: Remind him/her of his/her last action before the interruption.

HPL.question: A conspiracy of silence in which mishaps aren’t publicised and so individuals can’t learn from the mistakes of others, is a central characteristic of:
A human error associated with automation includes: Loss of __________ awareness caused by being out of the loop.

To ensure that the aircraft is operated in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations; to reduce the risk of omissions; to correctly sequence actions and to encourage cooperation and cross-checking is the ultimate purpose of:
When the risk of a decision is assessed as __________ and/or the time pressure is very __________, the individual is likely to make a quick decision based on past experience.
__________ describes the brain's ability to interpret (for example) multiple perspectives of a person's face as all belonging to the same person.

During a lesson in a disorientation trainer with no external vision, a student is told to move the head up and down while the training device rotates about the vertical axis. Why, during this manoeuvre, does the student suddenly feel dizzy and disoriented?
choices: The head movements disturb the processing of sensory inputs in the cerebral cortex areas of the student's brain, and subsequently, spatial orientation is lost.
Because the training device is rotating, and without outside vision, the interaction between the senses is disturbed when the head is moved.
The head movement itself has no effect on the disorientation; the rotation of the student about the vertical axis in combination with no outside vision alone account for the disorientation.
The head movements disturb the equilibrium between all sensory inputs, and after a certain period of time, the human brain is no longer able to compensate for this.
HPL.answer: Because the training device is rotating, and without outside vision, the interaction between the senses is disturbed when the head is moved.

HPL.question: __________ errors are very difficult to detect and often come to light only when an accident chain of events is examined.
What strategy should be put in place when faced with an anticipated period of stress?
Our mental model of the world is based
choices: on both our past experiences and the sensory information we receive
entirely on the sensory information we receive
on both our past experiences and our motor programmes
HPL.answer: on both our past experiences and the sensory information we receive

HPL.question: In __________ workload situations, there is less opportunity to listen and discuss matters because both pilots must concentrate on the task. In such situations there is a __________ amount of non-verbal communication.
The basis of the perceptual process is receiving __________ information and constructing mental models to make sense of it.
A culture which allows mistakes to be reported without undue risk of sanctions, and thus enables people to benefit from the knowledge of others' mistakes is a:
Active errors/failures are committed at:
choices: the system/system interface and have a delayed effect.
the human/system interface and have an immediate effect.
the human/system interface and have a delayed effect.
the system/system interface and have an immediate effect.
HPL.answer: the human/system interface and have an immediate effect.

HPL.question: __________ attention results in processing one set of information to the exclusion (almost) of all others.
Valid stress coping strategies include: ___________ seeking in which you seek to understand and thus predict the stressor. This is a short or long-term solution.
__________ in thinking causes an individual to unjustifiably favour one strand of reasoning over another leading sometimes to a faulty decision.
Stress increases arousal, which increases ___________.
A store of autobiographical information such as memories of places you have been to, people you know and life experiences you’ve had, is a description of:
False horizons caused by gently sloping terrain or gently sloping cloud tops can create __________.
Acute stress results in ___________ in the body's blood sugar level.
Valid stress coping strategies include: Inhibition, in which you do nothing, and just 'suck it up'. This is effective for ___________ stressors.
Mental models, can pose a threat because they can be very __________.
Very high ambition and need for achievement
choices: fulfil the requirements of stress resistance
improves the coping process with personal failures

HPL.question: Fundamental philosophies for automation: __________: automated systems can correct erroneous pilot action.
An unmotivated individual __________ learn a skill as fast as a motivated one.
__________ is a generalised dizziness which is not necessarily accompanied by spatial disorientation.
Faulty __________ models are the prime cause of cognitive illusions.
In the Swiss Cheese model, what do holes represent?
choices: Errors in the system or process.
Systems or processes designed to prevent harm
Systems or processes put in place to reduce risk.
Missing data in the risk management system.
HPL.answer: Errors in the system or process.

HPL.question: Complementing leadership to ensure the optimal functioning and effectiveness of the group, is a description of good:
Motor programmes are susceptible to: __________ in which the right intention is wrongly executed.
Mode Error is associated with:
The phases of learning a Motor Programme are:
A hypothesis is made and then information is sought to confirm it, is a description of:
A false sensation of pitching up when accelerating (e.g. take-off at night) or pitching down when decelerating (e.g. configuring the aircraft for landing in IMC) is a description of:
Falsely sensing an angular acceleration, or falsely sensing no angular acceleration when one is present, is an example of:
How may haze effect perception?
choices: Objects seem to be further away than in reality.
Objects seem to be closer than in reality.
Haze makes the eyes to focus at infinity
There will be better contrast between objects
HPL.answer: Objects seem to be further away than in reality.

HPL.question: A false or misinterpreted perception of a sensory experience is called __________.
The 3 components of the TEM model are:
Between which components, with reference to the SHELL Concept, covers pilot misinterpretation of the old three-point altimeter?
Valid stress coping strategies include: Obtaining emotional support from others. This ___________ practicable on the flight deck.
A typical example of an undesired aircraft state according to the TEM model would be:
choices: Flying too fast and/or too high during an approach.
Missing readback clearances between flight crew and ATC.
Approaching a runway with a crosswind component.
HPL.answer: Flying too fast and/or too high during an approach.

HPL.question: The fundamental restrictions of auto-flight systems are: a lack of __________ in unknown situations and a lack of motivation with regard to personal safety.
A standard behavioural response to a familiar situation, which may or may not be appropriate given the circumstances, is a description of:
The 'ironies of automation' are that design errors can leave tasks to the pilot that are too complex to automate, while causing loss of the pilot's manual and __________ skills.
A false sensation of tumbling, usually when you move your head while the aircraft is turning in IMC, is a description of:
Learning from pieces of knowledge and extrapolating them to new untried situations is an example of:
Choose the correct option regarding environmental threats (TEM model):
choices: Some environmental threats can be planned for and some will arise spontaneously, but they all have to be managed by flight crews in real time.
Environmental threats are usually latent in nature.
Environmental threats can be controlled (for example removed or, at least, minimised) at source by aviation organisations.
Environmental threats refer to weather and terrain only.
HPL.answer: Some environmental threats can be planned for and some will arise spontaneously, but they all have to be managed by flight crews in real time.

HPL.question: Which one of the following statements describes the act of decision making:
choices: Actively and consciously choosing between 2 or more options.
Accepting advice from a more senior crew member.
HPL.answer: Actively and consciously choosing between 2 or more options.

HPL.question: Considering the Threat and Error Management (TEM) model, which of the following situations is considered an error?
choices: Take-off with less than the legally required amount of fuel on board due to an erroneous calculation by the dispatch crew.
inadequate control inputs resulting in a hard landing and the collapse of the landing gear.
A descent below the glide path in wind shear.
A lateral offset from the cleared track as a result of a drifting IRS.
HPL.answer: inadequate control inputs resulting in a hard landing and the collapse of the landing gear.

HPL.question: Imitating and reproducing behaviours is an example of:
Very high traffic density in the circuit, or windshear on the final approach, are examples of __________ threats.
Mnemonics are a useful way of improving __________ recall.
A group of pilots are currently undergoing the same type rating training at the same time. The stress associated with the course will:
choices: Vary from pilot to pilot, depending on the amount of training completed.
Be the same for each pilot, provided they are all given the same reading material to study.
Vary from pilot to pilot, depending on each pilot's perception of the difficulty of the course.
Be the same for each pilot, since they have all started the course at the same time.
HPL.answer: Vary from pilot to pilot, depending on each pilot's perception of the difficulty of the course.

HPL.question: Lack of textural cues can cause difficulty __________.
Published procedures designed to reduce ambiguity and unexpected or unanticipated actions are known as:
Select the option which is not a Procedural Error (TEM model):
choices: Documentation: wrong weight and balance, fuel information, ATIS, or clearance information recorded, misinterpreted items on paperwork; incorrect logbook entries or incorrect application of MEL procedures.
Ground navigation: attempting to turn down wrong taxiway or runway, taxi too fast, failure to hold short or missed taxiway or runway.
Checklists: wrong challenge and response; items missed, checklist performed late or at the wrong time.
HPL.answer: Ground navigation: attempting to turn down wrong taxiway or runway, taxi too fast, failure to hold short or missed taxiway or runway.

HPL.question: In 1972, a psychologist named Edwards presented a concept of the interface between flight crew and other parts of the airspace environment. What is this concept called and the names of those elements involved ?
choices: The SHELL Concept. Software, hardware, environment, and liveware
The SHELL Concept. Software, harmony, environment, and location
The SHELL Concept. Software, hardware, environment and location
The SHELL Concept. Software, hardware, economy and liveware
HPL.answer: The SHELL Concept. Software, hardware, environment, and liveware

HPL.question: Stimuli which register attention are drawn into memory in sequence: __________ memory which has a large capacity and can hold information for very long periods.
Select the correct statement regarding decision making and biases:
choices: Confirmation bias is a tendency to give undue weight to information supporting the current mental picture.
Biases tend to differ among crew members and thus can help finding more probable solutions to a problem and improve the quality of the final decision if managed wisely.
Attentional bias occurs when the entire crew simultaneously focuses on one particular aspect while at the same time ignoring other important details.
Routine bias can help crews to find the most adequate solution quickly in conditions of high workload.
HPL.answer: Confirmation bias is a tendency to give undue weight to information supporting the current mental picture.

HPL.question: The "Break Point" is that point after which, if stress continues to rise:
choices: performance peaks and remains at this level.
performance is initially degraded and is then enhanced.

HPL.question: An __________ leader is a rigid thinker, often excessively obedient to "superiors" and excessively strict with ‘inferiors’ and unreceptive to their inputs.
A component of the SHELL model is: __________. Aircraft systems.
What is synergy in a crew?
choices: The coordinated action of unrelated individual performances in achieving a non-standard task
The coordinated action of all members towards a common objective, in which collective performance is proving to be more than the sum of the individual performances
The uncoordinated action of the crewmembers towards a common objective
A behavioural expedient associated with the desynchronisation of the coordinated actions
HPL.answer: The coordinated action of all members towards a common objective, in which collective performance is proving to be more than the sum of the individual performances

HPL.question: A __________ culture is seen by all to appropriately punish deliberate transgression. This is distinct from a non-punitive culture where deliberate transgressions go unpunished.
The role of a "learning culture" within a good safety culture is that:
choices: Safety relevant information is given to all employees concerned.
Dangerous violations must have appropriate consequences for the violator.
Human errors must be documented and discussed on an anonymous basis.
Processes and procedures must be adjusted to detect threats and errors.
HPL.answer: Processes and procedures must be adjusted to detect threats and errors.

HPL.question: The right amount of arousal optimises your ability to respond to events.
Very low workload situations can lead to less than optimal performance.
Error __________ describes a design philosophy in which the design of a system or process reduces the seriousness of the consequences of an error.
One possible countermeasure to the ironies of automation is regular __________.
Valid stress coping strategies include: Palliative coping, in which you reduce the symptoms using, for example, relaxation techniques. This is a ___________ solution.
Which of the following is an environmental threat according to the TEM (Threat and Error Management) model?
A sense of satisfaction resulting from, or causing, a general lack of critical analysis of the circumstances, is a description of:
The combination of interactions between, vision, equilibrium, proprioception and hearing provide pilots with:
Flickering light from strobes, or sunlight through rotors or propellers, can induce __________ and vertigo.
An inability to visually detect other aircraft in daylight, at high altitude and in clear skies, is known as:
Performance ___________ rapidly beyond the break point.
Safety culture is:
choices: NOT a sub-set of national culture.
considered to be a sub-set of national culture.
considered to be independent of national culture.
NOT a product of national culture.
HPL.answer: considered to be a sub-set of national culture.

HPL.question: What does Murphy's Law state?
choices: An opportunity to engage in more probable behaviours (or activities) will reinforce less probable behaviours (or activities).
Safety measures are offset by increased risk taking.
Anything that can go wrong, will go wrong.
In order to understand what someone is telling you, it is necessary for you to assume the person is being truthful, then imagine what could be true about it.
HPL.answer: Anything that can go wrong, will go wrong.

HPL.question: The operator of an aircraft takes disciplinary action against the captain of a flight, claiming that he/she violated established operating procedures by landing with insufficient fuel on board. The captain can plausibly demonstrate that he/she has only made a mistake when documenting the fuel mass in the technical logbook after the flight, while the actual fuel on board after landing was well within the operational limits. The operator decides to suspend the pilot from work for 10 days. Which of the following statements is correct with regard to the operator's safety culture?
choices: In a "just culture" environment, the punishment of an employee for making an error is an example of bad management; errors and violations should not be punished in order to promote an atmosphere of trust.

The operator demonstrates an adequate concern towards safety and considers negligent behaviour as unacceptable. Negligence displays a lack of awareness of risks and hazards, probably reducing the safety margin in flight.

The operator efficiently applies the principle of "just culture", fairly punishing negligent behaviour as a form of positive control. This can motivate employees to be more careful before taking action and promote risk awareness.

The operator does not apply the principle of "just culture" to foster trust and collaboration. Such an unintended slip should be reported and discussed to prevent their future re-occurrence, it should not be punished.
HPL.answer: The operator does not apply the principle of "just culture" to foster trust and collaboration. Such an unintended slip should be reported and discussed to prevent their future re-occurrence, it should not be punished.

HPL.question: During training the instructor suddenly cuts power to simulate an engine failure. Initially the student freezes, but then responds quickly and executes a perfect landing. Later, when discussing the event, the student feels tired but excited by the situation. What does he exhibit?
choices: Exhaustion phase, associated with elimination of toxins produced by the stress, like adrenaline and cortisol.
Fight-or-flight response, associated with adrenaline secretion for a rapid response to a stressor.
Alarm phase, which is associated with coping with sustained stress.
Resistance phase, which is associated with instantaneous arousal and reaction.
HPL.answer: Fight-or-flight response, associated with adrenaline secretion for a rapid response to a stressor.

HPL.question: As stress increases, the individual eventually reaches the ___________ point where he becomes overloaded.
An up-sloping runway can give the illusion that you are __________ on the approach.
Ergonomics are associated with:
The advantage of mental models is that they __________ .
choices: let you develop situation awareness with few or no external cues
help you to defend against illusions
enable the brain to deal quickly with very large amounts of information
are a way of selecting what is relevant from what is irrelevant
HPL.answer: enable the brain to deal quickly with very large amounts of information

HPL.question: What are two types of attention ?
Sensed information is used to slowly construct a useful perception of the world. This is a description of:

In a company, a safety culture is established where a person is not legally prosecuted when committing an error without intent, but where intentional violation or negligent behaviour are not tolerated. This safety culture is called:
The recognition schema is based on __________ and the outcome.
In terms of decision-making, the intention to become integrated into the team, to be recognised as the leader or to avoid conflicts may lead to:
choices: the improvement of internal risk assessment capabilities.
the attempt to agree on decisions made by other crew members.
an authoritarian approach thus demonstrating ones own ability to lead.
HPL.answer: the attempt to agree on decisions made by other crew members.

HPL.question: According to Rasmussen’s SRK model: The __________ mode involves smooth execution of highly practiced physical actions in which there is virtually no __________ monitoring.
A human error associated with automation includes: __________ monitoring: the error of looking at but not really taking-in information.
The intention was correct but there was a failure of execution is an example of an __________.
Stimuli which register attention are drawn into memory in sequence: Sensory store, one for each sense, which holds unprocessed information for __________ periods.
From the following list of stressors, which are psychological? 1 - noise 2 - loss of spouse or partner 3 - heat 4 - loss of job 5 - vibrations 6 - credit card debt
A false sensation of increasing or decreasing aircraft bank or attitude (caused by gentle or unintentional control inputs in IMC) is a description of:
1 of the 3 stages of the general adaption syndrome is: Stage 2: ___________ in which corticosteroids are released, blood flow increases and body fat becomes available for conversion to sugar.
The best countermeasure against approach path deviations is to use the __________ in VMC and the ILS indications in IMC.

For a crew operating an aircraft, a culture of organisational indiscipline, a general lack of oversight or supervision by the organisation, and commercial pressure are all examples of organisational __________.
A store of accumulated knowledge and language, which is highly structured and organised is a description of:
An internal conflict, in which you doubt and question your own ability and performance, is an example of:

A pilot becomes skilled when he/she: 1. trains or practises regularly 2. knows how to manage himself /herself 3. possesses all the knowledge associated with the aircraft 4. knows how to keep resources in reserve for coping with the unexpected.
An SOP which contains a procedural mistake is an example of:
Failure to maintain level flight when manually flying a turn is a type of:
The part that the organisation expects the individual to play within a group, which serves to provide clarity about what is expected from each group member is a description of:
A commercial organisation invests heavily in new technology solely to reduce a hazard that has a safety risk index of "acceptable". According to ICAO Doc 9859, what is the probable outcome?
choices: The organisation will significantly increase its safety level, attracting more customers, and could increase profits.
The cost can reduce profits with minimal safety improvements, and could lead to bankruptcy.
The "safety space" of the organisation will be significantly improved.
The risk index for this individual hazard will rise.
HPL.answer: The cost can reduce profits with minimal safety improvements, and could lead to bankruptcy.

HPL.question: The errors resulting from an illogical indexing system in an operations manual are related, according to the SHELL mode 1, to a conflict between:
While flying VFR "wings level" on top of clouds at 10000 feet, your artificial horizon indicates a 20 degree bank.
choices: No attitude correction is needed since you know that your vision is more reliable than the instrument with regards to spatial orientation.
You trust the instrument and level off according to the instrument read-out.
You take the proper action by "leaning" toward the lower end of the artificial horizon, thus compensating for the perceptional illusion.
You pull the circuit breaker to the artificial horizon knowing that perceptional illusions called "leans" might severely impair your control of the aircraft.
HPL.answer: You trust the instrument and level off according to the instrument read-out.

HPL.question: In the cockpit there is the captain, first officer and a student pilot who has been invited to the observer seat. Prior to take-off, the first officer completes checkpoints in the checklist, which the captain accepts with ease. What are the behaviours in this situation?
choices: Captain - cognitive, first officer - associative, student pilot - autonomous.
Captain - autonomous, first officer - associative, student pilot - cognitive.
Captain - autonomous, first officer - cognitive, student pilot - associative.
Captain - associative, first officer - autonomous, student pilot - cognitive.
HPL.answer: Captain - autonomous, first officer - associative, student pilot - cognitive.

HPL.question: High altitude hazards include: High intensity __________ light, which can eventually cause cataracts.
When travelling to tropical and developing countries, what are the two diseases that can lead to incapacitation and death within a short time period when exposed?
Incapacitation is most dangerous when its onset is __________.
More than __________ mg per day of caffeine produces over-stimulation of the central nervous system and degrades performance.
__________ binds readily to red blood cells, preventing oxygen from being absorbed and transported to tissues and organs.
Which of the following materials in aviation may cause health problems, when uncontained? 1. Fuel 2. Oxygen 3. Engine oil 4. Hydraulic fluid
High altitude hazards include: A greater concentration of __________ gas.
The cause of decompression sickness is __________ gas dissolved in the blood coming out of solution in conditions of low ambient pressure.
Trapped gas in the stomach or bowel causes intense abdominal pain. This is known as:
Blocked sinuses cause pressure build-up in the sinus passages. This causes intense pain in the face and forehead and possible nose bleeds. This is known as:
You must seek medical advice from an aeromedical examiner (AME) or aeromedical centre (AeMC) if you: Are admitted to a hospital or clinic for more than __________ hours.
If noxious fumes are detected, make __________ descent.
A blocked eustachian tube, which causes a difference between the middle ear and ambient pressure, can result in:

The __________ __________ __________ system is a data-driven means of continuously monitoring and managing fatigue-related safety risks. It is based upon scientific principles and operational experience that aims to ensure personnel are performing at adequate levels of alertness.
The symptoms of decompression sickness are:
choices: The bends, the leans and the chokes.
The bends, the chokes and the creeps.
HPL.answer: The bends, the chokes and the creeps.

HPL.question: In tropical countries possible sources of incapacitation include: __________ worms.
The maximum EASA blood/alcohol limit for flight and cabin crew is:
The most common cause of in-flight incapacitation is.
You must seek medical advice from an aeromedical examiner (AME) or aeromedical centre (AeMC) if you: __________.
choices: undergo a surgical operation or invasive procedure
HPL.answer: undergo a surgical operation or invasive procedure

HPL.question: Because of the design of the air conditioning system, noxious fumes or smoke can spread rapidly from their source throughout the cabin. They can quickly degrade your performance and lead to incapacitation. You immediate actions are to: Don oxygen masks and select __________ as soon as you suspect the presence of fumes.

Major causes of incapacitation in flight could be:
choices: gastrointestinal upset, stress, hypoxia and fatigue.
decompression sickness, high cabin temperature and fever.
drunkenness, fatigue, poor diet and headache.
smoking, acute medical condition, lack of sleep and stress.
HPL.answer: gastrointestinal upset, stress, hypoxia and fatigue.

HPL.question: During flight, a pilot may get sensory illusions about the pitch and bank angle. This is caused by the misinterpretation of signals from the vestibular apparatus. Which of the following is an element of the vestibular apparatus?
choices: The cochlea in the inner ear.
The eardrum in the ear canal.

HPL.question: Trapped gas under dental fillings causes intense toothache. This is known as:

Major infectious diseases associated with developing and/or tropical areas include:
choices: Malaria, yellow fever, tuberculosis, diabetes, rabies.
Malaria, yellow fever, coronary disease, polio, rabies.
Malaria, yellow fever, tuberculosis, polio, rabies.
Malaria, parasitic worms, tuberculosis, polio, rabies.
HPL.answer: Malaria, yellow fever, tuberculosis, polio, rabies.

HPL.question: If you feel so unwell that you require medication, then you should consider yourself unfit to fly.
__________ significantly increases the risk of decompression sickness because __________ forces more nitrogen into the blood stream.

Stimuli must be of a certain strength for the receptors to pick them up. This is called:
The incomplete combustion of fuel produces:
What may the impacts of excessive exposure to radiation (such as solar radiation) be?
choices: It increases the temperature in the flight crew compartment, causing an increase in stress levels, and resulting in decreased performance.
It increases radiation absorption by the skin, stimulating the release of melatonin and darken your skin colour permanently.
It may have a detrimental effect on your central nervous system, damage your internal organs, and cause skin cancer.
It may disrupt your circadian rhythm, thus disrupting your sleep pattern, leading to excessive fatigue during the flight.
HPL.answer: It may have a detrimental effect on your central nervous system, damage your internal organs, and cause skin cancer.

HPL.question: Decompression sickness can be avoided by ensuring that the cabin altitude never exceeds __________ ft or that you avoid prolonged flight where the cabin altitude exceeds 18 000 ft.

choices: Sleep lnertia, Sleep Latency, Sleep Regulation, and Sleep Apnoea.
Sleep Regulation, Elevated Sleep Drive, Desynchronisation, and Sleep lnertia.
Sleep Regulation, Sleep Apnoea, Diurnal Synchronisation, and Sleep Drive.
Circadian Rhythm, Homeostatic Sleep Drive, insomnia, and Sleepiness.
HPL.answer: Sleep Regulation, Elevated Sleep Drive, Desynchronisation, and Sleep lnertia.

HPL.question: The most important issue with an incapacitated pilot is to recognise the situation quickly and ensure that __________.
choices: no part of his/her body is interfering with the controls
the victim is immediately laid flat
ATC is made aware of the problem
HPL.answer: no part of his/her body is interfering with the controls

HPL.question: What are the major symptoms of gastrointestinal upsets causing incapacitation in flight?
choices: Vomiting, nausea, pain in the stomach.
HPL.answer: Vomiting, nausea, pain in the stomach.

HPL.question: One unit of alcohol is equivalent to __________ ml of pure alcohol.

Analysis of accidents involving the human factor in aviation shows that:
choices: failure of the human factor is always connected with technical breakdowns.
only pilot training will make it possible to improve the situation.
there is hardly ever a single cause responsible.
HPL.answer: there is hardly ever a single cause responsible.

HPL.question: Do not fly within __________ hrs of shallow diving using compressed air or __________ hrs if diving deeper than 30 ft using compressed air.

During flight, carbon monoxide poisoning is a threat that may be the result of:
choices: Exhaust gases from other aircraft ahead entering the cabin.
Unfettered recirculated bleed air entering the cabin.
Ineffective filtering by the air conditioning system of turbine engine bleed air.
A defective cabin heating system allowing exhaust gases to enter the cabin.
HPL.answer: A defective cabin heating system allowing exhaust gases to enter the cabin.

HPL.question: The maximum units of alcohol that can be consumed per day, without causing damage to organs, is __________ units for men and __________ units for women.

choices: cause painful muscle and abdominal cramps.
increase a pilot's resistance to decompression sickness.
cause the pilot to collapse, due to an excess of fluid in the body.
HPL.answer: cause painful muscle and abdominal cramps.

HPL.question: Which of the following types of radiation can be blocked by a sheet of paper?

What can pilots do to reduce the probability of suffering from noise-induced hearing loss?
choices: Use hearing protection equipment, like earplugs, or active noise-reduction headsets.
Avoid any kind of artificial blockage of the ear canal, including unusual earwax build-up.
Use the Valsalva manoeuvre when experiencing a ringing or buzzing of the ears due to noise.
Limit the duration of exposure to high-frequency noise (above 20 kHz) to less than 5 hours.
HPL.answer: Use hearing protection equipment, like earplugs, or active noise-reduction headsets.

HPL.question: High altitude hazards include: __________ which can damage DNA.
If you have not used a particular drug before __________.
choices: use only half the recommended dose
increase the time interval between doses

HPL.question: Diabetes __________ a licence disqualifier.
Symptoms of decompression sickness
choices: can only develop at altitudes of more than 40000 FT
are bends, chokes, creeps and neurological symptoms
are flatulence and pain in the middle ear
HPL.answer: are bends, chokes, creeps and neurological symptoms

HPL.question: __________ accelerations (g) are experienced when the aircraft is pitching nose-up or nose-down.

Injury caused by air pressure is known as:
You are flying above a fog layer. What's the danger in spotting traffic?
choices: An aircraft can come through the layer of fog in front of you.
You look at the fog instead of in front of you.
Your eyes focus some meters in front of you. The pilot is looking without seeing, which is dangerous.
There is no danger associated with it.
HPL.answer: Your eyes focus some meters in front of you. The pilot is looking without seeing, which is dangerous.

HPL.question: Otic barotrauma can be worse in the __________ because relatively __________ pressure at the entrance to the eustachian tube causes it to __________.

GNAV.question: From a navigational perspective, ‘visibility’ is defined as:
choices: The minimum required visual acuity permitted to undertaken visual navigation flight.
The ability to be able to see through the air.
The distance, measured in metres up to 5000 m and kilometres thereafter, at which it is possible to see an object.
The clarity of the lower atmosphere, in which commercial air transportation takes place.
GNAV.answer: The ability to be able to see through the air.

Mode S Selective will trigger replies of all mode S transponders. Mode A/C transponders are suppressed.

GNAV.answer: Mode S All-Call will transmit information to all mode S transponders.

fly the reverse of the heading being flown prior to becoming uncertain until a pinpoint is obtained.
fly expanding circles until a pinpoint is obtained.
set the heading towards a line feature such as a coastline, motorway, river or railway.
GNAV.answer: set the heading towards a line feature such as a coastline, motorway, river or railway.

Climb to a higher level and initiate the lost procedure.

16:36 UTC (RB to KRC = 249°) and 17:05 UTC (RB to KRC = 201°)

GNAV.answer: 16:39 UTC (RB to KRC = 249°) and 17:10 UTC (RB to KRC = 201°)

Scale expands with decreasing latitude, away from the pole.

Scale expands with increasing latitude, away from the pole.

East = date goes _________.

choices: The chart convergence between the two meridians.

GNAV.question: Some states implement daylight saving time (sometimes referred to as summer time) by advancing the clocks 1 hour in spring. Which of the following options is an effect of this?
choices: The daylight is shifted towards later in the day.
The daylight is shifted towards earlier in the day.
There is 1 hour of reduced daylight per day.
There is 1 hour of additional daylight per day.
GNAV.answer: The daylight is shifted towards later in the day.

GNAV.question: Which of the following, from a navigational perspective, are recognised as causes of reduced in-flight visibility?
choices: Haze, Smoke / Smog, High altitude flight.

GNAV.question: A pilot is flying VFR and is about to conduct an approach to an unfamiliar airfield just after the sunrise. What should he/she pay extra attention to?
choices: The duration of the morning civil twilight.

GNAV.question: You are flying a low level VFR flight over a snowy area with no visual checkpoints. What should you do?
choices: Climb to a higher level and initiate the lost procedure .
Turn at DR point to next leg.
GNAV.answer: Turn at DR point to next leg.

GNAV.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Illumination by the sun or the moon does not alter visibility, nor does it alter the range at which objects can be seen.
Illumination by the sun or the moon alters visibility, but does not alter the range at which objects can be seen.
Illumination by the sun or the moon does alter visibility, and alters the range at which objects can be seen.
Illumination by the sun or the moon does not alter visibility; however, it does alter the range at which objects can be seen.
GNAV.answer: Illumination by the sun or the moon does not alter visibility; however, it does alter the range at which objects can be seen.

GNAV.question: An aircraft at FL160, IAS 195 kt, OAT -25°C and WC -25 kt, is required to reduce speed in order to cross a reporting point 5 min later than planned. Assuming that flight conditions do not change, when 121 NM from the reporting point the aircraft should reduce IAS by what amount?

While proceeding en-route, after half the distance between two waypoints, the aircraft's position is 3 NM left of the desired track. The total distance between the two waypoints ls 120 NM. Using the 1 sin 60 rule and for the purpose of reaching the active waypoint, the heading should be changed by:
The time difference in Local Mean Time between sunset at positions A 50°N, 120°E and B 50°S, 120°E on the 21st of November is:
choices: some hours and the Sun rises earlier in B than in A.
some hours and the Sun rises earlier in A than in B.
negligibly small because A and B are located at the same meridian.
negligibly small because A and B are located symmetrically to the Equator.
GNAV.answer: some hours and the Sun rises earlier in B than in A.

GNAV.question: On a Mercator's projection the distance between (17°N, 035°E) and (17°N, 040° E) is 5 cm. The scale at 57° N is approximately:

An aircraft overflies waypoint 1 at 10:37 UTC and is overhead waypoint 2 at 10:49 UTC. The measured distance on the chart between the two waypoints is 11.4 cm. If 1 cm on the chart represents 3.2 NM on the Earth, what Ground Speed has been flown between the two waypoints?
Where is the International Dateline located?
choices: To the east of the 180°E/W meridian only.
To the west of the 180°E/W meridian.
In the vicinity of the 180°E/W meridian.
GNAV.answer: In the vicinity of the 180°E/W meridian.

GNAV.question: Given: DTK = 055°M, forecast drift = 15° left, planned heading = 065°M. At a fix 36 nm along the leg the aircraft was determined to be 3 nm left of track. What is the track error angle and what heading should be flown to parallel track?

An aircraft is flying a leg of 105 nm distance on a heading of 220°M. At the first planned DR Fix 45 nm along track, the actual Position Fix is found to be 3 nm right of track. What approximate heading is required to overfly the end of the leg?
When navigating by following a line feature, where should the line feature be kept?

Which of the following is the correct formula for solving off track errors?

choices: 4 nm of Cross Track Error after 40 nm of distance flown is equal to 6° of Track Error Angle.
3° of Track Error Angle produces 4.5 nm of Cross Track Error per 90 nm of distance flown.
2 nm of Cross Track Error after 30 nm of distance flown is equal to 4° of Track Error Angle.
4° of Track Error Angle produces 2 nm of Cross Track Error after a flight of 120 nm.
GNAV.answer: 4° of Track Error Angle produces 2 nm of Cross Track Error after a flight of 120 nm.

GNAV.question: Which of the following is the correct formula for solving closing angle errors?

When planning a VFR flight, the selection of the navigation features that are suitable for transferring from map to ground is required. What ground features are particularly important for VFR navigation? 1. Large water features, 2. Agricultural farm land, 3. Exceptionally high obstacles, 4. Telephone lines, 5. Isolated towns.
Which of the following will be easier to see when flying at low level?
choices: Power stations with large cooling towers.
GNAV.answer: Power stations with large cooling towers.

An aircraft is in Tokyo (35°39'N, 139°50'E) and plans to fly Anchorage (61°13'N, 149°52'W). What is the arc-to-time difference between Tokyo and Anchorage?

What is the best ground feature to check the track deviation for a north-south flight?
choices: A river in a north-south direction.
A railroad running from east to west.
An east to west power line.
GNAV.answer: A river in a north-south direction.

GNAV.question: If a VCP is not visible at the end of the leg being flown, what action should be taken by the pilot?
choices: Continue flight until the ETO and turn onto the planned heading for the next leg.
Turn back to the previous VCP.
Fly around in a circle looking for the VCP.
Head for the nearest line feature and follow it to a known ground feature.
GNAV.answer: Continue flight until the ETO and turn onto the planned heading for the next leg.

GNAV.question: Which of the factors listed below should be considered by the pilot when selecting landmarks as visual reference points? 1. Possibility of identification 2. Transmitted frequency 3. Visibility 4. Closeness to the track

Commercial aircraft at 25 000 ft amsl communicating with an ATSU 1200 ft amsl at a range of 128 nm over mountainous terrain up to 21 000 ft amsl.
Light aircraft at 1000 ft amsl communicating with an ATSU at sea level at a range of 40 nm over sea.
Light aircraft at 2000 ft amsl communicating with an ATSU 300 ft amsl at a range of 70 nm over flat land.
GNAV.answer: Commercial aircraft at 25 000 ft amsl communicating with an ATSU 1200 ft amsl at a range of 65 nm over flat land.

GNAV.question: Two positions lie at the same geographical latitude. Position A is at 076°E, Position B at 126°E. Sunrise occurs at 07:29 ST at Position B. Provided that both positions are within the same time zone, what is the ST of sunrise at Position A?

choices: A position on the ground chosen to identify an on-track navigation feature.
A position established by an aerodrome as a feature to be flown by or over as part of a VFR departure or arrival procedure.
A unique feature, or combination of features, used to positively identify a position on the surface of the Earth from an aircraft in flight.
A waypoint, aerodrome or navigation aid clearly identifiable on a chart.
GNAV.answer: A unique feature, or combination of features, used to positively identify a position on the surface of the Earth from an aircraft in flight.

What is the purpose of fan lines on a VFR chart used for in-flight navigation?
choices: Assist with working from large features to small features.
They permit the rapid assessment of track error angles.
They allow the pilot to see what terrain will be flown over from an off-track position fix to the next checkpoint.
They allow the pilot to see what features are within a pre-determined angular distance from the track line over the length of the fan line.
GNAV.answer: They permit the rapid assessment of track error angles.

A pilot flying a VFR flight got lost while in contact with ATC and with enough fuel in tanks. What are the recommended actions in this case?
choices: Continue the flight with the same heading until the position can be established.
Turn back to the last confirmed position.
Note the actual time and ask ATC for help.
Make an urgency call (PAN PAN) on frequency 121.5 MHz.
GNAV.answer: Note the actual time and ask ATC for help.

GNAV.question: The clock method is used to establish the amount of wind component used, from the wind angle: __________° = 1/4 (25%) of wind speed. __________° = 1/2 (50%) of wind speed. __________° = 3/4 (75%) of wind speed. __________° = ALL (100%) of wind speed.

Which of the following ground features should allow a pilot flying along a VFR track to best check for any time deviation?
choices: A double-lane road crossing a lake close to your intended track.
A single-lane road crossing a lake close to your intended track.
A double-lane road crossing your intended track.
A double-lane road crossing a railway close to your intended track.
GNAV.answer: A double-lane road crossing your intended track.

choices: It might NOT be easy to recognise visual waypoints, so he/she could fly past them .
Terrain contours are more difficult to spot compared to when flying at a high altitude.
Open areas are much easier to identify than built-up areas.
Vertical features disappear in the surrounding environment and are difficult to spot.
GNAV.answer: It might NOT be easy to recognise visual waypoints, so he/she could fly past them .

GNAV.question: An aircraft is using 160 Imperial Gallons of fuel (SG = 0.78) per hour. How many pounds of fuel will it use in 40 minutes?

Following line features, particularly If they are distinctive, removes the need for dead reckoning navigation.
Overflying an area containing several railway lines and roads, the correct line features can still be reliably identified.
Line features can be followed towards a significant position.
GNAV.answer: Line features can be followed towards a significant position.

Identify a feature to be used for guidance as far as possible down the planned track.
Delay any aircraft system checks until the aircraft is turned onto a new heading.
Plan to fly from point to point as identified on the map and then on the ground.
GNAV.answer: Identify a feature to be used for guidance as far as possible down the planned track.

Rate of Descent = Groundspeed (kt) x Gradient (%) x 60
Rate of Descent = Groundspeed (kt) x Gradient (%)
GNAV.answer: Rate of Descent = Groundspeed (kt) x Gradient (%)

choices: Rate of Descent = Groundspeed (kt) x Gradient (ft/nm)
Rate of Descent = Groundspeed (kt) ÷ Gradient (ft/nm) x 100
Rate of Descent = Groundspeed (kt) x Gradient (ft/nm) ÷ 60
Rate of Descent = Groundspeed (kt) x Gradient (ft/nm) x 60
GNAV.answer: Rate of Descent = Groundspeed (kt) x Gradient (ft/nm) ÷ 60

choices: It varies as it is dependent on the latitude.

choices: mean scale between pole and equator

GNAV.question: Which of the following may be used to obtain an unambiguous position fix?
choices: 2 x lines of position from 1 x landmark
2 x lines of position from 2 x landmarks
2 x reciprocal radials from 2 x VORs
GNAV.answer: 2 x lines of position from 2 x landmarks

Which statement is correct as regards the properties of a Great Circle?
choices: Both vertices of a great circle are positioned at the same latitude and 180° apart in longitude on the same hemisphere.
Both vertices of a great circle are situated at the same distance respectively North and South of the Equator and 180° apart in longitude.
The intersection point of a great circle and the Equator are named "the vertices", which are positioned 180° apart in longitude.

GNAV.answer: Both vertices of a great circle are situated at the same distance respectively North and South of the Equator and 180° apart in longitude.

For every 1° of TEA, an aircraft will be 2 nm off track over a distance of 30 nm along track.
For every 1° of TEA, an aircraft will be 1 nm off track over a distance of 60 nm along track.

GNAV.answer: For every 1° of TEA, an aircraft will be 1 nm off track over a distance of 60 nm along track.

An aircraft travels due south from N03°30’ W045°30’ for 1666.8 km. What is its final position?

What are the antipodes of a position on the surface of the Earth?
choices: The position on the opposite side of the Earth, in terms of longitude only
The position on the direct opposite side of the Earth, in terms of both latitude and longitude
The position in the same hemisphere of the Earth, in terms of latitude, and opposite in longitude
The position on the opposite side of the Earth, in terms of latitude only
GNAV.answer: The position on the direct opposite side of the Earth, in terms of both latitude and longitude

GNAV.question: What is the distance between N60°00’ E075°00’ and N60°00’ E015°00’?

How is a geodetic latitude defined?
choices: The angle (measured at the plane of the Equator) between a line, perpendicular to the surface of the Earth, joining a position north or south of the Equator to the centre of the Earth
The angle (measured at the plane of the Earth's vertical axis) between a line, perpendicular to the surface of the Earth, joining a position north or south of the Equator to the plane of the axis
The angle (measured at the plane of the Equator) between a line, perpendicular to the surface of the Earth, joining a position north or south of the Equator to the plane of the Equator
The angle (measured at the plane of the Equator) between a line, perpendicular to the Equator, joining a position north or south of the Equator to the plane of the Equator
GNAV.answer: The angle (measured at the plane of the Equator) between a line, perpendicular to the surface of the Earth, joining a position north or south of the Equator to the plane of the Equator

GNAV.question: What is the distance between S57°45’ W077°30’ and N36°30’ W077°30’?
What is the general direction of a meridian of longitude?
choices: North, from the North Pole to the South Pole.
North, from the South Pole to the North Pole.
South, from the South Pole to the North Pole.
South, from the North Pole to the South Pole.
GNAV.answer: North, from the South Pole to the North Pole.

RNAV.question: What determines the arc radius of the Fixed Radius Transition?
Which of the following operating codes are used by which modes of operation?
choices: C/A and P – SPS and PPS.
C/A – SPS only, P – PPS only.
C/A – SPS and PPS, P – PPS only.
C/A – PPS only, P – SPS only.
RNAV.answer: C/A – SPS only, P – PPS only.

RNAV.question: What is the accuracy of Mode S altitude reporting?
Referring to a 5 dot HSI, in which of the following cases may an aircraft descend on the GP?
choices: LOC deviation bar 3 dots right of centre and GP deviation bar centred.
LOC deviation bar 2 dots right of centre and GP deviation bar 3 dots below centre.
LOC deviation bar 2 dots left of centre and GP deviation 1 dot above centre.
LOC deviation bar centred and GP deviation bar 3 dots above centre.
RNAV.answer: LOC deviation bar 2 dots left of centre and GP deviation 1 dot above centre.

RNAV.question: Assume that one of the GPS/NAVSTAR satellites used by the receiver is faulty and that the PDOP has relatively low value when receiving signals from GPS satellites (including faulty). When signals from 6 satellites are received, the RAIM software in the receiver:
choices: Is unable to identify the faulty satellite.
Is not active, software needs 8 satellites to function correctly.
Is able to detect the 1 satellite that is faulty, but is unable to identify it.
Is able to detect the 1 satellite that is faulty and identify which one.
RNAV.answer: Is able to detect the 1 satellite that is faulty and identify which one.

RNAV.question: On which bearing do errors caused by the shoreline/coastal effect reach their maximum?
choices: Bearing 30 to 60 degrees to the coastline.

RNAV.question: Why should the tilt of an Airborne Weather Radar system (without auto tilt) be changed to a higher setting when descending over terrain?
choices: If the beam’s tilt remains at the setting used during cruise, the scanning range will be reduced and the strength of the reflected signals will be weaker.
The higher tilt setting will keep the beam above the aircraft’s flight path.
Not quite. Please review the lesson contents.
If the beam’s tilt remains at the setting used during cruise, the scanning range will be reduced and significant ground clutter may be displayed.
RNAV.answer: If the beam’s tilt remains at the setting used during cruise, the scanning range will be reduced and significant ground clutter may be displayed.

RNAV.question: A pilot is requested by an ATC controller’s to “Squawk Ident”. Which action should be taken by the pilot and what result will be shown to the controller?
choices: The pilot should press the transponder IDENT button, which will cause the aircraft’s data block on the ATC display to flash on and off repeatedly for 10 seconds.

The pilot should turn the transponder off, re-select the previously entered Mode A transponder code and turn the transponder to Standby, which will cause the aircraft’s data block on the ATC display to illuminate briefly.
The pilot should press the transponder IDENT button, which will cause the aircraft’s data block on the ATC display to illuminate briefly.

The pilot should turn the transponder off, re-select the previously entered Mode A transponder code and turn the transponder to Mode C, which will cause the aircraft’s data block on the ATC display to flash on and off repeatedly for 10 seconds.
RNAV.answer: The pilot should press the transponder IDENT button, which will cause the aircraft’s data block on the ATC display to illuminate briefly.

RNAV.question: During ILS Category II and III operations, the pre take-off runway holding point is different to the holding point used in Category I operations in order to:
choices: Move the holding point out of the ILS critical area as the holding is positioned within the ILS critical area during category I operations.
Increase the distance from the runway of taxiing aircraft during low visibility, precision approach operations.
Increase aircraft separation in very reduced visibility conditions.
Prevent unacceptable interference of the ILS signal due to aircraft coming too near to the runway.
RNAV.answer: Prevent unacceptable interference of the ILS signal due to aircraft coming too near to the runway.

RNAV.question: An aircraft is required to approach a VOR station via the 244° radial. In order to obtain correct sense indications the deviation indicator should be set to:
The maximum range that an aircraft at FL80 could expect to detect a signal from a VOR at an elevation of 313 m above sea level is:
Which statement is correct about the SBAS (Satellite-Based Augmentation Systems)?
choices: In an SBAS the pseudo range correction are determined by geostationary satellites and sent to the users by a network of ground stations.
In an SBAS the pseudo range correction are sent to the users by the satellite of the satellite systems (e.g. by GPS satellites for GPS).
In an SBAS the pseudo range corrections are sent to the users by geostationary satellites.
In an SBAS the pseudo range corrections are determined by geostationary satellites and sent to the users by the satellite of the satellite systems (e.g. by GPS satellites for GPS).
RNAV.answer: In an SBAS the pseudo range corrections are sent to the users by geostationary satellites.

RNAV.question: Regarding the monitoring system of the VOR - which statement is correct?
choices: Failure of the VOR stations to stay within required limits will trigger VOR caution annunciator in the cockpit.
Failure of the VOR station to stay within required limits can cause removal of identification and the navigation components from the carrier wave to cease.
System monitors directly the phase of the reference signal and the phase of the variable signal.
The monitoring system detects a change in the measured radial and the transmission power will be reduced and consequently only aircraft in the Terminal Area can use the VOR.
RNAV.answer: Failure of the VOR station to stay within required limits can cause removal of identification and the navigation components from the carrier wave to cease.

RNAV.question: Which of the following additional aircraft parameters can be downloaded by the Mode S transponder?
choices: Vertical rate, True Track angle and IAS
RNAV.answer: Vertical rate, True Track angle and IAS

RNAV.question: The direct track from an aircraft’s position to an NDB is 050°T. W/V = 000°/30. TAS = 120 kt. What relative bearing to the NDB must be maintained for the aircraft to navigate to the NDB via the procedure known as homing?
A frequency of 117.25 MHz is entered into a DME airborne interrogator. What frequencies will be used by the interrogator for interrogation and reply?
What is the name of the process used to fix an aircraft’s position using VDF lines of position?

A communications signal is being transmitted over a maximum range of 40 nm, using a 25 watt transmitter. What minimum power is required to increase the range to 60 nm?
