What is the maximum permissible mean course line shift for a CAT III ILS localiser?
RNP __________ requires special authorisation.
What is correct about fly-by and fly-over waypoints and turns?
choices: A fly-over waypoint is a waypoint that requires turn anticipation to allow tangential interception of the next segment of a route or procedure.
A fly-by waypoint is a waypoint that requires turn anticipation to allow tangential interception of the next segment of a route or procedure.
Turn via fly-over is always shorter than fly-by.
Fly-by waypoints require turning in the overhead.
RNAV.answer: A fly-by waypoint is a waypoint that requires turn anticipation to allow tangential interception of the next segment of a route or procedure.

RNAV.question: Which of the following is not one of the principal benefits of Area Navigation?
choices: Allows direct straight-line paths between departure and destination airports in all cases.
Instrument approaches at airports, which have no landing aids.
RNAV.answer: Allows direct straight-line paths between departure and destination airports in all cases.

RNAV.question: What is the correct acronym for an approach procedure based on area navigation?

RNAV.question: What are the components of Total System Error?
Which of the following navigation specifications requires 2 x Long Range Navigation Systems (LRNS), one of which may be IRS?
Can operators with aircraft equipped with a single IRS or INS extend their RNAV 10 capability time?
choices: Yes, they can extend their time by updating.
Yes, they can extend their time by applying to the State of Registration.
Yes they can extend their time by fitting 2 IRS systems.
RNAV.answer: Yes, they can extend their time by updating.

RNAV.question: Which of the following gives the best information about the progress of a flight between 2 en-route waypoints from a RNAV equipment?
PBN path terminator FA means:

What is the definition of a Radius to Fix flight path?
choices: Path defined by radius and arc length, centred on a fix.
Path to a position fix, based on a fixed radius from a point.
Path between 2 VOR radials, along an arc, at a fixed radius from one of the VORs.
Path along an arc at a fixed radius, commencing at a position fix.
RNAV.answer: Path defined by radius and arc length, centred on a fix.

RNAV.question: What is the validity of the Navigation Database, under the normal AIRAC cycle?
PBN Path terminator CA means:
An error during PBN operations arising from the RNAV system and its inability to accurately specify the desired path is a:
Which of the following groups the components of PBN?
choices: Navaid infrastructure, navigation specification, navigation application.
Navaid specification, navigation application, navigation equipment.
Navigation specification, navigation application, navigation equipment.
Navaid infrastructure, navigation technical information, navigation application.
RNAV.answer: Navaid infrastructure, navigation specification, navigation application.

RNAV.question: Which of the following best defines continuity?
choices: The permanent conformance of the true position and the required position.
A measure of the permanent accuracy of the system.
The capability of the system to perform its function without interruption.
The capability of the aircraft to always arrive at the correct time and position at any given waypoint.
RNAV.answer: The capability of the system to perform its function without interruption.

RNAV.question: Which of the following best describes Area Navigation?
choices: Area Navigation is defined as a means of navigation along any path, using station referenced navigation signals or a self-contained navigation system.
Area Navigation is defined as a means of navigation by the most direct route, using station referenced navigation signals or a self-contained navigation system.
Area Navigation is defined as a means of navigation along any chosen path, using GNSS wherever possible.
Area Navigation is defined as a means of navigation along any path, using station referenced navigation signals.
RNAV.answer: Area Navigation is defined as a means of navigation along any path, using station referenced navigation signals or a self-contained navigation system.

RNAV.question: Precision RNAV (P-RNAV) requires a track-keeping accuracy of:
choices: ± 5.0 NM for 95% of the flight time.
± 10.0 NM for 95% of the flight time.
± 1.0 NM for 95% of the flight time.
± 8.0 NM for 95% of the flight time.
RNAV.answer: ± 1.0 NM for 95% of the flight time.

RNAV.question: RNP AR APCH is used:
choices: In the arrival, approach and en-route phases of flight
In the approach phase of flight.
In all phases of flight except remote phases.
In all phases of flight except approach phases.
RNAV.answer: In the approach phase of flight.

RNAV.question: Which of the following is not an RNAV approach?
Which statement is true regarding an offset flight path?
choices: An offset flight path is used for holding.
It allows the crew to specify a vertical offset from a defined route.
It allows the crew to specify a lateral offset from a defined route.
An offset flight path is used for parallel approaches in terminal areas.
RNAV.answer: It allows the crew to specify a lateral offset from a defined route.

RNAV.question: How is Estimated Position Error (EPE) defined?
choices: Comparison by system of probable amount of current error against margin of error allowable; variable by statistical analysis of all available sensors.
Comparison by flight crew of probable amount of current error against margin of error allowable; variable by sensor used.
Comparison by system of probable amount of current error against margin of error allowable; variable by sensor used.
Comparison by system of actual amount of current error against margin of potential error allowable; variable by statistical analysis of all available sensors.
RNAV.answer: Comparison by system of probable amount of current error against margin of error allowable; variable by sensor used.

RNAV.question: Which of the following is a 3D RNAV precision approach?
Which of the following is not a navigation specification?
Which of the components of Total System Error is considered negligible and not factored into the mathematical solution for TSE?
What form of lateral guidance is permissible for a 3D LNAV/VNAV non-precision approach?
Which of the following best defines accuracy?
choices: The accuracy of the aircraft in relation to its time and position at any given waypoint.
The conformance of the true position and the required position.
A measure of the accuracy of the system.
The capability of the system to perform accurately without interruption.
RNAV.answer: The conformance of the true position and the required position.

RNAV.question: How can the RNAV 10 time limit be updated?
choices: By cross-checking and updating the position in the FMC using DME/DME.
By aligning the aircraft clocks to GNSS time.
By resetting the aircraft clocks to the correct UTC parameters.
By updating the position on the LRNS in use.
RNAV.answer: By updating the position on the LRNS in use.

RNAV.question: In which of the following navigation specifications may manual data entry be permitted in certain circumstances?
PBN guidance may be either:
The Total System Error assumed in PBN operations encompasses:
choices: Path Definition Error (PDE), Flight Technical Error (FTE), Navigation System Error (NSE)
Path Terminator Error (PTE), Path Calculation Error (PCE), Flight Technical Error (FTE)
Flight Technical Error (FTE), Navigation System Error (NSE), Path Calculation Error (PCE)
Path Calculation Error (PCE), Navigation System Error (NSE), Flight Crew Error (FCE)
RNAV.answer: Path Definition Error (PDE), Flight Technical Error (FTE), Navigation System Error (NSE)

RNAV.question: 3D RNAV fixing gives you:
choices: Horizontal, vertical profile and time guidance.

RNAV.question: Concerning FMC databases:
choices: company database and FMC databases can not be used at the same time.
the navigation database may be customised for the specific airline operations.
only the performance database may be customised by the company.
only the navigation database may be customised by the company's cost index strategy.
RNAV.answer: the navigation database may be customised for the specific airline operations.

RNAV.question: Which of the following is a 2D RNAV non-precision approach?
The minimum equipment requirement for RNP 4 operation is:
choices: 2 LRNS, both of which must be GNSS
2 LRNS, 1 of which must be GNSS
RNAV.answer: 2 LRNS, both of which must be GNSS

RNAV.question: What is meant by RNAV 5?
choices: The defined required accuracy of the navigation system, whereby the aircraft’s actual position must be within 5 nm laterally and horizontally of its stated position, for 95% of the total flight time within RNAV 5 airspace.
The containment limit of the aircraft is no more than 5 nm and the aircraft must be within 5 nm of its stated position throughout its flight time.

The defined required accuracy of the navigation system, whereby the aircraft’s actual position must be within 5 nm laterally and horizontally of its stated position, for 100% of the total flight time within RNAV 5 airspace.

The preferred accuracy of the navigation system, whereby the aircraft’s actual position must be within 5 nm laterally and horizontally of its stated position, for 90% of the total flight time within RNAV 5 airspace.
RNAV.answer: The defined required accuracy of the navigation system, whereby the aircraft’s actual position must be within 5 nm laterally and horizontally of its stated position, for 95% of the total flight time within RNAV 5 airspace.

RNAV.question: Which navigation specifications are included in Advanced RNP (A-RNP)?
choices: RNAV 5, RNAV/RNP 2, RNAV/RNP 1 and RNP APCH
RNAV 10, RNAV/RNP 4, RNAV/RNP 1 and RNP APCH
RNAV.answer: RNAV 5, RNAV/RNP 2, RNAV/RNP 1 and RNP APCH

RNAV.question: PBN path terminator 'TF' means:
Which of the following is true with regard to RNP/RNAV navigation specifications?
choices: Aircraft approved to more stringent accuracy requirements automatically meet the functional requirements of a navigation specification with a less stringent accuracy requirement.
Aircraft approved to more stringent accuracy requirements may not necessarily meet some of the functional requirements of a navigation specification with a less stringent accuracy requirement.
Accuracy requirements are always similar to functional requirements.
Aircraft approved to more stringent accuracy requirements will never meet the functional requirements of a navigation specification with a less stringent accuracy requirement.
RNAV.answer: Aircraft approved to more stringent accuracy requirements may not necessarily meet some of the functional requirements of a navigation specification with a less stringent accuracy requirement.

RNAV.question: An error in PBN operations relating to the execution of a flight along a defined path is a:
With reference to Performance Based Navigation (PBN) what is the name of a curved terminal or approach section defined by radius, arc length and fix?
Which of the following lists all the stages of flight when it is possible to change the route in the active flight plan on an FMS equipped aircraft?
choices: Only before the flight plan is activated.
Only once the aircraft is airborne.
At any time before take-off and throughout the flight.
RNAV.answer: At any time before take-off and throughout the flight.

RNAV.question: ICAO Annex 11 defines Area Navigation (RNAV) as a method of navigation which permits aircraft operation on any desired flight path:
choices: Within the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids or within the limits of the capability of self-contained navigation system, or a combination of these.
Outside the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids provided that it is equipped with a minimum of two serviceable self-contained navigation aids.
Outside the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids provided that it is equipped with a minimum of one serviceable self-contained navigation aid.
Within the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids provided that it is equipped with a minimum of one serviceable self-contained navigation aid.
RNAV.answer: Within the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids or within the limits of the capability of self-contained navigation system, or a combination of these.

RNAV.question: Which of the following best defines integrity?
choices: The belief in the aircraft navigation system, in relation to its time and position at all given waypoints.
The functional ability of the system to perform its function without interruption.
The measure of the trust that can be placed in the system.
The capability of the system to provide accurate information continuously.
RNAV.answer: The measure of the trust that can be placed in the system.

RNAV.question: Fly-By Turn - __________ the waypoint to intercept new track without delay.
What sets standards for the coding of flight procedures?
The navigation database in a PBN approved receiver is usually valid for?
What does the AR acronym of RNP AR APCH denote?
Which statement is correct, regarding PBN?
choices: PBN is not sensor specific, like conventional navigation.
PBN is navaid specific, like conventional navigation.
PBN is not sensor specific, unlike conventional navigation.
PBN is sensor specific, unlike conventional navigation.
RNAV.answer: PBN is not sensor specific, unlike conventional navigation.

RNAV.question: "Accuracy of navigation system" is a description of what navigation accuracy?.
Which of the following navigation specification is used in all phases of flight, except oceanic / remote regions and final approach?

choices: RNP APCH procedures can only be flown by commercial pilots holding a current, valid instrument rating for a multi-pilot aircraft.

RNP APCH procedures must be retrievable by name from the navigation database and conform to the published chart, which does not have to be carried if a moving map display is available in the pilot’s primary field of view.
RNP APCH procedures must be retrievable by name from the navigation database and conform to the published chart.
RNP APCH procedures must be stored in the current navigation database and index by airport name, runway and approach type.
RNAV.answer: RNP APCH procedures must be retrievable by name from the navigation database and conform to the published chart.

RNAV.question: Concerning an RNP AR APCH, what does AR stand for?
"Managed by gross reasonableness checks of navigation data during procedure design, and usually negligible" is a description of what navigation accuracy?

Basic RNAV requires a track-keeping accuracy of:
choices: +/- 5NM or better for 95% of the flight time.
+/- 3NM or better for 90% of the flight time.
+/- 2NM or better for 75% of the flight time.
RNAV.answer: +/- 5NM or better for 95% of the flight time.

RNAV.question: In terms of ‘X’, what is meant by RNAV ‘X’ and RNP ‘X’?
choices: The lateral system accuracy requirement where ‘X’ indicates required LNAV accuracy in nautical miles, for 90% of the flight time, with an added requirement for RNP to have an alerting and monitoring function.

The lateral system accuracy requirement where ‘X’ indicates required LNAV accuracy in nautical miles, for 95% of the flight time, with an added requirement for RNAV to have an alerting and monitoring function.

The lateral system accuracy requirement where ‘X’ indicates required LNAV accuracy in nautical miles, for 95% of the flight time, with an added requirement for RNP to have an alerting and monitoring function.

The lateral system accuracy requirement where ‘X’ indicates required VNAV accuracy in nautical miles, for 95% of the flight time, with an added requirement for RNP to have an alerting and monitoring function.
RNAV.answer: The lateral system accuracy requirement where ‘X’ indicates required LNAV accuracy in nautical miles, for 95% of the flight time, with an added requirement for RNP to have an alerting and monitoring function.

RNAV.question: RNAV/RNP system performance requirements are defined in terms of which of the following?

choices: In the oceanic and remote phase of flight.
In all phases of flight except in the en-route, approach and departure phases.
In the approach phase of flight.
In the en-route, approach and departure phases of flight.
RNAV.answer: In the oceanic and remote phase of flight.

What are permitted by the use of offset flight paths?
choices: They allow the RNAV computer to automatically select any route, off the defined route, at a fixed distance from a navaid.
They allow the crew to fly a route, offset from a defined airway between two VORs, at a fixed distance from airway.
They allow the crew to fly any route, entered into the RNAV computer off the defined route, at a fixed distance from a navaid.
They allow the crew to fly a parallel route, entered into the RNAV computer, at a fixed distance from defined route.
RNAV.answer: They allow the crew to fly a parallel route, entered into the RNAV computer, at a fixed distance from defined route.

RNAV.question: The selection of code 7500 on an aircraft SSR transponder indicates:
choices: unlawful interference with the planned operation of the flight
RNAV.answer: unlawful interference with the planned operation of the flight

RNAV.question: Mode S transponders can provide vertical tracking by using a _____ altitude increment.
The minimum number of ground stations required to give range and bearing information using Direction Finding alone is:

R
choices: The lunar wind and gravitation of earth, moon and stars.
The solar wind and gravitation of sun, moon and planets.
RNAV.answer: The solar wind and gravitation of sun, moon and planets.

RNAV.question: In which increments of altitude is a Mode C pressure altitude transmitted?
Which is the most significant difference between GBAS and SBAS?
choices: SBAS uses an intermediate satellite to relay correction factors to the aircraft, GBAS transmits correction factors information directly to the aircraft.
SBAS uses an intermediate satellite to relay correction factors to the aircraft, GBAS transmits error data directly to the aircraft.
SBAS uses an intermediate satellite to relay error data to the aircraft, GBAS transmits correction factors directly to the aircraft.
GBAS uses an intermediate satellite to relay correction factors to the aircraft, SBAS transmits error data directly to the aircraft.
RNAV.answer: SBAS uses an intermediate satellite to relay correction factors to the aircraft, GBAS transmits error data directly to the aircraft.

RNAV.question: How is lateral position determined on an ILS LOC?
choices: Phase difference, calculated from 2 overlapping left and right lobes of energy, modulated at 150 Hz and 90 Hz respectively.
Difference in depth of modulation, calculated from 2 overlapping left and right lobes of energy, modulated at 150 Hz and 90 Hz respectively.
Phase difference, calculated from 2 overlapping left and right lobes of energy, modulated at 90 Hz and 150 Hz respectively.
Difference in depth of modulation, calculated from 2 overlapping left and right lobes of energy, modulated at 90 Hz and 150 Hz respectively.
RNAV.answer: Difference in depth of modulation, calculated from 2 overlapping left and right lobes of energy, modulated at 90 Hz and 150 Hz respectively.

RNAV.question: What is being indicated by a flashing reply lamp or illuminated letter “R”?
choices: The transponder is in reply mode and can only reply to ground based interrogations and not respond to TCAS interrogations.
The transponder is being interrogated by a ground station and is replying to that interrogation
The transponder is receiving replies from a ground station it is interrogating.
The transponder is relaying Mode S / TCAS interrogations from another aircraft to the controlling ATC facility.
RNAV.answer: The transponder is being interrogated by a ground station and is replying to that interrogation

RNAV.question: One of the worldwide SBAS in use is: _________ - India.
How many satellites are required for a 3D position fix?
Within which time period must SBAS alert users of GNSS malfunctions?
Frequency band of the SBAS data link is:
choices: VHF band of ILS and VOR systems.
A signal with the same frequency as GPS.
RNAV.answer: A signal with the same frequency as GPS.

RNAV.question: What frequencies are used by SSR?
Marker beacons are identified visually (cockpit lights) and audibly (Morse identification) as follows: Outer marker - __________ coloured - __________ dashes per second at __________frequency.
What information is provided in a satellite 3D position fix?
choices: Latitude, longitude, altitude and satellite ID.

RNAV.question: When Mode C is selected on the aircraft SSR transponder the additional information transmitted is:
choices: Aircraft height based on sub-scale setting.

RNAV.question: An aircraft is approaching the MLS extended centre-line from the left. How will the cockpit indications present themselves?
choices: The horizontal guidance deviation bar will move towards the centre from the right side of the EHSI.
The horizontal guidance deviation bar will be in the centre of the EHSI and the aircraft indicator will move from the left towards the centre.
The horizontal guidance deviation bar will move towards the centre from the left side of the EHSI.
The horizontal guidance deviation bar will be in the centre of the EHSI and the aircraft indicator will move from the right towards the centre.
RNAV.answer: The horizontal guidance deviation bar will move towards the centre from the right side of the EHSI.

RNAV.question: As a flight progresses you observe that what you saw as one return on your AWR screen has now turned into two separate echoes.
choices: The AWR is malfunctioning and the information cannot be trusted.
It is a function that shows areas of CAT.
It is normal since with decreasing range the beam width azimuth will also decrease.
It is due to unwanted returns from contamination on the radome.
RNAV.answer: It is normal since with decreasing range the beam width azimuth will also decrease.

RNAV.question: Which transponder mode results in interrogations being received and aircraft identification plus altitude being returned?
Which of the following phenomena is least likely to be detected by radar?
choices: Wet snow and turbulence in cloud that has precipitation.
Turbulence in cloud that has precipitation.

RNAV.question: What is shown on the ATC RADAR screen when the pilot pushes the Special Position Identification (SPI) button on the transponder?
choices: The removal of that aircraft from the RADAR display.
A flashing indication of all the aircraft which are not "squawking ident".
A flashing indication of the aircraft which is "squawking ident".
A flashing indication of all the aircraft on the RADAR display.
RNAV.answer: A flashing indication of the aircraft which is "squawking ident".

RNAV.question: Mode __________ interrogation contains either: Specific aircraft address. All-call. Selective surveillance calling (Roll-call).
What is the largest source of error with NDB/ADF systems?
A RAIM system has excluded a satellite. How many satellites are required to maintain a 3D Position fix with RAIM capability?
One of the worldwide SBAS in use is: _________ - USA.
What are the wavebands of the ILS components?
choices: LOC – VHF, GP – VHF, DME – VHF
LOC – VHF, GP – UHF, DME – UHF
LOC – UHF, GP – UHF, DME – VHF
LOC – VHF, GP – UHF, DME – VHF
RNAV.answer: LOC – VHF, GP – UHF, DME – UHF

RNAV.question: What is defined by a pseudo-range?
choices: A circular line of position on the surface of the Earth with the receiver at the centre of the circle and the pseudo-range forming the distance from the satellite to the receiver.
A sphere with the receiver at the centre and the pseudo-range forming the distance from the satellite to the receiver.
A sphere with the satellite at the centre and the pseudo-range forming the circumference of the receiver.
A sphere with the satellite at the centre and the pseudo-range forming the distance from the satellite to the receiver.
RNAV.answer: A sphere with the satellite at the centre and the pseudo-range forming the distance from the satellite to the receiver.

RNAV.question: What is the most significant factor when calculating UERE?
During preparation for an MLS curved approach the DME/P is found to be inoperative. What type of approach must be flown?
choices: Standard ILS-type approach with a straight-in final approach segment.
The curved approach may be flown using DME/N but using higher approach minima at a greater range.
There are no restrictions to the curved MLS approach, which is dependent on horizontal and vertical guidance only.
The curved approach may be flown using DME/N but using higher approach minima.
RNAV.answer: Standard ILS-type approach with a straight-in final approach segment.

RNAV.question: SSR modes of operation are determined by the time spacing between pulse pairs, and are: Mode __________ - addressing and flight data.
One of the worldwide SBAS in use is: _________ - Japan.
What would be the approximate range over the sea of an NDB transmitting at 250 watts?
What is defined by “an area around LOC and GP antennas where operations are prohibited during ILS operations”?
Which of the following is not a GNSS, commercially used for aircraft navigation?
What is the minimum coverage area of the final approach path (FAP) for a ground-based augmentation system (GBAS) augmented approach?
choices: 10° either side of the FAP to a distance between 15 and 20 NM, and 35° either side of the FAP up to a distance of 15 NM.
10° either side of the FAP to a distance of 25 NM, and 35° either side of the FAP up to a distance of 17 NM.
35° either side of the FAP to a distance of 20 NM, and 20° either side of the FAP up to a distance of 10 NM.
10° either side of the FAP to a distance between 17 NM and 22 NM, and 30° either side of the FAP up to a distance of 17 NM.
RNAV.answer: 10° either side of the FAP to a distance between 15 and 20 NM, and 35° either side of the FAP up to a distance of 15 NM.

RNAV.question: What can be calculated by the receiver by using Doppler effect or change of calculated position?
One of the worldwide SBAS in use is: _________ - Western Europe and the Mediterranean.
Which statement relating to the stabilisation of airborne weather radar antennas is true?
choices: They are stabilised with respect to the pitch, roll, and yaw-axis.
They are stabilised with respect to the pitch and rollaxis but not with respect to the yaw-axis.
The pilot can choose the axes of stabilisation with the systems stabilisation selector switch.
They are stabilised with respect to the yaw-axis, but not with respect to the pitch and roll axis.
RNAV.answer: They are stabilised with respect to the pitch and rollaxis but not with respect to the yaw-axis.

RNAV.question: How many Mode A addresses are available to transponders?
What is the area of coverage of a GBAS protected zone, with reference to the extended centerline of any approach?
Which transponder mode setting is selected in order to provide aircraft identification and altitude information to an interrogating station?
in which frequency band does an ILS GP transmit?
What are the maximum LOC and GP deviations on an ILS cockpit indicator?
Multipath interference in ground-based radar systems is the result of:
choices: multiple echo paths, and enables targets to be accurately identified.
ionospheric reflection, which amplifies the echoes from targets.
echoes from targets caused, for example, by ground reflection.
line-of-sight echoes being repeated multiple times.
RNAV.answer: echoes from targets caused, for example, by ground reflection.

RNAV.question: What information, additional to primary radar, is obtained by SSR Modes A and C?
choices: Aircraft bearing, range, airframe 24-bit ID and pressure altitude.
Aircraft airframe 24-bit ID and pressure altitude.

RNAV.question: When may an MLS curved approach be flown?
choices: Published approach procedure, with DME/P functional, with an authorised flight crew using an automatic flight control system.
Published approach procedure, with DME/P functional, with an authorised flight crew.
Published approach procedure, with DME/P functional, and using an automatic flight control system.
Published approach procedure and using an automatic flight control system.
RNAV.answer: Published approach procedure, with DME/P functional, with an authorised flight crew using an automatic flight control system.

RNAV.question: What does the acronym RAIM stand for?
GBAS ground subsystems provide two services, the precision approach service and the GBAS positioning service. The precision approach service provides:
choices: Horizontal position information to support RNAV operations.
Horizontal position information on the ground.
Deviation guidance for Going Around Segments.
Deviation guidance for Final Approach Segments.
RNAV.answer: Deviation guidance for Final Approach Segments.

RNAV.question: A GPS satellite is marked unhealthy by:
choices: An independent international body controlling the functioning of GPS.
The space division of the Department of Transportation of the USA.

RNAV.question: SSR modes of operation are determined by the time spacing between pulse pairs, and are: Mode __________ - identification.
What are the primary modes of operation used in NAVSTAR/GPS?
Marker beacons are identified visually (cockpit lights) and audibly (Morse identification) as follows: Inner marker - __________ coloured - __________ dots per second at __________ frequency.
What are the main components of SSR?
choices: ATC radar system and squawk box.
Ground-based transmitter with remote receiving antenna for capturing reply echoes from aircraft.

RNAV.question: A Mode C-transponder is able to report the pressure altitude in:

An aircraft is on the 120° radial from a VOR station. Course 340° is selected on the HSI (Horizontal Situation Indicator). If the Magnetic Heading is 070°, the deviation bar relative to the aeroplane model, will be:
How is the DME frequency selected for a MLS approach?
choices: It is frequency paired to the MLS SHF frequency, which is automatically selected by the MMR on entering the DME channel number.
Using a separate standard DME interrogator and DME frequency.
It is frequency paired to the MLS SHF frequency, which is automatically selected by the MMR on entering the DME frequency.
It is frequency paired to the MLS SHF frequency and automatically selected by the MMR on entering the MLS frequency and/or channel number.
RNAV.answer: It is frequency paired to the MLS SHF frequency and automatically selected by the MMR on entering the MLS frequency and/or channel number.

RNAV.question: How is distance information obtained for MLS approaches?
Which of the following is not a Mode S interrogation type?
The 3 main components of an ILS are?
What is the recommended nominal GP angle?
The quadrantal error of an ADF:
choices: May be caused by the interference of VORs within range of the ADF receiver and cannot be compensated for.
Is caused by aircraft magnetism and varies with the deviation as shown on the deviation table.
Is caused by interference from the sky wave.
Is compounded by an electro-magnetic force induced in the receiver aerial by the signal re-radiating from the aircrafts metallic surfaces, causing multi-path signals.
RNAV.answer: Is compounded by an electro-magnetic force induced in the receiver aerial by the signal re-radiating from the aircrafts metallic surfaces, causing multi-path signals.

RNAV.question: Which of the following contain the principle elements of a GNSS?
choices: Space, Receiver, Ground and Control segments.

RNAV.question: According to the principle of operation in an ILS, the glide path indicator needle is centred when the Difference in Depth of Modulation (DDM) is:
How is vertical position determined on an ILS GP?
choices: Difference in depth of modulation, calculated from 2 overlapping upper and lower lobes of energy, modulated at 150 Hz and 90 Hz respectively.
Phase difference, calculated from 2 overlapping upper and lower lobes of energy, modulated at 90 Hz and 150 Hz respectively.
Difference in depth of modulation, calculated from 2 overlapping upper and lower lobes of energy, modulated at 90 Hz and 150 Hz respectively.
Phase difference, calculated from 2 overlapping upper and lower lobes of energy, modulated at 150 Hz and 90 Hz respectively.
RNAV.answer: Difference in depth of modulation, calculated from 2 overlapping upper and lower lobes of energy, modulated at 90 Hz and 150 Hz respectively.

RNAV.question: What frequency band does MLS operate in?
SPS uses the _________frequency only.
What is a consequence of LOC and GP lateral (side) lobes?
choices: False LOC and GP beams, which causes reverse sensing on the cockpit display indications.
Additional LOC and GP beams, which can be used to provide alternative approaches to landing for suitably equipped aircraft.
False LOC and GP beams, which causes excessive indications on the cockpit display indications, outside normal indications.
Interference with the ILS cockpit display equipment, which may cause erratic indications.
RNAV.answer: False LOC and GP beams, which causes reverse sensing on the cockpit display indications.

RNAV.question: The frequency range for ILS is?
What is the Q code for a magnetic bearing from a VDF station?
SSR modes of operation are determined by the time spacing between pulse pairs, and are: Mode __________ - altitude.
How could a pilot counter the effects of reverse sensing when flying a LOC BC approach?
choices: By using an OBI and setting the course selector at the bearing of the ILS front course .
By using a HSI and setting the course selector at the bearing of the ILS front course.
By using an OBI and setting the course selector at the bearing of the LOC back-course .
By using a HSI and setting the course selector at the bearing of the LOC back-course.
RNAV.answer: By using a HSI and setting the course selector at the bearing of the ILS front course.

RNAV.question: A back beam from the LOC antenna can be used as what type of approach?
choices: Precision back-course approach with glide path information.
Non-precision back-course approach with glide path information.
Non-precision back-course approach with no glide path information.
Precision back-course approach with no glide path information.
RNAV.answer: Non-precision back-course approach with no glide path information.

RNAV.question: By what term is Mode S Selective Surveillance Call more commonly known?
In a primary radar using pulse technique, pulse length determines:
The interrogator transmits its interrogation signal as a series of __________ __________.
What is an advantage of an SSR with a selective addressing mode over primary radar?
choices: It is independent from airborne and space based systems.
Its range is unrelated to its transmitting power.
It allows for unambiguous aircraft identification.
In case of a transponder malfunction, the SSR can be used as a primary radar.
RNAV.answer: It allows for unambiguous aircraft identification.

RNAV.question: How is a satellite identified to a GNSS receiver?
choices: The satellite transmits a unique Pseudo-Random Noise (PRN) code to the receiver, containing the satellite ID and time of transmission.
The receiver interrogates the satellite, which responds with its unique ID number in the form of a Pseudo-Random Noise (PRN) code.

Each satellite transmits an Almanac which contains all of the approximate positions of each satellite, which is then compared to the on-board Almanac at the receiver, to check the integrity of pseudo-ranges.
Each satellite transmits a database of all Pseudo-Random Noise (PRN) codes, which are received at the receiver, and compared to the positions of each satellite in its on-board Ephemeris.
RNAV.answer: The satellite transmits a unique Pseudo-Random Noise (PRN) code to the receiver, containing the satellite ID and time of transmission.

RNAV.question: Which of the following affects VDF range?
choices: The height of the transmitter and of the receiver.
Strength of the pilot's voice when transmitting.
RNAV.answer: The height of the transmitter and of the receiver.

RNAV.question: Which of the following frequencies are used by which modes of operation?
choices: L1 and L2 – SPS and PPS
L1 – SPS and PPS, L2 – PPS
RNAV.answer: L1 – SPS and PPS, L2 – PPS

RNAV.question: What is the MLS protected zone coverage, in relation to the runway extended centreline?

Marker beacons are identified visually (cockpit lights) and audibly (Morse identification) as follows: Middle marker - __________ coloured - __________ alternating dots and dashes at __________ frequency.
For what reason is a mask angle set-up in a GPS-receiver?
choices: To select from all visible GPS-satellites the satellite-configuration which results in the smallest GDOP.
To make the receiver select GPS-satellites with a certain optimum elevation which is about equal to the mask angle.
To deny the receiver the use of GPS-satellites with an elevation less than the mask angle.
To eliminate the reception of the signal from GPS-satellites with an elevation of about 90°.
RNAV.answer: To deny the receiver the use of GPS-satellites with an elevation less than the mask angle.

RNAV.question: In what increments does Mode S carry out enhanced vertical tracking?
What is the coverage of the ILS LOC protected zone, in relation to the runway extended centreline?
The interrogator and transponder use different __________.
What guidance is provided during an MLS approach?
choices: Horizontal, vertical and distance guidance during the approach and horizontal guidance during a missed approach.
Horizontal, vertical and distance guidance during all approach and missed approach phases.
Horizontal and vertical guidance during the approach only.
Horizontal, vertical and distance guidance during the approach only.
RNAV.answer: Horizontal, vertical and distance guidance during the approach and horizontal guidance during a missed approach.

RNAV.question: An ILS warning flag will appear on either the localiser or the glideslope display when:
choices: Only when both the 90 Hz and the 150 Hz signals are lost by one of the aircraft receivers.
When the ILS ground station detects a fault in the aircraft receiver.
Either the 90 Hz or the 150 Hz signal is lost by one of the aircraft receivers.
Only when valid signals for both localiser and glideslope are lost.
RNAV.answer: Either the 90 Hz or the 150 Hz signal is lost by one of the aircraft receivers.

RNAV.question: Which of the following ILS approaches will provide guidance down to and along the surface of the runway?
What is the plan coverage of the ILS GP protected zone, in relation to the runway extended centreline?
Each satellite transmits timing and ranging signals on 2 frequencies, L_________ and L_________.
How many different MLS frequencies are available?
What is the maximum time to alert (TTA) if the signal is lost when using SBAS augmentation during RNP APCH procedures?
What equipment is required by an aircraft to fly an MLS approach?
choices: Multi-mode receiver in MLS mode plus specific MLS display equipment.
VHF NAV receiver, DME interrogator plus OBI.
Multi-mode receiver in MLS mode plus standard display equipment.
RNAV.answer: Multi-mode receiver in MLS mode plus standard display equipment.

RNAV.question: What is the meaning of the transponder special code 7600?
choices: Unlawful interference with the safe conduct of a flight.

RNAV.question: How many Mode S aircraft addresses are currently in use?
Which transponder mode results in interrogations being received but only aircraft identification being returned?
With thunderstorms reported in the vicinity, when lining up on the runway what would you do with the weather radar?
choices: Select map mode to get a wider coverage during the take-off period.
Turn the Ground clutter switch to off.
Increase the gain to get a better image.
After scanning upwards to look for weather, set the tilt a few degrees up.
RNAV.answer: After scanning upwards to look for weather, set the tilt a few degrees up.

RNAV.question: RAIM is a type of _________ using GNSS information only.
What, typically, are the additional on-board sensors forming constituent parts of an AAIM system?
choices: Barometric altimetry and VHF NAV equipment.

RNAV.question: What does the acronym NDB stand for?
What part of the ICAO frequency range of VORs is shared with ILS?
__________ : a complete series of values of a periodical process.
What is correct regarding antenna shadowing?
choices: Terrain blocking the path between the transmitter and receiver/aircraft antenna.
Poor reception of GPS signals due to very weak signals compared to the background noise at that frequency.
Reduced reception by an antenna when part of the airframe blocks the signal to the antenna.
Protection of a radar-reception antenna from the strong signals produced by a nearby transmission antenna.
RNAV.answer: Reduced reception by an antenna when part of the airframe blocks the signal to the antenna.

RNAV.question: VHF, UHF, SHF and EHF propagate as direct line-of-sight __________ wave.
How is a VOR frequency differentiated from an ILS frequency?
choices: VOR – even number after the decimal, ILS – odd number after the decimal.
VOR – odd number before the decimal, ILS – even number before the decimal.
VOR – even number before the decimal, ILS – odd number before the decimal.
VOR – odd number after the decimal, ILS – even number after the decimal.
RNAV.answer: VOR – even number after the decimal, ILS – odd number after the decimal.

RNAV.question: When homing to an NDB with a wind from the left, what change, if any, can be expected to the aircraft heading?
choices: A decrease in heading with right drift.
A decrease in heading with left drift.
An increase in heading with left drift.
RNAV.answer: A decrease in heading with right drift.

RNAV.question: Which mode of propagation is most likely to be the primary means of propagation for a signal being transmitted on a frequency of 116.45 MHz?
The skip distance of HF-transmission will increase with:
choices: higher frequency and higher level of the refracting ionospheric layer.
higher frequency and lower level of the refracting ionospheric layer.
lower frequency and lower level of the refracting ionospheric layer.
lower frequency and higher level of the refracting ionospheric layer.
RNAV.answer: higher frequency and higher level of the refracting ionospheric layer.

RNAV.question: According to the International Telecommunication Union (ITU} code, a radio signal may be classified by three symbols. The abbreviation A3E is used for the type of transmission in which the carrier wave is:
choices: A continuous wave interrupted with a keyed Morse code ident as used by an NDB.
A double sideband carrier wave, frequency modulated for speech, such as is used for VHF-COM.
Amplitude modulated to transmit the Morse code ident, as is used by a VOR.
Amplitude modulated by a speech signal, such as is used for VHF-COM.
RNAV.answer: Amplitude modulated by a speech signal, such as is used for VHF-COM.

RNAV.question: What is the ICAO frequency range for NDB transmitters?
__________ propagation: signal reflected from surfaces near the receiver arrives at the receiver from several directions almost simultaneously.
Doppler Effect: the __________ of a wave increases or decreases if there is relative motion between the transmitter and the receiver.
How are radio waves in MF propagated?
choices: At daytime as ground wave and sky wave, during night only as ground wave.
At daytime and during night only as ground wave.
At daytime as ground wave, during night as ground wave and sky wave.
At daytime as ground wave, during night only as sky wave.
RNAV.answer: At daytime as ground wave, during night as ground wave and sky wave.

RNAV.question: How is a VOR radial converted into a true bearing?
The AWR system may not be able to detect anything behind __________ rain, owing to the total beam energy being __________ by the rain.
A radio signal may be classified by three symbols in accordance with the ITU radio regulation e.g. A 1 A. Which statement is true?
choices: The second symbol indicates the nature of information to be transmitted.
The three symbols together indicate which device is transmitting on the carrier.
The third symbol indicates the nature of the signal modulating the main carrier.
The first symbol indicates the type of modulation of the main carrier.
RNAV.answer: The first symbol indicates the type of modulation of the main carrier.

RNAV.question: How is a Radio Magnetic Indicator (RMI) used to indicate the bearing to/from a VOR?
choices: The needle indicates true bearing TO the VOR at the point of the needle.
The needle indicates true bearing TO the VOR at the tail of the needle.
The needle indicates magnetic bearing TO the VOR at the point of the needle.
The needle indicates magnetic bearing FROM the VOR at the point of the needle.
RNAV.answer: The needle indicates magnetic bearing TO the VOR at the point of the needle.

RNAV.question: Using which mode of propagation is it possible for a signal to be transmitted over long ranges on a frequency of 289 KHz, at 06.30 UTC in the USA?
Which mode of propagation is most likely to be the primary means of propagation for a signal being transmitted on a frequency of 388.5 KHz, at 14.30 UTC in Western Europe?
Phase __________ : the angular difference in phase angle between the corresponding points of 2 cycles of equal frequency/wavelength, measured in degrees.
Refraction from ionospheric layers is used in which of the following radio frequencies:
RMI Radial __________ (QDM) - at the point of the needle.
DME operates in the __________ frequency band, using __________ frequencies for interrogation and reply.

International Telecommunication Union (ITU) classification abbreviations used in aviation include the (1) ____ _ abbreviation. This designates carrier wave emissions amplitude modulated with Morse code which is used by (2) _____ .
What is the receiver aerial location of a GNSS system?
How many navigational signals are transmitted by a VOR transmitter?
choices: 4 – reference phase, variable phase, identification and ATIS.
3 - reference phase, variable phase and identification.

RNAV.question: Radio signal frequency: the frequency of the __________ wave.
AWR may be used to detect turbulence and __________ indirectly by analysing the movement of water droplets.
Which mode of propagation is most likely to be the primary means of propagation for a signal being transmitted on a frequency of 315 KHz, at 11.30 UTC in the Republic of Ireland?
What is the order of colours, with increasing intensity of precipitation, on a modern airborne weather radar system?
What is the approximate speed of light?
The cockpit displays indicate compass bearing to and from an NDB: __________ - at the tail of the needle.
What is the beam width normally used by modern radar systems for the detection of weather systems?
When raising the frequency of an electromagnetic wave, the:
An aircraft is flying away from a ground station, whilst transmitting a signal at a frequency of 134.975 MHz. What is the approximate frequency being received at the ground station?
What is the maximum deviation that can be shown by the deviation bar on a standard omni-bearing indicator in VOR mode?
__________ space: the gap between the end of the ground wave and the first returning sky wave. Also known as the skip zone.
What Q code refers to the magnetic bearing from the ground station?
DME groundspeed is calculated by rate of change of __________, and reads 0 when flying a DME arc at a constant range.
The super position of two EM-waves of the same or nearly the same frequency is called:
At what speed do radio waves travel?
What techniques do primary surveillance radar systems use to obtain information?
What does the term "antenna shadowing" mean?
choices: The antenna is placed under a dome.
Antenna shadowing occurs when the incoming line-of-sight signal from the source is partially or fully blocked by another antenna in front of it.
Terrain deflects the signal transmitted by the aircraft's transmitter.
The antenna is shielded from the sun in order to reduce the influence of the ionosphere.
RNAV.answer: Antenna shadowing occurs when the incoming line-of-sight signal from the source is partially or fully blocked by another antenna in front of it.

RNAV.question: The cockpit displays indicate compass bearing to and from an NDB: __________ - at the point of the needle.
What is the range of an NDB locator beacon?
An AWR display uses __________ and range marker lines to indicate bearing and range to targets.
What are the 2 items of active equipment used in distance measurement?
What is meant by keying in A 1 A modulation:
choices: adding information on the carrier wave by use of a modulating signal.
changing the amplitude of the carrier wave to add information.
interrupting the carrier wave to break it into dots and dashes.
interrupting the modulating signal to break it into dots and dashes.
RNAV.answer: interrupting the carrier wave to break it into dots and dashes.

RNAV.question: __________ : the physical distance travelled by one complete wave in one cycle.
What is the maximum permissible tracking error when tracking to or from an NDB?
Which aircraft would a DME transponder preferentially respond to?
choices: The 100 aircraft with the strongest signals.
The 100 aircraft at the lowest altitudes.
The 100 aircraft at the highest altitudes.
RNAV.answer: The 100 aircraft with the strongest signals.

RNAV.question: In which frequency band may fading occur during the twilight period?
What is the approximate wavelength of an airborne weather radar system?
When homing: __________ crosswind = __________ drift = heading increasing.
Which of the following forms of modulation maintains a constant frequency?
What waveband do airborne weather radars typically operate in?
The phase angle of a wave is:
choices: The deflection on a wave expressed in degrees from 000° to 360°.
The angle of the modulation on a wavelength expressed in degrees from 000° to 360°.
The fraction of one wavelength expressed in degrees from 000° to 360°.
The position of a modulation on a wavelength expressed in degrees from 000° to 360°.
RNAV.answer: The fraction of one wavelength expressed in degrees from 000° to 360°.

RNAV.question: Scalloping is a fluctuation of the navigation signal and occurs when signals are __________ by terrain, buildings or vehicles.
The process by which EM-energy is taken up by the atmosphere is called:
What does the acronym VDF stand for?
What are the 2 main functions of an airborne weather radar system?
choices: Detection of thunderstorms and in-flight icing.
Detection of cumulonimbus clouds and turbulence.
Detection of adverse weather and ground navigation.
RNAV.answer: Detection of adverse weather and ground navigation.

RNAV.question: The line-of-sight range is limited by the __________ of the Earth.
By what angle should a 4° beam be tilted to determine whether distant clouds are above the flight path of an aircraft in level flight?
choices: The tilt angle should be maintained at 0° and the gain increased

RNAV.question: What ionospheric phenomena is responsible for the propagation of NDB signals at night?
The ionosphere is divided into which layers by day and by night?
choices: They are the same by day and by night.
E and F by day and D, E and F by night.
D and E by day and F by night.
D, E, F1, F2 by day and E and F by night.
RNAV.answer: D, E, F1, F2 by day and E and F by night.

RNAV.question: The wavelength of a non-directional beacon (NDB) with a frequency of 300 kHz is:
Why do VHF radio signals used for communication and navigation have a limited range?
choices: Direct waves interfere with ionosphere waves.
Sky waves are refracted from the D-layer.
Ground waves are absorbed by the Earth's surface.
Because of the curvature of the Earth.
RNAV.answer: Because of the curvature of the Earth.

RNAV.question: The wave length of a radio signal transmitted at a frequency of 118.7 MHz is:
What is the ICAO frequency range of VORs?
What is the principle of range measurement by a DME interrogator?
choices: Propagation delay – time taken by signal to transmit between interrogator and transponder and back to the interrogator.
Propagation delay – time taken by signal to transmit between transponder and interrogator and back to the transponder.
RNAV.answer: Propagation delay – time taken by signal to transmit between interrogator and transponder and back to the interrogator.

RNAV.question: __________ waves - signal refracted from E and F layers of ionosphere.
What is the maximum permissible tracking error when tracking to or from a VOR?
A student pilot has just learnt that meteorological information for aircraft en route on long-haul flights is sent by radio. What kind of radio receiver is needed to receive this information?
The wavelength of a radio signal with a frequency of 121. 9 5 MHz is:
What is a DME line of position?
choices: A circle with the DME transponder at the centre and the radius formed by the ground range.
A circle with the DME transponder at the centre and the radius formed by the DME range.
A circle with the DME transponder at the centre and the circumference formed by the DME range.
A circle with the aircraft at the centre and the radius formed by the DME range.
RNAV.answer: A circle with the DME transponder at the centre and the radius formed by the DME range.

RNAV.question: What system is used by air traffic controllers for the in-flight identification of aircraft not fitted with transponders?

RNAV.answer: The E and H fields are perpendicular to each other.

the process to provide a radio carrier wave for transmission.

RNAV.answer: the process of impressing and transporting information by radio waves.

RNAV.question: A vertically-mounted dipole antenna is used for RF transmissions. The receiving antenna has to be:

ASP.answer: A steady increase in the oil temperature.

ASP.question: Consider a piston-engine aircraft with a constant speed propeller. Upon reaching cruising altitude when less power is required, engine power is
choices: maintained but the blade angle is decreased, to decrease RPM.

ASP.answer: reduced by lowering the manifold pressure and increasing the blade angle, to decrease RPM.

behind TDC at each second crankshaft revolution.
ASP.answer: before TDC at each second crankshaft revolution.

ASP.answer: To supply positive fuel pressure to a fuel injection system.

ASP.answer: Provision of fuel to the engines, appropriate pressure to enable engine operation.

ASP.answer: Some aeroplane tails have ice-protection systems.

ASP.answer: Mass air flow through the cabin is constant.

In the line between the booster pump and the engine.

ASP.answer: maintain a constant and sufficient air mass flow to ventilate the cabin.

Does not affect aerodynamic performance of the wing and causes no reduction in maximum thrust.
Reduces aerodynamic performance of the wing and causes a reduction in maximum thrust.
Reduces aerodynamic performance of the wing and causes no reduction in maximum thrust.
ASP.answer: Does not affect aerodynamic performance of the wing and causes a reduction in maximum thrust.

ASP.answer: cabin pressure decreases more slowly than atmospheric pressure.

ASP.question: Cabin air for a large aeroplane during flight:
choices: Has a constant oxygen ratio regulated to a preset value.

The nose wheel strut and mounts are not built to withstand the shock of a nose wheel first landing and may either collapse or be severely damaged.

ASP.answer: The nose wheel strut and mounts are not built to withstand the shock of a nose wheel first landing and may either collapse or be severely damaged.

An hydraulic actuator attached in parallel to mechanical linkages. Movement of the pilot’s controls simultaneously moves the control surface and a servo, which moves the actuator.

ASP.question: The purposes of an accumulator in a hydraulic system are to:

replacement of parts after a given number of cycles or hours of use.

monitoring of critical parameters and the replacement of parts if a limit value is exceeded.
ASP.answer: capability to withstand a certain amount of weakening of the structure without catastrophic failure.

ASP.answer: The two main types of landing gear are: a tricycle with a nose wheel; tail wheel.

ASP.question: Which of the following best describes shimmy:

ASP.answer: They are irritating to the skin and eyes.

To function as a buffer to assist the hydraulic system during heavy braking.

Anti-corrosive, high flash point and high compressibility.
ASP.answer: Thermal stability, anti-corrosive and high flash point.

When starting a turbine engine, the igniters were incorrectly left off and a wet start occurred. The pilot aborted the start sequence, waited a while, and then initiated the start sequence again with the igniters correctly selected on. After ignition in the second start sequence, what will happen?
choices: A wet start will happen again, because excessive fuel from the previous start attempt has not been removed.
The fuel deposits from the previous start attempt in the combustion chamber will burn up instantaneously, resulting in an explosing and a rapid rise of TGT.
The engine will operate with significantly lower TGT value, until all the excessive fuel from the previous start attempt has been burnt.
The turbine engine will continue to operatre withing normal range, since the excessive fuel is drained by drain valves in the combustion section.
ASP.answer: The turbine engine will continue to operatre withing normal range, since the excessive fuel is drained by drain valves in the combustion section.

ASP.question: What are the possible causes of a hot start, and what are the indications of one? A hot start can be caused by...
choices: an early starter cut-out, fuel mis-scheduling, or strong tailwinds. The engine may spend a considerable time at very low RPM (sub-idle) but should continue to accelerate, the turbine temperatures may appear high or exceed the limitations.
a late starter cut-out, insufficient fuel supply, or strong headwinds. The engine will accelerate to flight idle RPM and the turbine temperatures may appear low.

an early starter cut-out, fuel mis-scheduling, or strong tailwinds. The engine may spend a considerable time at very low RPM (sub-idle) and stops accelerating, the turbine temperatures may appear high or exceed the limitations.

high outside air temperature, fuel mis-scheduling, or high starter motor RPM. The engine may spend a considerable time at very high RPM but stops accelerating, the turbine temperatures may appear high or exceed the limitations.
ASP.answer: an early starter cut-out, fuel mis-scheduling, or strong tailwinds. The engine may spend a considerable time at very low RPM (sub-idle) but should continue to accelerate, the turbine temperatures may appear high or exceed the limitations.

ASP.question: If the ground wire between the magnetos and the ignition switch of a piston engine becomes disconnected the most noticeable result will be that...

the engine cannot be started with the ignition switch in the “ON” position.
the engine cannot be shut down by turning the ignition switch to the “OFF” position.
a still operating engine will run down.
ASP.answer: the engine cannot be shut down by turning the ignition switch to the “OFF” position.

ASP.answer: Volume of fuel relative to the volume of air.

ASP.question: Viscosity is...
choices: the temperature dependence of an oil.

ASP.answer: the tendency of a liquid or gas to resist flow.

choices: Mass of fuel required to produce unit power for unit time

ASP.answer: Mass of fuel required to produce unit power for unit time

Air flow into the engine air intake is decreased when they are open, which decreases engine performance

ASP.answer: Air flow across the engine is increased when they are open, which increases cooling efficiency

Lower compression ratio, higher octane rating required
ASP.answer: Higher compression ratio, higher octane rating required

ASP.answer: To measure and analyse current engine performance to predict future life
