It will be annunciated. Continue only if visual references permit a manual landing.
INS.answer: It will not be annunciated, but a further downgrade, preventing autoland, causes AP disconnection and requires an immediate go-around.

INS.question: LAND3' implies __________ APs engaged or __________ multi-channel AP(s) engaged. This gives a __________ autoland capability.
Requires a HUD, EVS and/or CVS.
The PF makes mode and parameter selections.
Stall warnings may comprise: aerodynamic buffet, warning lights, buzzers or messages, and a __________ __________.
The purpose of an autoland system is to:
choices: Reduce aircraft wear through smoother landings and gentler braking.
Allow landing with no minimum visibility.
Allow landing in visibility too low for a manual landing.
INS.answer: Allow landing in visibility too low for a manual landing.

INS.question: The overspeed warning on a conventional ASI is the VMO/MMO pointer.
During a final approach, the flight director is engaged in the G/S mode (tracking the ILS Glide Slope). If the horizontal command bar is deviating upward, it means that:
choices: The aircraft is below the glide slope.
The pitch angle must be reduced.
The aircraft is above the glide slope.
The pitch angle must be increased.
INS.answer: The pitch angle must be increased.

INS.question: Which of the following is NOT true?
choices: The magnitude of autopilot output signals increase with decreasing airspeed.
Autopilot output pitch signals vary with flap setting to account for the associated changes in longitudinal stability.
The magnitude of autopilot output signals diminishes with increasing speed.
Landing gear and flap positions have no effect on autopilot output signal magnitude.
INS.answer: Landing gear and flap positions have no effect on autopilot output signal magnitude.

INS.question: On a modern aircraft, the flight director modes are displayed on the:
choices: Control panel of the flight director only.
Upper strip of the ND (Navigation Display).
Upper strip of the PFD (Primary Flight Display).
Upper strip of the ECAM (Electronic Centralised A/C Management).
INS.answer: Upper strip of the PFD (Primary Flight Display).

INS.question: The computer of the autopilot system uses, among others, input signals from the... The combination of all the correct statements is:
The A/T controls air speed:
choices: By varying engine thrust, except when in TOGA mode.
Either by varying engine thrust or by varying the aircraft's pitch attitude.
Either by varying engine thrust or by varying aircraft's pitch attitude, depending on the aircraft type.
INS.answer: Either by varying engine thrust or by varying the aircraft's pitch attitude.

INS.question: For large EFIS aircraft, an aural warning associated with overspeed warning is required.
Sequences modes when a descent is started.
Immediate awareness and later response required.
Thrust is modulated as required to achieve and maintain the parameter set in the FMS or on the MCP.
The VMO/MMO pointer is a large red and white 'barber's pole' indicating the lower of VMO and MMO against the airspeed scale.
If an autoland capability downgrade occurs before alert height:
choices: It will be annunciated. Go-around if RVR is too high for reversion. If RVR permits reversion continue using a higher approach category with a lower DH.
You may continue the autoland approach with only 1 channel because the risk of a further failure, in the short time remaining, is deemed minimal.
It will be annunciated. Go-around if RVR is too low for reversion. If RVR permits, continue the approach using a lower approach category with a higher DH.
INS.answer: It will be annunciated. Go-around if RVR is too low for reversion. If RVR permits, continue the approach using a lower approach category with a higher DH.

INS.question: In fly-by-wire (FBW) aircraft, auto-trim functions during automatic and manual flight.
N1 or EPR passed from the FMS is the target.
Mode has a box around it for a period of time.
Immediate awareness and response required.
Flight envelope protection (FEP) systems:
choices: Actively prevent the aircraft from exceeding any aerodynamic limit.
Actively resist the aircraft approaching any safety margin.
Passively resist bank or roll exceeding set fixed values.
Actively resist the aircraft leaving the normal flight envelope.
INS.answer: Actively resist the aircraft leaving the normal flight envelope.

INS.question: Low frequency.
The aircraft follows a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter.
This phase is sometimes also known as the tracking phase.
Energy awareness…
choices: Is never adequate with A/T engaged; manual thrust control is always safer.
Is unaffected by A/T because the noise of the engines provides adequate cues.
Can be lowered if you don't carefully monitor your speed and thrust setting.
Is always improved by using autothrust.
INS.answer: Can be lowered if you don't carefully monitor your speed and thrust setting.

INS.question: The flight envelope protection system prevents the aircraft from exceeding the limits of the following parameters... The combination that of all correct statements is:
High frequency.
Which one of the following is a valid description of the requirements for warnings, cautions and advisories?
choices: Warnings must be in direct line-of-sight when seated. Typically attention-getter lights are mounted on the forward overhead panel.
Most modern aircraft now only use captions on EICAS or EWD: red for warnings, amber for cautions, and white for advisories.
Warnings, cautions and advisories must have attention-getter lights on the glareshield: red for warnings, amber for cautions and any other colour for advisory alerts.
Warnings and cautions must be in direct line-of-sight when seated. Typically attention-getter lights on the glareshield are provided.
INS.answer: Warnings and cautions must be in direct line-of-sight when seated. Typically attention-getter lights on the glareshield are provided.

INS.question: Used on go-around.
The pilot of a modern, large turbojet aeroplane sets the vertical speed mode of the autopilot to carry out a climb. What must he/she be particularly careful of?
choices: The engines may overspeed as the autothrottle attempts to maintain airspeed.
If the climb is prolonged, there is a risk that the airspeed may reduce towards the stall.
The autopilot may select a rate of climb outside the maximum permissible limit of the aeroplane.
The aeroplane may overspeed in an attempt to maintain the rate of climb.
INS.answer: If the climb is prolonged, there is a risk that the airspeed may reduce towards the stall.

INS.question: When the autopilot ls engaged, the role of the automatic pitch trim is to:
choices: respond to altitude changes in Altitude Hold mode.
relieve the autopilot servo motor and return the aircraft in-trim when disconnecting the autopilot .
block the elevator and pilot the aircraft only via the trim tab actuator or the horizontal stabiliser.
INS.answer: relieve the autopilot servo motor and return the aircraft in-trim when disconnecting the autopilot .

INS.question: A fail-operational hybrid landing system is fitted to an aircraft. What does this consist of?
choices: A fail-operational landing system with a synthetic vision overlay, enabling better monitoring, and so a lower minimum RVR, than is possible with a simple fail-operational automatic landing system.

A fail-operational landing system which, If the runway has NO low visibility approach aid, can overlay the enhanced vision system on the head-up display to allow continued operations below normal RVR minima.
A fail-passive guidance system and a secondary independent landing system enabling automatic landing if the guidance system fails.
A fall-passive automatic landing system and a secondary independent guidance system such as a head-up display (HUD). This enables the pilot to land manually if the automatic landing system fails.
INS.answer: A fall-passive automatic landing system and a secondary independent guidance system such as a head-up display (HUD). This enables the pilot to land manually if the automatic landing system fails.

INS.question: Mode appears in large font on the top row of the FMA.
In FBW aircraft, auto-trim operates at half speed when there is a risk of overspeed or underspeed.
CMD' or 'SINGLE CH' or 'NO AUTOLAND' implies __________ AP engaged giving __________ autoland capability.
EFIS aircraft represent overspeed using a red and black, or red and white, 'barber's pole' on the speed tape at and above VMO/MMO.
Identify which FEP functions are exclusive to FBW aircraft. Stall Protection.
The following is an example of a warnings, cautions or advisory: Engine vibration.
The autopilot is disengaged. What kind of warning will the flight crew get?
choices: Both a visual and an aural warning.
A vibration in the flight controls.
INS.answer: Both a visual and an aural warning.

INS.question: The flight envelope protection system prevents the aircraft from exceeding the limits of the following parameters (among others):
Associated with AP/FD modes which control airspeed with pitch.
Which of the following statements about the AP and FD is/are correct?
choices: Modes are identical for the FD and the AP and are selected using the same MCP (FCU) controls.
AP modes are mostly the same as FD modes except during initial descent from cruise altitude.
More modes are available for the FD (e.g. smooth climb) because the sensitivity of the AP is limited.
The increased sensitivity of the FD modes means that the FD bars are usually slightly deflected when the AP is engaged.
INS.answer: Modes are identical for the FD and the AP and are selected using the same MCP (FCU) controls.

INS.question: A fail-operational hybrid system is:
choices: A fail-passive automatic landing system with a secondary automatic landing system in case the primary system fails.
A fail-passive automatic landing system with a secondary independent guidance system such as a HUD to allow manual landing if the primary system fails.
A fail-operational automatic landing system supplemented with SVS, CVS and HUD.
A fail-operational secondary with a fail-passive primary automatic landing system supplemented by CVS and SVS.
INS.answer: A fail-passive automatic landing system with a secondary independent guidance system such as a HUD to allow manual landing if the primary system fails.

INS.question: Air speed fluctuations can cause the A/T to overcompensate, leading to speed oscillations.
The following is an example of a warnings, cautions or advisory: Cabin depressurisation.
The 2 functions of an AFCS are: Aircraft __________, stabilising the aircraft around its centre of gravity. Aircraft __________, along the aircraft's flight path.
The primary purpose of a flight director system is to…
choices: Fly the aircraft automatically using a closed-loop system.
Provide pitch and roll attitudes to the AP.
Provide a backup attitude guidance system only when the AP is switched off.
Provide rate guidance to reduce pilot workload, increase accuracy and smoothness of flying, and reduce aircraft fatigue.
INS.answer: Provide rate guidance to reduce pilot workload, increase accuracy and smoothness of flying, and reduce aircraft fatigue.

INS.question: The mode controls the aircraft.
Comprises a Fail-Passive automatic landing system and a secondary independent guidance system enabling the pilot to complete a manual landing after the failure of the primary system.
Mode is on the second row of the FMA.
The horizontal stabiliser must be in the 'green band' for landing.
The following is an example of a warnings, cautions or advisory: Unreliable airspeed.
Depending on aircraft type, the following parameters cause a take-off configuration warning to activate: Pitch trim not in the normal range, or not in agreement with FMS or sensed CG.
Identify which FEP functions are exclusive to FBW aircraft. Overspeed Protection.
A flight control system ls fail-passive if, in the event of a failure:
choices: the system operates as a fail-operational hybrid landing system.
there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude and the landing is completed automatically.
there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically.
the system operates as a fall-operational system.
INS.answer: there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically.

INS.question: The A/T should be left engaged, no matter how big the turbulence-induced fluctuations become.
Aircraft manufacturers set the stall warning speed:
choices: A safe margin below the actual stalling speed of the aircraft.
10 kt above the speed at which the aircraft will stall.
A safe margin above the actual stalling speed of the aircraft.
10 kt below the speed at which the aircraft will stall.
INS.answer: A safe margin above the actual stalling speed of the aircraft.

INS.question: Amber or yellow alert lights, captions and messages.
What are the main inputs to the autopilot/autoflight?
choices: Air Data Computer, Inertial Referencing System, Mode Control Panel.
Inertial Referencing System, Mode Control Panel, TCAS.
Inertial Referencing System, Mode Control Panel, GPWS.
INS.answer: Air Data Computer, Inertial Referencing System, Mode Control Panel.

INS.question: In a heading capture mode, the autopilot gives a bank attitude input:
choices: Of a fixed value equal to 20°.
Proportional to the aircraft indicated airspeed but not exceeding a value of 25°.
Proportional to the deviation between the selected heading and the current heading but not exceeding a given value.
Of a fixed value equal to 30°.
INS.answer: Proportional to the deviation between the selected heading and the current heading but not exceeding a given value.

INS.question: When using AP or FD: You can only properly determine which modes are engaged or armed by looking at the indications on the __________.
Is this a characteristics of a yaw damper or of other rudder control systems: Large magnitude.
Select the level of alert matching each description: No aural alert required.
LAND2' implies __________APs engaged giving a __________ autoland capability.
Is this statements about the trim system true or false? There is always a trim system for each axis.
Which one of the following statements is true with regard to the operation of a Mach trim system:
choices: It only operates above a pre-determined Mach number.
It operates over the full aeroplane speed range.
It only operates when the autopilot is engaged.
It operates to counteract the larger than normal forward movements of the wing centre of pressure at high subsonic airspeeds.
INS.answer: It only operates above a pre-determined Mach number.

INS.question: Which of the following correctly describes the difference between an armed mode and an engaged mode in an autopilot system?
choices: They are the same thing: different manufacturers use different terminology
Only a three-axis autopilot can operate in an engaged mode.
An armed mode will only become engaged when the flight crew switches to the engaged mode.
An armed mode will only become engaged when certain criteria are met.
INS.answer: An armed mode will only become engaged when certain criteria are met.

INS.question: During cruise with full automation engaged and the autothrottle in speed mode. How is speed control achieved?
choices: The autothrottle maintains constant engine thrust, while the autopilot uses the elevator to maintain altitude.
The autothrottle will vary engine thrust, while the autopilot varies the aircraft pitch to maintain altitude.
The autopilot maintains constant pitch, while the autothrottle maintains rated N1 thrust.
The autopilot varies the aircraft pitch, while the autothrottle maintains constant engine thrust.
INS.answer: The autothrottle will vary engine thrust, while the autopilot varies the aircraft pitch to maintain altitude.

INS.question: Select the level of alert matching each description: Awareness required, subsequent response may be necessary.
An aeroplane has a yaw damper that is unserviceable... What is the potential problem that the yaw damper is intended to prevent from happening at high altitudes?
Flight Envelope Protection systems of an aircraft with conventional flight controls (non fly-by-wire) can include:
Select the correct AP/FD mode state for this statement: Not all modes can be in this state.
Flight Director Information supplied by an FD computer is presented in the form of command bars on the following instrument:
Select the correct system type relating to each characteristic... There must be no out-of-trim condition following the failure of an autopilot.
Three axis autopilot permits control in __________.
For large aircraft, an aural warning must be associated with the overspeed warning if a barber's pole is used.
Is this a characteristics of a yaw damper or of other rudder control systems: High frequency.
The yaw damper system controls:
choices: the ailerons, with Mach Number as the input signal.
the rudder, with the angular rate about the yaw axis as the Input signal.
the ailerons, with the angular rate about the yaw axis as the input signal.
the rudder, with Mach Number as the Input signal.
INS.answer: the rudder, with the angular rate about the yaw axis as the Input signal.

INS.question: Has a time limit, typically 5 minutes, extended to 10 following an engine failure.
Its sub mode is indicated above the engine instruments.
Failure of systems not directly involved in the autoland process __________ influence the ability to perform an autoland. They __________ affect your minima/DH for the approach.
The system can still carry out an automatic landing following the failure of an autopilot.
Air speed and trend vectors are a good aid to setting manual thrust.
Mode change accompanied by an aural alert.
The following is an example of a warnings, cautions or advisory: Engine failure.
Depending on aircraft type, the following parameters cause a take-off configuration warning to activate: Take-off speed is not set in the FMS.
Flight director (FD) indications: In left turn with 25 degrees of bank passing heading 005. The set heading is 360.
When using AP or FD: If FD guidance is incorrect it should be __________.
When can more than one autopilot be engaged at the same time in an aircraft?
Depending on aircraft type, the following parameters cause a take-off configuration warning to activate: The flaps/slats are not in agreement with the setting in the FMS.

There are 2 main variants of autothrust installation. Modes are selected only on the MCP or TOGA switches. The thrust levers __________ with A/T commands. Mode selections can be made using the thrust levers. The levers __________ with A/T commands.
Which of the following statements about stall warning and protection is/are true?
choices: Stall warning systems simply provide warnings; stall protection systems actively resist the aircraft entering a stall.
Stall warning systems always have stick pushers, whereas stall protection systems use advanced computer algorithms.
Stall protection systems are used on FBW aircraft whereas stall warning systems are used on conventional aircraft.
Stall warning systems do not prevent a stall, whereas stall protection systems make stalling impossible.
INS.answer: Stall warning systems simply provide warnings; stall protection systems actively resist the aircraft entering a stall.

INS.question: Which of the following conditions describes a self-induced oscillation (PIO)?
choices: Deviations from the desired state which rapidly decrease in magnitude.
Any small deviation in pitch causes the aircraft to 'porpoise'.
Control inputs result in stable or unstable deviations from the desired state.
The air speed continues to decrease after a pitch-down control input.
INS.answer: Control inputs result in stable or unstable deviations from the desired state.

INS.question: A yaw damper:
choices: Is a rudder damper and its purpose is to prevent Dutch roll.
Is an elevator augmentation system which counteracts the nose-down effect if the Mach number is higher than 0.8.
Is a trim tab for roll control.
INS.answer: Is a rudder damper and its purpose is to prevent Dutch roll.

INS.question: Is this a characteristics of a yaw damper or of other rudder control systems: Low frequency.
Identify which FEP functions are exclusive to FBW aircraft. Bank Limitation.
Select the level of alert matching each description: Short aural alert.
Select the AP mode phase relating to this statement: The aircraft's trajectory is based on the rate of closure and difference between the original parameter and the new parameter.
Manual thrust adjustments should not be too aggressive.
An autothrust system reduces pilot workload and…
choices: Maintains air speed under all changes of environmental conditions and autoflight modes.
Improves thrust stability in vertical speed mode, and airspeed stability in level change.
Either improves airspeed stability, or maintains predetermined thrust in changing environmental conditions.
INS.answer: Either improves airspeed stability, or maintains predetermined thrust in changing environmental conditions.

INS.question: You are flying an aircraft at FL350 with the autopilot engaged in VNAV and LNAV modes. What are the consequences of an auto-trim failure in these conditions?
choices: The autopilot will disconnect and the pilot flying should take the controls.
The abnormal rudder jam checklist should be performed.
The company should be notified and advice should be seen from MCC.
An emergency descent should be initiated.
INS.answer: The autopilot will disconnect and the pilot flying should take the controls.

INS.question: Maximum thrust for the ambient conditions is set.
Identify which FEP functions are exclusive to FBW aircraft. 'G' Limitation.
Which is the correct sequence of events for a CAT IIIB autoland?
choices: LOC engaged, G/S engaged, 1500 FT RA, LAND3, FLARE armed, FLARE engaged, A/T RETARD.
LOC engaged, G/S armed, G/S engaged, LAND2, 1500 FT RA, FLARE armed, FLARE engaged, A/T RETARD.
G/S engaged, LOC engaged, 1500 FT RA, LAND3, FLARE armed, FLARE engaged, A/T RETARD.
LOC and G/S armed, LOC engaged, G/S engaged, LAND3, 1500 FT RA, FLARE armed, A/T RETARD, FLARE engaged.
INS.answer: LOC engaged, G/S engaged, 1500 FT RA, LAND3, FLARE armed, FLARE engaged, A/T RETARD.

INS.question: Self-induced oscillations most commonly involve deviations in __________.
Manual thrust control is always necessary to correct turbulence-induced oscillation.
In flight level change, 300 kt climb with 15 degrees pitch up, MCP set speed 320 kt.
__________ loop control systems use feedback from an action or state to compare the actual state with the intended state.
The following is an example of a warnings, cautions or advisory: Single hydraulic or electrical fault.
The Yaw Damper system is designed to increase the damping ratio of:
What is the green band/area on a pitch trim indicator?
choices: The range within which the stabiliser should be set for landing.
The maximum range of trim that can be set by the autopilot.
The allowable range for normal operation.
The range within which the stabiliser trim should be set for take-off.
INS.answer: The range within which the stabiliser trim should be set for take-off.

INS.question: The Yaw Damper system: 1. Counters any wrong pilot action on the rudder pedals. 2. Counters Dutch roll. 3. Is active only when autopilot is engaged. The combination of all the correct statements is:
Which autothrust modes/sub-modes are described by this statement: Associated with AP/FD modes which maintain trajectory.
Red alert lights, captions and messages.
Depending on aircraft type, the following parameters cause a take-off configuration warning to activate: The flaps/slats not in the normal range for take-off.
Identify which FEP functions are exclusive to FBW aircraft. Pitch Limitation.
The following is an example of a warnings, cautions or advisory: Slightly low oil pressure or hydraulic quantity.
What does the autopilot roll-out mode control do during an autoland?
choices: Maintains the localiser centreline by controlling rudder/nose wheel steering.
Carries out an automatic go-around if speed is excessive.
It applies full reverse thrust once on the ground.
Roll-out mode stays engaged until turning off the runway.
INS.answer: Maintains the localiser centreline by controlling rudder/nose wheel steering.

INS.question: The aircraft's attitude is changed to change trajectory to achieve a new parameter.
Sequences modes during autoland.
Is this a characteristics of a yaw damper or of other rudder control systems: Small magnitude.
Depending on aircraft type, the following parameters cause a take-off configuration warning to activate: The speedbrake is stowed.
Closed-loop control systems can enter a state of self-induced oscillation if:
choices: The feedback loop has very low latency.
The amplitude of the system output signals is too low.
The system overcompensates for deviations from the desired state.
The flight control actuators aren't properly tuned to be counter-resonant
INS.answer: The system overcompensates for deviations from the desired state.

INS.question: The AFDS will automatically disengage from the LNAV mode if:
choices: A new desired altitude is selected.

INS.question: There must be no deviation from the intended flight path following the failure of an autopilot.
A mode disengages and a basic mode replaces it by default.
The primary purpose of the AFCS is to:
choices: Provide the crew with the correct flight parameters for each flight phase (speed, attitude, heading etc).
Reduce pilot workload and aircraft fatigue, and increase passenger comfort
Automate all phases of flight, including the take-off.
Optimise the fuel efficiency of the flight by using gentle control inputs.
INS.answer: Reduce pilot workload and aircraft fatigue, and increase passenger comfort

INS.question: The purpose of the Dutch-roll filter is to:
choices: Filter yaw input signals to prevent the yaw damper from resisting the pilots' or autopilot's rudder control inputs, while responding to the higher frequency Dutch Roll oscillations.
Ensure the yaw damper system reacts to all manual or automatic inputs as well as Dutch Roll oscillations.
Ensure the yaw damper only reacts to the pilot's or autopilot's rudder inputs, while filtering out Dutch Roll oscillations.
Send low frequency signals into the yaw damper computer.
INS.answer: Filter yaw input signals to prevent the yaw damper from resisting the pilots' or autopilot's rudder control inputs, while responding to the higher frequency Dutch Roll oscillations.

INS.question: Alert height is the point on approach after which downgrades from fail-__________ to fail-__________ are not annunciated.
Mode in small font (Boeing) and a different colour.
The purpose of a yaw damper is to counteract the __________ aerodynamic __________ known as dutch-roll.
The following is an example of a warnings, cautions or advisory: Fire.
How does the yaw damper detect dutch roll?
choices: Using a rate gyro that measures angular rate.
Using a gyro and Inputs from the IRS, depending on the aircraft type.
Using accelerometers and inputs from the IRS only, depending on the aircraft type.
INS.answer: Using a gyro and Inputs from the IRS, depending on the aircraft type.

INS.question: Maximum thrust without time limit is the target.
Pilots must monitor the FMAs during a CAT III approach to ensure:
choices: A/T RETARD mode doesn't arm before LAND3 extinguishes.
FLARE mode does not arm above 500 FT RA.
Modes are armed and engaged by the trigger radio heights or other parameters.
A/T RETARD mode engages before FLARE mode engages.
INS.answer: Modes are armed and engaged by the trigger radio heights or other parameters.

INS.question: What is the purpose of the TCS (Touch Control Steering)?
choices: assist the flare during the autoland.
steering of the aircraft via a touch screen.
disengagement of the autopilot to make a flight path change, before reengaging it back.
temporary manual flying while the autopilot ls still engaged.
INS.answer: temporary manual flying while the autopilot ls still engaged.

INS.question: VNAV (or in Airbus aircraft: CLB/DES) captures and maintains the vertical flight path __________
choices: selected on the UP DN thumbwheel

INS.question: What happens if, during an automatic approach and landing, the radio altimeter fails?
choices: The automatic landing system will not be able to perform the flare phase.
The automatic landing system will be fully operational.
The Glide Slope mode will NOT be operational.
The automatic braking sequence will be impacted.
INS.answer: The automatic landing system will not be able to perform the flare phase.

INS.question: Among the following functions of an autopilot, those related to the aeroplane stabilization are: 1. Pitch attitude holding...
The usual measure of engine speed is:
choices: RPM is used for turbofan engines, and percentage of maximum RPM is used for piston engines.
RPM for piston engines, and percentage of maximum RPM for turbofan engines.
For all engine types, the percentage of maximum RPM.
INS.answer: RPM for piston engines, and percentage of maximum RPM for turbofan engines.

INS.question: A GPWS is able to alert the crew of excessive sink rate (rate of descent) while below a certain height above terrain. Where does the GPWS derive the sink rate from?
choices: The rate of change of GPS altitude.
The air data computer rate of descent.
The rate of change of radar altitude.
INS.answer: The air data computer rate of descent.

INS.question: The disadvantages of a float type fuel gauge are: 1. The design is complex. 2. The indications are influenced by the aircraft attitude variations. 3. The indications are influenced by the accelerations. 4. The indications are influenced by temperature variations. The combination of correct statements is:
Terrain between 2000 ft above and 500 ft below the aircraft is shown in yellow or amber.
Can be used to sense the difference in pressure between two pressure sources.
ACAS II systems use the Mode C transponder to receive other traffics' Mode S broadcasts.
RA data is used to inhibit aural warnings below set heights.
In an aircraft NOT fitted with an EFIS the master caution light illuminates and an audible alarm is triggered. How does the crew find information about the cause of the caution indication?
choices: This can only be distinguished from the audible alert.
Only from a message on the ECAM.
The master caution will indicate the nature of the problem.
From the annunciator lights on the central warning panel.
INS.answer: From the annunciator lights on the central warning panel.

INS.question: The flight data recorder must automatically stop data recording when the:
choices: Landing gear is extended and locked.
Aircraft cannot any longer move by its own power.
Main gear shock strut compresses when touching the runway.
INS.answer: Aircraft cannot any longer move by its own power.

INS.question: Measures a wide range of pressure, but sensitivity is inversely proportional to range of operation.
Acquired data from the Aircraft Condition Monitoring System (ACMS) may be used:
choices: As part of an FDM and safety programme.
In place of the FWS to generate alerts.
By the EFB for performance calculations.
INS.answer: As part of an FDM and safety programme.

INS.question: The direction of intruders is found using direction-finding antennae.
GPWS visual warnings can be:
choices: Red 'PULL, UP, PULL UP' on the PFD, ND and CDU, or red warning lights on the glareshield.
Red 'PULL UP' or 'WIND SHEAR' on PFD, and/or red warning lights on the glareshield.
Amber 'PULL UP, PULL UP on the ND, and/or amber warning lights on the glareshield.
Amber captions on the PFD and red warning lights on the glareshield.
INS.answer: Red 'PULL UP' or 'WIND SHEAR' on PFD, and/or red warning lights on the glareshield.

INS.question: According to CS 25, a CVR (Cockpit Voice Recorder) must record... The combination of the correct statements is:
The indication of a fuel float gauge varies with... The combination of correct statements is:
At a high angle of attack, dependent on the type of airplane, the stall protection system can... The combination of the correct statements is:
A system which measures the temperature of the air in the tank and the time taken for transmissions to travel to and from the surface of the fuel.
The terrain awareness display is visible on the ND whenever terrain is detected.

You need 4000 kg of fuel for your flight. As you arrive at the aircraft, the refueller hands you a receipt for 2000 L of fuel showing s.g. 0.78. He says he used 4000 kg to set the aircraft's automatic refuelling system. Which of the following is an acceptable figure for the fuel remaining, after the previous flight, in the aircraft technical log?
Which of the following statements is/are correct as regards a synchroscope on a multi-engine aircraft? A synchroscope ls used to:

The types of tachometer found on aircraft include: Rotating __________ : A flexible shaft connects the engine and the instrument, and drives a drag cup by magnetism. They are found on smaller and older aircraft.
No RA can be generated below 1000 ft above the ground.
An approximately accurate system only used in small aircraft.
Select the Mode associated this description of conventional GPWS: An aural 'TERRAIN, TERRAIN alert and a visual 'TERRAIN' on the PFD.
FWC data is used to inhibit RAs during wind shear and GPWS warnings.
At high altitudes, aircraft performance is taken into account to inhibit 'climb' and 'increase climb' RAs.

Terrain >2000 ft amsl is shown in red on the ND.

A training aircraft is approaching an intended stall. No aural or visual indication of the impending stall is given; you feel aerodynamic buffet. Then, the stick pusher activates. What do you enter into the technical log book?
choices: Stall warning and stall protection working.
Stall warning and stall protection inoperative.
Stall warning inoperative, stall protection working.
Stall warning working, stall protection inoperative.
INS.answer: Stall warning inoperative, stall protection working.

INS.question: The cockpit voice recorder must preserve the conversation and aural warnings of the last:

Match the description to the correct TCAS output: Will draw red areas on the EVSI or PFD VSI.
Total fuel consumption is calculated by:
The outputs of the GPWS are: 1. Pitch up command to the AFCS 2. Aural alert 3. Aural Warning 4. Aural Klaxon Alert 5. Terrain shown on ND The combination regrouping all correct statements is:
When a TCAS RA is generated, the required vertical speed:
choices: Shows a red arc on the VSI as your target rate of climb/ descent.

INS.question: The terrain awareness display is shown on the ND when selected; this prevents weather radar information from being displayed.

Torque sensors may be: Mechanical. The axial load of a helical gear drives a piston compressing oil in a cylinder. The oil __________ is proportional to the torque. This system is relatively heavy, expensive and maintenance intensive.
The disadvantages of a float type fuel gauge are: 1... 2... 3... 4... The combination of correct statements is:
Select the Mode associated this description of conventional GPWS: Aural 'WIND SHEAR, WIND SHEAR' warning and a visual 'WIND SHEAR' on PFD.
An external pressure source is fed to the interior, causing the unit to expand when pressure increases.
An Aeroplane Condition Monitoring System (ACMS) makes use of aircraft input data and also:
choices: an erase button, a data management unit, and a headset jack.
a headset jack, a data management unit, and outputs (e.g. a printer or ACARS).
a data management unit, a recording unit, and outputs (e.g. a printer or ACARS).
an area microphone, a recording unit, and an erase button.
INS.answer: a data management unit, a recording unit, and outputs (e.g. a printer or ACARS).

INS.question: After a Radio Altimeter failure, which of the following systems are affected? 1. Autobrake system 2. EGPWS 3. Autothrottle 4. ISIS
Fuel flow meters measure the volume or __________ of fuel per unit of time. They are normally measured in the __________ fuel line and represent the rate at which the engines are consuming fuel.
ACAS II is:
choices: An ICAO standard for anti-collision systems.
A device which helps aircraft avoid collisions with other traffic.
A computer system in ATC centres which coordinates traffic automatically to avoid collisions.
The brand name of the system developed by Honeywell which automatically deconflicts traffic.
INS.answer: An ICAO standard for anti-collision systems.

INS.question: The purpose of GPWS is to:
choices: Warn of potential controlled flight into terrain.
Prevent excessive rates of descent, within predefined parameters.
Prevent closure with terrain below predefined limits.
INS.answer: Warn of potential controlled flight into terrain.

INS.question: Is a device in the CVR control panel which captures cockpit noises and conversations.
Select the Mode associated this description of conventional GPWS: An alert is triggered by excessive deviation below the ILS glide slope.
Summarise benefits of IHUMS:
choices: Improved rotor track & balance giving lower vibration levels, increasing maximum operating altitude, accurate recording of flight exceedances.
Accurate recording of flight exceedances;, cockpit voice recorder/flight data recorder allows accurate accident /incident investigation & HOMP, higher airspeeds possible.
Reduced risk of catastrophic failure of rotor or gearbox, improved rotor track & balance giving lower vibration levels, accurate recording of flight exceedances.

Reduced risk of catastrophic failure of rotor or gearbox, accurate recording of flight exceedances & cockpit voice recorder/flight data recorder allows accurate accident /incident investigation & HOMP but also maintenance costs increase.
INS.answer: Reduced risk of catastrophic failure of rotor or gearbox, improved rotor track & balance giving lower vibration levels, accurate recording of flight exceedances.

INS.question: A TCAS RA:
choices: May require a reversal of the initial commands if ATC override the RA.
May not require any change of pitch; no manoeuvre should be started until the required control inputs needed are understood.
Must only be complied with if no conflict with ATC instructions exists.
Always requires a change of pitch of 3 to 4 degrees only.
INS.answer: May not require any change of pitch; no manoeuvre should be started until the required control inputs needed are understood.

INS.question: The airline you are working for has a FDM system in operation. What is true about the acquired Information? 1. If the pilot purposely and recklessly exceeds stated parameters and limitations, the company can put him/her under Investigation. 2. The data will be used to find reoccurring adverse safety trends. 3. The Information will be used to improve crew training.
On a multi-engine aircraft, a synchroscope provides an indication of the difference in:

The relative position of intruders is determined from their GNSS position.
Measures high pressure sources.
A stall warning system (1)_____ and the stall protection system (2)_____.
choices: (1) Alerts the pilot (2) Prevents the stall
(1) Prevents the stall (2) Alerts the pilot
(1) Prevents the stall (2) Prevents the stall
(1) Alerts the pilot (2) Alerts the pilot
INS.answer: (1) Alerts the pilot (2) Prevents the stall

INS.question: The enhanced GPWS terrain display uses the following colours:
Contains test and erase buttons, a headset jack, and a status light or gauge.

A Cockpit Voice Recorder must record:
choices: voice or audio signals identifying navigation or approach aids introduced into a headset or speaker and data recording flight and engine parameters.

flight data, voice or audio signals identifying navigation or approach aids introduced into a headset or speaker and voice communications: transmitted from or received in the aeroplane by radio, and of flight-crew members on the flight deck.

voice or audio signals identifying navigation or approach aids introduced into a headset or speaker and voice communications, transmitted from or received ln the aeroplane by radio, of flight-crew members on the flight deck, of flight-crew members on the flight deck using the aeroplane's Interphone system, and of flight-crew members on the flight-deck using the public address system (If installed).

voice or audio signals identifying navigation or approach aids introduced into a headset or speaker and voice communications: transmitted from or received in the aeroplane by radio, of flight-crew members on the flight deck, of flight-crew members on the flight deck using the aeroplane's interphone system including calls between cabin crew stations (if installed), and of flight-crew members on the flight-deck using the public address system (if installed).
INS.answer: voice or audio signals identifying navigation or approach aids introduced into a headset or speaker and voice communications, transmitted from or received ln the aeroplane by radio, of flight-crew members on the flight deck, of flight-crew members on the flight deck using the aeroplane's Interphone system, and of flight-crew members on the flight-deck using the public address system (If installed).

INS.question: An engine vibration meter is indicating '4'. What is the unit of this indication?
Select the Mode associated this description of conventional GPWS: A visual 'DON'T SINK' on the PFD, and an aural 'DON'T SINK, DON'T SINK'.

Which of the following statements is/are correct as regards a synchroscope on a multi-engine aircraft? A synchroscope ls used to: 1. reduce structural vibration and noise 2. achieve symmetrical thrust and fuel consumption.
Concerning a fuel gauge system, the most relevant fuel parameter is:
Which of the following are main features of IHUMS?
choices: Cockpit voice recorder & rotor system adjustment

INS.question: The purpose of a Flight Data Monitoring (FDM) programme is to collect flight data:
choices: individually, to measure each pilot's performance.
to measure all crew member's performance.
individually, for the safety evaluation of each pilot.

INS.question: Match the description to the correct TCAS output: Displayed as a hollow diamond.
The purpose of GPWS is:
choices: to alert the pilots of hazardous terrain in front of and below the aircraft.
to alert the crew if there are deviations from certain aerodynamic parameters like altitude, airspeed and angle of attack.
to provide information and alert the pilots of a potentially hazardous terrain situation.
to avoid the aircraft having a CFIT.
INS.answer: to provide information and alert the pilots of a potentially hazardous terrain situation.

INS.question: FDM is a safety programme which normally protects the anonymity of pilots.
Which of the following statements about cockpit voice recorders is/are accurate?
choices: You are permitted to erase the CVR recording after flight.
The CVR only records words spoken in the cockpit.
The CVR may be mounted anywhere in the airframe.
Tampering with the CVR system or its data is an offence.
INS.answer: You are permitted to erase the CVR recording after flight.

INS.question: Select the Mode associated this description of conventional GPWS: Visual 'GLIDE SLOPE' on the PFD and an aural 'GLIDE SLOPE' alert.
They are determined by comparing GNSS/ADIRU position and geometric altitude with the terrain/obstructions database.

ADC data is used to calculate the relative altitude of intruders and to inhibit 'climb' RAs when performance is limited.

Has an impact-resistant housing, capable of surviving in deep water, and an underwater locator beacon.
If crew awareness is required and subsequent crew action may be required, the flight warning system (FWS) generates:
The Flight Data Recorder makes use of:
choices: a recording system, an "event• button, and an underwater locating device.
an erase button, a recording system, and an area microphone.
an area microphone, a headset jack and an "event" button.
an underwater locating device, an erase button, and a headset jack.
INS.answer: a recording system, an "event• button, and an underwater locating device.

INS.question: Select the Mode associated this description of conventional GPWS: Inhibited close to the ground to avoid nuisance warnings during landing.

Has a partly evacuated capsule, expanding and contracting when the pressure around it changes.
In case of impending stall, the flight warning system (FWS) generates:
Select the Mode associated this description of conventional GPWS: Excessive terrain closure rate, even if not descending.

Measures low to medium pressures.
The flight warning system (FWS) generates a caution message if:
choices: Crew awareness is required and subsequent crew action may be required.
Immediate recognition and corrective or compensatory action by the crew is required.
Immediate crew awareness is required and subsequent crew action will be required.
Crew awareness is required and corrective or compensatory action by the crew is immediately required.
INS.answer: Immediate crew awareness is required and subsequent crew action will be required.

INS.question: Consider the 2 statements below: 1. 15° Celsius = 273 Kelvin. 2. 15° Celsius = 59° Fahrenheit. Which combination of answers matches the statements?
Which of the following are factors that determine the type and number of parameters to be recorded by a FDR (flight data recorder)?
choices: Recording duration and reliability of the FDR.
Recording capacity and number of flight crew members.
Recording capacity and applicable operational requirements.
Recording duration and the maximum flight time of the aircraft.
INS.answer: Recording capacity and applicable operational requirements.

INS.question: Select the Mode associated this description of conventional GPWS: A high rate of descent at low altitude triggers an alert.
When TAWS is fitted it must be connected to a:

EGPWS/TAWS relies on accurate position data. Consequently:
choices: Excessive position accuracy commonly generates spurious warnings. In this case, obtain clearance from ATC before climbing.
There is a risk of no warning, or false warnings, of potential impact with terrain. Terrain function should be inhibited if position accuracy is downgraded.
Warnings should be disregarded if position accuracy is in doubt, or if the EPU is greater than 2 nm.
The system won't generate alerts or warnings if the EPU/EPE/ANP is greater than 2 nm.
INS.answer: There is a risk of no warning, or false warnings, of potential impact with terrain. Terrain function should be inhibited if position accuracy is downgraded.

INS.question: What is correct regarding the FDM? A Flight Data Monitoring (FDM) programme collects and analyses aircraft flight data for the purpose of:
choices: Displaying to the crew any adverse safety trend.
Identifying adverse safety trends and tailoring training programmes.
Displaying to the crew any exceeded parameter.
Identifying adverse safety trends and automatic reporting to the Competent Authority.
INS.answer: Identifying adverse safety trends and tailoring training programmes.

INS.question: By what means are messages from an Aeroplane Condition Monitoring System (ACMS) transmitted to the maintenance base?
choices: Conventional analogue radios, with crew notification.
The Flight Data Recorder, when the aircraft 1s on the ground.
The commander, through VHF or HF voice communication.

INS.question: Select the Mode associated this description of conventional GPWS: Altitude loss after take-off or go-around triggers an alert.

Identify the type of TCA's aural alert: Climb, crossing climb'.
A CVR consists of:
choices: an Event Mark Device, Emergency Locator Transmitter, test button, and erase button.
a tape recorder, Underwater Locating Device, area microphone, and control unit.
a Digital Flight Data Acquisition Unit, area microphone, erase button, and tape recorder.
an Underwater Locating Device, illuminating light, speakers, tape recorder, and control unit.
INS.answer: a tape recorder, Underwater Locating Device, area microphone, and control unit.

choices: When the aeroplane clears the runway.
When the main gear shock strut compresses when touching the runway.
When the landing gear is extended and locked.
When the aeroplane cannot any longer move by its own power.
INS.answer: When the aeroplane cannot any longer move by its own power.

The electromotive force of a thermocouple is not modified if one or several intermediate metals are inserted in the circuit provided that:
choices: Contact points are maintained at equal temperature between these different metals.
These metals are not the same as those constituting the thermocouple.
These metals are maintained at a temperature higher than that of the cold source.
These metals are maintained at a temperature lower than that of the cold source.
INS.answer: Contact points are maintained at equal temperature between these different metals.

INS.question: An electronic torque meter senses:
choices: Twisting of the engine output shaft.
Torsion on the propellers or rotors.
Angular velocity of the propellers or rotors.
Oil pressure from the reduction gearbox.
INS.answer: Twisting of the engine output shaft.

INS.question: Grave exceedances of parameters may warrant further investigation by the operator.

choices: An aural warning in the initial take-off roll.
A visual warning in the initial take-off roll.
INS.answer: An aural warning in the initial take-off roll.

choices: Carry out as quickly as possible any non-normal or emergency checklist actions to stabilise the situation.
Acknowledge, but then delete, any non-critical, non-normal checklist actions if your workload is currently too high.
First consider the consequences of actions commanded by the electronic checklist before actioning them.
Follow the recommended actions exactly and completely at all times.
INS.answer: First consider the consequences of actions commanded by the electronic checklist before actioning them.

INS.question: Comprises a curved metal tube, open at one end, which straightens slightly when internal pressure rises.

choices: Does not indicate the relative bearing of proximate traffic.
Should not be interpreted as tracks because the system's design makes this unreliable.
Is a reliable indicator of aircraft tracks, but only at low altitudes.
Are accurately displayed tracks because the directional antennae are carefully calibrated.
INS.answer: Should not be interpreted as tracks because the system's design makes this unreliable.

INS.question: What is, in computer terminology, an operating system?
choices: The bus structure that allows data communication.
The central processing unit's control unit.
The programme that controls a computer's basic functions.
The control display unit that allows computer control.
INS.answer: The programme that controls a computer's basic functions.

INS.question: Identify the type of TCA's aural alert: 'Climb, climb'.

a white or cyan empty lozenge.

choices: A hydraulic driver turning a drum with magnetic pick-offs.

alerts; press the master caution twice

0.17 m aft of the main wheels.

choices: a reduced rate of climb capability.
an improved rate of climb capability.
M&B.answer: a reduced rate of climb capability.

M&B.question: The centre of gravity is the:
choices: Centre of thrust along the longitudinal axis, in relation to a datum line.
Neutral point along the longitudinal axis, in relation to a datum line.
Point where all the aircraft mass is considered to be concentrated.
Focus along the longitudinal axis, in relation to a datum line.
M&B.answer: Point where all the aircraft mass is considered to be concentrated.

M&B.question: Loads must be adequately secured in order to:
choices: avoid any Centre of Gravity (CG) movement during flight.
prevent excessive 'g' loading during the landing flare.
avoid unplanned Centre of Gravity (CG) movement and aircraft damage.
M&B.answer: avoid unplanned Centre of Gravity (CG) movement and aircraft damage.

For a given configuration, the stall speed of an aeroplane will be highest when loaded:
choices: to the maximum allowable mass with the most aft CG.
to a low total mass with the most aft CG.
to the maximum allowable mass with the most forward CG.
to a low total mass with the most forward CG.
M&B.answer: to the maximum allowable mass with the most forward CG.

Inability to descend from the cruise.
M&B.answer: Loss of control, or reduced control effectiveness.

a reduction in the fuel flow and endurance.
an improved angle of climb and increased obstacle clearance.
an increase in the fuel flow and specific range.
M&B.answer: a reduction in the rate of climb and the range.

choices: Degradation or loss of nose-wheel steering.
No likelihood of a nose-up overbalance (on a tricycle gear aircraft) on the ground resulting in tail damage.
M&B.answer: Degradation or loss of nose-wheel steering.

choices: By arranging them carefully so that they don't fall over in flight.
By strapping it down to pallets, locked into place using restraining straps.
By using restraining nets, attached to attachment points and tie-down points.

M&B.answer: By using restraining nets, attached to attachment points and tie-down points.

Latches within rollers and tracks, or straps at tie-down points
Locking points at strategic positions along the aircraft fuselage bulkheads

M&B.answer: Latches within rollers and tracks, or straps at tie-down points

M&B.question: The floor limit of an aircraft cargo hold is 5 000 N/m². It is planned to load-up a cubic container measuring 0.4 m of side. It's maximum gross mass must not exceed (assume g = 10 m/s²):

choices: The point in the horizontal plane from which all masses are referenced.

M&B.answer: The product of the mass and the balance arm.

The maximum mass due to landing runway limitations.
M&B.answer: The maximum mass due to landing runway limitations.

Basic Empty Mass, Traffic Load and Variable Load
Basic Empty Mass, Traffic Load and Fuel

1.3 m right of the 15 kg mass.
0.7 m left of the 25 kg mass.
1.25 m right of the 15 kg mass.
M&B.answer: 1.25 m right of the 15 kg mass.

M&B.question: Which of these following statements is INCORRECT?
choices: The regulated landing mass is the maximum permitted landing mass, which complies with both structural and performance landing mass limitations.
The regulated take-off mass is the maximum permitted take-off mass, which complies with both structural and performance take-off mass limitations.
The regulated landing mass is the lower of the MSLM and PLLM.
The regulated landing mass is the greater of the MSLM and PLLM.
M&B.answer: The regulated landing mass is the greater of the MSLM and PLLM.

choices: Flight cases and aircraft loading containers.

choices: decreases, and the fuel consumption decreases.

M&B.question: The useful load is:
choices: The gross mass of the aeroplane ready for flight but excluding fuel.
The gross mass of the aeroplane ready for flight but excluding traffic load.
The combined mass of the passengers, baggage, cargo and non-revenue load.
The mass of the traffic load and fuel.
M&B.answer: The mass of the traffic load and fuel.

Distance to New CG (CGN) = √(Moment x Mass)
Distance to New CG (CGN) = Moment ÷ Mass
Distance to New CG (CGN) = Moment x Mass
M&B.answer: Distance to New CG (CGN) = Moment ÷ Mass

choices: increase in range and stall speed.
increase in range and decrease in stall speed.
increase in stability and trim drag.
Increase in stability and decrease in trim drag.
M&B.answer: increase in range and decrease in stall speed.

choices: Max Traffic Load = ATOM + DOM – Take-Off Fuel
Max Traffic Load = ATOM – DOM – Take-Off Fuel
Max Traffic Load = ATOM – DOM + Take-Off Fuel
Max Traffic Load = ATOM + DOM + Take-Off Fuel
M&B.answer: Max Traffic Load = ATOM – DOM – Take-Off Fuel

choices: Remain constant, drag will decrease and endurance will decrease.
Be greater, drag will increase and endurance will decrease.
Be decreased, drag will decrease and endurance will increase.
Remain constant, drag will increase and endurance will increase.
M&B.answer: Be greater, drag will increase and endurance will decrease.

M&B.question: The range of permissible CG positions is limited by:
choices: Maximum and minimum forward (fore) and rearward (aft) CG limits
Maximum forward (fore) and rearward (aft) CG limits
Maximum forward (fore), lateral and rearward (aft) CG limits
Maximum and minimum forward (fore), lateral and rearward (aft) CG limits
M&B.answer: Maximum forward (fore) and rearward (aft) CG limits

choices: m x MO = d x DarmCGO

M&B.question: What is the effect of a forward CG on the time to reach cruising altitude?
choices: A forward CG decreases the maximum Rate of Climb and increases the time to reach cruising altitude.
A forward CG increases the maximum Rate of Climb and decreases the time to reach cruising altitude.
The CG position has no impact on the Rate of Climb.
A forward CG allows the selection of a higher cruising altitude, therefore increases the time to reach cruising altitude.
M&B.answer: A forward CG decreases the maximum Rate of Climb and increases the time to reach cruising altitude.

When in equilibrium:
choices: The forces acting on an aircraft are reduced to zero.
The forces acting on an aircraft are equal.
The aircraft must be in straight, steady, unaccelerated flight.
The sum of the moments of the forces are zero.
M&B.answer: The sum of the moments of the forces are zero.

The stalling speed of an aeroplane will be highest when it is loaded with a:
choices: high gross mass and aft centre of gravity.
high gross mass and forward centre of gravity.
low gross mass and forward centre of gravity.
low gross mass and aft centre of gravity.
M&B.answer: high gross mass and forward centre of gravity.

choices: The aircraft must be withdrawn from service.

In calculations with respect to the position of the centre of gravity a reference is made to a datum. The datum is:
choices: A reference plane which is chosen by the aircraft manufacturer. Its position is given in the Aircraft Flight or Loading Manual.
Calculated from the data derived from the weighing procedure carried out on the aircraft after any major modification.
An arbitrary reference chosen by the pilot which can be located anywhere on the aircraft.
M&B.answer: A reference plane which is chosen by the aircraft manufacturer. Its position is given in the Aircraft Flight or Loading Manual.

choices: Re-weighing not required if no significant amendments made to aircraft

Multiply standard masses by a reduction factor AND remove fuel or baggage
Remove those passengers exceeding the standard mass allowance by 1.2 or more.
Determine the actual masses by weighing AND apply an adequate mass increment.
M&B.answer: Determine the actual masses by weighing OR apply an adequate mass increment.

What is the Dry Operating Index (DOI)?
choices: An index for the aft and forward CG limits at Dry Operating Mass.
An index for the position of the centre of gravity at Dry Operating Mass.
An index for the average CG at Dry Operating Mass.
An index for the %MAC at Dry Operating Mass.
M&B.answer: An index for the position of the centre of gravity at Dry Operating Mass.

choices: The maximum amount of extra variable load that can be accepted without exceeding any of the mass limitations.
The minimum amount of extra traffic load that can be accepted without exceeding any of the mass limitations.
The maximum amount of extra load that can be accepted without exceeding any of the CG limitations.
The maximum amount of extra traffic load that can be accepted without exceeding any of the mass limitations.
M&B.answer: The maximum amount of extra traffic load that can be accepted without exceeding any of the mass limitations.

choices: Underload = Allowed All-up Mass - Actual Traffic Load
Underload = Allowed Traffic Load - Actual Traffic Load
M&B.answer: Underload = Allowed Traffic Load - Actual Traffic Load

choices: An Aircraft Prepared for Service (APS) CG report.
An Aircraft Prepared for Service (APS) weighing schedule.
An Aircraft Prepared for Service (APS) mass and index.

choices: Only those forming part of the DOM.
Only those forming part of the AUM.
Only those forming part of the BEM.
Only those forming part of the OM.
M&B.answer: Only those forming part of the BEM.

M&B.question: The Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM) of an aeroplane is always:
choices: The Take-off Mass minus the Take-off Fuel Mass.
The Take-off Mass minus the wing fuel mass.
The Take-off Mass minus the fuselage fuel mass.
The Maximum Take-off Mass minus the Take-off Fuel Mass.
M&B.answer: The Take-off Mass minus the Take-off Fuel Mass.

choices: Fuel Index = Fuel Mass x SG x Fuel Index Correction Factor.
%MAC = Fuel Mass x SG x Fuel Index.

M&B.question: Which equation is correct in order to calculate the centre of gravity? The sum of the:
choices: Moments multiplied by the sum of the masses.
Masses multiplied by the sum of the moments.
Moments divided by the sum of the masses.
Masses divided by the sum of the moments.
M&B.answer: Moments divided by the sum of the masses.

M&B.question: The Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the mass of the aeroplane with no usable fuel on board. It is a limitation which is:
choices: Governed by the Traffic Load to be carried. It also provides protection from excessive "wing bending".
Governed by the Traffic Load to be carried. It also provides protection from excessive wing bending.
Listed in the Flight Manual as a fixed value. It is a structural limit.
Tabulated in the Flight Manual against arguments of airfield elevation and temperature.
M&B.answer: Listed in the Flight Manual as a fixed value. It is a structural limit.

M&B.question: How is the CG Moment Arm calculated for the Basic Empty Mass?
choices: CG Moment Arm = Total Moment ÷ Total Mass
CG Moment Arm = Total Moment x Total Mass
CG Moment Arm = Total Mass x Total Moment
CG Moment Arm = Total Mass ÷ Total Moment
M&B.answer: CG Moment Arm = Total Moment ÷ Total Mass

M&B.question: Select the statement which best defines the Datum.
choices: Is a fixed point from which all balance arm distances are measured.
Is a fixed vertical plane from which all distances are measured.
Is a vertical plane through which all the forces of gravity are said to act.
Is the point through which all the forces of gravity are said to act.
M&B.answer: Is a fixed point from which all balance arm distances are measured.

M&B.question: What is the standard mass for checked baggage for a flight on an aircraft having 20 or more passengers seats, originating in London, UK and terminating in Casablanca, Morocco?
The fleet mass is:
choices: The average Dry Operating Mass and average CG position for all aircraft in the fleet.
The average Operating Mass and CG position for all aircraft in the fleet.
The average Dry Operating Mass and average CG position for at least 76% of aircraft in the fleet.
The average Dry Operating Mass and average CG position for at least 51% of aircraft in the fleet.
M&B.answer: The average Dry Operating Mass and average CG position for all aircraft in the fleet.

choices: 6925 lb and 201.3 inches from the nose wheel of the aircraft.
3525 lb and 172.7 inches from the datum.
6925 lb and 176.3 inches from the nose wheel of the aircraft.
6925 lb and 177.2 inches from the datum.
M&B.answer: 6925 lb and 201.3 inches from the nose wheel of the aircraft.

Individual aircraft, not part of a fleet average programme, must be re-weighed:
choices: Re-weighing not required if no significant amendments made to aircraft.

The moment for an item is:
choices: The square of the distance the item is from the datum divided by its mass.
The distance the item is from the datum divided by its mass.
The mass of the item multiplied by its distance from the datum.
The mass of the item divided by its distance from the datum.
M&B.answer: The mass of the item multiplied by its distance from the datum.

choices: Operating Mass = DOM + Trip Fuel - Alternate Fuel

choices: An operator's group of aircraft of the same model and configuration.
A group of 9 or fewer aircraft of the same model and configuration.
A group of 4 or fewer aircraft of the same model and configuration.
A group of 19 or fewer aircraft of the same model and configuration.
M&B.answer: An operator's group of aircraft of the same model and configuration.

M&B.question: In which document will standard masses for flight crew, passengers and luggage be found?
The actual Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM) is equal to the:
choices: Basic Empty Mass plus the fuel loaded.
Actual Landing Mass plus Trip Fuel.
Dry Operating Mass plus the Traffic Load.
Operating Mass plus all the Traffic Load.
M&B.answer: Dry Operating Mass plus the Traffic Load.

M&B.question: The maximum quantity of fuel that can be loaded into an aircraft's tanks is given as 400 US gallons. If the fuel density (specific gravity) is given as 0.79 the mass of fuel which may be loaded is:

Unfortunately, the ground staff incorrectly loaded all the cargo into the forward cargo hold. If the distance between the cargo holds ls 517 inches, is the aeroplane's CG within limits?
choices: Yes, it moves rearwards but is within limits.
No, it is out of the forward limit.
No, it is out of the rear lilt.
M&B.answer: No, it is out of the forward limit.

M&B.question: An aeroplane weighing schedule indicates that: The Empty Mass is 57 320 kg. The nominal Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is 60 120 kg. The Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is given as 72 100 kg. Which of the following is a correct statement in relation to this aeroplane?
choices: Operational items have a mass of 2800 kg and the maximum Useful Load is 11 980 kg.
Operational items have a mass of 2800 kg and the maximum Traffic Load for this aeroplane is 14 780 kg.
Operational items have a mass of 2800 kg and the maximum Traffic Load for this aeroplane is 11 980 kg.
Operational items have a mass of 2800 kg and the maximum Useful Load is 14 780 kg.
M&B.answer: Operational items have a mass of 2800 kg and the maximum Traffic Load for this aeroplane is 11 980 kg.

M&B.question: An aircraft is weighed before it enters service:
choices: To establish its CG position at maximum mass.
To establish the minimum required take-off distance at maximum all-up mass.
To establish its mass and CG.
M&B.answer: To establish its mass and CG.

M&B.question: Which one of the following shipments can be loaded in a cargo compartment with a floor loading of 70 kg/m2? Shipment W: 500 kg on a pallet sized 2 m x 2 m Shipment X: 500 kg on a pallet sized 1 m x 1 m Shipment Y: 600 kg on a pallet sized 2 m x 2 m Shipment Z: 600 kg on a pallet sized 3 m x 3 m (All pallets are in direct contact with the cargo floor).

choices: Governed by the distribution of the mass within the aircraft.
Always parallel to the aircraft's vertical axis.
At right angles to the flight path.

M&B.question: At which masses must the CG position be within the CG envelope, including any LMC?

choices: Whenever there is a modification applied to the aircraft.
Whenever the cumulative change to the DOM exceeds plus/minus 0.5% of the MSLM.
Whenever the cumulative mass changes to the DOM exceeds plus/minus 5% of the MSTOM.

M&B.answer: Whenever the cumulative change to the DOM exceeds plus/minus 0.5% of the MSLM.

choices: All in-flight equipment, plus the accumulated effects of modifications and repairs.
Basic equipment and accumulated effects of modifications and repairs.
Basic equipment or accumulated effects of modifications and repairs.
M&B.answer: Basic equipment and accumulated effects of modifications and repairs.

Is defined under the assumption that fuel is consumed from the inner wing tanks first. Which combination of statements is correct?

For the B737 as loaded in Figure 4.13 of CAP 696 what is the new landing mass and %MAC if an extra 500 kg of cargo is off loaded from compartment 1?
What is the stabiliser trim setting for flaps 5 if the CG is 14%.
Referring to CAP 696 Section 2 SEP1, what is the full range of distance between the forward and aft CG limits at BEM?
Which document requires the operator to ensure that the loading, mass and aircraft CG comply with limitations specified in the AFM, POH or the Operations Manual.
The trim sheet displays: -Aft CGs (larger %MACs) to the __________.
By adding to the Basic Empty Mass the mass of crew, crew baggage, catering, and operational equipment for a specific flight, we get the:

The maximum load per running metre of an aircraft is 350 kg/m. The width of the floor area is 2 metres. The floor strength limitation is 300 kg per square metre. Which one of the following crates (length x width x height) can be loaded directly on the floor?
choices: A load of 500 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.5 m x 1 m x 1 m.
A load of 400 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.4 m x 0.8 m x 0.8 m.
A load of 400 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.2 m x 1.2 m x 1.2 m.
A load of 700 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.8 m x 1.4 m x 0.8 m.
M&B.answer: A load of 400 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.2 m x 1.2 m x 1.2 m.

M&B.question: The term 'Maximum Zero Fuel Mass' (MZFM) consists of:
choices: The maximum mass authorized for a certain aeroplane not including the fuel load and operational items.
The maximum mass for some aeroplanes including the fuel load and the Traffic Load.
The maximum mass authorized for a certain aeroplane not including Traffic Load and fuel load.
The maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel.
M&B.answer: The maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel.

M&B.question: Calculate the Basic Empty Mass and CG position of the aircraft given the following data: Reference point situated 60 inches from the Datum. Nosewheel load of 1275 kg situated -27 inches from the reference point. Left mainwheel load of 5383 kg situated +105 inches from the reference point. Right mainwheel load of 5287 kg situated +105 inches from the reference point. Ballast of 96 kg situated +112 inches from the reference point.
choices: BEM 11945 kg. CG 150.91 inches aft of the datum.
BEM 12043 kg. CG 80 inches aft of the datum
BEM 10862kg. CG 80 inches aft of the structural reference point
BEM 12041 kg CG 151.02 inches aft of the structural reference point
M&B.answer: BEM 11945 kg. CG 150.91 inches aft of the datum.

M&B.question: The captain has received a calculated load sheet with his pre-flight package. The ground handler now hands over a final load sheet. ln this scenario, which one does the captain have to use?
choices: The final load sheet provided by the ground handler.
The load sheet he has received with his pre-flight package.
It depends on the operator's SOPs which one the captain has to use.
Neither one. It is his responsibility to calculate the load sheet himself.
M&B.answer: The final load sheet provided by the ground handler.

M&B.question: Complete figure 2.4 in CAP 696 to determine the take-off mass and CG for the SEP1 aeroplane (BEM 2415 lb and CG 77.7 in) with one pilot mass 165 lb, with 2 passengers mass 200 lb and 220 lb in seats 3 and 4 and a crate mass 150 lb in area B. Block fuel 30 US Gall.
A location in the aircraft which is identified by a number designating its distance from the datum is known as:

Given: The Take-off Mass (TOM) of an aeroplane is 141 000 kg. Total fuel on board is 63 000 kg including 14 000 kg reserve fuel and 1 000 kg of unusable fuel. The Traffic Load (TL) is 12 800 kg. What is the Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM)?

An aircraft has a total mass of 5430 kg with a CG of 5.43 m aft of the datum line. Minutes before despatch an additional load of 210 kg was loaded onto the aircraft. The aircraft's new CG is 5.56 m aft of the datum. The additional load was placed:
choices: 9.05 m aft of the datum line.
3.49 m aft of the datum line.
8.92 m aft of the datum line.
1.94 m aft of the datum line.
M&B.answer: 8.92 m aft of the datum line.

M&B.question: Determine the ramp mass in the following conditions: Basic empty mass (BEM) 3 210 lb Arm for BEM 88.5 in One pilot 160 lb Front seat passenger 200 lb Centre seat passengers 290 lb One passenger rear seat 110 lb Baggage in zone 1 - 100 lb Baggage in zone 4 - 50 lb Block fuel 100 US Gal Trip fuel 55 US Gal Fuel for start up and taxi 3 US Gal Fuel density 6 lb/US Gal.

Due to variations in the actual passenger distribution, cargo loading, or fuel distribution in comparison with the data used during the pre-flight preparation of the mass and balance documentation, the Operator (1) ___ which is/are (2) ___ restrictive than the certified CG limits.
choices: (1) applies a CG margin of 15%; (2) more
(1) applies a CG margin of 15%; (2) less.

M&B.question: Which of the following statements best describes the "Regulated Landing Mass'?"
choices: The Maximum Landing Mass as determined by the aircraft manufacturer.
The greatest of the Performance Limited Landing Mass and Structural Limited Landing Mass.
The Maximum Landing Mass as approved by the aircraft's State of Registration.
The lowest of the Performance Limited Landing Mass and Structural Limited Landing Mass.
M&B.answer: The lowest of the Performance Limited Landing Mass and Structural Limited Landing Mass.

M&B.question: Calculate the centre of gravity in % MAC (mean aerodynamic chord) with following data: Distance datum - centre of gravity: 12.53 m Distance datum - leading edge: 9.63 m Length of MAC: 8 m

A mass of 600 kg is loaded at a station which is located 12 metres behind the present centre of gravity and 18 metres behind the datum. (Assume g=10 m/s2) The moment for that mass used in the loading manifest is:

The basic empty mass of an aircraft is 30 000 kg The masses of the following items are: Catering 300 kg Safety and rescue material nil Fly away kit nil Crew (inclusive crew baggage) 365 kg Fuel at take-off 3000 kg Unusable fuel 120 kg Passengers, baggage, cargo 8 000 kg The Dry Operating Mass is:
If the CG of an aircraft is close to its forward limit, what will be achieved if fuel is transferred from the wing tanks to the aeroplane's fin or horizontal stabiliser tanks?
choices: Best fuel economy, by repositioning the CG forward.
Efficient stability control, by repositioning the CG aft.
Best range, by repositioning the CG forward.
Efficient fuel consumption, by repositioning the CG aft.
M&B.answer: Efficient fuel consumption, by repositioning the CG aft.

M&B.question: Determine the length of the MAC, given: Leading edge at wing root: STA 235 Trailing edge at wing root: STA 250 Leading edge at wing tip: STA 148 Trailing edge at wing tip: STA 212 Leading edge of MAC: STA 192 Trailing edge of MAC: STA 224 Note: Body stations are distances from the aircraft nose in 10 -1 m.
The Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is:
choices: Tabulated in the Flight Manual against arguments of airfield elevation and temperature.
Governed by the Traffic Load to be carried.
A structural limit listed in the Flight Manual as a fixed value.
M&B.answer: A structural limit listed in the Flight Manual as a fixed value.

M&B.question: In mass and balance calculations which of the following describes the datum?
choices: It is the most aft position of the centre of gravity.
It is the point on the aircraft designated by the manufacturers from which all centre of gravity measurements and calculations are made.
It is the most forward position of the centre of gravity.
It is the distance from the centre of gravity to the point through which the weight of the component acts.
M&B.answer: It is the point on the aircraft designated by the manufacturers from which all centre of gravity measurements and calculations are made.

M&B.question: Refer to CAP 696 figure 4.12. The ZFM of an aeroplane is equal to 48 000 kg and the CG position is at 25 % MAC. Which one of the statements below is correct ?
choices: The graph does not provide enough information to assess compliance with the CG limit.
The Index at ZFM is outside the allowed CG range.
The Index at ZFM is within limits and in an aft position.
A ZFM of 48 000 kg is not allowed for this aircraft type.
M&B.answer: The Index at ZFM is within limits and in an aft position.

M&B.question: Given: Fuel volume: 3800 US Gallons Fuel density: 0.79 kg/l. The fuel mass ls:

Given : Actual mass 116 500 lb Original CG station 435.0 Compartment A station 285.5 Compartment B station 792.5 If 390 lb of cargo is moved from compartment B (aft) to compartment A (forward), what is the station number of the new CG?
Dry operating mass is the take-off mass of the aircraft less:
choices: All usable fuel, portable water and chemicals.
Traffic load, portable water and lavatory chemicals.
All usable fuel and traffic load.
M&B.answer: All usable fuel and traffic load.

M&B.question: If all the moments are positive when calculating mass (weight) and balance, the position of the datum would be at the:
choices: Nose, or forward of the aircraft.
Centre line of the nose or tail wheel depending on the aircraft type.
M&B.answer: Nose, or forward of the aircraft.

M&B.question: Which equation represents a conversion of 1 US gallon AVGAS into lbs?
The Dry Operating Mass includes:
choices: crew and crew baggage, catering, removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals.
fuel and passengers baggage and cargo.
M&B.answer: crew and crew baggage, catering, removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals.

M&B.question: The Take-off Mass (TOM) of an aircraft is 8470 kg Total fuel on board is 1 600 kg including 450 kg reserve fuel and 29 kg of unusable fuel The Traffic Load (TL) is 770 kg What is the Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM)?
What effect does a CG outside the aft limit have on aircraft longitudinal stability and controllability?
Given: Mass on nose wheel: 285 kg Mass on left main wheels: 1465 kg Mass on right main wheels: 1395 kg Distance between the nose and main wheels: 7 ft 8 in Calculate the aircraft's CG position.
choices: 83.7 in aft of the nose wheel.
18.3 in forward of the main gear.
9.2 in forward of the main gear.
7.1 ft aft of the nose wheel.
M&B.answer: 83.7 in aft of the nose wheel.

M&B.question: The Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is a mass limitation for the:
choices: Total load of the fuel imposed upon the wing.
Allowable load exerted upon the wing considering a margin for fuel tanking.

M&B.question: A baggage weighing 50 kg is tied down on the baggage zone of the aircraft and the moment is -5000 KG mm The arm of the baggage zone is:
choices: -10 nm and is located forward of the datum.
+100 nm and is located aft of the datum.
+10 nm and is located aft of the datum.
-100 nm and is located forward of the datum.
M&B.answer: -100 nm and is located forward of the datum.

M&B.question: According to OPS regulations, standard masses for checked baggage may be used if the aircraft:

A mass of 500 kg is loaded at a station which is located 10 metres behind the present Centre of Gravity and 16 metres behind the datum. (Assume g = 10 m/s2). The moment for that mass used in the loading manifest is:
The arm is the ___ distance of a load as measured from the aircraft ___ .

The following data applies to an aircraft which is about to take-off. MSTOM 8600 kg, PLTOM 8470 kg, DOM 5110 kg, Crew and special operating equipment 290 kg, Take-off fuel 1460 kg. Calculate the traffic load.
The floor of the main cargo hold is limited to 4000 N/ms2. It is planned to load a cubic container each side of which measures 0.5 m. The maximum gross mass must not exceed (assume g = 10 m/s2):
What is underload?
choices: Underload = Allowed Traffic Load - Actual Traffic Load
