Underload = Allowed All-up Mass - Actual Traffic Load
M&B.answer: Underload = Allowed Traffic Load - Actual Traffic Load

M&B.question: An aircraft is used for Commercial Air Transport. Since the aircraft's initial entry into service, 3 years ago, several repairs and modifications have been executed. These changes were accurately documented. The Operator uses individual aircraft masses. Does the aircraft need to be re-weighed now?
choices: No, but it must be re-weighed within the next 12 months.
No, but it must be re-weighed with in the next 6 years.
Yes, because the applicable EU regulation requires a re-weighing every 3 years.
Yes, because re-weighting should be done after every repair and/or modification.
M&B.answer: No, but it must be re-weighed within the next 12 months.

M&B.question: Moment (balance) arms are measured from a specific point to the body station at which the mass is located. That point is known as:
choices: The centre of gravity of aeroplane

M&B.question: Using the standard mass figure from CAP 696 Page 5. You are about to depart for a commercial flight, with an aircraft having a flight crew of 7 members and 115 passengers. As part of your pre-flight calculations and given the following information, you need to calculate the Traffic Load in accordance with the standard passenger and baggage masses, as defined in the annex. Flight crew: 4 male & 3 female, Male passengers: 70, Female passengers: 35, Children: 10, Baggage: 62 items, Standard mass for a flight crew member: 85 kg, Non-revenue load: 500 kg

OPS.question: A Low Visibility Take-Off (LVTO) is defined as a take-off with an RVR less than ____ m
What is the definition for a microburst? A microburst lasts for about 1 minute to 5 minutes and is a highly concentrated and powerful:
choices: up draught of air, typically less than 5 km across.
down draught of air, typically less than 5 km across.
up draught of air, typically more than 5 km across.
down draught of air, typically more than 5 km across.
OPS.answer: down draught of air, typically less than 5 km across.

OPS.question: When taking-off after a wide body aircraft which has just landed, you should take-off:
choices: beyond the point where the aircraft's wheels have touched down.
in front of the point where the aircraft's wheels have touched down.
at the point where the aircraft's wheels have touched the ground and on the down wind side of the runway.
at the point where the aircraft's wheels have touched down and on the wind side of the runway.
OPS.answer: beyond the point where the aircraft's wheels have touched down.

OPS.question: Any localised treatment to the aircraft must be carried out __________ otherwise, a difference in lift could cause uncommanded roll immediately after take-off.
Procedures applied by an aerodrome for the purpose of ensuring safety during low-visibility operations (LVOs)'  is the definition applied to:
An aircraft having undertaken an anti-icing procedure and having exceeded the holdover time of the anti-icing fluid:
choices: does not require a new anti-icing procedure before take-off.
must only undertake a de-icing procedure before take-off.
must only undertake a new anti-icing procedure before take-off.
must undertake a de-icing procedure before a new application of anti-icing fluid before take-off.
OPS.answer: must undertake a de-icing procedure before a new application of anti-icing fluid before take-off.

OPS.question: The highest risk of bird strikes occurs:

During a manual approach, the aeroplane is subjected to wind shear with a decreasing headwind. ln the absence of a pilot action, the aeroplane: 1. flies above the intended approach path 2. flies below the intended approach path 3. has an increasing true airspeed 4. has a decreasing true airspeed The combination of correct statements is:

After a commercial passenger flight, the flight crew awaits by the baggage carousel for their luggage. Their hold luggage is delivered last, when all the passengers have already left. The flight crew notices that there is a piece of luggage remaining on the carousel which has NOT been claimed. According to ICAO Annex 17 and for security reasons, the definition of such baggage would be:
An emergency landing is required when there is an immediate risk to the aircraft or passengers. In this case declare a __________.
Water is not displaced from under the tyres fast enough to allow the tyre to make pavement contact'. This is a description of:

__________ landing may be necessary when there is no immediate danger to the aeroplane, but a reduction in system redundancy, or a reduction in safety margins make it necessary to land rather than continue flight.
Whenever a potential bird hazard is observed, the commander shall:
choices: inform immediately the bird control unit (BCU) directly by radio.
immediately inform the local ATS unit.
inform other aircraft in the vicinity by radio.
submit a written hazard bird strike report upon arrival and within 48 hours.
OPS.answer: immediately inform the local ATS unit.

OPS.question: In case of a cargo compartment fire, the system which should be switched off, is generally the:
During an explosive decompression at flight level 370 (FL 370), your first action will be:
choices: to put on the oxygen mask
OPS.answer: to put on the oxygen mask

OPS.question: ln case of a serious threat based on the presence of a bomb on board a pressurised aircraft and disregarding any fuel considerations:
choices: you carry out an emergency descent to reach the safety altitude.
you go down to the level corresponding to the indicated cabin altitude and keep the aircraft in a clean configuration until the final approach.
you descend to the flight level corresponding to the indicated cabin altitude or the safety altitude if higher and take preventive steps by putting yourself in a landing approach configuration.
you climb to the maximum flight level which does not need the use of pressurisation.
OPS.answer: you descend to the flight level corresponding to the indicated cabin altitude or the safety altitude if higher and take preventive steps by putting yourself in a landing approach configuration.

OPS.question: Which one of the following statements accurately describes the CS-25 requirement for fuel jettison systems?
choices: Fuel jettison systems are required to ensure that, within 15 minutes, the aircraft's mass can be reduced to a point where the aircraft will meet the approach climb gradient performance requirements.
Fuel jettison systems are required to ensure that, within 15 minutes, the aircraft's mass can be reduced to a point where the aircraft will meet the maximum structural landing weight requirements.
Fuel jettison systems are required to ensure that, within 30 minutes, the aircraft's mass can be reduced to a point where the aircraft will meet the approach climb gradient performance requirements.
Fuel jettison systems are required to ensure that, within 30 minutes, the aircraft's mass can be reduced to a point where the aircraft will meet the maximum structural landing weight requirement.
OPS.answer: Fuel jettison systems are required to ensure that, within 15 minutes, the aircraft's mass can be reduced to a point where the aircraft will meet the approach climb gradient performance requirements.

OPS.question: Friction generates heat, and the temperature rise turns residual water into high pressure steam. The steam causes the rubber to ‘revert’, becoming soft and gummy, which traps steam within the tyre's footprint'. This is a description of:
A runway designated as 'compacted or rolled snow' is given a SNOWTAM code of:
The visual phase of an instrument approach to bring an aircraft into position for landing on a runway not suitably located for a straight-in approach'. This is a description of:
Whenever practicable, what transponder code shall be used to provide recognition of an aircraft which is being subjected to unlawful interference:
To avoid wake turbulence, when flying behind and close to a large aeroplane, the pilot should manoeuvre whenever possible:
choices: below and downwind from the large aeroplane.
below and upwind from the large aeroplane.
above and upwind from the large aeroplane.
above and downwind from the large aeroplane.
OPS.answer: above and upwind from the large aeroplane.

OPS.question: Two aeroplanes are arriving from the same direction to land at an airport where making a straight-in approach and landing with a tailwind (within operational limits) will shorten the flight time by a few minutes. One of the aeroplanes has carbon brakes and the other steel brakes.
choices: The aeroplane with steel brakes should use the runway with a headwind as steel brakes are more efficient at absorbing energy at higher brake temperatures, making them less susceptible than carbon brakes to brake fading.
The aeroplane with steel brakes should NOT land with a tailwind as steel brakes are NOT approved for hard braking because steel brakes cannot absorb large amounts of energy.

The aeroplane with carbon brakes are more likely to suffer from brake overheat if landing with a tailwind as carbon brakes are sensitive to heat and will NOT absorb the energy as efficiently as steel brakes.
There can be a benefit in landing with a tailwind using carbon brakes as carbon brakes remain efficient at high temperatures and the wear is mainly determined by the number of applications.
OPS.answer: There can be a benefit in landing with a tailwind using carbon brakes as carbon brakes remain efficient at high temperatures and the wear is mainly determined by the number of applications.

OPS.question: What is the definition for horizontal windshear?
choices: The change of the horizontal wind vector with horizontal distance, as might be determined by two or more anemometers mounted at the same height along a runway.
The change of vertical wind vector with height, as might be determined by two or more anemometers at different heights on a mast.
The change of horizontal wind vector with height, as might be determined by two or more anemometers at different heights on a mast.

The change of the vertical wind vector with horizontal distance, as might be in a SNOWTAM, a runway condition code of 5 means: determined by two or more anemometers mounted at the same height along a runway.
OPS.answer: The change of the horizontal wind vector with horizontal distance, as might be determined by two or more anemometers mounted at the same height along a runway.

OPS.question: For each aircraft type, CS-25 requires the manufacturer to:
choices: Demonstrate that all passengers and crew can be evacuated within 60 seconds with 40% of the emergency exits available. Conducted in darkness with a representative cross-section of ‘passengers’.
Demonstrate that all passengers and crew can be evacuated within 90 seconds with all of the emergency exits available. Conducted in darkness with a representative cross-section of ‘passengers’.
Demonstrate that all 50% of passengers and crew can be evacuated within 90 seconds with half of the emergency exits available.
Demonstrate that all passengers and crew can be evacuated within 90 seconds with half of the emergency exits available. Conducted in darkness with a representative cross-section of ‘passengers’.
OPS.answer: Demonstrate that all passengers and crew can be evacuated within 90 seconds with half of the emergency exits available. Conducted in darkness with a representative cross-section of ‘passengers’.

OPS.question: An application of heated anti-icing fluid to de-ice the aeroplane which then remains on the surface to provide anti-icing for a limited period'. This is a description of:
According to Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes (CS 25), when an aeroplane needs to show compliance with the Emergency Evacuation requirements with an actual demonstration:
choices: at least 10 infants, 2 years old or younger, must be carried by female passengers.
not more than 50% of the emergency exits in the sides of the fuselage may be used.
a full briefing on the procedures to be followed in the demonstration must be given to the passengers.
aisles and emergency exit access ways must be clear of all obstructions, to avoid injuries.
OPS.answer: not more than 50% of the emergency exits in the sides of the fuselage may be used.

OPS.question: For an aircraft to operate in icing conditions at night, it must be equipped with a means to illuminate __________.
In a SNOWTAM, a runway condition code of 5 means:
choices: The pilot report of braking action is POOR.
The pilot report of braking action is GOOD.
The pilot report of braking action is GOOD to MEDIUM.
The pilot report of braking action is MEDIUM to POOR.
OPS.answer: The pilot report of braking action is GOOD.

OPS.question: One of the main characteristics of windshear is:
choices: it occurs only at a low altitude (2000 ft) and never in the horizontal plane.
it occurs only at a low altitude (2000 ft) and never in the vertical plane.
it can occur at any altitude in both the vertical and horizontal planes.
it can occur at any altitude and only in the horizontal plane.
OPS.answer: it can occur at any altitude in both the vertical and horizontal planes.

OPS.question: De-icing followed by anti-icing to provide maximum possible protection'. This a description of:
What equipment is required for determination of DH in CAT II and CAT III approaches?
According to OPS regulations, what is the planning flight preparation minima for a destination alternate with a CAT Il approach available?
Which 1 of the following statements accurately describes the security precautions at an airport?
choices: The landside area of an airport is more tightly controlled than the airside because the passengers have not yet been screened.
It's not possible to secure an airfield because of the very large perimeter boundary.
For the purposes of security, airport areas are usually divided into topside, airside, landside, and runways. Appropriate security measures are put in place for each area.
Areas of the airside of an airport are identified as priority risk areas where, in addition to access control, other security controls are applied.
OPS.answer: Areas of the airside of an airport are identified as priority risk areas where, in addition to access control, other security controls are applied.

OPS.question: The correct definition of a safe forced landing is:
choices: an inevitable landing on land or sea from which one may reasonably expect no injuries on board.
a landing on land or sea from which it is guaranteed no injuries will result to the occupants.
an unavoidable landing or ditching with a reasonable expectancy of no injuries to persons in the aircraft or on the surface.
a voluntary landing on land or sea carried out by the crew in order to protect the aircraft and its occupants.
OPS.answer: an unavoidable landing or ditching with a reasonable expectancy of no injuries to persons in the aircraft or on the surface.

OPS.question: A fast decompression is recognisable by the following elements: 1. mist in the cabin 2. air streaming out of the aircraft 3. expansion of body gases 4. blast of air released violently from the lungs The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
The inability of a tyre to penetrate a very thin residual fluid film left on the pavement after most trapped water has been displaced'. This is a description of:
An inspection of an aircraft interior after passenger access, and of the hold, checking for suspicious objects'. This is a description of:
choices: An emergency check, following an IED telephone threat.

OPS.question: A braking action of 0.25 and below reported on a SNOWTAM is:
Select the correct line which maybe seen in a SNOWTAM when the estimated surface friction is reported.
The estimated time that anti-icing fluid will prevent ice and frost formation and accumulation of snow on treated surfaces'. This is a description of:
choices: The maximum time for flight in severe icing conditions.

OPS.question: Select the correct presentation of friction measurement or calculated coefficient in a SNOWTAM:
The dynamic hydroplaning spin-up speed (for a non-rotating tyre) is:

An aircraft has been flying with one of its two transponders defective and the failure has been deferred in accordance with the MEL. During a 30 minute turnaround, an engineer replaces the defective transponder with a new one. Prior to commencing the next commercial air transport flight, what must the commander ensure?
choices: NO additional documentation is required. When the engineer performing the deferral in accordance with the MEL signed for the pending change of the transponder, this included clearance for the maintenance release at a later point.
The engineer must certify to have changed the transponder in accordance with the prescribed procedures and maintenance release must be signed for by an authorised person.
There is NO requirement for any additional documentation since the defective transponder was deferred according to the MEL and needed to be changed at the first opportunity.
The commander must visually inspect to ensure that the transponder has been changed in accordance with the prescribed procedure prior to signing the maintenance release.
OPS.answer: The engineer must certify to have changed the transponder in accordance with the prescribed procedures and maintenance release must be signed for by an authorised person.

OPS.question: A light aircraft is landing in a busy airport which operates multiple runways. Which runway should the pilot choose as preferential to avoid wake turbulence after a heavy aircraft landing?
The maximum validity of a SNOWTAM is:

An aerodrome observation reports the following runway contamination: 02170135 09L 5/2/2 100/50/75 NR/06/06 WET/SLUSH/SLUSH Which of the following would be the correct SNOWTAM Performance Calculation Section when ATIS reports the following winds: 260/15
Who is responsible for establishing the procedures for inspecting an aircraft when ground de-icing and anti-icing make this necessary?
According to CS 25, if a fuel jettisoning system is required, it must be capable of jettisoning enough fuel within:
Which of the following best describes Runway Visual Range?
choices: The range at which the pilot of an aircraft on the extended centre line of a runway during an approach to land can see the runway surface markings; or the lights delineating the runway or its centre line.
The range at which the pilot of an aircraft on the extended centre line of a runway during an approach to land is able to see the centre line of a runway.
The range over which the pilot of an aircraft on the centre line of a runway can see the runway surface markings; or the lights delineating the runway or identifying its centre line.

The range over which the pilot of an aircraft on the centre line of a runway can see either the runway surface markings, including the runway centre line; or the runway centre line lights and runway edge lights.
OPS.answer: The range over which the pilot of an aircraft on the centre line of a runway can see the runway surface markings; or the lights delineating the runway or identifying its centre line.

OPS.question: A runway designated 'wet or water patches' is given a SNOWTAM code of:

An Operator is carrying out Commercial Air Transport with aeroplanes and helicopters, including Low Visibility Operations. Which annexes of the European Regulations on Air Operations contain the requirements applicable to this Operator?
Which of the following statements is correct regarding the establishment of noise abatement procedures by the operator?
choices: NADP 1 or NADP 2 must be chosen for an airport, either by the commander or by the operator.
The same procedure must be applied for all airports.
The operator should establish its own NADPs by complying with the NADPs published by the authority.
The operator must establish NADP 1 and NADP 2.
OPS.answer: The operator should establish its own NADPs by complying with the NADPs published by the authority.

OPS.question: An aircraft is flying from London, Heathrow, UK to New York, JFK, USA and is within the NAT High Level Airspace at FL 360. A hydraulic warning light has come on, which may necessitate a change of level. The in-flight contingency procedure requires an offset from the assigned route. If prior clearance cannot be obtained, what would be the initial action?
choices: A turn to the left or right of track by at least 45° and immediately initiate a descent to a lower level.
Turn to the right of track in order to avoid any nearby traffic, which would follow the Strategic Offset Procedure (SLOP).
A turn to the right of track of at least 45° towards the nearest alternate, which is Keflavik, Iceland.
A turn to the right of track of at least 30° towards the nearest alternate, which is Keflavik, Iceland.
OPS.answer: A turn to the right of track of at least 30° towards the nearest alternate, which is Keflavik, Iceland.

OPS.question: The dynamic hydroplaning spin-down speed (for a rotating tyre) is:
Commanders must report bird activity to __________ using an ASR.
A runway where braking coefficients are reported as 31 /30/29 would have an estimated braking action of:
choices: Medium to poor, with the last third being poor.
Medium to good, with the last third being medium.
Medium, with the last third being medium to poor.
First third medium and the two remaining thirds medium to poor.
OPS.answer: Medium, with the last third being medium to poor.

OPS.question: A precautionary procedure which protects clean surfaces against ice formation for a limited period of time'. This is a description of:
For a given ambient temperature and type of anti-icing fluid, in which of the following conditions will the holdover (protection) time be the shortest?
Refuelling or de-fuelling with Avgas or wide-cut fuel _________ permitted while passengers are embarking, on board, or disembarking.
The global air-to-air frequency, for use when out of range of VHF ground stations, for exchange of operationally significant information is:

For 3- or 4-engined aeroplanes, at an AEO cruising speed, according to the FCOM, in ISA, still-air conditions and based on actual take-off mass, the maximum distance for a take-off alternate aerodrome should not be farther from the departure aerodrome than:
The NAT track message is typically published at:

For single-engined turbine aeroplane operations at night or in IMC, at normal cruising speed in still-air conditions, based on actual take-off mass, the maximum distance for a take-off alternate aerodrome should not be farther from the departure aerodrome than:
Items capable of posing a risk to health, safety, property or the environment and listed in the TIs or classified according to the TIs'. This is a description of:
choices: Dangerous goods which must never be carried on aircraft.
Dangerous goods which can only be carried by an Operator with a permanent approval to carry DGs.

OPS.question: Planning minima for all IFR flights should comply with which of the following criteria?
choices: Plan for at least 1 destination aerodrome + 1 destination alternate aerodrome so that no fewer than 2 safe-landing options are available during normal operations when reaching the destination aerodrome.
Plan for at least 1 aerodromes so that no fewer than 1 safe-landing option is available during normal operations when reaching the destination aerodrome.
Plan for at least 2 aerodromes so that 2 safe-landing options are available during normal operations when reaching the destination aerodrome.
Plan for at least 1 aerodrome so that 2 safe-landing options are available during normal operations when reaching the destination aerodrome.
OPS.answer: Plan for at least 1 aerodrome so that 2 safe-landing options are available during normal operations when reaching the destination aerodrome.

OPS.question: Which of the following criteria are applicable to the departure aerodrome planning minima?
choices: The commander should not commence take-off unless weather conditions at the departure aerodrome are no less than the applicable landing minima at that aerodrome, unless a weather-permissible take-off alternate aerodrome is available.

The commander may commence take-off provided weather conditions at a suitable take-off alternate aerodrome are forecast to be no less than the applicable landing minima at that aerodrome within 1.5 hours of take-off.
The commander should not commence take-off unless the RVR and DH for a non-precision approach at the departure aerodrome are no less than the applicable landing minima at that aerodrome.
The commander may commence take-off provided weather conditions at the departure aerodrome are forecast to be no less than the applicable landing minima at that aerodrome within 2 hours of take-off.
OPS.answer: The commander should not commence take-off unless weather conditions at the departure aerodrome are no less than the applicable landing minima at that aerodrome, unless a weather-permissible take-off alternate aerodrome is available.

OPS.question: 2 destination alternates are needed when:
choices: At the ETA +/- 2 hr the weather is such that, for a circling operation, ceiling ≥DA.
At the ETA +/- 1 hr the weather is such that safety margins cannot be met, or no meteorological information is available.
At the ETA +/- 2 hr the weather is such that, for a circling operation, ceiling ≥DH.
At the ETA +/- 2 hr the weather is such that saefety margins cannot be met,, or no meteorological information available.
OPS.answer: At the ETA +/- 1 hr the weather is such that safety margins cannot be met, or no meteorological information is available.

OPS.question: Noise abatement procedures must not prohibit the use of _____ _____ during landing.
According to ICAO, noise abatement procedures during landing:
choices: prohibit the use of reverse thrust.
apply in case of instrument approaches only.
shall not prohibit the use of reverse thrust.
apply in case of visual approaches only.
OPS.answer: shall not prohibit the use of reverse thrust.

OPS.question: Which of the following statements is correct, concerning precision approach minima for ETOPS ERA?
choices: A CAT II approach DH at an ETOPS ERA will be no lower than 100 ft.
The CAT I approach DH  at an ETOPS ERA will be no lower than 200 ft.
Additional ceiling and visibility increments only apply to CAT I minima.
The CAT I approach DH  at an ETOPS ERA will be no lower than 400 ft.
OPS.answer: The CAT I approach DH  at an ETOPS ERA will be no lower than 400 ft.

OPS.question: Noise abatement should not be the determining factor in the designation of a runway, under the following circumstances: 1. when crosswind component, including gusts, exceeds 15 kt. 2. when the tailwind component, including gusts, exceeds 5 kt. 3. when the runway surface conditions are adversely affected. The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
Complete this sentence regarding NAT HLA ATS Communications: "NAT operations outside VHF range require 2 ____, one of which should be ____."

During a manual approach, the aeroplane is subjected to wind shear with an increasing headwind. ln the absence of a pilot action, the aeroplane: 1. flies above the intended approach path 2. flies below the intended approach path 3. has an increasing true airspeed 4. has a decreasing true airspeed The combination of correct statements is:
According to the European Regulation on Air Operations, operations under IFR, or under VFR over routes NOT navigated by reference to visual landmarks:
choices: aircraft are only required to be equipped with one VOR and one ADF when area navigation is required.
only one radio communication system is necessary under normal operating conditions to communicate with an appropriate ground station at any point on the route, including diversions.
aircraft shall be equipped with one short range and one long range communication system.
aircraft shall be equipped with radio communication and navigation equipment in accordance with the applicable airspace requirements.
OPS.answer: aircraft shall be equipped with radio communication and navigation equipment in accordance with the applicable airspace requirements.

OPS.question: Who has the responsibility for establishing operating procedures for noise abatement purposes during instrument flight in compliance with ICAO PANS OPS 8168 the:
choices: state in which the aeroplane is operating

OPS.question: An aircraft has departed from Dublin on a transoceanic flight to Montreal. Prior to entering NAT HLA (High Level Airspace) at level flight, the flight crew performs a final confirmation of the aircraft systems serviceability and checks the two primary altimeter readings. Unless otherwise specified, within how many feet of each other must the altimeter readings be?

An aerodrome may be nominated as an ETOPS ERA aerodrome for flight planning and dispatch purposes, if available forecast weather conditions for a period lasting from the earliest potential landing time until 1 hour after the latest nominated time of use, equals or exceeds:
choices: For a precision approach, a ceiling of DA/H +400 ft and visibility of VIS +1500 m.
For a precision approach, a ceiling of DA/H +200 ft and visibility of VIS +800 m.
For a circling approach, a ceiling of MDA/H +200 ft and visibility of VIS +800 m.
For a non-precision approach, a ceiling of MDA/H +200 ft and visibility of VIS +800 m.
OPS.answer: For a precision approach, a ceiling of DA/H +200 ft and visibility of VIS +800 m.

OPS.question: A category I precision approach (CAT I) is an approach which may be carried out with a runway visual range of at least:
Which of the following statements about Blue Spruce routes is/are accurate?
choices: The Blue Spruce routes are published twice daily.
Blue Spruce routes are fixed routes across the northern part of the NAT HLA.
Blue Spruce routes are special routes exempt from NAT HLA requirements.
Blue Spruce routes are often used by aircraft with only 1 LRNS.
OPS.answer: Blue Spruce routes are fixed routes across the northern part of the NAT HLA.

OPS.question: If your ETA for an oceanic entry point changes (and the aircraft is not under ADS-C surveillance), you must pass a revised ETA to ATS if the change is greater than:

Using the Basic Fuel/Energy Procedure with Variations, what is the minimum reduced contingency fuel that should be uplifted using the RCF 2 procedure? Cruise fuel consumption = 2400 kg/hr Hold fuel consumption = 1800 kg/hr Flight time = 4 hours
What does the abbreviation MOPSC refer to?
The term decision height (DH) is used for:

Thrust is reduced to climb thrust above 800 ft, the airspeed is kept constant at not less than V2 + 10 kt. Then, at not more than 3000 ft, accelerate with positive rate of climb for flap/slat retraction'. This is a description of:
According to SLOP, it is recommended that flight crews of aircraft capable of programming automatic offsets:
choices: Should select flying an offset to the left (ODD flight levels)or to the right (EVEN flight levels) of track up to 2 nm in 0.1 nm increments.
Should select flying an offsetor to the left of track up to 2 nm n 0.1 nm increments.
Should randomly select flying centreline or an offset to the right of track up to 2 nm in 0.1 nm increments.
Should randomly select flying centreline or an offset to the left or to the right of track up to 2 nm in 0.1 nm increments.
OPS.answer: Should randomly select flying centreline or an offset to the right of track up to 2 nm in 0.1 nm increments.

OPS.question: Who is ultimately responsible for ensuring that all equipment and baggage is properly secured:
The best method for preventing gross navigation errors is to:
choices: Maintain an accurate list of waypoints.
Re-read your clearance before oceanic entry.
Plot your position accurately on a chart.
Maintain Mach number +/- 0.2 or TAS +/- 20 kt.
OPS.answer: Plot your position accurately on a chart.

OPS.question: A departure alternate is required:
choices: If the crosswind is out of limits for take-off
When carrying DGs on a cargo aircraft.
If, for performance or weather issues, it may not be possible to return to the departure aerodrome.
If the RVR is less than 1500 m
OPS.answer: If, for performance or weather issues, it may not be possible to return to the departure aerodrome.

OPS.question: MNPS is the abbreviation for:
A list of dangerous goods, which may not be transported by air, can be found in:
choices: the shipper's declaration for dangerous goods.
the Technical Instructions for the Safe Transport of Dangerous Goods by Air.
OPS.answer: the Technical Instructions for the Safe Transport of Dangerous Goods by Air.

OPS.question: In accordance with ICAO PANS OPS 8168, noise preferential routes are established to ensure that departing and arriving aeroplanes avoid overflying noise-sensitive areas in the vicinity of the aerodrome as far as practicable. In establishing noise preferential routes:
choices: turns during take-off and climb should not be required unless the bank angle for turns is limited to 28° (climbing at V2 + 10 to 20 kt)
turns during take-off and climb should not be required unless the bank angle for turns is limited to 20° (climbing at V2 + 10 to 20 kt)
turns during take-off and climb should not be required unless the aeroplane has reached and can maintain throughout the turn a height of no less than 100 m above terrain and the highest obstacle.
no turns should be required coincident with a reduction of power associated with a noise abatement procedure.
OPS.answer: no turns should be required coincident with a reduction of power associated with a noise abatement procedure.

OPS.question: Which of the following best describes Mach Number Technique?
choices: An in-flight technique whereby all participating aircraft operating along certain routes should maintain an assigned Mach number for the entire flight.
An in-flight technique whereby successive aircraft operating along all NAT HLA routes are assigned a Mach number by ATC for all flight above FL300.
An in-flight technique whereby successive aircraft operating along suitable routes are cleared by ATC to maintain a Mach number for a portion of the en-route phase of flight.

An in-flight technique for accuratlely converting Mach number to TAS and thereafter to an accurate and reliable GS, to permit monitoring and accurate reporting of flight progress, thereby ensuring aircraft separation.
OPS.answer: An in-flight technique whereby successive aircraft operating along suitable routes are cleared by ATC to maintain a Mach number for a portion of the en-route phase of flight.

OPS.question: Which of the following is/are single-LRNS routes:
choices: Most Blue Spruce routes and at least 1 Tango route.
All the Blue Spruce and Tango routes.
OPS.answer: Most Blue Spruce routes and at least 1 Tango route.

OPS.question: Regarding all weather operations, if VAT is from 91 kt to 120 kt, the aeroplane is in:
Whose responsibility is it to ensure that a suitable ETOPS en-route alternate is available within the approved, diversion time, at all points of any ETOPS segment(s)?
Who is responsible for developing procedures to ensure escape paths are unobstructed before taxi, take-off and landing?
In MNPS airspace, the speed reference for turbo-jet aircraft is the:
Refuelling or de-fuelling with Avgas or wide-cut fuel shall not take place:
choices: …unless passengers are embarking, on board or disembarking.
…if the operator has conducted a suitable and sufficient risk assessment, considering the high risk of using wide-cut fuel types.
...if the operator has established appropriate procedures.
...when passengers are embarking, on board or disembarking.
OPS.answer: ...when passengers are embarking, on board or disembarking.

OPS.question: For 2-engined aeroplanes, at an OEI cruising speed according to the FCOM, in ISA, still-air conditions and based on actual take-off mass, the maximum distance for a take-off alternate aerodrome should not be farther from the departure aerodrome than:
"A DG-related occurrence resulting in fatal or serious injury or major damage". This is a description of:
Using the Basic Fuel/Energy Scheme, contingency fuel is the greater of either the fuel required for:
choices: 5% of planned trip fuel or 5% of trip fuel for remainder of flight; or 5 minutes at cruising speed at 1000 ft (300 m) above destination in standard conditions.

5% of planned trip fuel or 5% of trip fuel for remainder of flight; or 5 minutes at OEI speed at 1500 ft (450 m) above destination in standard conditions, with the remaining engine set at maximum continuous power.
5% of planned trip fuel or 5% of trip fuel for remainder of flight; or 5 minutes at holding speed at 1500 ft (450 m) above destination in standard conditions.
5% of planned trip fuel or 10% of trip fuel for remainder of flight; or 10 minutes at holding speed at 1500 ft (450 m) above destination in standard conditions.
OPS.answer: 5% of planned trip fuel or 5% of trip fuel for remainder of flight; or 5 minutes at holding speed at 1500 ft (450 m) above destination in standard conditions.

OPS.question: Communication using HF radio is still common in the NAT HLA. Which of the following statements about HF radio communication is correct?
choices: Even when VHF radio reception isn't available, HF reception always will be.
At night, or when the sun is low, lower frequencies are used.
HF radio reception is usually clearer and more reliable than VHF.
Unlike VHF, HF radio reception is not significantly affected by the state of the ionosphere.
OPS.answer: At night, or when the sun is low, lower frequencies are used.

OPS.question: During a flight in NAT MNPS airspace at FL 390, if all long range navigation systems of an aircraft become unserviceable and if no instructions are received from the ATC within a reasonable delay, the pilot in command should consider, broadcasting on 121.5 MHz:
Regarding Noise Abatement Procedures, the first procedure (NADP 1) is used for noise reduction:
choices: Not applicable - there is no such procedure.

OPS.question: An aircraft is flying from Athens to Milan. The weather at the destination is below the applicable minima. The pilot may not take off unless the weather at the expected time of (1) _____ at (2) _____ is above the applicable minima.
Without ETOPS approval, twin-engined aeroplanes may not fly over a route which contains any point further from an adequate aerodrome than can be flown in the threshold time, OEI, in __________.
The pre-flight check before a NAT HLA flight must include a check of the aircraft's __________ because waypoint ETAs are based on its information.
Flights planning to operate outside VHF range may request HF exemption under certain circumstances. What condition is applied to any approval being issued?
choices: At least 1 alternative non-HF LRCS is carried

OPS.question: A DG-related occurrence resulting in injury, damage, fire, breakage, spillage, leakage of fluid or radiation or where the integrity of the packaging has failed, or seriously jeopardises the aircraft or its occupants". This is a description of:
ETOPS approval is part of:
What is meant by "reaching the destination aerodrome"?
choices: Arriving at the final approach fix at the destination aerodrome.
Reaching the missed approach point at the destination aerodrome.
Reaching DA/H or MDA/H at the destination aerodrome.
OPS.answer: Reaching DA/H or MDA/H at the destination aerodrome.

OPS.question: Refuelling or de-fuelling with Avgas or wide-cut fuel __________ permitted while passengers are embarking, on board, or disembarking.
According to ICAO Doc 4444, a wake turbulence non-radar separation minima of 2 minutes shall be applied to:
choices: LIGHT aircraft landing behind a MEDIUM aircraft.
MEDIUM aircraft taking-off behind a HEAVY aircraft from an intermediate part of a parallel runway separated by less than 760 m.
MEDIUM aircraft landing behind a HEAVY aircraft.
LIGHT aircraft taking-off behind a MEDIUM aircraft from an intermediate part of the same runway.
OPS.answer: MEDIUM aircraft landing behind a HEAVY aircraft.

OPS.question: The European Regulation on Air Operations states that for operations under IFR, or under VFR over routes NOT navigated by reference to visual landmarks, additional VOR or ADF systems are required on any route, or part thereof, where navigation is based on these respective signals. If neither of these are available, can the route still be flown?
choices: No, because the propagation characteristics of each system are different.
No, the carriage of VOR and ADF is mandatory.
Yes, provided position reporting with an appropriate ATC station can be performed.
Yes, if safe navigation can be performed with alternative equipment.
OPS.answer: Yes, if safe navigation can be performed with alternative equipment.

OPS.question: ICAO Annex 18 is a document dealing with:
choices: the safety of the air transport of dangerous goods.
the air transport of live animals.
the technical operational use of aircraft.
OPS.answer: the safety of the air transport of dangerous goods.

OPS.question: The (ETA +/-1 hr) planning minima for an isolated destination, a destination alternate, or en-route alternate aerodromes, for Type B approach operations, are:
What class of dangerous goods is represented by the label shown here?
Recency, training and checking requirements must be met for each type/variant operated by an individual crew member, except where the __________ approves credit(s) across types or variants.
During a conversion course, flight crew may not operate other types or classes of aircraft. This rule doesn't apply to flight crew who are exclusively operating Performance Class __________ aircraft.
Consider the applicable operational requirements on task specialists' responsibilities. Task specialists' duties shall be specified:
Identify the true and false statements. Personnel must have access to parts of the OM related to their duties.
choices: Only if they are flight crew

OPS.question: When a pilot has an OML licence restriction, the other pilot must be:
choices: No OML, less than 60 years old.
Fully qualified on type, no OML, less than 65 years old.
Fully qualified on type, no OML, less than 59 years old.
Fully qualified on type, no OML, less than 60 years old.
OPS.answer: Fully qualified on type, no OML, less than 60 years old.

OPS.question: In unforeseen circumstances, the aircraft can operate with reduced crew if passenger numbers are reduced to ensure the rules are met. In such cases a report must be made to __________.
Identify the true and false statements. Crew members must have personal copies of the OM Part A and Part B.

Cabin crew can operate on up to __________ different aeroplane types. This number may be increased if the procedures are similar. In this context a 'different type’ means that equipment locations, exits or procedures are different.
Pilots operating both aeroplanes and helicopters may only operate __________ type(s) of each.
Identify the true and false statements. Flight crew must have personal copies of the OM Parts A, B and C.
choices: Only if required by the Authority

OPS.question: A non-technical crew member assigned to perform in-flight duties related to the safety of passengers' is a description of:
Operators must not permit the use of portable electronic devices:
choices: Of any type at any time.
That can adversely affect aeroplane systems or equipment.
OPS.answer: That can adversely affect aeroplane systems or equipment.

OPS.question: The location from where the crew member normally starts and ends a series of FDPs and where crew accommodation is not required'. This is a definition of:
During a night flight, an observer located in the cockpit, seeing an aircraft coming from front left on approximate opposite parallel track, will first see the:
As a minimum the flight safety documentation system comprises the __________ manual and the __________ control manual.
The ICAO document applicable to operations by operators authorised to conduct international CAT operations is:
The commander or operator must submit an ASR to __________ for any incident that endangered, or could have endangered, safety.
__________ training is appropriate when 2 variants of the same aircraft type have very similar equipment and handling characteristics.

An aircraft is due to be operated with 160 passengers. The aircraft has not yet been assigned a required minimum number of cabin crew by the competent authority. For this trip, ___ cabin crews are required.
Before conducting CAT operations, the operator must:
choices: Apply for an AOC from EASA.
Apply for an AOC from the relevant Authority.
Obtain an AOC issued by the relevant Authority.
OPS.answer: Obtain an AOC issued by the relevant Authority.

OPS.question: According to ICAO Annex 6, what shall the Operator establish for the use and guidance of operational personnel, as part of its safety management system?
Life rafts are required for flight over water at ‘long distances’ from land. For an aeroplane capable of continuing OEI to an aerodrome this means the lesser of:
choices: 120 min at cruising speed and 300 nm.
120 min at cruising speed and 400 nm.
180 min at cruising speed and 200 nm.
90 min at cruising speed and 400 nm.
OPS.answer: 120 min at cruising speed and 400 nm.

OPS.question: Sole authority as to whether an 'acceptable deferred defect' is acceptable for the flight rests with:
Identify if this is a true or false statement. Digital flight data monitoring programmes use data from operations for safety and disciplinary purposes.
First-aid oxygen is required for any aeroplane which:
choices: Requires cabin crew and is pressurised and which operates at a pressure altitude > 19 000 ft.
Requires cabin crew and is pressurised and which operates at a pressure altitude > 25 000 ft.
Requires cabin crew and is pressurised and which operates at a pressure altitude > 10 000 ft.
Requires cabin crew or is pressurised or which operates at a pressure altitude > 25 000 ft.
OPS.answer: Requires cabin crew and is pressurised and which operates at a pressure altitude > 25 000 ft.

OPS.question: TAWS is required:
choices: For all turbine-powered aircraft, but not piston-engined aircraft.
Only for aircraft certified to operate under IFR.
For all aircraft with a MCTOM > 5700 kg or a MOPSC > 9
For all aircraft with a MCTOM > 5700 kg or MOPSC > 19.
OPS.answer: For all aircraft with a MCTOM > 5700 kg or a MOPSC > 9

OPS.question: An aircraft must have cabin crew, when there are passengers on board, if its MOPSC is greater than:
An ATC service appropriate to airspace and rules of the air:
choices: Must be used for all flights when possible.
Must be used by all aircraft with a MCTOM > 27 000 kg.
Must be used by all aircraft with a MCTOM > 20 000 kg.
Is not essential for a flight in which no passengers are carried.
OPS.answer: Must be used for all flights when possible.

OPS.question: Consider the applicable operational requirements on task specialist's responsibilities. The task specialist shall report any fault, failure, malfunction or defect, which is believed to affect the safe operation of the aircraft, to:
Identify the true and false statements. Copies of all parts of the OM must be kept in the aircraft library.
choices: Only if required by the operator

OPS.question: ln accordance with OPS regulations, an operator must ensure that the MDH for a VOR approach is not lower than:
The MEL (Minimum Equipment List) shall be established by:
Which statement is true about required equipment?
choices: All required flight equipment is not subjected to an equipment approval.
All flight equipment is subject to an equipment approval.
Accurate time pieces can be used without an equipment approval.
Child-restraint devices are subject to an equipment approval.
OPS.answer: Accurate time pieces can be used without an equipment approval.

OPS.question: The correct statement concerning extinguishing agents onboard aircraft is:
choices: Water may only be used for minor fires.
A powder extinguisher is suitable for extinguishing a cockpit fire.
Carbon dioxide is only used in the cargo hold.
Halon is an effective extinguishing agent for use in aircraft.
OPS.answer: Halon is an effective extinguishing agent for use in aircraft.

OPS.question: An emergency medical kit required for any aircraft with a:
choices: MOPSC > 30 and which intends to fly > 60 minutes from an aerodrome with medical assistance available.
MOPSC > 30 and which intends to fly > 30 minutes from an aerodrome with medical assistance available.
MOPSC > 20 and which intends to fly > 45 minutes from an aerodrome with medical assistance available.
MOPSC > 20 and which intends to fly > 60 minutes from an aerodrome with medical assistance available.
OPS.answer: MOPSC > 30 and which intends to fly > 60 minutes from an aerodrome with medical assistance available.

OPS.question: A pilot is performing the pre-flight preparations on an aircraft whose first Certificate of Airworthiness was issued in 2010. This is the first time the pilot is operating an aircraft where a Flight Data Recorder (FDR) is required. The following is a requirement about the operation of the FDR:
choices: The FDR sensors must be switched on, as data are recorded from sensors that are independent from the information shown to the flight crew, to improve integrity of the recording.
Regardless of pilot action, recording will start and stop automatically to ensure the FOR can record data at all times when the aeroplane is capable of moving under its own power.
Regardless of pilot action, the FDR automatically records at any time when there are persons on board the aeroplane to determine liability in the event of a failure of any system.
The FDR must be manually started when the flight crew begin the pre-flight preparations and then manually stopped when the doors are opened after landing, to preserve the data.
OPS.answer: Regardless of pilot action, recording will start and stop automatically to ensure the FOR can record data at all times when the aeroplane is capable of moving under its own power.

OPS.question: The commander must produce all required documents within a reasonable time if asked by a representative of:
Which of the following correctly states the requirement for spare fuses?
Before exercising Commander’s discretion the commander must:
choices: Obtain the permission of the Operator.
Obtain the permission of all the crew members.
Obtain the permission of the majority of the crew members.
Consult the crew on their alertness levels before deciding on extension.
OPS.answer: Consult the crew on their alertness levels before deciding on extension.

OPS.question: How many battery-powered accessible megaphones are required on an aircraft with a MOPSC of 61-99?
The MMEL (Master Minimum Equipment List) is drawn up by:
__________ training is required when the variants are broadly similar but have some significant differences that justify time in the simulator or aircraft.
The term 'CAT operations' describes:
choices: The carriage of passengers or mail in any circumstances.
The carriage of passengers, cargo or mail across international borders.
The transport of passengers, cargo or mail for remuneration or valuable reward.
Any flight operated by the holder of a commercial pilot's licence.
OPS.answer: The transport of passengers, cargo or mail for remuneration or valuable reward.

OPS.question: During __________ phases of flight, cabin crew must be seated at assigned station and must not perform any duties other than those required for safety.
An item which does not consistently accomplish its intended purpose, or function within its design limits or tolerances is most properly classed as __________.
CAT operations are only legal if the operator has an:
The first aid oxygen equipment must be capable of a mass flow of at least __________ litres STPD per minute.

Flight time specification schemes must specify recurrent extended recovery rest periods to compensate for cumulative fatigue. Such periods must be a minimum of __________ hours, including __________ local night(s).
According to Annex 6, what is the definition of an Air Operator Certificate?
choices: A certificate needed to carry out specified commercial international air transport operations, but not for domestic commercial flights.
A certificate the crew will present to immigration officers, stating that all passengers on board fulfil the visa requirements needed.
A certificate automatically authorising an operator to carry out domestic air services in any ICAO contracting State.
A certificate authorising an operator to carry out specified commercial air transport operations.
OPS.answer: A certificate authorising an operator to carry out specified commercial air transport operations.

OPS.question: An aircraft with 29 passengers requires how many fire extinguishers?

You have recently passed your initial training and line check for an operator and it is only your 6th flight as an inexperienced pilot. During the briefing, you realise that the captain you're scheduled to fly with has also recently passed his/her command upgrade and it is only his/her 3rd flight. Can you fly together?
choices: Yes, since both of you have completed your respective training, you count as experienced crew.
Yes, you have passed your supernumerary flights therefore you can fly with an inexperienced captain.
Yes, as long as the dispatcher is aware and allows it.
No, there are too many inexperienced flight crew.
OPS.answer: No, there are too many inexperienced flight crew.

OPS.question: What area of operations is covered by Regulation 965/2012 Annex VIII?
Identify the true and false statements. All personnel must have personal access to the OM Parts A, B and C.
A captain may be assigned to operate from the co-pilot's position for training or checking a __________ or when designated by the operator to act as co-pilot.

For passenger oxygen systems, the required minimum supply is the amount of oxygen needed for a constant rate descent from the aeroplane’s maximum certificated operating altitude to 15 000 ft in __________ minutes.
Any task a crew member performs for the operator'. This is a definition of:
The regulatory green navigation light is located on the starboard side with a coverage angle of:
As a flight crew member, you are to report for a period of airport standby. When does the airport standby period commence?
choices: 30 minutes before arriving at the airport.
From reporting at the reporting point.
45 minutes before arriving at the airport.
OPS.answer: From reporting at the reporting point.

OPS.question: If a crew member is working for more than one operator the responsibility for flight, duty and rest records rests with:

Flight crew must not operate on more than __________ type(s) or variant(s) unless competent to do so. The Operator must assess the differences, similarities, SOPs and handling characteristics of the aircraft to ensure that such an operation is justified.

A pilot working for a CAT operator has performed 105 duty hours in the last 13 consecutive days. On the 14th day, the operator's crewing department calls, asking the pilot to operate a flight with a total duty of 8 hours later that same day. According to the EU-OPS regulations, what is the correct decision?
choices: NOT operate the flight, since duty shall NOT exceed 110 duty hours in any 14 consecutive days.
Operate the flight, since the limit for duty is 115 duty hours in any 14 consecutive days.
Operate the flight, since the limit for duty is 120 duty hours in any 14 consecutive days.
NOT operating the flight, since duty shall NOT exceed 105 duty hours in any 14 consecutive days.
OPS.answer: NOT operate the flight, since duty shall NOT exceed 110 duty hours in any 14 consecutive days.

OPS.question: According to OPS regulations, for a pressurised aeroplane, following an emergency descent, the maximum pressure altitude at which each member of the flight crew on flight deck duty are not required to be supplied with supplemental oxygen, without flight time limitation is:
To act as commander in commercial air transport on a single-pilot aeroplane, how many hours must the holder of a CPL(A) fly on a multi-engine type under IFR?
The point when the aircraft first moves under its own power for the purpose of preparing for take-off'. This is a definition of:
choices: Start of a flight duty period.

OPS.question: The average flow rate of first aid oxygen must be __________ litres per minute per person at standard temperature and pressure, dry (STPD).
During a turnaround, the pilots get a visit from a competent authority who requests to see the aircraft's documents. What should the commander do in this situation?
choices: The commander must not provide such documents,. the inspector should contact the operator.
Cali his/her superior and ask before showing these documents.
Provide to that person the documentation required to be carried on board.
Comply because anybody is allowed to see those documents.
OPS.answer: Provide to that person the documentation required to be carried on board.

OPS.question: You are the pilot of a calibration flight requiring a task specialist to be on board. The task specialist is aware of an incident that could endanger the safety of the operation. Who must he/she report this to?
An aircraft with 42 passengers requires how many fire extinguishers?
Identify if this is a true or false statement. A flight data monitoring programme must exist for aircraft with MCTOM > 27 000 kg.
choices: Only if required by the state of registry

OPS.question: When operating an in-flight relief (heavy) crew at or above FL 200, the commander can be relieved by:
choices: A commander, or a CPL/ATPL-holding co-pilot who is type-rated, satisfies the recency requirements and is in date with recurrent training.
Any CPL-holding co-pilot who is type-rated, satisfies the recency requirements and is in date with recurrent training.
A commander, or an ATPL-holding co-pilot who is type-rated, satisfies the recency requirements and is in date with recurrent training.
OPS.answer: A commander, or an ATPL-holding co-pilot who is type-rated, satisfies the recency requirements and is in date with recurrent training.

OPS.question: Identify if this is a true or false statement. A flight data monitoring programme should exist for aircraft with MCTOM > 20 000 kg.
The minimum CVR loop recording time is:
choices: 25 hrs if the aircraft's MCTOM > 5700 kg and its C of A was issued after 1 Jan 2021 and 1 hr for all other aeroplanes.
25 hrs if the aircraft's MCTOM > 27 000 kg and its C of A was issued after 1 Jan 2021 and 2 hrs for all other aeroplanes.
10 hrs if the aircraft's MCTOM > 27 000 kg and individual C of A after 1 Jan 2021 and 2 hrs for all other aeroplanes.
25 hrs if the aircraft's MCTOM > 5700 kg and its C of A was issued after 1 Jan 2021 and 2 hrs for all other aeroplanes.
OPS.answer: 25 hrs if the aircraft's MCTOM > 27 000 kg and its C of A was issued after 1 Jan 2021 and 2 hrs for all other aeroplanes.

PER.question: What is the screen height for take off from a wet runway for a Class B aircraft?
With reference to CAP 698 Figure 3.7. Why is wind omitted from the graph?
choices: Wind is automatically incorporated into the graph.
Wind is only considered when climbing in certain directions.
The data is measured with reference to the air.
The data is measured with reference to the ground.
PER.answer: The data is measured with reference to the air.

PER.question: The stalling speed or the minimum steady flight speed at which the aeroplane is controllable in landing configuration is abbreviated as:
Compared with clean configuration, a take off with a 10° flaps setting will result in:
choices: A decreased field length limited TOM and a decreased climb limited TOM.
An increased field length limited TOM and a decreased climb limited TOM.
A decreased field length limited TOM and a increased climb limited TOM.
An increased field length limited TOM and a increased climb limited TOM.
PER.answer: An increased field length limited TOM and a decreased climb limited TOM.

PER.question: What conditions allow the "increase V1" technique to increase the allowable take-off mass? The take off mass is:
choices: Limited by both the field & length and the maximum tyre speed.
Not limited by the field nor by the maximum tyre speed.
Limited either by the runway length or by the maximum tyre speed.
PER.answer: Not limited by the field nor by the maximum tyre speed.

PER.question: With reference to CAP 698 Figure 3.10. Given the following information, calculate the barrier speed for a multi-engine piston airplane. Pressure altitude: 4000 ft Outside air temp: 10°C Aircraft mass: 3450 lb
A Class B aeroplane has a wingspan of 10 metres. 1000 metres from the start of the departure sector, the width of the sector is __________ metres.
What is the effect of excess thrust on a climb at constant angle?
choices: Converts excess thrust to increase flight path angle.
Accelerates and rate of climb increases.
PER.answer: Accelerates and rate of climb increases.

PER.question: You are in a single engine piston aircraft with a stall speed of 68 kt. What is the minimum value of VR for this aircraft?
Refer to CAP 698 Figure 4.1. For a maximum allowable tailwind of 10 kt calculate the maximum wind strength that can be accepted for a take off from runway 06 with wind from 180 degrees.
The critical engine inoperative:
choices: Decreases the power required and increases the total drag due to the additional drag of the windmilling engine and the compensation of the yaw moment.
Increases the power required and the total drag due to the additional drag of the windmilling engine and the compensation of the yaw moment.
Does not affect the aeroplane performance since it is independent of the power plant.
Increases the power required and decreases the total drag due to the windmilling engine.
PER.answer: Increases the power required and the total drag due to the additional drag of the windmilling engine and the compensation of the yaw moment.

PER.question: Assume a normal approach and landing with a class B aircraft on a wet runway. Which of the following values shows the corresponding screen height?
The rotation speed VR for normal utility single-engined landplanes (MTOM 5700 kg or less) must be the same as or faster than:
choices: 1.10 VMC or 1.20 VS1, whichever is the greater.
1.05 VMC or 1.10 VS1, whichever is the greater.

PER.question: The reference speed of the aeroplane, in a specified landing configuration, at the point where it descends through the landing screen height in the determination of the landing distance for manual landings is:
Which of the following provides maximum obstacle clearance during climb?
choices: The speed for maximum rate of climb.
The speed for maximum climb angle Vx.
The speed, at which the flaps may be selected one position further UP.
PER.answer: The speed for maximum climb angle Vx.

PER.question: The Performance Class B take-off flight path:
choices: Begins at 50 ft above the surface at the end of the TODR and ends at approximately 1000 ft above the surface.
Begins at the point of lift-off and ends at the 50 ft screen height.
Begins at the start of the take-off and ends at approximately 1500 ft above the surface.
Begins at 50 ft above the surface at the end of the TODR and ends at approximately 1500 ft above the surface.
PER.answer: Begins at 50 ft above the surface at the end of the TODR and ends at approximately 1500 ft above the surface.

PER.question: Which factor must be applied, if not stated differently in AFM, for a Performance Class B aeroplane when taking-off on a runway with 1% upslope?
Assume a normal approach and landing with a class B airplane on a dry runway. Which of the following values shows the corresponding screen height?
The speed at which the pilot starts to apply back pressure to initiate rotation on take-off is:
What is the effect on performance when the outside air pressure is low:
choices: Decreases the take off roll due to a lower TAS.
Increases the take-off roll due to reduced lift available on the wing.
Increases take-off roll due to decrease in thrust available.
Decreases take-off roll due to increase in thrust available.
PER.answer: Increases take-off roll due to decrease in thrust available.

PER.question: For an SEP Aircraft. Using the data provided in CAP 698 as required. Determine the required headwind given: OAT+30°C, Pressure altitude: 2000 ft, TODA 1900 ft, Mass 3200 lbs, Flaps at Approach, Dry asphalt runway.

The departure sector begins at the point where the aircraft reaches __________ ft above the surface. At this point the width of the departure sector is half the aeroplane's wingspan plus __________ metres.

For multi-engine Class B aeroplanes, the operator must ensure that the aircraft is capable of continuing flight, at or above the relevant minimum altitudes for safe flight stated in the Operations Manual, to a point __________ft above the aerodrome.
The stall speed or the minimum steady flight speed obtained in a specified configuration is:
The maximum angle of bank permitted after take-off below 50 ft for an aeroplane in Performance Class B is:
The stall speed or the minimum steady flight speed in the landing configuration is:

The operator must ensure that the aircraft, in the meteorological conditions expected for the flight, and in the event of engine failure, is capable of reaching a place at which a safe forced landing can be made.
choices: This requirement applies only to single-engine Class B aeroplanes.
This requirement applies to all Class B aeroplanes.
This requirement applies to single-engine Class B aeroplanes taking-off in IMC.
This requirement applies to all multi-engine Class B aeroplanes.
PER.answer: This requirement applies only to single-engine Class B aeroplanes.

PER.question: The 1g stall speed at which the aeroplane can develop a lift force (normal to the flight path) equal to its weight is:
Which of the following is correct concerning fuel consumption change, at altitude, of a propeller driven aeroplane?
The reference stall speed in the landing configuration is:
For a Performance Class B, multi-engined aeroplane, in order to eliminate any problems associated with a critical engine failure:
choices: engines are mounted away from the aeroplane's centreline.
propellers with a minimum of three blades are used.
all propellers turn ln the same direction.

PER.question: The stall speed or the minimum steady flight speed at which the aeroplane is controllable is:
The effect of increasing the flap setting, from zero to the recommended take-off setting, on the length of the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) and the Field Length Limited Take-off mass (TOM) is:
choices: Increased TOD required and increased field length limited TOM.
Decreased TOD required and decreased field length limited TOM.
Decreased TOD required and increased field length limited TOM.
Increased TOD required and decreased field length limited TOM.
PER.answer: Decreased TOD required and increased field length limited TOM.

PER.question: For an MEP Aircraft. Using the data provided in CAP698 as required. Determine the TOD for an aircraft, mass 4500 lb, flaps up, 1000 ft pressure altitude, 20°C and 10 kt headwind component.
What percentages of the head wind and tail wind component are taken into account when calculating the take off field length required?
The gradient of the take-off flight path from 50 ft to the engine failure height is the average all-engine gradient multiplied by a factor of __________.
The minimum power required speed VMP is __________ VMD.
What is the minimum width of a clearway?
In the cruise, optimum range and endurance is most likely to be achieved when the CG position is slightly __________.
The speed at which an aircraft achieves its maximum rate of climb is known as __________.
What is the effect of increased mass on the performance of a gliding aeroplane?
choices: The speed for best angle of descent increases.
PER.answer: The speed for best angle of descent increases.

PER.question: In a steady unaccelerated descent:
choices: The thrust steadily reduces with altitude.
Thrust and a component of weight are balanced by the drag.
The lift must be less than the combined components of weight.
The lift steadily reduces with altitude.
PER.answer: Thrust and a component of weight are balanced by the drag.

PER.question: Wet and contaminated runways increase the take-off distance because of the twin influences of displacement drag and __________ drag.
A 10% increase in the speed at the screen height, results in a __________% increase in the landing distance. Answer as a number.
Climb gradient is the __________ divided by the __________ times 100.
choices: vertical height gained; horizontal distance flown
horizontal distance flown; horizontal distance flown
horizontal distance flown; vertical height gained
vertical height gained; vertical height gained
PER.answer: vertical height gained; horizontal distance flown

PER.question: Lowering flaps __________ the rate of climb and __________ VY.
A decrease in the turbojet aeroplane's mass __________ Vx and __________ the excess thrust.
The initial part of the descent is flown at a constant __________.
Aeroplanes powered by reciprocating engines with an MOPSC of more than 9 or a maximum take-off mass exceeding 5700 kg are in Performance Class:
For a turbojet engine fuel flow = SFC x __________.
If the demonstrated crosswind is considered to be limiting, then it’s entered as an operating limitation in:
choices: The Abnormal Procedures section of the training manual.

PER.question: What is the specific range (SAR)?
The primary purpose of a continuous descent to final approach is to:
choices: Minimise noise disturbance to people under the flight path.

PER.question: An aeroplane is taking off on Runway 18. The reported wind is 210/40 kt. The headwind component is __________ kt. The crosswind component is __________ kt.
How does an increase in mass affect VY and VX?
The __________ is the angle of the aircraft’s flight path (in degrees) measured with respect to the Earth’s horizontal.
The flight path angle is the angle between the:
choices: path of the aircraft relative to True North.
longitudinal axis and the path of the aircraft.
path of the aircraft relative to the horizon.
PER.answer: path of the aircraft relative to the horizon.

PER.question: The intersections of the thrust available and the drag curve are the operating points of the aeroplane:
The __________ an aerodrome’s pressure altitude, the longer the TOD.
The take-off distance available (TODA) is normally:
choices: The runway plus stopway. The TODA is the lesser of: TORA plus stopway, or 1.5 times TORA.
The runway plus stopway and clearway.
The runway plus the clearway. The TODA is the lesser of: TORA plus clearway, or 1.5 times TORA.
The runway plus the clearway. The TODA is the lesser of: TORA plus clearway, or 0.5 times TORA.
PER.answer: The runway plus the clearway. The TODA is the lesser of: TORA plus clearway, or 1.5 times TORA.

PER.question: Other factors remaining constant, the effect an increase of altitude, in a standard atmosphere, has on the value of Vx and Vv in terms of TAS is:
choices: Vx will decrease and Vv will increase.

PER.question: With regard to turbo jet aeroplanes, wind (1) ____ endurance and (2) ____ the maximum endurance speed. Which option is the correct one?
choices: (1) does not affect, (2) does not affect
PER.answer: (1) does not affect, (2) does not affect

PER.question: In Europe CS-23 covers:
choices: The operation of aeroplanes in the Normal category, with a passenger seating configuration up to 19 or less and a MCTOM of 8618 kg (or less).
The operation of aeroplanes in the Normal category, with a passenger seating configuration up to 19 or less and a Mass of 8618 kg (or less).
Covers large aeroplanes with a MCTOM greater than 5700 kg.
PER.answer: The operation of aeroplanes in the Normal category, with a passenger seating configuration up to 19 or less and a MCTOM of 8618 kg (or less).

PER.question: The specific air range (SAR) __________ affected by wind, because it depends on NAM/kg of fuel or TAS/fuel flow.
In steady, unaccelerated, straight-and-level flight:
choices: T must be greater than D.
W cosθ is parallel to the flight path.

PER.question: For a given air gradient, a headwind __________ the ground gradient; a tailwind __________ it.
Endurance is maximised when the fuel flow is __________.
Gross Performance diminished by a safety factor (margin), laid down by the appropriate authority is known as:
A decrease in atmospheric pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on take-off performance:
choices: A reduced take-off distance and improved initial climb performance.
An increased take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance.
An increased take-off distance and improved initial climb performance.
A reduced take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance.
PER.answer: An increased take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance.

PER.question: The maximum operating CAS is __________
Aeroplanes powered by propeller engines with an MOPSC of 9 or less and a maximum take-off mass of 5700 kg or less are in Performance Class:
When not flat-rated, thrust reduces with altitude because:
choices: The temperature reduces, thus reducing the mass flow through both turbojet engines and propellers.
The temperature reduces, thus reducing the thermal efficiency of engines.
The air density reduces, thus reducing the mass flow through both turbojet engines and propellers.
Altitude reduces the velocity of flow through the propeller or turbojet engine.
PER.answer: The air density reduces, thus reducing the mass flow through both turbojet engines and propellers.

PER.question: The theoretical altitude at which the rate of climb is zero is called the__________ ceiling.
Extending flap __________ excess thrust.
__________ is the minimum speed that ensures you can retain sufficient control of the aircraft when in the approach and landing configuration.

The average performance that a fleet of aircraft can be expected to achieve, when satisfactorily maintained and flown in accordance with the techniques described in the flight manual' is a description of:
MECON __________ as the cost index increases.
The cost index is the cost of time/the cost of fuel. A lower cost index weights the flight towards __________ savings. A higher cost index weights the flight towards __________ savings.
Along with aeroplane mass, which other factors have an influence on the service ceiling?
choices: Airspace capacity and clear air turbulence.
Air temperature and the position of the CG.
PER.answer: Air temperature and the position of the CG.

PER.question: For a turbojet aircraft, VX occurs at __________.
With regard to the effect of altitude on the speed for maximum endurance for a propeller-driven aeroplane, as altitude increases, the speed for maximum endurance will:
choices: decrease, because the power required decreases with altitude.
increase, because the power required increases with altitude.
decrease, because aeroplane drag decreases with altitude.
increase, because aeroplane drag increases with altitude.
PER.answer: increase, because the power required increases with altitude.

PER.question: When a turbojet aeroplane climbs using a climb schedule, the initial part of the climb is flown at constant __________ and subsequently at constant __________.
An aircraft is descending at 193 kt TAS in still air with a vertical speed of 1000 ft/min. The descent gradient is:
The point during the climb at which the designated climb CAS and designated climb Mach number coincide is known as the __________altitude.
For a turbojet engine, SFC is lowest (best) when:
choices: The aircraft is flying at VMD.
The engine is running at its design RPM (approximately 90 to 95% maximum).
The engine is running at VMP.
PER.answer: The engine is running at its design RPM (approximately 90 to 95% maximum).

PER.question: The net flight path climb gradient after take-off compared to the gross climb gradient is:
The "Density altitude" is:
choices: the height obtained by setting the subscale of an altimeter to QNE.
the height in the standard atmosphere at which the prevailing density occurs.
the altitude in the standard atmosphere at which the prevailing density occurs.
the altitude obtained by setting the subscale of an altimeter to QNH.
PER.answer: the altitude in the standard atmosphere at which the prevailing density occurs.

PER.question: Turbojet range is greatest at __________ altitude because this is where SFC is __________.
In a propeller-driven, twin-engined aircraft, VXSE is __________ than VX.
An increase in atmospheric pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on landing performance:
choices: An increased landing distance and improved go-around performance.
An increased landing distance and degraded go-around performance.
A reduced landing distance and improved go-around performance.
A reduced landing distance and degraded go-around performance.
PER.answer: A reduced landing distance and improved go-around performance.

PER.question: For a turbojet-powered aeroplane, the lowest SFC occurs:
choices: At the altitude where the engine is running at full throttle (full throttle height).
Whenever the engine is running at the lowest RPM needed to sustain straight and level flight.
At the altitude where the thrust required requires the engine core to run at its optimum design RPM.
Whenever the engine is running at its optimum design RPM (90-95% of maximum).
PER.answer: At the altitude where the thrust required requires the engine core to run at its optimum design RPM.

PER.question: Turns __________ climb performance.

Multi-engined aeroplanes powered by turbo-propeller engines with an MOPSC of more than 9 or a maximum take-off mass exceeding 5700 kg, and all multi-engined turbo-jet powered aeroplanes are in Performance Class:
The optimum altitude for range is __________ for a propeller-driven aeroplane compared with a turbojet-driven aeroplane.
If you don’t let the automatics manage the descent:
choices: Set a target CAS or Mach number to avoid the risk of any speed exceedance.
The aeroplane will descend at the minimum rate of descent.
Select a target CAS to avoid the risk of a MMO exceedance.
Select a target CAS to avoid the risk of a VMO exceedance.
PER.answer: Select a target CAS to avoid the risk of a VMO exceedance.

PER.question: With regard to the CG and its effect on performance select the correct statement.
choices: A forward CG increases stability and increases fuel consumption.
An aft CG decreases stability and increases fuel consumption.
An aft CG increases stability and decreases fuel consumption.
A forward CG increases stability and decreases fuel consumption.
PER.answer: A forward CG increases stability and increases fuel consumption.

PER.question: A tailwind __________ the range (SGR).
The maximum operating Mach number is known as __________.
Compared with still-air, the effect a headwind has on the values of the maximum range speed and the maximum gradient climb speed respectively is that:
choices: The maximum range speed decreases and the maximum gradient climb speed increases.
The maximum range speed decreases and the maximum gradient climb speed decreases.
The maximum range speed increases and the maximum gradient climb speed is not affected.
The maximum range speed decreases and the maximum gradient climb speed is not affected.
PER.answer: The maximum range speed increases and the maximum gradient climb speed is not affected.
