Solar radiation helps to provide sufficient energy for __________.
The atmosphere is divided into layers according to how the __________ varies with height.
Which is true of the temperature at the tropopause?
choices: It is higher in equatorial regions than in polar regions.
It is highest in middle latitudes.
It is higher in polar regions than in equatorial regions.
There is no significant difference with change of latitude.
MET.answer: It is higher in polar regions than in equatorial regions.

MET.question: At high altitudes a powerful oxidant called __________ must be removed from the cabin air.
In conditions of conditional stability, stability is determined by whether the air is saturated or not. If saturated, then the air is __________, if unsaturated (dry) then the air is __________.
The geostrophic wind scale quantifies the relationship between isobar spacing and the __________ __________ __________.
Air temperature is a measure of __________ energy.
Subsiding air creates a column of relatively warmer air which decreases the average ELR and __________ atmospheric stability. This __________ cloud formation.
Define a 'HIGH.
choices: An area with higher pressure than that of the horizontal environments.
MET.answer: An area with higher pressure than that of the horizontal environments.

MET.question: Mountain waves should be expected:
choices: on the downwind side of the mountain range.
on the upwind side of the mountain range.
MET.answer: on the downwind side of the mountain range.

MET.question: The atmospheric layer above the troposphere, where temperature is constant with height up to about __________ km, is called the __________.
Up to a height of about 20 km, 1 of the 2 principal layers in the atmosphere is the __________ where temperature __________ with height.
The transition altitude for the day is 4500 ft. The QNH on this summer day is 1030 hPa. At the transition altitude you change the altimeter to the SPS. It now reads:
Turbulence __________ the transfer of heat energy between atmospheric layers.
Flight towards an area of low temperature causes the indicated altitude to be __________ than the true altitude. This error is __________.
When flying in mountainous terrain and assuming ISA temperatures and strong winds, which of the following is correct?
choices: In cases of the venturi effect, the actual altitude of the aircraft is lower than the indicated altitude.
In cases of the combined effect of surface friction and adiabatic compression of the air, the dynamic pressure is lower than indicated by the altimeter.
In cases of adiabatic compression of the air, the temperature is lower than indicated.
In cases of the venturi effect, the indicated altitude of the aircraft is lower than the actual altitude.
MET.answer: In cases of the venturi effect, the actual altitude of the aircraft is lower than the indicated altitude.

MET.question: Which of the following is true of a 'land breeze'?
choices: It blows from land to water.
It blows from water to land.
MET.answer: It blows from land to water.

MET.question: An isobaric trough results in __________ weather because there is pronounced surface __________.
On traditional mean sea level pressure (MSLP) synoptic charts the plotted __________ use these values.
If the ELR is less than both the DALR and SALR then the atmosphere is __________.
____________________ is absorbed or released whenever water in the atmosphere changes its state (for example, from liquid to ice).
You are on an approach to an airfield, descending through the friction layer. The wind changes from a headwind to a slight right crosswind.
choices: This is typical for southern hemisphere.
This is due to changing wind directions on approach.
The airfield is most probably situated near water (on the coast).
This is typical for northern hemisphere.
MET.answer: This is typical for southern hemisphere.

MET.question: An omega block is an extreme version of a blocking high. This feature remains stationary __________ period.
If the ELR is greater than both the DALR and SALR, then the atmosphere is __________.
In the ISA, between 11 km and 20 km altitude, the temperature lapse rate is __________.
Identify this pressure feature by its description: An area in which the atmospheric pressure is less than its surroundings.
Liquid water existing at a temperature below its freezing point is said to be __________.
Air density is approximately 50% of MSL at __________ 000 ft and 25% of MSL at __________ 000 ft.

A plain in western Europe with an average elevation of 500 m (1600 ft) above sea level is covered with a uniform AC layer of cloud during the summer months. At what height above the ground is the base of this cloud to be expected?
What is encountered during the summer, over land, in the centre of a cold air drop?
What is the Bora?
choices: An anabatic wind in the Rockies.
Cold katabatic wind over the Adriatic.
Northerly wind blowing from the Mediterranean.
Warm anabatic wind blowing to the Mediterranean.
MET.answer: Cold katabatic wind over the Adriatic.

MET.question: Associate the facility with the service it provides: Forecasts of volcanic ash clouds.
Mountains can affect ice accretion, due to orographic intensification, because:
choices: They form a topographical barrier where high pressure systems with moderate to severe icing conditions may form.
This is often referred to as the Föhn effect.
The air may become polluted by dust from the mountain slopes, creating hygroscopic freezing nuclei.
On the leeward side supercooled water droplets form due to the associated temperature drop.
MET.answer: The air may become polluted by dust from the mountain slopes, creating hygroscopic freezing nuclei.

MET.question: The stages and life cycle of a mid-latitude depression are:
When are the rainy seasons in equatorial Africa?
choices: March to May and August to October
December to February and July to October.
March to May and October to November
April to July and December to February.
MET.answer: March to May and October to November

MET.question: You are flying in the northern hemisphere at 2000 ft over a flat country area. An anticyclone is ahead of you and a depression is behind you. The wind affecting you, will be:
What is the average diameter of a tropical revolving storm in the mature stage?
How many hurricanes form on average per year in the Atlantic?
Which of the following situations favours the formation of heavy thunderstorms?
choices: The passage of a warm front in the morning.
A cold front on the leeward side of a mountain range.
A cold front approaching a mountain range in the evening.
A warm sector moving over a snow-covered ground.
MET.answer: A cold front approaching a mountain range in the evening.

MET.question: The wind speed in a system with curved isobars compared to a system with straight isobars is (other conditions being the same):
Atmospheric __________ is mostly caused by rising or sinking air drawing in air from either side.
Which is true of a secondary depression in the northern hemisphere?
choices: It tends to maintain its position relative to the primary.
It rapidly closes on, and merges with the primary.
It tends to move round the primary in an anticyclonic sense.
It tends to move round the primary in a cyclonic sense.
MET.answer: It tends to move round the primary in a cyclonic sense.

MET.question: What does the term SIGMET signify?
choices: A SIGMET is an actual weather report at an aerodrome and is generally issued at half-hourly intervals.
A SIGMET is a flight forecast, issued by the meteorological station several times daily.
A SIGMET is a warning of dangerous meteorological conditions.
A SIGMET is a brief landing forecast added to the actual weather report.
MET.answer: A SIGMET is a warning of dangerous meteorological conditions.

MET.question: In which part of the world are tropical revolving storms (TRS) most frequent?
choices: Northern Indian Oceans around India, Sri Lanka.
North-West Pacific (for example Japan, Korea, SE Asia).
MET.answer: North-West Pacific (for example Japan, Korea, SE Asia).

MET.question: In the northern hemisphere advection of warm air aloft indicates:
choices: the approach of a warm occlusion.
MET.answer: the approach of a warm occlusion.

MET.question: Generally, cold fronts move __________ than warm fronts.
The location of which jet stream is largely dependent on the position of weather fronts?
__________ lows result from small-scale lows forming downwind of mountain barriers.

Air rising or sinking in the atmosphere encounters barriers which prevent further vertical motion so, vertical motion is translated into horizontal motion. This is common at the bottom of high pressures near the surface and the top of low pressures near the tropopause. This description describe the mechanism which causes __________.
VTSP CNL AD WRNG 2 300100/300300 This message means:
choices: There is an aerodrome warning between 01:00Z and 03:00Z on the 30th of the month.
There are two occasional warnings for a certain weather phenomena.
The aerodrome warning number 2 issued at VTSP is canceled.
The aerodrome VTSP is closed during the mentioned timeframe.
MET.answer: The aerodrome warning number 2 issued at VTSP is canceled.

MET.question: A blocking anticyclone in the northern hemisphere is:
choices: a cold anticyclone, situated over Scandinavia and steering depressions.
a cold anticyclone, situated between 50°N and 70°N and steering depressions.
a quasi-stationary, cold anticyclone, situated between 50°N and 70°N.
a quasi-stationary, warm anticyclone, situated between 50°N and 70°N.
MET.answer: a quasi-stationary, warm anticyclone, situated between 50°N and 70°N.

MET.question: They prepare global sets of gridded forecasts for flight planning (upper wind, temperature, humidity) and also produce gridded datasets for specific FLs showing the temperature of the tropopause, the direction and speed of the maximum wind, cumulonimbus clouds, icing and turbulence. This is a function of __________.
Continental tracks __________ the relative and absolute humidity of an air mass.
What types of cloud will you see flying at FL 50 towards a warm front?
choices: At some 500 km from the front, groups of CB, later at some 250 km thickening AS.
At some 500 km AS, later CS and at some 80 km before the front CB.
At some 800 km CS, later AS, and at some 300 km NS until the front.
Mainly clear skies. At some 100 km from the front NS begins.
MET.answer: At some 800 km CS, later AS, and at some 300 km NS until the front.

MET.question: What are the meanings of the meteorological abbreviations SQ, BR, MIFG and SG respectively?
choices: Sudden increase in wind speed lasting for at least one minute / mist / shallow fog / snowgrains.
Short wind gust / fog / shallow fog / snowgrains.
Short wind gust / mist / shallow fog / polar snow.
Sudden strong increase in wind speed lasting for at least one minute / haze / patches of fog / snowgrains.
MET.answer: Sudden increase in wind speed lasting for at least one minute / mist / shallow fog / snowgrains.

MET.question: A SIGMET message concerning a tropical cyclone begins with a 2-letter identifier code group:
On which coast of North America, is the danger of tropical revolving storms the greatest?
In Europe, warm occlusions are more common in __________; cold occlusions are more common in __________.

A continuous broadcast of arrival or departure information for busy airports, preceded by an identification letter. Includes such information as runway in use, surface wind, RVR, present weather, significant cloud and type of approach expected. This is a description of a service called __________.
The whole polar front moves in the same direction as, and parallel to, the isobars in the __________ at a speed determined by the geostrophic interval of the __________ isobars.
Associate the facility with the service it provides: Provides SIGMETs and AIRMETs.
Subsidence tends to produce __________ pressure gradients with little weather.
Non-frontal low-pressure areas with weak circulation that occur due to intense heating over the continents in the subtropics during the warm season. This is a description of a __________ low.
What is the typical position of ITCZ in July?
choices: Over West Africa at 25° N and stretches up to the north of the Arabian sea.

MET.question: Although the large-scale structure of atmospheric circulation varies from year to year (e.g. El Nino/La Nina events), the basic structure remains fairly constant because it is determined by:
choices: the Earth's rotation rate, the passage of air from high to low pressure, and the unequal heating of land and sea.
the permanent transport of heat from the equator to higher latitudes by ocean currents such as the Gulf Stream.
varying solar influx, which is compensated by the specific heat capacity of the continents and seas.
the Coriolis force acting on the atmosphere and the constant temperature profiles over the oceans.
MET.answer: the Earth's rotation rate, the passage of air from high to low pressure, and the unequal heating of land and sea.

MET.question: Associate the met product and its description: Weather report which supplements routine reports when significant improvements or deteriorations occur.
Convergence tends to __________ the creation of active weather.
At the passing of a warm front, the wind __________.
Where is a squall line most likely to be expected?
choices: In front of a cold occlusion at higher levels.
At the surface position of a warm front.
In front of an active cold front.
MET.answer: In front of an active cold front.

MET.question: Associate the met product and its description: Met actuals report giving routine weather reports.
On a significant weather chart you notice a surface weather front with an arrow labelled with the number 5 pointing outward perpendicular from the front. This would indicate:

An _____ is a report from an aircraft in flight given in either of 2 standard formats: Routine aircraft observations given during en-route and climb-out phases of the flight; generally only requested from aircraft with a data link capability. Special and other non-routine aircraft observations during any phase of the flight.
Most mid-latitude depressions move from __________ to __________ in __________.
Both types of AIREP can be transmitted by datalink or voicecom __________.
Polar lows are caused by very cold air from ice shelves or very cold land masses blowing over the relatively warmer sea. This produces __________ atmospheric conditions.
If during the last 10 minutes preceding the issuance of a METAR the wind velocity deviates more than 10 kt from mean value obtained during the same period of time, this will be indicated as:
In an occluded front, the warm sector air is __________.
choices: squeezed between the warm and cold fronts

MET.question: At the approach of a warm front (northern hemisphere) the wind direction changes from the surface up to the tropopause. The effect of this change is that the wind
choices: backs in the friction layer and veers above the friction layer.
veers in the friction layer and veers above the friction layer.
veers in the friction layer and backs above the friction layer.
backs in the friction layer and backs above the friction layer.
MET.answer: veers in the friction layer and veers above the friction layer.

MET.question: The approximate inclined plane of a warm front is:
Air masses that travel over colder to warmer locations are heated from below, this __________ the ELR and __________ stability.
Tracking clouds, or areas of water vapour across consecutive satellite images, can reveal __________.

Which option correctly places, in a chronological order, the four stages of a mid-latitude depression life cycle? The stages are named and described as follows: Occlusion: the cold front has caught up with the warm front, the warm air has been partially lifted up. Developed: fronts are well defined, there is a pronounced warm sector. Cyclogenesis: a disturbance and fall in pressure causes cyclonic circulation. Frontolysis: all the warm air has been lifted up.
How often shall the information produced by an airfield windshear alert system be updated?
The 500 hPa contour chart is equivalent to:

The mass of air in the column reduces because air leaves more quickly at high level than it can enter at the surface. Net loss of mass means lower pressure. This is a description of high level __________.
Associate the met product and its description: An area forecast for low altitude intended for GA aircraft.
Where are easterly waves found?
choices: On the poleward side of the subtropical high pressure belt.
Between subtropical high pressure cells and ITCZ.
In the region of the subtropical jet stream.
MET.answer: Between subtropical high pressure cells and ITCZ.

MET.question: Between which latitudes are you most likely to find the region of travelling polar front depressions during summer?
What are the typical bases of 'ALTO' type clouds in mid-latitudes?
A layer of stratus is most likely to be dispersed by:
choices: The release of latent heat due to precipitation.
Insolation resulting in the lifting of the condensation level.
Absorption of long waved solar radiation in the stratus layer.
MET.answer: Insolation resulting in the lifting of the condensation level.

MET.question: Associate the type of precipitation with the most appropriate description. Transparent or partly or completely opaque pieces of ice with a diameter 5 mm to 50 mm.
The Bora is a type of __________ wind.
__________ is a suspension of very small, usually microscopic water drops (liquid or solid) in the air, reducing visibility at the surface to between 1000 m and 5000 m.
Jet streams have a core speed of at least __________ kt, are typically about 2000 NM long and about __________ NM wide.
Which of the following choices lists only main cloud genera that are mostly the clue for an unstable thermal stratification in the atmosphere?
The main factor which contributes to the formation of very low clouds ahead of a warm front is the:
choices: reduction of outgoing radiation due to clouds.
warm air moving over a cold surface.
saturation of the warm air by rain falling into it and evaporating.
saturation of the cold air by rain falling into it and evaporating.
MET.answer: saturation of the cold air by rain falling into it and evaporating.

MET.question: Assign the description to an icing intensity category: The rate of accumulation is such that even short encounters become potentially hazardous.
Associated the type of wind with the appropriate description: During the night, cooling surface air flows downslope.
In which of these temperature bands is ice most likely to form on the aircraft structure?
A strong difference in wind speed or direction over a relatively short distance is known as __________.
Which of the following factors have the greatest effect on the formation of the various types of ice on an aircraft?
choices: Aircraft speed and size of cloud droplets.
Aircraft speed and curvature of the aerofoil.

MET.question: Associate the type of precipitation with the most appropriate description. White, opaque, approximately round ice particles. Often falling with snow, near 0 °C. Normal diameter is 2 mm to 5 mm.
The most common hazards that thunderstorms pose to aviation include:
choices: all of the answers described are correct.
MET.answer: all of the answers described are correct.

MET.question: Which of the following cloud types is found at high levels?
If a SCWD slowly freezes after contact with an airframe it usually creates __________ ice.
Assign the correct description to the type of wind: Occurs along the valleys of coastlines east of the Adriatic sea.
A permanent, persistent jet stream created by the temperature difference between the Hadley and Ferrel cells and found between 25° (winter) to 40° (summer) Is a description of the __________.
The fastest jet stream is the __________.
Coalescence describes the process in which:
choices: Small particles of ice come together to form large clumps of hail.
Falling water droplets in relatively warm clouds (above 0°C) come together and grow until they are massive enough to fall as rain.
Falling water droplets in very cold clouds (colder than -15°C) form large droplets of supercooled rain.
Falling ice particles in relatively warm clouds (above 0°C) descend and melt into large water droplets, eventually falling as rain.
MET.answer: Falling water droplets in relatively warm clouds (above 0°C) come together and grow until they are massive enough to fall as rain.

MET.question: When reporting vertical visibility at a German aerodrome, the code group VV004 means:
Orographic storms form __________.
choices: as a result of sea breezes

MET.question: The seasonal jet stream found only in the northern hemisphere at about 60°N in the arctic ocean is called the __________ jet stream.
In the US, in __________ very large tornadoes can develop, with much stronger winds and a diameter of about 150 metres or more.
The threat of negative windshear is a sudden __________ in airspeed.
Below about __________°C SCWD are rarely, if ever, encountered.

A large, severe storm characterised with a mesocyclone/rotating updraft. The powerful rotating updraft allows the storm to live longer and become more ‘organised’ than normal single cell or multi-cell thunderstorms. They commonly produce tornadoes, large hail and destructive winds. This is a description of __________.
Assign the correct description to the type of wind: Forms when an area of high-pressure sits over the cold central European land mass while low-pressure develops over the warmer sea.
Overland, in the friction layer, the surface wind speed is about __________% of the geostrophic wind speed.

It forms when high pressure systems stop the vertical motion of air, trapping pollutants in the lower layers. It requires a good supply of particles from dust, sand and pollution and relatively stable atmospheric conditions. This is a description of the formation of __________.

Associate the definition and defined term: The greatest horizontal distance at which a black object near the ground can be seen against a bright background. Or, the greatest distance at which a light of 1000 candelas can be seen against an unlit background.
Turbulent mixing promotes cloud formation, usually __________ the turbulent inversion.
Fog comprising SCWD is known as __________ fog.

Centrifugal force reduces the wind speed around a low and increases the speed around a high, for the same isobar spacing when compared to the geostrophic wind. This is a description of the creation of the __________ wind.
The impact of __________ droplets falling on a water surface is imperceptible. Visibility is inversely related to both the intensity of precipitation and the number of droplets.
If the wings of an aircraft are contaminated with ice, one can expect the aircraft to have:
choices: Degraded stall characteristics but a better gust response due to an improved roll behaviour.
Nearly unchanged stall characteristics as the ice will mostly form on the thickest and thus the innermost part of the wing.
Degraded stall characteristics and problems with roll manoeuvres.
A degraded response in the roll, pitch and yaw axes but improved stall characteristics (due to the increased wing area).
MET.answer: Degraded stall characteristics and problems with roll manoeuvres.

MET.question: Which of the following scenarios will most likely produce advection fog?
choices: A mild moist airstream flowing over colder surfaces with a wind in excess of 30 kt.
A light breeze blowing colder air out to sea.
Morning in autumn with freezing temperature over land but still a couple degrees above freezing over sea, with a slight wind from sea to land.
Warm moist air settling over a warmer surface under no-wind conditions.
MET.answer: Morning in autumn with freezing temperature over land but still a couple degrees above freezing over sea, with a slight wind from sea to land.

MET.question: Assign the description to an icing intensity category: The rate of accumulation can overwhelm de-icing/anti-icing systems. Immediate exit from the condition is necessary or divert and land asap.
Associated the type of wind with the appropriate description: During the day, warm, less dense air at the surface flows upslope.
Which of these are examples of a stable cloud?
Which precipitation type generally has the greatest impact on visibility?

A build-up of static electricity due to collisions with particles can cause a blueish coloured light which is often seen flickering around the edges and over the surfaces of the windscreen. This is known as:
Associate the cloud type with the severity of icing most likely to be encountered: Cu.
Associate the cloud type with the severity of icing likely to be encountered: St.
Which statement is true about the relationship between the water content of different types of winter precipitation and the associated visibility?
choices: light snow compared to heavy snow causes a lower visibility due to the compact nature of the small snowflakes associated with light snow.
ice pellets and freezing rain, because they have a bigger structure, obscure more than snowflakes.
hail from thunderstorms obscures more than snowflakes due to the greater whiteness (the property of being white in colour) of hail.
snowflakes, due to their open structure, obscure more than water droplets.
MET.answer: snowflakes, due to their open structure, obscure more than water droplets.

MET.question: Associate the type of wind with the appropriate description: Well developed winds create flow from the tops of mountains, down the valleys and onto the plains. They peak at dawn.
Which of the following statements about lightning and lightning strikes is correct?
choices: Spherical lightning often penetrate into aircraft.
Lightning strikes always cause heavy damage.
The aircraft is temporarily part of the lightning trajectory.
Compasses and electronics are always affected.
MET.answer: The aircraft is temporarily part of the lightning trajectory.

MET.question: Small SCWD are commonly associated with ambient temperatures between -15°C and __________°C.
When air directly in contact with a cold surface cools and condenses into cloud, this mechanism is known as __________ cooling.
Clouds dissipate by the process of __________.
When established on the final approach path, and after passing below a cloud associated with a microburst, an aircraft can experience:
How high can a Cumulonimbus (CB) cloud be?
An __________ is a line on a chart connecting points of equal height and equal barometric pressure.
What is drizzle?
choices: Water droplets of more than 0.5 mm in diameter.
Precipitation which forms mostly in CB and CU clouds.
Typical precipitation, when NS clouds are present.
Small water droplets of 0.2 to 0.5 mm in diameter.
MET.answer: Small water droplets of 0.2 to 0.5 mm in diameter.

MET.question: The approximate ratio of jet stream length to their width is __________:1.
A complex of thunderstorms that becomes organised on a scale larger than individual thunderstorms, but smaller than extratropical cyclones, is called a _____.
Atmospheric air is normally __________ charged.
Why are there no or very few clouds, when a high pressure area is present?
choices: Warm air moves over a cold surface, thus, generating stability.
The air is warmed from below.
Because of rising air, cooling adiabatically at the saturated adiabatic lapse rate.
Because of subsiding air, subject to adiabatic heating.
MET.answer: Because of subsiding air, subject to adiabatic heating.

MET.question: Hill fog is formed by __________ lifting of air.
A thin layer of hard frost on the upper surfaces of the wings before flight:
choices: Isn't dangerous because the ice layer is very thin.
Isn't dangerous because its likely to blow off during the take-off roll.
Is often found on aircraft left out overnight, but is usually confined to surfaces in contact with wing fuel.
Is potentially very dangerous and must be removed before flight.
MET.answer: Is potentially very dangerous and must be removed before flight.

MET.question: The RVR is usually __________ the reported ground or met visibility.
Which statement corresponds to the definition of severe turbulence?
choices: Aircraft may be out of control for short periods, occupants are forced violently against seat belts, loose objects are tossed about.
Aircraft gets out of control and crashes.
Aircraft will be damaged and an emergency landing will be absolutely necessary.
Difficulty in walking, occupants feel strain against seat belts, loose objects move about.
MET.answer: Aircraft may be out of control for short periods, occupants are forced violently against seat belts, loose objects are tossed about.

MET.question: Fog or mist forms when the surface air becomes __________. Further cooling causes condensation/sublimation.
Mountain waves form when winds blow at approximately __________ relative to the mountain axis.
Which 1 of these is NOT a recognised process for cloud formation?
choices: Adiabatic cooling (rising air expands and cools).
Mechanical processes (air is forced up by turbulence, mountains or fronts and cools).
Advection (warm, moist air moves over a cooler surface and cools).
Radiative cooling (surface layers cool at night through net loss of energy)
Sublimation (air sublimates moisture from melting ice crystals and cools).
MET.answer: Sublimation (air sublimates moisture from melting ice crystals and cools).

MET.question: A westerly wind is one which flows __________ the west.
What is the meaning of the abbreviation 'LLWAS'?
choices: A low level warning system for the detection of thunderstorms.
A North American system for detection and warning provision of marked temperature inversions.
A North American system for detection and warning provision of low level windshear.
A North American radar network for the detection of tornadoes.
MET.answer: A North American system for detection and warning provision of low level windshear.

MET.question: Associate the cloud type with the severity of icing likely to be encountered: As.
Which of the following layers of fog above land is coded as MIFG?
choices: A layer less than 2 m above ground level.
A layer up to 3 m above ground level.
MET.answer: A layer less than 2 m above ground level.

MET.question: Which of the following conditions are most favourable to the formation of mountain waves?
choices: Moist unstable air at mountain top and wind of less than 5 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.
Unstable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least 20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge.
Either stable or unstable air at mountain top and a wind of at least 30 knots blowing parallel to the mountain ridge.
Stable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least 20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge
MET.answer: Stable air at mountain top altitude and a wind at least 20 knots blowing across the mountain ridge

MET.question: The largest SCWD are most likely to be found in the lower levels of __________ clouds. SCWD __________ encountered outside of cloud.
Assign the correct description to the type of wind: Is channelled along the Rhone valley- a natural venturi amplifying the wind speed.
Altostratus clouds are classified as:
Nocturnal jets, also known as boundary layer jets, are a type of __________ jet stream.
Drizzle is most commonly associated with clouds that have __________ updrafts.

Which of the following statements is/are correct? 1. In a mixed cloud the ice crystals grow at the expense of supercooled water droplets. 2. In the mid-latitudes heavy rain showers are only formed by the coalescence process.
Thin wings are __________ prone to icing than thick wings.
An air mass containing St and Sc clouds is cooling as it is lifted over high ground. Which of the following will happen to the concentration of water droplets or ice particles?
choices: The concentration will remain the same, and their sizes will increase.
The concentration will remain the same.

MET.question: For mountain waves to form the atmosphere must be __________.
A rapid, temporary, localised increase in wind speed is called a __________.
Associate the cloud type with the severity of icing likely to be encountered: Sc.
Assign the correct description to the type of wind: Is driven by high-pressure over north-western Europe and low pressure in the Mediterranean.
Which one of the following statements concerning the formation of aircraft icing is most correct?
choices: A cloud consisting of both supercooled water droplets and ice crystals produces aircraft icing.
Greatest risk of icing conditions is experienced in cirrus clouds.
Probability of icing increases when dry snow starts to fall from a cloud.
Greatest risk of icing when cloud temperature decreases well below minus 12°C.
MET.answer: A cloud consisting of both supercooled water droplets and ice crystals produces aircraft icing.

MET.question: The RVR stop-end measurement is normally taken about __________m from the end of the runway.
Associate the cloud type with the severity of icing likely to be encountered: Ns (near its base).
Visible ice crystals at your flight level indicate a __________ risk of clear ice.
During the night the land cools much more rapidly than the sea. The warmer air over the sea rises, drawing air off the land. This describes:
In which of the following situations can freezing rain be encountered?
choices: Behind a warm front in the summer.
Ahead of a warm front in the winter.
Ahead of a cold front in the summer.
Ahead of a warm front in any conditions.
MET.answer: Ahead of a warm front in the winter.

MET.question: In which environment is aircraft structural ice most likely to have the highest rate of accretion?
The morning following a clear, calm night when the temperature has dropped to the dew point, is likely to produce:

Is common when cold continental air passes over the comparatively warmer ocean in winter in the higher latitudes. Occurs over inland seas, lakes and rivers in winter. Dissipates when the source air becomes warmer. This is a description of __________.
Associate the definition and defined term: The visibility at the surface near a runway in the direction of landing.
Medium clouds usually have a base above __________ and below __________ 000 ft.
Associate the cloud type with the severity of icing likely to be encountered: Ci, Cc, Cs.
What kind of turbulence is dependent on the sun's radiation and therefore follows a pronounced diurnal pattern?
The Earth is normally __________ charged.
Associate the definition and defined term: The greatest visibility value which is reached within at least half the horizon circle or at least half of the surface of the aerodrome.
From what type of cloud does drizzle fall?
What is signified if an occlusion is described as 'cold'?
choices: It derives from a polar depression.
The air ahead of the associated warm front is colder than the air behind the associated cold front.
The air ahead of the associated warm front is less cold than the air behind the associated cold front.
The air mass is less cold than ISA.
MET.answer: The air ahead of the associated warm front is less cold than the air behind the associated cold front.

MET.question: In what type of cloud would you likely encounter the most severe icing and turbulence?
A semi-permanent, disjointed sinuous jet stream found between 40°N and 65°N which is stronger and higher in winter is a description of the __________ __________ jet stream.
Which of the following statements about airframe icing is/are correct?
choices: The worst airframe icing results from small supercooled water droplets freezing instantly on contact with the airframe.
Rime ice is formed by slow-freezing supercooled water droplets.
Airframe icing occurs when supercooled water droplets come into contact with a sub-zero airframe.
The severest airframe icing occurs when an airframe comes into contact with ice crystals at high altitude.
MET.answer: Airframe icing occurs when supercooled water droplets come into contact with a sub-zero airframe.

MET.question: Associate the type of precipitation with the most appropriate description. Very small, opaque, white particles of ice which fall from stratiform clouds. Flat or elongated. Diameter < 1 mm.
Mountain waves may be visible due to the presence of __________ cloud and/or rotor cloud.
__________ are small scale downbursts of 2-5 minutes and less than 4 km. The windspeed can be up to 130 kt.

Warm moist air passes over a cooler surface cooling its low layers below its dew point. The surface temperature must be below the dew point of the warmer air. This describes the creation of __________ fog.
During which stage of thunderstorm development are rotor winds characterised by roll clouds most likely to occur?
Over the sea, the values for direction and speed are__________° and __________% respectively.
Cloud to ground lightning delivers __________ charges from the air to the ground.
How far and how high up can mountain waves reach originating from the Rocky Mountains (USA)?
choices: By the dimensions of the affecting mountain.
Up to the tropopause and 600 NM downwind.
Up to the tropopause and horizontally as long as there are mountains.
Up to 36 000 ft and approximately 300 NM downwind.
MET.answer: Up to the tropopause and 600 NM downwind.

MET.question: Define a 'LOW'
choices: An area with lower pressure than that of the horizontal environments.
MET.answer: An area with lower pressure than that of the horizontal environments.

MET.question: Assign the appropriate type of stability to the description of event: A strong atmospheric inversion.
The pressure measuring device which uses a flexible, partially evacuated metal capsule, is called an __________ barometer.
When flying in warm air (warmer than standard atmosphere), indicated altitude is:
choices: The same as the true altitude.

MET.question: Considering the North Atlantic area north of 60°N during the winter, the mean height of the Tropopause is approximately:
The primary means of transferring energy vertically through the atmosphere is __________.
3 principal types of high pressure zones occur at mid-latitudes:
choices: The cold temporary anticyclone, the warm high and the cold high.
The cold temporary cyclone, the warm high and the cold high.
Subsidence, convergence and cold highs over the seas.
MET.answer: The cold temporary anticyclone, the warm high and the cold high.

MET.question: In a mountain-valley wind circulation, the mountain wind blows:
choices: During the day down from the mountains.
At night down from the mountains.
During the day up from the valley.
At night up from the valley.
MET.answer: At night down from the mountains.

MET.question: The Earth's surface cools at night because:
choices: The earth continues to radiate heat so there is a net loss of energy.
The atmospheric air is colder at night because there is no solar radiation.
MET.answer: The earth continues to radiate heat so there is a net loss of energy.

MET.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the temperature at the tropopause?
choices: It is higher in equatorial regions than in polar regions.
Tropopause temperature is independent of latitude.
It is higher in polar regions than in equatorial regions.
It is highest in middle latitudes.
MET.answer: It is higher in polar regions than in equatorial regions.

MET.question: The US still uses the imperial unit __________ .
Although the large-scale structure of atmospheric circulation varies from year to year (e.g. El Nio/La Nia events), the basic structure remains fairly constant because it is determined by:
choices: The permanent transport of heat from the equator to higher latitudes by ocean currents such as the Gulf Stream.
The Earth's rotation rate, the passage of air from high to low pressure, and the unequal heating of land and sea.
Varying solar influx, which is compensated by the specific heat capacity of the continents and seas.
The Coriolis force acting on the atmosphere and the constant temperature profiles over the oceans.
MET.answer: The Earth's rotation rate, the passage of air from high to low pressure, and the unequal heating of land and sea.

MET.question: In a land and sea breeze circulation the land breeze blows:
choices: During the night and is weaker than the sea breeze.
During the day and is weaker than the sea breeze.
During the night and is stronger than the sea breeze.
During the day and is stronger than the sea breeze.
MET.answer: During the night and is weaker than the sea breeze.

MET.question: With regard to temperature, which of the following is correct for the polar climates?
choices: The mean temperature of all months is below plus 10°C.
The mean temperature of all months is below minus 10°C.
The mean temperature of all months is above 0°C, but temperatures as high as plus 10°C will never be reached.
The mean temperature of the warmest month is 10°C or above, and of the coldest month below minus 3°C.
MET.answer: The mean temperature of all months is below plus 10°C.

MET.question: The wind which results from warming on the side of a mountain valley is known as:
An outside air temperature of -35 °C is measured while cruising at FL200. What is the temperature deviation from the ISA at this level?
Cold air compacts isobaric pressure levels. The true distance between any given flight level and the surface __________.
A parcel of air has been cooled to the point where its relative humidity is 100%, further cooling will result in __________.

A battery-powered telemetry instrument carried into the atmosphere by a weather balloon which measures various atmospheric parameters and transmits them by radio to a ground receiver is called a __________.
Subsiding air warms at the DALR of 3°C per 1000 ft which is __________ than the average ELR.
A flight level is a __________ altitude expressed in hundreds of feet.
In the proximity of the polar jet stream, where do wind shear and clear air turbulence (CAT) occur?
choices: The largest vertical wind shears are found at the jet stream core.
CAT is generated by horizontal wind shear only.
In units of kt/1000 ft, horizontal wind shears near the jet stream are larger than vertical wind shears.
Most CAT areas are found on the cyclonic side of the jet stream.
MET.answer: Most CAT areas are found on the cyclonic side of the jet stream.

MET.question: Which type wind flows down slope becoming warmer and drier?
A percentage figure comparing the amount of water vapour actually present in the air and the maximum amount it can possibly hold is known as the __________; __________.
Identify the type of inversion with the appropriate descriptor: Formed at night when colder, denser air sinks, displacing warmer air aloft.
The wind indicator for a weather observation receives the measured value from an anemometer. Where is this instrument placed?
choices: Close to the station about 2 m above the ground.
On a mast 10 m above the runway.
On a mast 20 m above the runway.
MET.answer: On a mast 10 m above the runway.

MET.question: Which one of the following statements applies to the tropopause?
choices: It is, by definition, a temperature inversion.
It separates the troposphere from the stratosphere.
It indicates a strong temperature lapse rate.
MET.answer: It separates the troposphere from the stratosphere.

MET.question: Assign the appropriate type of stability to the description of event: Cold air advection over a warmer surface.
The primary mechanism for heat transfer within the atmosphere is __________ caused by the horizontal variation in air __________.
Which of these statements about the tropopause are correct or incorrect? 1- In the real atmosphere the tropopause is a continuous surface. 2- The height of the tropopause in the ISA is 11 km.
The horizontal transfer of energy in the atmosphere is called __________.
In warm air the true distance between flight levels __________.
What is correct regarding an anabatic wind? It can be described as a wind that blows:
choices: Upslope caused by instability due the adiabatic heating in a valley.
Downslope due to cold air that slides down a valley.
Upslope due to warming of air in a valley.
MET.answer: Upslope due to warming of air in a valley.

MET.question: Identify the terms from the definition: The phase change from solid ice to water vapour.
Identify the type of inversion with the appropriate descriptor: Common in high pressure areas, where the descending dry air warms faster than the static environmental air.
A line of equal temperature, or a region of constant temperature with height, is called an __________.
Identify this pressure feature by its description: A region where the atmospheric pressure at the surface is greater than its surrounding environment.
Identify the terms from the definition: The phase change of water from liquid to solid.
Which of the following combinations of pressure and temperature is correct in the ICAO standard atmosphere?
In the __________ over SE Asia, the tropopause can be as high as FL 600.
Identify this pressure feature by its description: An extension of a high, characterised by a protrusion of isobars away from the centre of the high.
When a parcel of displaced air has the same lapse rate as the ELR, the atmospheric conditions are __________.
Identify the terms from the definition: The phase change from water vapour to liquid water.
Convergence over a uniform surface is caused by:
choices: Frictional force together with anti - cyclonic curvature of the isobars.
Frictional force together with straight isobars.
Frictional force together with cyclonic curvature of the isobars.
MET.answer: Frictional force together with cyclonic curvature of the isobars.

MET.question: A stark temperature change between the major air masses causes the tropopause to change height rapidly. This mainly happens between the Hadley, Ferrel and Polar __________ and is known as a __________.
What is the temperature at 20 000 ft in the ICAO Standard Atmosphere?
Conditions most favourable for the formation of a low-level frictional turbulence are:
choices: Strong wind, smooth terrain, stable lapse rate.
Light wind, rough terrain, stable lapse rate.
Strong wind, rough terrain, steep lapse rate.
light wind, smooth terrain and a stable lapse rate
MET.answer: Strong wind, rough terrain, steep lapse rate.

MET.question: The primary heat source for the atmosphere is:
choices: Terrestrial radiation from the Earth to the air.
Terrestrial radiation from the air to the Earth.
MET.answer: Terrestrial radiation from the Earth to the air.

MET.question: The vertical position of an aircraft at, or below, the transition altitude is normally expressed as as __________.
Identify the term from its definition: The calculated barometric pressure at MSL, derived by observing the current pressure at an aerodrome and correcting for elevation using ISA.
Identify the type of inversion with the appropriate descriptor: Warm less dense air flows up and over cooler, denser air.

Which of the following instruments can be used for measuring the atmospheric humidity:
1. A hygrometer.
2. A pair of wet and dry thermometers.
3. A psychrometer.
choices: A pair of wet and dry thermometers.

MET.question: A trough line is marked as a black line on low level significant weather charts and surface pressure charts because:
choices: It isn't a sufficiently significant feature to warrant being drawn with isobars.
It signifies an area of abnormally high wind speeds.
It is a useful area for navigation thanks to the relatively calm, clear skies it produces.
It signifies a line of convergence/convective weather which might otherwise not be apparent from the isobar pattern.
MET.answer: It signifies a line of convergence/convective weather which might otherwise not be apparent from the isobar pattern.

MET.question: In the Siberian __________ the tropopause exists at about FL 220.
Unsaturated air compresses and warms when it is forced to __________.
When descending through the transition layer, vertical position is expressed as __________.
In the International Standard Atmosphere the decrease in temperature with height below 11 km is:
When air converges at high level and diverges at the surface:
choices: The mass of air in the column increases because the air can't leave the column as quickly at the bottom as it enters at the top.
The mass of air in the column increases because the volume of air in the column becomes steadily greater.
The mass of air in the column decreases.
MET.answer: The mass of air in the column increases because the air can't leave the column as quickly at the bottom as it enters at the top.

MET.question: Which of the following values corresponds to a SW-wind?
Identify the term from its definition: The barometric pressure at the aerodrome reference point/runway threshold. It is the altimeter setting to obtain height above the reference point/threshold.
Which of the following values corresponds to a NE-wind?
The SI unit of atmospheric pressure used in aviation is the _____.
During the day, as the ambient temperature increases, the relative humidity __________.
__________ anticyclones are large-scale patterns that are nearly stationary and which prevent the normal west to east flow.
__________ is the barometric pressure at an observation point, reduced to MSL using the observed temperature at the surface and assuming an isothermal layer from the point to MSL.
The very lowest part of the atmosphere is in direct contact with the Earth's surface. It changes temperature from day to night by the process of __________.
Which FL corresponds with the 500 hPa pressure level?
Identify the terms from the definition: The phase change from liquid water to water vapour.
Up to which flight level could the effects of mountain waves be expected to be encountered?
Supercooled condensation droplets will probably freeze:
choices: If they come into contact with a cold surface.
MET.answer: If they come into contact with a cold surface.

MET.question: In the troposphere the temperature lapse rate is approximately __________°C per 1000 ft. The average height of the tropopause is about __________ km.
Identify the type of inversion with the appropriate descriptor: Created by turbulent mixing modifying the surface layer lapse rate.
Identify this pressure feature by its description: An extension of a low, characterised by a protrusion of isobars away from the centre of the low.
The wide variation of temperature lapse rates in the troposphere is primarily caused by:
choices: Changes in surface temperature and air mass movement.
The reduction in air density with height.
MET.answer: Changes in surface temperature and air mass movement.

MET.question: An 'ANABATIC' wind is a wind which:
choices: Blows up a hill or mountain mainly during the day.
Blows up a hill or mountain mainly during the night.
Blows down a hill or mountain mainly during the night.
Blows down a hill or mountain mainly during the day.
MET.answer: Blows up a hill or mountain mainly during the day.

MET.question: You are planning an IFR flight eastbound and find that the highest obstacle along the route has an elevation of 5400 ft. The ISA deviation is -20°C and QNH 990. What is the lowest usable flight level on this flight?
Assign the appropriate type of stability to the description of event: Warm air advection over a cooler surface.
Lines of equal (constant) pressure on a pressure map are called __________.
An elongated or extended region of relatively low atmospheric pressure, often associated with fronts is known as an isobaric __________.
High pressure regions on charts can be identified by:
choices: Widely spaced isobars whose values are decreasing with distance from the core.
Isobars marked with light line weights (rather than the heavy line weights used for lows).
Closely spaced isobars whose values are decreasing with distance from the core.
Widely spaced isobars whose values are increasing with distance from the core.
MET.answer: Widely spaced isobars whose values are decreasing with distance from the core.

MET.question: An aircraft flies from London to South France and experiences a strong wind from the left. Which of the following is correct?
The typical height of the vertical area affected by sea breeze in mid-latitudes is approximately:
After climbing though the transition altitude vertical position is expressed as a __________ __________.

It is the early afternoon on a sunny day in summer, and you are flying over the west coast of the Netherlands. If there is a non-frontal environment with a slack pressure gradient, the wind direction at the surface is likely to be:
The 'greenhouse effect' describes how:
choices: Energy is trapped in the atmosphere because of the layer of ozone at the tropopause.
Energy is added to the atmosphere because water vapour, CO₂ and methane absorb long wave terrestrial radiation.
Energy is added to the atmosphere because water vapour, CO₂ and methane allow more solar radiation to penetrate the atmosphere.
Energy is added to the atmosphere because water vapour, CO₂ and methane absorb long wave solar radiation.
MET.answer: Energy is added to the atmosphere because water vapour, CO₂ and methane absorb long wave terrestrial radiation.

MET.question: Identify the correct statement relating density and moisture.
choices: The density of moist air is greater than the density of dry air because water is heavier than air.
The density of moist air is less than the density of dry air because water vapour has a lower mass than oxygen and nitrogen.
The density of air doesn't depend on its moisture content, it depends only on its temperature.
In humid air, the oxygen and nitrogen displace the water vapour.
MET.answer: The density of moist air is less than the density of dry air because water vapour has a lower mass than oxygen and nitrogen.

MET.question: The troposphere is the:
choices: Boundary between the mesosphere and thermosphere.
Boundary between the stratosphere and the mesosphere.
Part of the atmosphere below the tropopause.
Part of the atmosphere above the stratosphere.
MET.answer: Part of the atmosphere below the tropopause.

MET.question: What will the altimeter be indicating if the aircraft’s true altitude is 10 000 ft when the OAT is -30°C at a pressure altitude of 10 000 ft?
In which of the following circumstances would the formation of a low-level jet stream in the evening be most likely?
choices: An inflow of cold air over land or strong radiation cooling in the evening can lead to an inversion; at or just below the top of the inversion a low-level jet stream can form.
The inflow of air into the base of a CB or TS at night can result, occasionally, in the concentration of the wind near the cold surface, which leads to the formation of a low-level jet stream.
When warm air in the evening moves into the friction layer near the surface, a low-level jet stream can sometimes form, within or above the top of the layer.
When the airflow near the surface is forced against a mass of cold air ahead of a warm front at night, the low-level wind increases and can occasionally form a low-level jet stream.
MET.answer: An inflow of cold air over land or strong radiation cooling in the evening can lead to an inversion; at or just below the top of the inversion a low-level jet stream can form.

MET.question: Identify the term from its definition: The vertical distance above mean sea level.
When a parcel of air contains the maximum amount of water vapour that is possible to hold at the current temperature and pressure (RH 100%) the air is said to be __________.
The atmosphere comprises 78% __________, 21% __________ and 1% of other gases.
Sea level __________ pressure is the result of the weight force of the mass of the atmosphere bearing down on it.
Given:  Pressure altitude: 3000 ft  indicated altitude: 2500 ft  Temperature : ISA +21°C What is the true altitude?
Which of the following is a valid explanation for the lack of visible weather in the stratosphere?
choices: The complete absence of water vapour in the stratosphere means that weather can't form.
Very strong winds at the tropopause (jet streams) prevent clouds from rising higher.
The relatively hot air of the stratosphere (heated by insolation) traps the relatively cold air of the troposphere.
The isothermic or inversion conditions in the stratosphere create a physical barrier to further vertical development of cloud.
MET.answer: The isothermic or inversion conditions in the stratosphere create a physical barrier to further vertical development of cloud.

MET.question: The region of the atmosphere which is normally stable and has few clouds is known as the:
In frontal thunderstorms storms __________ are normally high and continuous along the frontal surface.
If a SCWD instantly freezes on contact with the airframe, it usually forms __________ ice.
What can a pilot do to avoid Ice Crystal Icing?
choices: Avoid CB on the downwind side and stay above the tropopause.
Avoid CB on the upwind side and stay below the tropopause.
Avoid CB on the upwind side and stay above the tropopause.
Avoid CB on the downwind side and stay below the tropopause.
MET.answer: Avoid CB on the upwind side and stay above the tropopause.

MET.question: Over the sea, the values for direction and speed are __________° and __________% respectively.
Associate the cloud type with the severity of icing likely to be encountered: Ac.
The Bergeron-Findeisen theory:
choices: Explains the formation of hailstones in Cumulus clouds.
Explains the formation and growth of snowflakes.
Explains the formation of raindrops in cloud where the temperature is above freezing.
Presumes that at high levels in a cloud, some water droplets turn to ice and grow by sublimation.
MET.answer: Presumes that at high levels in a cloud, some water droplets turn to ice and grow by sublimation.

MET.question: The abbreviation for this cloud is __________. (Stratus)

The temperature is cold enough to allow tiny ice crystals to form around microscopic bits of dirt. These tiny ice crystals then stick together when they collide, constantly increasing in size and mass. This is a description of the mechanism for creating __________.
Moderate turbulence can be expected in:
Within a short interval, several flight crews report that they have experienced strong clear air turbulence in a certain airspace. What is the consequence of these reports?
choices: The airspace in question, will be temporarily closed.
The responsible aviation weather office will issue a SPECI.
The responsible aviation weather office will issue a storm warning.
The responsible aviation weather office will issue a SIGMET.
MET.answer: The responsible aviation weather office will issue a SIGMET.

MET.question: The most severe airframe icing is associated with SCWD __________ because, on impact with an airframe, the rate of freezing of the SCWD is __________ by the release of latent heat.

The saturated air lying immediately above the warm moist surface almost instantly condenses when it comes into contact with the colder air. A marked inversion is required and temperatures are often close to zero. This describes the formation of __________.
The RVR stop-end measurement is normally taken about __________ m from the end of the runway.
Overland, in the friction layer, the difference in direction between the surface wind and the geostrophic wind is about __________°.
After a prolonged VMC descent in very cold air, you penetrate a humid air mass. What type of icing will you encounter?
A semi-permanent, disjointed sinuous jet stream found between 40°N and 65°N which is stronger and higher in winter is a description of the __________ jet stream.
The typical duration of the mature stage of a thunderstorm is about __________ to __________ minutes.
The arctic front jet stream occurs from about 20 000 to __________ ft.
Wind direction is given in degrees relative to North in __________ most meteorological reports and North in __________ reports broadcast by ATC.
The ICAO Standard Atmosphere assumes that temperature will reduce at the rate of:
choices: 2°C per 1000 ft up to 36 090 ft and will then rise at 0.3 °C per 1000 ft up to 65 617 ft then it will remain constant.
2°C per 1000 ft up to 36 090 ft and will then decrease at 0.3 °C per 1000 ft up to 65 617 ft.
2°C per 1000 ft up to 65 617 ft after which it will remain constant to 104 987 ft.
2°C per 1000 ft up to 36 090 ft after which it remains constant to 65 617 ft.
MET.answer: 2°C per 1000 ft up to 36 090 ft after which it remains constant to 65 617 ft.

MET.question: Convective activity over land in mid-latitudes is greatest in:
choices: Winter during the night and early morning.
Summer during the night and early morning.

MET.question: How does the height of the tropopause normally vary with latitude in the northern hemisphere?
choices: It decreases from south to north.
It remains constant from north to south.
It increases from south to north.
It remains constant throughout the year.
MET.answer: It decreases from south to north.

MET.question: Define a 'LOW'.
choices: An area with lower pressure than that of the horizontal environments.
MET.answer: An area with lower pressure than that of the horizontal environments.

MET.question: The QFF at an airfield located 400 metres above sea level is 1016 hPa. The air temperature is 10 °C higher than a standard atmosphere. What is the QNH?
choices: It is not possible to give a definitive answer.

MET.question: Up to a height of about 20 km, 1 of the 2 principal layers in the atmosphere is the __________ where temperature __________ with height.

choices: An area with higher pressure than that of the horizontal environments.
MET.answer: An area with higher pressure than that of the horizontal environments.

MET.question: When a rain shower approaches and passes an airfield, the following will happen:
choices: The temperature rises and dew point drops.
The temperature drops and dew point rises.
The temperature remains unchanged and dew point drops.
The temperature rises and dew point remains unchanged.
MET.answer: The temperature drops and dew point rises.

MET.question: Associate the met product and its description: A briefing service for low level GA aircraft < FL 120.
Most mid-latitude depressions move from __________ in __________.
What is the abbreviation used in METAR and TAF, when ice particles with a diameter of 4 mm have been observed?

choices: boundary between polar and tropical air masses.
boundary between arctic and polar air masses.
constant frontal activity situated at about 80 degrees north and south.
boundary between arctic and tropical air masses.
MET.answer: boundary between polar and tropical air masses.

MET.question: At the __________ surface and aloft __________ produces areas of low pressure.
You intend to carry out a VFR flight over the Alps, on a fine and hot summer day. What is the best time of day to conduct this flight?
Associate the met product and its description: Provides a forecast for an aerodrome, usually covering a period of 9, 24 or 30 hours.
Which weather phenomena are typical for the northern side of the Alps with strong winds from the south (Foehn)?
choices: Decrease in temperature, moderate to severe icing.

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a cold front?
choices: The area of strongest winds around the eye of a storm
The leading edge of a colder air mass advancing, forcing warmer air to rise
A boundary where warm air pushes under cold air, lifting it up
A zone of calm, stable weather following a low-pressure system
MET KAHOOT.answer: The leading edge of a colder air mass advancing, forcing warmer air to rise

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a ridge?
choices: A narrow zone of strong temperature gradient between two air masses
The boundary between two converging airflows near the surface
An elongated area of high pressure extending outward from a high
The rising branch of a Hadley cell along the equator
MET KAHOOT.answer: An elongated area of high pressure extending outward from a high

MET KAHOOT.question: What kind of weather can we expect in a cold air drop?
choices: Clear skies, calm winds, and warming temperatures
Showers, thunderstorms, and generally unstable conditions
Continuous, steady precipitation with layered clouds
Dense fog formation under a strong inversion
MET KAHOOT.answer: Showers, thunderstorms, and generally unstable conditions

MET KAHOOT.question: What is ISA?
choices: International Standard Atmosphere, "reference" model of the atmosphere
International Synoptic Association for weather forecasts
A scale used to classify turbulence strength
MET KAHOOT.answer: International Standard Atmosphere, "reference" model of the atmosphere

MET KAHOOT.question: The temperature at 4000 ft is measured to be 7C, what is the ISA deviation?
MET KAHOOT.answer: 0 C

MET KAHOOT.question: FU indicates what kind of weather phenomenon?
MET KAHOOT.answer: Smoke

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a land breeze?
choices: Daytime wind blowing from sea to land
Wind blowing from land to sea
Wind shift caused by passing cold front
MET KAHOOT.answer: Wind blowing from land to sea

MET KAHOOT.question: The ISA deviation at 39000ft is +12 C, what is the OAT?
What are the three global circulatory cells?
MET KAHOOT.answer: Hadley, Ferrel, Polar

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a SIGMET?
choices: A notice about airport closures and runway conditions
A warning of significant weather affecting aircraft safety
A routine forecast of surface pressure and winds
A chart showing isobars and frontal positions
MET KAHOOT.answer: A warning of significant weather affecting aircraft safety

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a travelling frontal depression?
choices: A stationary zone of weak high pressure
A low-pressure system, generally moving with warm & cold fronts
A tropical storm forming near the equator
A gap in a front caused by mountain ranges
MET KAHOOT.answer: A low-pressure system, generally moving with warm & cold fronts

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a secondary depression?
choices: A weak high that builds behind the main low-pressure system
A smaller low-pressure system forming near a main depression
A trough of low pressure extending from a ridge
A tropical cyclone that follows another cyclone
MET KAHOOT.answer: A smaller low-pressure system forming near a main depression

MET KAHOOT.question: What is an adiabatic process?
choices: Air warming due to contact with a hot surface
Cooling caused by mixing with cold air
A process where air changes temperature without heat exchange
MET KAHOOT.answer: A process where air changes temperature without heat exchange

MET KAHOOT.question: Advection is?
choices: Cooling of air by radiation at night
MET KAHOOT.answer: Horizontal movement of air

MET KAHOOT.question: What are geostationary satellites?
choices: Satellites in low Earth orbit circling twice per day
Satellites that track only weather fronts
Satellites at a great distance from earth, appearing to be stationary
MET KAHOOT.answer: Satellites at a great distance from earth, appearing to be stationary

MET KAHOOT.question: ENAT 171400Z 1715/1722 13005KT 9999 -RA BKN050 TEMPO 1715/1722 SHRA SCT020TCU TEMPO 1717/1720 BKN008= Ceiling at 2200Z?
What is the siberian high?
choices: A tropical low-pressure system near the equator
A stormy low over the North Atlantic
A large, cold, high-pressure system over Siberia in winter
A warm high-pressure system over southern Russia
MET KAHOOT.answer: A large, cold, high-pressure system over Siberia in winter

MET KAHOOT.question: What is an anti-cyclone?
choices: A sudden drop in pressure along a front
A cyclone moving in the opposite direction of normal winds
MET KAHOOT.answer: A high-pressure system

MET KAHOOT.question: What does VCSH mean on a METAR?
MET KAHOOT.answer: Showers in the vicinity

MET KAHOOT.question: Determine RVR. ENKR 171700Z 1718/1803 16005KT 9999 FEW008 PROB40 TEMPO 1718/1803 SHRA PROB40 1721/1803 0300 FG VV001=
MET KAHOOT.answer: Not given

MET KAHOOT.question: What is an anabatic wind?
choices: Downslope wind blowing at night from mountains to valleys
Strong horizontal wind along a coastal line
MET KAHOOT.answer: Upslope wind on a mountainside

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a warm occlusion?
choices: Occluded front where the air behind the front is warmer than the air ahead
Occluded front where the air behind the front is colder than the air ahead
A tropical warm front forming over the ocean
A front where cold air advances beneath warm air
MET KAHOOT.answer: Occluded front where the air behind the front is warmer than the air ahead

MET KAHOOT.question: You are flying from a high to a low-pressure system in Nowhere Else, Australia. Where will the wind be coming from?
MET KAHOOT.answer: From your right

MET KAHOOT.question: How many octas of the sky is covered if FEW is stated?
Condensation is a process in which
choices: Liquid water changes into water vapor
Ice turns directly into water vapor
Water vapor turns into liquid water
MET KAHOOT.answer: Water vapor turns into liquid water

MET KAHOOT.question: Dew point describes
choices: The temperature at which air becomes saturated
The current air temperature at a location
The temperature at which water freezes
The maximum temperature expected during the day
MET KAHOOT.answer: The temperature at which air becomes saturated

MET KAHOOT.question: What is the height of the tropopause in ISA?
MET KAHOOT.answer: 11km

MET KAHOOT.question: How may a new metar after this look, after heavy showers? ENHD 171720Z 17003KT 9999 FEW024 14/09 Q1008=

choices: A wind pattern caused by temperature differences
A sudden drop in temperature at the surface
A cloud type forming at very high altitudes
A layer of the atmosphere where temperature remains constant with height
MET KAHOOT.answer: A layer of the atmosphere where temperature remains constant with height

MET KAHOOT.question: What is an isobar?
choices: A line on a weather map connecting points of equal pressure
A line indicating the path of a storm system
A line showing the boundary between two air masses
A line connecting points of equal temperature
MET KAHOOT.answer: A line on a weather map connecting points of equal pressure

MET KAHOOT.question: What is an anemometer?
choices: A device for measuring air pressure
A tool to detect precipitation type
An instrument used to measure wind speed
MET KAHOOT.answer: An instrument used to measure wind speed

MET KAHOOT.question: METAR OMDB 171600Z 27006KT 250V310 CAVOK 34/26 Q1003 NOSIG= What does 250V310 indicate?
choices: Cloud base height between 2500 and 3100 ft
MET KAHOOT.answer: Wind direction varying between 250 and 310

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a microburst?
choices: A small, intense downdraft causing strong, localized wind
A sudden updraft forming cumulus clouds
A weak horizontal wind along a mountain ridge
A slow-moving cold front over a large area
MET KAHOOT.answer: A small, intense downdraft causing strong, localized wind

MET KAHOOT.question: What does the NE monsoon of India signify?
choices: Sudden thunderstorms over the Himalayas in spring
Heavy, wet winds from the southwest in summer
Tropical cyclones moving from the Bay of Bengal
Dry, cool winds from the northeast during winter
MET KAHOOT.answer: Dry, cool winds from the northeast during winter

MET KAHOOT.question: What does R07L/P1500N indicate?
choices: Runway 07L RVR less than 1500 m, decreasing
Runway 07L RVR is 1500 m, normal conditions
Runway 07L RVR greater than 1500 m, no change
MET KAHOOT.answer: Runway 07L RVR greater than 1500 m, no change

choices: The layer where clouds begin to form
The lowest part of the atmosphere affected by surface friction
A high-altitude layer where winds are strongest
A boundary between warm and cold air masses
MET KAHOOT.answer: The lowest part of the atmosphere affected by surface friction

MET KAHOOT.question: What does the black arrow with the number 20, perpendicular to the occlusion, indicate?
choices: The occlusion is advancing moving at 20kts
MET KAHOOT.answer: The occlusion is advancing moving at 20kts

MET KAHOOT.question: What is the dry composition of the atmosphere?
MET KAHOOT.answer: 78% N, 21% O, 1% other gases

MET KAHOOT.question: What is an isohypse?
choices: A line connecting points of equal pressure at the same altitude
Line connecting points of equal temperature on a map
A line connecting points of equal precipitation
Line connecting points of equal wind speed
MET KAHOOT.answer: A line connecting points of equal pressure at the same altitude

MET KAHOOT.question: What is latent heat?
choices: Heat measured by a thermometer in the air
Heat transferred by conduction in solids
Heat lost due to radiation at night
Heat absorbed or released during a phase change
MET KAHOOT.answer: Heat absorbed or released during a phase change

MET KAHOOT.question: What kind of weather is NS associated with?
choices: Continuous rain or snow, overcast skies
MET KAHOOT.answer: Continuous rain or snow, overcast skies

MET KAHOOT.question: Why is the air clear in the eye of a TRS?
choices: Sinking air suppresses clouds and precipitation
MET KAHOOT.answer: Sinking air suppresses clouds and precipitation

choices: Cannot see through clouds or at night
MET KAHOOT.answer: Cannot see through clouds or at night

MET KAHOOT.question: Why does the tropopause inhibit vertical movement of air?
choices: Air pressure is too low for clouds to form
Moisture condenses and stops air rising
Winds are too strong to allow vertical movement
MET KAHOOT.answer: The ELR changes to isothermal

MET KAHOOT.question: What does the suffix -lysis indicate?
MET KAHOOT.answer: Breaking down or decomposition

MET KAHOOT.answer: It shifts southward and strengthens

choices: Colder above the poles than the equator
Warmer above the poles than the equator
About the same as at the equator
MET KAHOOT.answer: Warmer above the poles than the equator

MET KAHOOT.question: What is clear air turbulence?
choices: Turbulence in clear air, usually near jet streams
MET KAHOOT.answer: Turbulence in clear air, usually near jet streams

choices: A low-pressure "belt" near the equator with convective activity
A high-pressure zone near the poles
A region of constant clear skies
A jet stream over the tropics
MET KAHOOT.answer: A low-pressure "belt" near the equator with convective activity

MET KAHOOT.question: TAF AMD: ENSS 171822Z 1718/1721 17008KT 9999 -RA FEW008 BKN045 TEMPO 1718/1720 BKN003 SCT020TCU= What does TAF AMD mean?
choices: Amended: the forecast has been revised and updated
MET KAHOOT.answer: Amended: the forecast has been revised and updated

MET KAHOOT.question: What generally happens with relative humidity between the afternoon and early morning hours?

MET KAHOOT.answer: Yes.

MET KAHOOT.answer: Fog or low clouds form due to cooling from below

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a squall line?
choices: A line of light rain clouds
A long, organized band of severe thunderstorms
MET KAHOOT.answer: A long, organized band of severe thunderstorms

MET KAHOOT.question: Where do tropical cyclones usually form?
choices: Warm ocean regions near the equator
MET KAHOOT.answer: Warm ocean regions near the equator

MET KAHOOT.question: What is a weather front?
MET KAHOOT.answer: Boundary between two air masses

MET KAHOOT.question: What is the Coriolis effect?
choices: Apparent deflection of winds due to Earth's rotation
Cooling of air at high altitudes
MET KAHOOT.answer: Apparent deflection of winds due to Earth's rotation

MET KAHOOT.question: Given the coriolis effect, in what direction will an air mass moving northwards in the northern hemisphere deflect?
MET KAHOOT.answer: To the right

MET KAHOOT.question: What is the definition of wind shear?
choices: Rapid change of wind speed and/or direction with height
MET KAHOOT.answer: Rapid change of wind speed and/or direction with height

MET KAHOOT.question: What is lightning?
choices: A sudden electrostatic discharge in the atmosphere
MET KAHOOT.answer: A sudden electrostatic discharge in the atmosphere

MET KAHOOT.question: Given QNH 1007, isa deviation of -22, and an indicated altitude of 9760ft. Find the true altitude.

choices: Combination of mist and fog, up to 5m
MET KAHOOT.answer: Shallow fog, usually less than 2m

POF.question: Study the diagram. Identify the correct statement below.
choices: The correcting fin side force is shown at A and requires left rudder pedal to achieve it.
The correcting fin side force is shown at A and requires right rudder pedal to achieve it.
The correcting fin side force is shown at B and requires left rudder pedal to achieve it.
The correcting fin side force is shown at B and requires right rudder pedal to achieve it.
POF.answer: The correcting fin side force is shown at B and requires right rudder pedal to achieve it.

POF.question: The __________ is the maximum load expected in service. Exceedance may cause permanent structural distortion.
The aerodynamic force produced by a propeller blade element (its total reaction) is resolved into _________ __________ .
Flaps may be protected by overload protection devices which prevent flap extension, above __________.
A __________ provides a physical barrier reducing span wise flow towards the tips.

choices: Upper surface flow separation caused by the increase in drag.
Upper surface flow separation caused by the adverse pressure gradient.
Upper surface flow separation caused by the transition from laminar to turbulent flow.
Upper surface flow separation caused by the forward movement of the CP.
POF.answer: Upper surface flow separation caused by the adverse pressure gradient.

POF.question: A Diamond DA-42, with gear and flap up, is flying a 4 nm radius turn at 165 kt. An Airbus A380 is also flying a 4 nm radius turn at 180 kt, but with gear and flap down.
choices: The Airbus has the greater angle of bank.
Both aircraft have the same angle of bank but experience different load factors.
Both aircraft have the same angle of bank.
The DA-42 has the greater angle of bank.
POF.answer: The Airbus has the greater angle of bank.

POF.question: A __________ tab linked directly to the flying controls, deflects to move the main control surface. This reduces the force required at the control column to move the control.
Stall warning is necessary because monitoring __________ alone is not an adequate countermeasure against stalling.

The purpose of vortex generators is to.
choices: Prevent normal shock waves from forming
Re-energise the boundary layer, which has lost energy to the normal shock wave
Prevent the normal shock wave from spreading span wise
POF.answer: Re-energise the boundary layer, which has lost energy to the normal shock wave

POF.question: The difference between the geometric and effective pitch is called __________.
During a short period oscillation, the altitude:
choices: varies significantly, whereas during a phugoid it remains approximately constant
remains approximately constant, whereas during a phugoid it varies significantly
varies significantly, as it does during a phugoid
remains approximately constant, as it does during a phugoid
POF.answer: remains approximately constant, whereas during a phugoid it varies significantly

Limit rudder deflection above a certain angle of bank to limit the maximum forces felt by the fin.
Limit rudder deflection to a pre-set yaw rate.
Limit rudder deflection during the final approach.
POF.answer: Limit rudder deflection above a certain IAS to limit the maximum forces felt by the fin.

POF.question: The design feature where the wing's angle of incidence is progressively reduced towards the tip is called __________. This reduces the tendency of the tips to stall first.
