Load factor __________ in a turn and, thus, stalling speed __________ in a turn.

A __________ balance adds an area of control surface in front of a hinge to reduce the hinge moment.
The primary effect of elevator is __________. The secondary effect is __________.
If the rudder is held deflected, yaw __________.
choices: continues to increase at a steady rate.

POF.question: Higher Mach numbers at altitude result in a higher slow-speed stall speed and a reduction in  CRIT:
choices: Only after MCRIT has been exceeded.
Because of the onset of shock stall at MCRIT.
Because compressibility causes a shallower upwash at the leading edge.
Because compressibility causes steeper upwash at the leading edge.
POF.answer: Because compressibility causes steeper upwash at the leading edge.

POF.question: The __________ propeller is most efficient at low speeds and less efficient at higher speed. It is often used on low-powered training aircraft.

the coefficient of drag increases and the coefficient of lift decreases.
the shock wave intensifies and the reduction in air density from in front of the shock wave to behind it increases.
the shock wave moves aft and the coefficient of lift increases.
POF.answer: the shock wave moves aft and the coefficient of lift increases.

increasing bank angle, increasing thrust, slat extension.

a higher weight, selecting a higher flap setting, a forward CG movement.

Significant pitch-up of the nose immediately before the stall, 3. The audible stall warning sounds, 4. The controls become light and less effective close to but before the stall.

POF.question: Because the load factor increases when manoeuvring and in turbulence, a load factor of __________ g is normally used to determine the buffet onset Mach numbers when using a BOB chart.

The phenomenon whereby the aircraft tries to rotate in the opposite direction from the propeller is called '__________ '. This can produce a __________ when on the ground during the take-off run. On light twin aircraft this effect can be reduced by using counter-rotating propellers.

The narrow range of available operating speeds, bounded by the onset of low speed buffet at one side and the onset of high speed buffet at the other is known as the buffet margin. It __________ with altitude.
The maximum time an aircraft can remain on the ground before take-off after de-icing/anti-icing is known as the __________ time. If precipitation is falling, this will __________ the time.
If, after anti-icing/de-icing you exceed the holdover time while waiting for take off, you __________.
choices: may continue the take-off provided you see no sign of contamination.
You should make note of this in the aircraft technical log, and then continue the take-off provided you see no sign of contamination.
must repeat the entire anti-ice/de-ice procedure.
must have the surfaces visually inspected by an engineer.
POF.answer: must repeat the entire anti-ice/de-ice procedure.

POF.question: If positive static directional stability is very strong it will be __________ to change the aircraft’s direction.
An object with static __________ stability begins to move back towards equilibrium after being displaced.
__________ instability can occur when directional stability is strong and lateral stability is weak.

Positive static lateral stability is the tendency of an aeroplane to:

roll to the left in a right turn.
roll to the left in the case of a sideslip (with the aeroplane nose pointing to the left of the incoming flow).
roll to the left in the case of a sideslip angle (with the aeroplane nose pointing to the right of the incoming flow).
POF.answer: roll to the left in the case of a sideslip (with the aeroplane nose pointing to the left of the incoming flow).

POF.question: The principal design element contributing to directional stability is __________.

POF.question: The pilots prepare and trim the aircraft for take-off, setting the trim for a CG position at 12% of the MAC. But due to an error, the real position of the CG is at 24% of the MAC. What could this cause?
choices: The length of the runway may not be sufficient to take-off.
Risk of over rotation that can lead to a tail strike.
Large stick forces are required to achieve rotation.
POF.answer: Risk of over rotation that can lead to a tail strike.

POF.question: Comparing the power output from the propeller with the power input by the engine gives a measure of propeller __________.
Assuming ISA conditions and a climb above the tropopause at constant Mach number and aeroplane mass, the:

Which of the following would indicate that the aircraft had entered a full stall, if you do NOT respond to the warning and try to maintain level flight using the elevator?
choices: The nose pitching down with a full pitch-up elevator.
The effect of the rudder control being reversed.
The aileron controls give a feeling of a heavy buffet.
The nose yaws to the right regardless of the rudder input.
POF.answer: The nose pitching down with a full pitch-up elevator.

POF.question: The __________ is the failing load of the structure. Exceedance may cause structural failure.
Which of the following statements about the 'banking method' is/are accurate?
choices: The technique requires you to apply up to 5° of bank towards the live engine.
The technique uses a sideways component of the drag vector to counterbalance the yawing moment.
A 5° limit on bank angle is imposed because of the risk of stalling the aircraft.
Unlike the wings-level method, the banking method doesn't require the fin to generate a side force.
POF.answer: The technique requires you to apply up to 5° of bank towards the live engine.

POF.question: A Mach trimmer automatically adjusts the incidence of the __________ to counter the pitch changes. It is a mandatory item for any aircraft designed to fly in, or close to, the transonic range. If it is unserviceable, or fails in flight, the Mach number must be restricted to well below MCRIT.

Clear and rime ice accumulate most quickly below __________ KIAS, at lower altitudes in visible moisture and the airframe is at or below 0°C.

In the cruise, an aircraft's Mach number:
choices: Reduces when flying into colder air because of the increase in the LSS.
Changes when the aircraft flies from cold to warm air because the LSS varies with temperature.
Reduces when flying into colder air because of the reduction in the LSS.
Stays the same when flying into colder or warmer air because the aircraft's TAS also changes proportionately.
POF.answer: Stays the same when flying into colder or warmer air because the aircraft's TAS also changes proportionately.

POF.question: A tailplane stall triggered by ice contamination causes the aircraft to pitch __________.
Given an aeroplane in steady, straight and level flight at low speed and considering the effects of CG location and thrust, the highest value of wing lift occurs at:

Which statement about propeller icing is correct? I. Propeller icing increases blade element drag and reduces blade element lift. II. Propeller icing reduces propeller efficiency.
choices: I is incorrect, II is correct.
I is correct, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is incorrect.
POF.answer: I is correct, II is correct.

POF.question: An aircraft is taking off, its VA is 260 kt. If weight decreases by 20%, the new VA will be:

Flap retraction may provoke a stall of an ice-contaminated wing __________ an ice-contaminated tailplane.

The altitude where the aeroplane is experiencing both low speed and high speed buffet determines its __________.
Mach number is a measure of the __________ of the air.
The local speed of sound in air is proportional to the:
choices: Square root of the air temperature in Kelvin (K).
Square root of the air temperature in degrees Celsius (°C).
POF.answer: Square root of the air temperature in Kelvin (K).

POF.question: An aeroplane has a current mass of 52 metric tonnes. Its VA is 160 kt. What is its VA after burning 3000 kg of fuel?
For a parcel of air, its density __________ with an increase in altitude and decrease in temperature.

Thin, slippery and low energy, with relatively little drag' is a description of the __________ boundary layer.
The CP of a symmetrical aerofoil:
choices: Is at approximately 1/4 of the chord from the leading edge, and does not move with changes of AoA.
Is at approximately 1/3 of the chord from the leading edge at 0 degrees AoA, and moves aft with increasing AoA.
Is at 1/4 of the chord from the leading edge at 2 degrees AoA, and moves forwards with increasing AoA.
Is at 1/3 of the chord from the leading edge and does not move with changes of AoA.
POF.answer: Is at approximately 1/4 of the chord from the leading edge, and does not move with changes of AoA.

POF.question: What is the SI unit of measurement for power?

choices: increasing the camber of the aerofoil.
POF.answer: increasing the camber of the aerofoil.

choices: Static pressure increases and total pressure is unchanged.
Static pressure and total pressure decrease.
Static pressure decreases and total pressure increases.
Static pressure decreases and total pressure is unchanged.
POF.answer: Static pressure decreases and total pressure is unchanged.

POF.question: Excessively __________ pitch results in high torque drag and reduction in thrust. It is very inefficient and risks overboosting the engine.

choices: Dutch roll is usually encountered during an approach in turbulence.
A roll damper is used in most aeroplanes to counteract Dutch roll.
If Dutch roll occurs, try to counteract the oscillations by opposite rudder.
If the yaw damper is inoperative, consider reducing speed and altitude.
POF.answer: If the yaw damper is inoperative, consider reducing speed and altitude.

POF.question: The overall change in pitching moment from MCRIT to MDRAG DIVERGENCE is __________.

downwards, increasing the negative camber of tailplane and elevator.
upwards, increasing the negative camber of the tailplane and elevator.
upwards, increasing the positive camber of the tailplane and elevator.
POF.answer: upwards, increasing the negative camber of the tailplane and elevator.

POF.question: VMCG (minimum control speed on the ground) is the minimum CAS during the take-off run at which you can maintain control using the __________ without deviating more than __________ ft laterally from the centre line after failure of the critical engine.

choices: I is incorrect, Il is correct.
I is correct, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is incorrect.
POF.answer: I is incorrect, Il is correct.

POF.question: Consider a fixed-pitch propeller aeroplane at take-off. When the aeroplane accelerates during the take-off run phase, the blade angle of attack will (1) _____ and the thrust produced by the propeller will (2) _____ .

Sophisticated angle of attack type stall warning systems __________ take the effect of ice contamination into account.

choices: Is less likely on CAT jet aircraft when compared with less strongly built light aircraft.
May be overcome by locking the inboard ailerons.
Is the result of one wing stalling before the other.

POF.question: For a given blade pitch angle, thrust __________ as air speed increases.
What happens following the deployment of leading edge devices, while the trailing edge flaps remain retracted?
choices: CLMAX is decreased, approach and landing speeds are decreased, but the nose up attitude gives the pilot a poorer view of the runway.
CLMAX is decreased, approach and landing speeds are increased, but the nose down attitude gives the pilot a better view of the runway.
CLMAX is increased, approach and landing speeds are decreased, and the nose down attitude gives the pilot a better view of the runway.
CLMAX is increased, approach and landing speeds are decreased, but the nose-up attitude will give the pilot a poorer view of the runway.
POF.answer: CLMAX is increased, approach and landing speeds are decreased, but the nose-up attitude will give the pilot a poorer view of the runway.

POF.question: Two identical aeroplanes A and B, with the same mass, are flying steady level co-ordinated 20 degree bank turns. If the TAS of A is 130 kt and the TAS of B is 200 kt:
choices: the turn radius of A is less than that of B.
the rate of turn of A is less than that of B.
the load factor of A is greater than that of B.
the lift coefficient of A is less than that of B.
POF.answer: the turn radius of A is less than that of B.

POF.question: The coefficient of yawing moment (__________) is the yawing moment per unit of dynamic pressure (q), wing area (S) and wing span (b).

reducing the size of the vertical tail.
POF.answer: the use of a high, rather than low, wing mounting.

POF.question: Disregarding the restoring effect of fuselage area behind the CG, an increased distance between the fuselage CP and the CG is __________.
The pitching moment is much greater at higher indicated airspeeds because:
choices: Dynamic pressure is proportional to V.
Of the movement of the CP.
Dynamic pressure is proportional to V².
Of the movement of the CG.
POF.answer: Dynamic pressure is proportional to V².

impossible to calculate, because we need the aircraft's angle of bank.

The stabiliser does not move, but the elevator will be deflected downwards.
The leading edge of the stabiliser will be raised.
The leading edge of the stabiliser will be lowered.
POF.answer: The leading edge of the stabiliser will be lowered.

POF.question: An increase in mass causes the drag curve to move __________ and ________.

Parasite drag increases, induced drag reduces by the same amount, so total drag stays the same.
Parasite drag reduces, induced drag increases by a smaller amount, so total drag reduces.
Parasite drag reduces, induced drag increases by a larger amount, so total drag increases.
POF.answer: Parasite drag reduces, induced drag increases by a larger amount, so total drag increases.

The new CL is less than 0.38.
The new CL is 0.38 because you're still at the same altitude.
The new CL must be greater than 0.38 to maintain the same altitude.
POF.answer: The new CL must be greater than 0.38 to maintain the same altitude.

It is normal on take-off when fully loaded.
POF.answer: It is considered to be the stall limit on jet transport aircraft.

Insufficient take-off flap increases the risk of encountering buffet but decreases the risk of a stall.

POF.answer: With underslung engines, the use of the take-off/go-around power setting (TOGA) produces powerful nose­ up pitching moments, increasing the risk of a stall.

reduce stall speed and drag during take-off and landing.

reduce stall speed, increase CLMAX with minimum increase in drag for take-off, but with a relatively high drag for approach and landing.
POF.answer: reduce stall speed, increase CLMAX with minimum increase in drag for take-off, but with a relatively high drag for approach and landing.

Dual set of controls are needed and a flight instructor.
Dual set of instruments are needed and a competent observer.
Dual set of instruments are needed and a flight instructor.
ALW.answer: Dual set of controls are needed and a flight instructor.

ALW.question: According to the Standardised European Rules of the Air, what will the distance from the clouds be when an aircraft flies under VFR in the following conditions: Airspace: Class G Aircraft altitude: 3500 ft AMSL Terrain elevation: 2800 ft AMSL
choices: Clear of clouds and with the surface insight.
ALW.answer: Clear of clouds and with the surface insight.

ALW.question: An aerodrome reference code' number 4' refers to an aeroplane reference field length of:
ALW.answer: 1800 m and over.

ALW.question: The standard colour used for apron safety lines is:
ALW.answer: Any conspicuous colour.

ALW.question: Which of the following statements regarding Pattern B runway holding markings is most correct?
choices: Used when there is more than one holding point before runway used for CAT I, and CAT II/III operations.
Used to define the CAT I, II and III holding positions.
ALW.answer: Used when there is more than one holding point before runway used for CAT I, and CAT II/III operations.

ALW.question: A runway is observed to have the first third covered in 5mm of STANDING WATER, the second third covered with WET ICE and the last third covered with ICE. Which of the following would be the correct runway condition report for this runway?
Information about those meteorological services providing SIGMET information can be found in which part of the AIP?
ALW.answer: GEN

ALW.question: Runway centreline markings are provided on:
choices: Runways which have a length of 1200 m or more.
Runways which have a width of 45 m or more.
ALW.answer: All paved runways

ALW.question: What colour is a land aerodrome beacon?
ALW.answer: White or white/green.

ALW.question:
According to ICAO Annex 14, aerodrome mandatory instruction signs are:
1. Runway designation signs,
2. Runway exit signs,
3. Category I, II or III holding position signs,
4. Runway-holding position signs,
5. Road-holding position signs,
6. NO ENTRY signs,
7. Direction signs,
8. Location signs.
Which of these statements correctly describes the normal location of a runway threshold?
choices: At a distance of 5 m from the runway end unless operational considerations justify the choice of another location.
At the extremity of a runway unless operational considerations justify the choice of another location.
At a distance of 100 m from the runway end unless operational considerations justify the choice of another location.
At a distance of 300 m from the runway end unless operational considerations justify the choice of another location.
ALW.answer: At the extremity of a runway unless operational considerations justify the choice of another location.

ALW.question: The absolute minimum separation between 2 aircraft using the Mach number technique is ________ and occurs when the leading aircraft is __________ than the following aircraft.
ALW.answer: 5 minutes, faster.

ALW.question: For an aerodrome to be 'controlled' it must:
choices: Be located within a control zone.
Have an air traffic control service.
Be located in a control area.
Be located in a control zone and have a control tower.
ALW.answer: Have an air traffic control service.

ALW.question: A revised EAT must be transmitted to the aircraft without delay whenever it differs by ____ minutes or more from a previous one.
The movement of persons, vehicles and towed aircraft on the manoeuvring area of an AD:
choices: Must be controlled by the TWR to protect aircraft from unauthorised people and vehicles.
Must be controlled by the TWR to avoid hazard to them or to aircraft landing, taxiing or taking off.
Must be controlled by the apron management service to avoid hazard to them or to aircraft landing, taxiing or taking off.
Must be controlled by the TWR to avoid hazard to fast-moving emergency response vehicles.
ALW.answer: Must be controlled by the TWR to avoid hazard to them or to aircraft landing, taxiing or taking off.

ALW.question: The minimum standard horizontal radar separation between successive aircraft is _____nm
The 'aerodrome elevation' is the height of:
choices: The highest point in the landing area.
The threshold of the main precision runway.
ALW.answer: The highest point in the landing area.

ALW.question:
Instrument approaches are designed according to:
1. ACN
2. PCN
3. Aircraft to be accommodated
4. Possible obstacles
If a prominent obstacle protrudes into the circling area:
choices: You must land on the instrument runway regardless of the conditions.
A non-circling sector may be established, provided that the obstacle is outside the final approach or missed approach area.
A non-circling sector may be established, provided that the obstacle is outside the missed approach area.
A circling approach cannot be made.
ALW.answer: A non-circling sector may be established, provided that the obstacle is outside the final approach or missed approach area.

ALW.question: Altitude should be referred to as flight levels...
ALW.answer: Above the transition altitude.

ALW.question: Speed and configuration are adjusted to prepare for the final approach'. This is a description of the tasks in the:
ALW.answer: Intermediate segment.

ALW.question: A straight departure is defined as one in which:
choices: The departure track is within 30 of the orientation of the runways centre line.
The initial departure track is within 15 of the orientation of the runways centre line.
The departure track is within 45 of the orientation of the runways centre line.
The departure track is within 15 of the orientation of the runways centre line.
ALW.answer: The initial departure track is within 15 of the orientation of the runways centre line.

ALW.question: The aim of the final approach is either to land or?
choices: Establish visual contact with the aerodrome.
ALW.answer: Enter the visual pattern.

ALW.question: On a precision approach using QNH, OCA plus safety margin plus a margin for the aircraft and crew gives a:
ALW.answer: DA

ALW.question: You have received holding instructions for a radio fix. The published holding procedure is: all turns to the right, 1 minute outbound, inbound MC NDB 052. You are approaching the fix on an inbound Magnetic Track 232. The appropriate entry procedure is:
ALW.answer: Either offset or parallel

ALW.question: The most significant factor affecting the size of the required protected area, is the _________of the aircraft using the procedure.
ALW.answer: Speed

ALW.question: To be considered a 'straight-in' approach, the maximum angle between the final approach track and the extended RWY centre line must not exceed:
Which procedure should you follow after experiencing 2-way communication failure during a flight in accordance with IFR in VMC?
choices: Continue to fly in VMC and return to the aerodrome of departure.
Continue to fly in VMC, land at the nearest suitable aerodrome, report the arrival by the most expeditious means to the appropriate Air Traffic Control unit.
Continue the flight at the assigned level and route, carry out level changes as indicated in the filed ATC flight plan, land at the destination aerodrome at the planned ETA.
Maintain the assigned level and route and land at the nearest aerodrome where VMC prevails.
ALW.answer: Continue to fly in VMC, land at the nearest suitable aerodrome, report the arrival by the most expeditious means to the appropriate Air Traffic Control unit.

ALW.question: To close a flight plan after landing at an aerodrome without an ATS facility you must:
choices: Turn off your transponder, to indicate to the nearest ATSU that you have landed.
Submit an arrival report to the nearest ATSU within 3 hours of landing.
Submit an arrival report to the nearest ATSU ASAP after landing.
Submit an arrival report to control authority for the FIR ASAP after landing.
ALW.answer: Submit an arrival report to the nearest ATSU ASAP after landing.

ALW.question: An aircraft registered in Italy is flying over the Mediterranean, 100 NM from the closest coast, inside Libyan FIR. To verify that the pilots are complying with the right rules of the air, which documents should they check?
Which of the following has the right-of-way against a vehicle that is operating on an apron?
ALW.answer: An aircraft being towed.

ALW.question: The application of technical or other means which are intended to identify and/or detect weapons, explosives or other dangerous devices, articles or substances which may be used to commit an act of unlawful interference' this is a definition of:
ALW.answer: Screening.

ALW.question: The ICAO annex which deals with entry and departure of persons and their baggage on international flights is:
ALW.answer: Annex 9.

ALW.question: A generic term meaning, as the case may be, uncertainty phase, alert phase or distress phase' is a definition of:
ALW.answer: An emergency phase

ALW.question: A situation wherein uncertainty exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants' is a definition of:
ALW.answer: The uncertainty phase.

ALW.question: Which of the following statements concerning the flight crew compartment door is correct:
choices: The door shall be lockable from the flight deck side only.
The door must be marked as an emergency access and be kept clear of obstructions at all times.
The door may be made of a fireproof material.
The door must be capable of being unlocked from the cabin side because it is an emergency exit from the aircraft.
ALW.answer: The door shall be lockable from the flight deck side only.

ALW.question: The movement area of an airport, the adjacent terrain and buildings with controlled access are called:
ALW.answer: Airside.

ALW.question: If an aircraft subject to unlawful interference must depart from its assigned flight level, and no RSUPPs are in place to dictate what action should be taken, the PiC should:
choices:
Fly at a level which differs from the normal IFR cruising levels by:
1000 ft in 2000 ft RVSM areas.
2000 ft in 4000 ft VSM areas.

Fly at a level which differs from the normal IFR cruising levels by:
1000 ft in 1000 ft RVSM areas.
2000 ft in 2000 ft VSM areas.

Fly at a level which differs from the normal IFR cruising levels by:
500 ft in 1000 ft RVSM areas.
1000 ft in 2000 ft VSM areas.

Fly at a level which differs from the normal VFR cruising levels by:
500 ft in 1000 ft RVSM areas.
1000 ft in 2000 ft VSM areas.
ALW.answer:
Fly at a level which differs from the normal IFR cruising levels by:
500 ft in 1000 ft RVSM areas.
1000 ft in 2000 ft VSM areas.

ALW.question: The initial actions of the PIC of an aircraft subject to unlawful interference are:
choices:
Try to notify the ATSU controlling the flight.
Divert as soon as possible to the first available suitable airfield.

Try to notify the ATSU controlling the flight.
Fly the assigned track and cruising level at least until able to notify an ATS unit or within ADS-B or radar coverage.
Land as soon as practicable.

Only use ADS-B or CPDLC to try to alter the ATSU in secret.
Slowly change heading and height (to avert suspicion) to head towards a suitable aerodrome.
Land as soon as possible.

Try to notify the ATSU controlling the flight.
Fly the assigned track.
Fly at a cruising level 500 ft different for the assigned one.
Land as soon as practicable.
ALW.answer:
Try to notify the ATSU controlling the flight.
Fly the assigned track and cruising level at least until able to notify an ATS unit or within ADS-B or radar coverage.
Land as soon as practicable.

ALW.question: Which part of the AIP contains information on holding, approach and departure procedures?
ALW.answer: ENR

ALW.question: What does the acronym RCAM refer to?
choices: Report of Runway Conditions And Measurements
ALW.answer: Runway Condition Assessment Matrix

ALW.question: What is the name of the publication issued by or with the authority of a State which contains aeronautical information of a lasting character essential to air navigation?
ALW.answer: The Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP).

ALW.question: The simple approach lighting system comprises a row of lights extending, where possible, not less than __________ m from the threshold. A row of lights forms a crossbar 18 m or 30 m in length __________ m from the threshold.
A notice containing information concerning flight safety, air navigation, technical, administration or legislative matters and originated at the AIS of a state is called:
ALW.answer: An Aeronautical Information Circular (AIC).

ALW.question: The approach lighting system ends at:
choices: The start of the runway TDZ marks.
ALW.answer: The runway threshold.

ALW.question: Operationally significant changes to the AIP are published in accordance with:
choices: AIC procedures and identified by the acronym AIC followed by a number.
AIRAC procedures and identified by the acronym AIRAC.
NOTAM procedures and identified by acronym NOTAM followed by a number.
AIP supplements and shall be clearly identified.
ALW.answer: AIRAC procedures and identified by the acronym AIRAC.

ALW.question: With regard to aircraft under 5700 kg, the pavement classification system (ACN-PCN):
choices: Is not applicable to aircraft under 5700 kg.
Is used to define the maximum ACN for a pavement.
Lists the types of aircraft permitted to use that pavement.
ALW.answer: Is not applicable to aircraft under 5700 kg.

ALW.question: Runway-lead-in lighting comprises:
choices: Groups of at least 3 green lights, flashing in sequence towards the runway.
Groups of at least 3 white lights, flashing in sequence towards the runway.
Groups of flashing green lights, either side of the runway threshold.
Group of at least 5 flashing yellow lights.
ALW.answer: Groups of at least 3 white lights, flashing in sequence towards the runway.

ALW.question: What are the 2 main categories of approach lighting system?
ALW.answer: Simple and precision.

ALW.question: What is the overriding requirement for a signals area on an aerodrome?
choices: It must be clearly visible from the air.
It is used for VFR + IFR operations.
It must be big enough to contain all signals.
It must be clearly visible from all parts of the manoeuvring area.
ALW.answer: It must be clearly visible from the air.

ALW.question: The colour and pattern of a road holding position marking:
choices: Is a double solid yellow line.
Conforms with the markings established in the State's road traffic rules.
Is determined by the State's national aviation authority.
Is a double solid white line.
ALW.answer: Conforms with the markings established in the State's road traffic rules.

ALW.question: When a threshold is displaced, what colour shall the runway edge lights be in the approach direction between the beginning of the runway and the displaced threshold?
choices: Flashing red, intermittent with flashing white.
Blue, this portion of the runway is considered to be a taxiway.
ALW.answer: Red.

ALW.question: Runway centreline lights must be provided:
choices: On runways equipped for CAT I precision approaches.
On runways equipped for CAT I precision approaches where the runway width is less than 45 m.
On a precision approach runway CAT II or III.
On runways intended to be used for take-off with an RVR > 400 m by aeroplanes with high landing speeds.
ALW.answer: On a precision approach runway CAT II or III.

ALW.question: Which of the following Annexes to the Chicago convention contains minimum specifications for the design of aerodromes?
ALW.answer: Annex 14.

ALW.question: The standard colour used for aircraft stand markings is:
ALW.answer: Yellow.

ALW.question: A taxiway intermediate holding position is marked by:
choices: A solid yellow line across the width of the taxiway.
A solid yellow double line across the width of the taxiway.
A dashed yellow line across the width of the taxiway.
ALW.answer: A dashed yellow line across the width of the taxiway.

ALW.question: Air Information Circulars (AIC) that deal with administrative matters are printed on which colour paper?
ALW.answer: White.

ALW.question: The fixed, unidirectional runway threshold and wing bar lights are coloured:
ALW.answer: Green.

ALW.question: The standard colour used for runway markings is:
choices: Contrasting to the runway surface and acceptable to the authority.
ALW.answer: White.

ALW.question: According to ICAO Annex 14 Volume 1 (Aerodrome Design and Operations), which of the following must be frangible? 1. Fixed objects when marked by markers. 2. Stopway edge markers. 3. Taxiway edge markers. 4. Unpaved runway edge markers.
What is the definition of a RESA?
choices: An area clear of obstructions that can be used to balance the take-off.

A defined rectangular area on the ground or water under the control of the appropriate authority, selected or prepared as a suitable area over which an aeroplane may make a portion of its initial climb to a specified height.
An area symmetrical about the extended runway centre line and adjacent to the end of the strip primarily intended to reduce the risk of damage to an aeroplane undershooting or overrunning the runway.
An area including taxiway that can be used for aircraft movements.
ALW.answer: An area symmetrical about the extended runway centre line and adjacent to the end of the strip primarily intended to reduce the risk of damage to an aeroplane undershooting or overrunning the runway.

ALW.question: An aircraft making a radar approach should be advised to consider executing a missed approach if the aircraft is not visible on the radar display for any significant interval during the:
ALW.answer: Last 2 nm of the approach.

ALW.question: The primary duty provided by a radar unit is:
choices: To assist aircraft on the location of storms.
To assist aircraft where navigation appears unsatisfactory.
To assist aircraft due to failure of airborne equipment.
ALW.answer: To provide radar separation.

ALW.question: Which statement is correct? During a 'Visual Approach' in Controlled Airspace (Class C):
choices: ATC will apply separation only with other IFR-traffic.
ATC will apply separation with other traffic.
The pilot will apply separation with other traffic.
ATC will apply separation with other arriving traffic.
ALW.answer: ATC will apply separation with other traffic.

ALW.question: Who is normally responsible for the preparation and dissemination of the ATIS message?
choices: The meteorological office serving the aerodrome(s).
ALW.answer: The air traffic services.

ALW.question: An air traffic advisory service uses the words advise or suggest to:
choices: To indicate the height an aircraft should be at during an SRA approach.
Clear an aircraft to take-off or land.
Direct aircraft along a desired track.
ALW.answer: Propose a course of action.

ALW.question: If the crew of an aircraft making a straight-in approach are unfamiliar with the approach procedure:
choices: ATC must pass them all significant details of the procedure.
They must request a surveillance radar approach.
They must request a visual approach.
ATC must pass them the final approach track.
ALW.answer: ATC must pass them the final approach track.

ALW.question: When an arriving aircraft is making a straight-in approach, a departing aircraft may take-off in any direction which is at least 45 degrees from the reciprocal of the direction of approach:
choices: Until 2 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.
Until 10 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.
Until 3 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.
Until 5 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.
ALW.answer: Until 3 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.

ALW.question: Which class or classes of airspace requires separation between all types of flight (IFR and VFR)?
choices: Class A, Class B and Class C.
ALW.answer: Class A and Class B.

ALW.question: A strayed aircraft is:
choices: An aircraft in a given area but whose identity has not been established.
Only that aircraft which has deviated significantly from its intended track.
Only that aircraft which reports that it is lost.
An aircraft which has deviated significantly from its intended track or which reports that it is lost.
ALW.answer: An aircraft which has deviated significantly from its intended track or which reports that it is lost.

ALW.question: Clearances are issued by an ATC unit for the purpose of:
ALW.answer: Achieving separation between controlled flights.

ALW.question: During an improved accuracy SRA, distance and height information are given every ____ km.
Essential traffic information must be given to the flights concerned:
choices: Whenever they constitute essential traffic to other aircraft.
Whenever they constitute essential traffic to each other.
Whenever they are likely to constitute essential traffic.
ALW.answer: Whenever they constitute essential traffic to each other.

ALW.question:
The objectives of an aerodrome control service include the prevention of collisions between:
1) Aircraft flying in the aerodrome traffic circuit and local area around the aerodrome.
2) Aircraft operating on the manoeuvring area.
3) Aircraft landing and taking off.
4) Aircraft and vehicles operating on the manoeuvring area.

The combination of correct statements is:

Aircraft A and B are flying to Paris. Aircraft A takes off from London Heathrow and is in front of Aircraft B with 1 minute difference. Aircraft B takes off from London City Airport at the same direction, 150 (M) inbound Paris Charles de Gaulle VOR for holding procedure before landing. What will be the appropriate flight level for each aircraft?
choices: Aircraft A: FL240; and Aircraft B: FL260.
Aircraft A: FL260; and Aircraft B: FL240.
Aircraft A: FL270; and Aircraft B: FL250.
Aircraft A: FL250; and Aircraft B: FL270.
ALW.answer: Aircraft A: FL250; and Aircraft B: FL270.

ALW.question: To find out whether you can still receive communications ATC will instruct you:
choices: Either to manoeuvre or make a signal.
To flash your navigation lights on and off.
To contact them on the voice channel of a navigation aid such as VOR.
ALW.answer: Either to manoeuvre or make a signal.

ALW.question: Which class or classes of airspace dont require ATC to provide separation between VFR aircraft?
ALW.answer: Classes C to G.

ALW.question: Clearances contain which of the following items:
choices: Aircraft identification, clearance limit, track and headings of the route of flight, level of flight.
Aircraft identification, clearance limit, initial heading of flight, level of flight.
Aircraft identification, route of flight, level of flight or changes of levels en-route if required.
Aircraft identification, clearance limit, route of flight, level of flight.
ALW.answer: Aircraft identification, clearance limit, route of flight, level of flight.

ALW.question: The purpose of radar vectoring is to:
choices: Direct the aircraft to fly along a desired track.
Direct the aircraft to fly a flight planned route.
Direct the aircraft to fly a continuous descent final approach (CDFA)
Direct the aircraft to fly along a desired heading.
ALW.answer: Direct the aircraft to fly along a desired track.

ALW.question: Types of airspace - A controlled airspace extending upwards from the surface of the Earth to a specified upper limit is a:
ALW.answer: Control Zone.

ALW.question: During an SRA the landing clearance (or an alternative clearance) is normally passed to the aircraft before it reaches _____ nm from touchdown.
When an aircraft will pass through the level of another aircraft on the same track, the following minimum longitudinal separation shall be provided:
choices: 20 minutes at the time the level is crossed.
15 minutes at the time the level is crossed.
5 minutes at the time the level is crossed.
10 minutes at the time the level is crossed.
ALW.answer: 5 minutes at the time the level is crossed.

ALW.question: When ATC clears you to leave the hold at a given time you must:
choices: Adjust your flight path (while remaining within the holding pattern) so that you leave the holding pattern at the time specified.
Immediately fly to the holding fix and hold over it until the cleared time to leave it.
Continue to fly the full holding pattern while adjusting your speed to ensure that you exit the holding fix at the correct time.
Adjust your flight path (while remaining within the holding pattern) so that you leave the holding point at the time specified.
ALW.answer: Adjust your flight path (while remaining within the holding pattern) so that you leave the holding point at the time specified.

ALW.question: You must not manoeuvre your aircraft in response to traffic advisories because:
choices: Because ATC clearances always take precedence over TAs and RAs.
TAs don't show the approximate position of other aircraft.
TAs offer only limited bearing accuracy. It would be difficult to interpret sufficient information from the TA display to make the appropriate manoeuvre.
TAs only offer avoidance information to one of the conflicting aircraft.
ALW.answer: TAs offer only limited bearing accuracy. It would be difficult to interpret sufficient information from the TA display to make the appropriate manoeuvre.

ALW.question: If a missed approach is initiated prior to reaching the MAPt, at what altitude/height shall the aircraft overfly the MAPt?
choices: A turn towards the IAF can be initiated without overflying the MAPt.
An any altitude/height equal to or greater than that required by the procedure.
Initiation of the missed approach before the MAPt is prohibited.
It must overfly the MAPt at the corresponding approach altitude/height minima.
ALW.answer: An any altitude/height equal to or greater than that required by the procedure.

ALW.question: When an aircraft carries a serviceable transponder, the pilot shall operate the transponder:
choices: at all times during flight, regardless of whether SSR is used for ATS purposes or not.
only when the aircraft is flying within controlled airspace.
only when the aircraft is operating within airspace where SSR is used for ATS purposes .
ALW.answer: at all times during flight, regardless of whether SSR is used for ATS purposes or not.

ALW.question: The minimum obstacle clearance provided by the minimum sector altitude is ________ (m) within a radius of 25 nm of the aerodromes homing facility.
The maximum allowable intercept angle on the IF when conducting a precision approach is:
The maximum allowable intercept angle on the IF when conducting DR navigation is:
For a precision approach the missed approach point is established:
choices: At a point where the glide path intersects the MDA.
At a point where the glide path intersects the DA/H.
At a point where the glide path intersects the OCA.
Over a navigation facility, fix, waypoint or at a specified distance from the FAF.
ALW.answer: At a point where the glide path intersects the DA/H.

ALW.question: When should QNH be obtained in the descent?
choices: Before the transition altitude when cruising within the transition layer.
ALW.answer: Before the transition level.

ALW.question: QNH altimeter-setting reports should be provided from sufficient locations because:
choices: Different ADs calculate it slightly differently.
Of the significant variation in atmospheric pressure laterally.
It changes with the depth of the transition layer.
ALW.answer: Of the significant variation in atmospheric pressure laterally.

ALW.question: The primary advantages of ACAS are:
choices: It permits you to maintain own separation in certain types of controlled airspace.
It helps ATC to maintain safe separation between aircraft.
It improves your situation awareness and helps you to avoid mid-air collisions
ALW.answer: It improves your situation awareness and helps you to avoid mid-air collisions

ALW.question: For a non-precision approach procedure, what will be produced when an additional margin is added to the OCH when considering the effects of operational factors?
ALW.answer: The minimum descent height.

ALW.question: Those portions of the airspace where it is determined that air traffic control service will be provided to IFR flights are designated as:
ALW.answer: Control areas or control zones.

ALW.question: An Obstacle Clearance Altitude (OCA) is referenced to:
ALW.answer: Mean sea level.

ALW.question: A turning departure is one in which the initial departure track deviates from the alignment of the extended runway centre line by more than:
What is the maximum intercept angle for aircraft being vectored to intercept the localiser for simultaneous indepedent parallel approaches?
ALW.answer: 30 degrees.

ALW.question: The maximum allowable intercept angle on the IF when conducting a non-precision approach is:
An aircraft is on VOR track 332 for a straight-in-approach. What runway direction could the pilot expect to have?
Regarding a hold, when does the outbound timing commence?
choices: Over or abeam the holding fix, whichever is earlier.
Over or abeam the holding fix, whichever is later.
ALW.answer: Over or abeam the holding fix, whichever is later.

ALW.question: To maintain your aircraft within the holding pattern you take account of the known wind to:
ALW.answer: Adjust your heading and time.

ALW.question: When is it permissible to set QNH whilst flying above the transition layer?
choices: Only when climbing though the transition layer.
When descending to a cleared altitude, but not when flying level.
Only when descending though the transition altitude.
When flying above the transition layer.
ALW.answer: When descending to a cleared altitude, but not when flying level.

ALW.question: You get a number during descent / before commencing an approach:
ALW.answer: Before passing the transition level.

ALW.question: During the approach phase, safe clearance from terrain and obstacles is ensured by:
choices: A volume of protected airspace surrounding the defined track and vertical profile.
ALW.answer: A volume of protected airspace surrounding the defined track and vertical profile.

ALW.question: The objective of the Commission Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 of 5 October 2012 is:
choices: To lay down detailed rules for commercial air transport operations with aeroplanes and helicopters, including ramp inspections of aircraft of operators under the safety oversight of another State when landed at aerodromes located in the territory subject to the provisions of the treaty.
To establish the common rules of the air and operational provisions regarding services and procedures in air navigation that shall be applicable to general air traffic.
To lay down common requirements for the provision of air traffic management and air navigation services (ATM/ANS) and other air traffic management network functions.
To lay down common requirements for the competent authorities, and the qualified entities acting on their behalf, which exercise certification, oversight and enforcement tasks.
ALW.answer: To lay down detailed rules for commercial air transport operations with aeroplanes and helicopters, including ramp inspections of aircraft of operators under the safety oversight of another State when landed at aerodromes located in the territory subject to the provisions of the treaty.

ALW.question: You are tracking 050 inbound to the MUM VOR. Which entry must you perform into the hold if the inbound course is 270 with right turns?
ALW.answer: Offset.

ALW.question: A holding is a standard turns with a holding entry of 010 degrees inbound. Flying of 030 degrees heading. Which holding should you fly?
ALW.answer: Direct

ALW.question: An MOC of 984 ft is provided:
choices: During the initial phase of the missed approach.
During the initial approach segment only.
During the initial approach and the very early part of the intermediate segment.
ALW.answer: During the initial approach and the very early part of the intermediate segment.

ALW.question: If a communication failure is experienced on an IFR flight in IMC, the pilot must:
choices: Proceed to the navigation aid serving the destination aerodrome and commence descent at the estimated time of arrival or the expected approach time, whichever is later.

Proceed to the navigation aid serving the destination aerodrome and commence descent at the expected approach time or, if no expected approach time has been received, as close as possible to the estimated time of arrival resulting from the current flight plan.
Try to reach VMC and land at the nearest suitable aerodrome.
Land at the nearest suitable aerodrome.
ALW.answer: Proceed to the navigation aid serving the destination aerodrome and commence descent at the expected approach time or, if no expected approach time has been received, as close as possible to the estimated time of arrival resulting from the current flight plan.

ALW.question: During flight, the correct FL should be selected according to the aircraft's:
ALW.answer: Magnetic track.

ALW.question: For night VFR the cloud ceiling must not be less than:
You must stop and hold at all runway-holding positions unless:
choices: These are holding positions for a runway which is not in use.
You can see that there is no conflict with other traffic.
An explicit clearance to enter or cross the runway has been issued by the aerodrome control tower.
An explicit clearance to enter or cross the runway has been issued by the apron management service or ATC control tower.
ALW.answer: An explicit clearance to enter or cross the runway has been issued by the aerodrome control tower.

ALW.question: The objective of the Standardised European Rules of the Air (SERA) is:
choices: To establish the common rules of the air and operational provisions regarding services and procedures in air navigation that shall be applicable to general air traffic within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 551/2004.
To establish common requirements for the provision of air traffic management and air navigation services (ATM/ANS) and other air traffic management network functions.

To lay down detailed rules for commercial air transport operations with aeroplanes and helicopters, including ramp inspections of aircraft of operators under the safety oversight of another State when landed at aerodromes located in the territory subject to the provisions of the treaty.
To lay down common requirements for the competent authorities, and the qualified entities acting on their behalf, which exercise certification, oversight and enforcement tasks.
ALW.answer: To establish the common rules of the air and operational provisions regarding services and procedures in air navigation that shall be applicable to general air traffic within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 551/2004.

ALW.question: On the ground, when 2 aircraft are approaching head on:
choices: Air Traffic has to be informed.
Both aircraft should declare an emergency.
Both aircraft must stop or where practicable alter course to the right to keep well clear.
Both aircraft must stop or where practicable alter course to the left to keep well clear.
ALW.answer: Both aircraft must stop or where practicable alter course to the right to keep well clear.

ALW.question: An EIR ___________ valid for instrument approaches outside controlled airspace.
ALW.answer: Is not

ALW.question: The Basic Regulation refers to a:
choices: Non-binding rule adopted by the European Commission, establishing aeronautical rules and basic standards.
Non-binding rule adopted by EASA, establishing implementing Acts and Delegated Acts.
Binding rule adopted by the EASA, establishing Acceptable Means of Compliance.
Binding rule adopted by the European Parliament and the Council, establishing the EASA.
ALW.answer: Binding rule adopted by the European Parliament and the Council, establishing the EASA.

ALW.question: Soft law uses:
choices: Certification specifications (CS). Delegated acts. Guidance Material (GM).
Soft rules. Acceptable Means of Compliance (AMC). Guidance Material (GM).
Certification specifications (CS). Acceptable Means of Compliance (AMC). Implementing rules (IR).
Certification specifications (CS). Acceptable Means of Compliance (AMC). Guidance Material (GM).
ALW.answer: Certification specifications (CS). Acceptable Means of Compliance (AMC). Guidance Material (GM).

ALW.question: The issue of a passenger ticket __________ a form of contract. If a document of carriage isn't issued, the contract _______ valid.
ALW.answer: Is, is

ALW.question: For the issue of an instrument rating the holder of a PPL or CPL shall have completed at least 50 hours of cross-country flight time as pilot-in-command, according to the relevant FCL requirements, the minimum required cross country flight hours in the relevant aircraft category are:
ALW.answer: 10 hours

ALW.question: A PPL holder completes a night rating. After completion he/she is allowed to:
choices: Night fly in IFR and VFR.
ALW.answer: Night fly in VFR.

ALW.question: What does 'Proficiency Check' mean?
choices: The administrative action taken after a rating or certificate has lapsed.
A check on the pilots flight skills for the Initial Issue of a rating, not requiring any oral examination.
The demonstration of skill to revalidate or renew ratings or privileges, and including such oral examination as may be required.
The initial flight test conducted for the issue of a flying license.
ALW.answer: The demonstration of skill to revalidate or renew ratings or privileges, and including such oral examination as may be required.

ALW.question: _________ ensure that regulations are introduced and are applied fairly and uniformly.
ALW.answer: Implementing acts.

ALW.question: The right to land in another state for technical purposes such as refuelling or maintenance is the freedom of the air.
ALW.answer: 2nd.

ALW.question: Authority-maintained rules and directives are known as:
ALW.answer: Regulations.

ALW.question: With regard to EASA Part-FCL, explain the term competent authority:
choices: The competent authority shall be an authority designated by EASA to whom a person applies for the issue of international accepted type ratings.
The competent authority shall be an authority designated by the Member State to whom a person applies for the issue of pilot licences or associated ratings or certificates.
In Europe, EASA is the competent authority, designated by the European Member States to whom a person or company applies for the issue of pilot licences and airworthiness certificates.
The competent authority shall be an authority designated by all Member States.
ALW.answer: The competent authority shall be an authority designated by the Member State to whom a person applies for the issue of pilot licences or associated ratings or certificates.

ALW.question: An IR is valid for 1 year. It must be revalidated within the ____ months immediately preceding its expiry date.
The issue of a passenger ticket __________ a form of contract. If a document of carriage isn't issued, the contract _______
ALW.answer: Is, is

ALW.question: According to the relevant medical requirements, the applicant for a Commercial Pilot's licence shall hold a current:
choices: medical assessment as prescribed by the State issuing the licence.
ALW.answer: Class I medical assessment.

ALW.question: During the climb-out phase of a flight, the pilot-in-command becomes incapacitated. The co-pilot takes over control of the aircraft and decides to return for landing. Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: This is an irregularity in operations. The operator must inform the Authority by writing an Irregularity Report.
This is an irregularity. The pilot-in-command or the Operator must deposit a report on behalf of the involved airport Authority within the following 48 hours.
This is a serious incident. The crew must follow the procedure relevant to an incident.
This is an accident. The crew must follow the procedure relevant to an accident.
ALW.answer: This is a serious incident. The crew must follow the procedure relevant to an incident.

ALW.question: A means by which the introduction of weapons, explosives or other dangerous devices, articles or substances which may be used to commit an act of unlawful interference can be prevented' this is a definition of:
ALW.answer: Security control.

ALW.question: If screened passengers have mixed with unscreened passengers after a security screening point
choices: They and cabin and hold baggage must be re-screened.
The passengers must be re-screened using a whole body scanner or hand search.
They and their cabin baggage must be re-screened before boarding.
ALW.answer: They and their cabin baggage must be re-screened before boarding.

ALW.question: The conduct of an accident investigation may be delegated, in whole or in part, to:
choices: The State of Registry, the State of the Operator or any other State by mutual arrangement and consent.
ALW.answer: The State of Registry, the State of the Operator or any other State by mutual arrangement and consent.

ALW.question: ICAO Annex 12 is applicable to which geographical areas?
choices: Over the territories of Contracting States and over the high seas.
Over Contracting States and Territorial waters.
ALW.answer: Over the territories of Contracting States and over the high seas.
1, 2, 3, 4 is correct.

ALW.question: How are Search and Rescue Regions in remote areas organised?
choices: By the IATA Search and Rescue Committee.
They are not as they are too inaccessible.
By the ICAO Search and Rescue Committee.
ALW.answer: By regional air navigational agreements.

ALW.question: The 'PAPI' shall consist of:
choices: 2 wing bars of 6 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced.
2 wing bars of 4 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced.
A wing bar of 4 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced.
A wing bar of 2 sharp transition multi-lamp equally spaced.
ALW.answer: A wing bar of 4 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced.

ALW.question: Which part of the AIP contains a brief description of the service(s) responsible for search and rescue?
ALW.answer: GEN

ALW.question: The PCN is the ________ ACN that can routinely use the pavement.
ALW.answer: highest

ALW.question: What is the length of a CAT I approach lighting centreline? Answer in metres.
What is the shape of the ground symbol that indicates landing direction?
ALW.answer: T

ALW.question: The fixed, unidirectional runway end lights are coloured:
ALW.answer: Red.

ALW.question: Approach lights and crossbars are measured from the:
ALW.answer: Threshold.

ALW.question: A runway __________ is an area of specified dimensions enclosing a runway to provide for the safety of aircraft operations.
ALW.answer: Strip.

ALW.question: ____________ allow aircraft to wait safely on a taxi route before proceeding. Holding bays should be provided where the traffic volume is medium or high.
ALW.answer: Holding bays

ALW.question: Whose responsibility is it to ensure the flow of information necessary for the safety, regularity, and efficiency of international air navigation?
choices: The national aviation authorities of the States.
ALW.answer: The Aeronautical Information Service (AIS).

ALW.question: Which of the following alternatives describes the complete CAT 1 (Calvert) type of approach light system?
choices: 5 crossbars, centre line with 3, 2 and 1 lamp per light unit.
3 crossbars, centre line with 3, 2 or 1 lamp per light unit.
4 crossbars, centre line with 3 or 2 lamps per light unit.
3 crossbars, centre line with 3 or 2 lamps per light unit.
ALW.answer: 5 crossbars, centre line with 3, 2 and 1 lamp per light unit.

ALW.question: According to ICAO Annex 14, which of the following is necessary when aircraft refuelling operations take place at the same time as passengers are embarking, on board or disembarking?
choices: Ground equipment shall be positioned so as to allow the use of a sufficient number of exits for expeditious evacuation.
All exits from the aircraft must be open for an expeditious evacuation in the event of a fire.
Rescue and fire fighting vehicles must be manned and at their stations in order to be available in the event of a fire.
Rescue and fire fighting vehicles must be positioned at the aircraft in order to be available in the event of a fire.
ALW.answer: Ground equipment shall be positioned so as to allow the use of a sufficient number of exits for expeditious evacuation.

ALW.question:
Which of the following elements are included in an ASHTAM?
1. Name of volcano.
2. Flight levels and routes affected.
3. FIR affected.
4. Time and date of eruption.
5. Validity
The declared distances, which shall be calculated for each runway direction, are the take-off run available (TORA):
choices: take-off distance available (TODA), accelerate-stop distance available (ASDA), and runway-end safety area (RESA).
accelerate-stop distance available (ASDA), landing distance available (LDA), and, if present, length of any displaced thresholds (THR).
take-off distance available (TODA), accelerate-stop distance available (ASDA), and landing distance available (LDA).
take-off distance available (TODA), and runway length (RL).
ALW.answer: take-off distance available (TODA), accelerate-stop distance available (ASDA), and landing distance available (LDA).

ALW.question: Aeronautical ground lights on and in the vicinity of aerodromes may be turned off, provided that they can be brought back into operation before the expected arrival of an aircraft in at least:
ALW.answer: 1 hour.

ALW.question: Trapezoidal markers or cones, indicate the boundary:
choices: When a landing area has no runway.
Of the end of a stopway.
Of the edges of a grass runway.
ALW.answer: When a landing area has no runway.

ALW.question: Track separation between two GNSS equipped aircraft flying above FL 200 is achieved by ensuring that:
choices: Each aircraft is on a track with zero offset between 2 waypoints. At least one is at least 23 nm from a common point.
Each aircraft is on a track with zero offset between 2 waypoints. At least one is at least 15 from a common point.
Each aircraft is on a track with zero offset between 2 waypoints. At least one is diverging from a common point by at least 30.
Each aircraft is on a track with zero offset between 2 waypoints. At least one is at least 15 nm from a common point.
ALW.answer: Each aircraft is on a track with zero offset between 2 waypoints. At least one is at least 23 nm from a common point.

ALW.question: The French Safety Board (BEA) published a preliminary report of a serious incident involving an Airbus A330 being operated as a commercial air transport flight at Sidney, Australia. The Report states: "During take-off, a section of engine cowling from the NO. 1 engine separated from the aircraft. The crew conducted a fuel dump and returned the aircraft to Sydney." The incident did NOT involve an engine fire. What is the most appropriate explanation for why the crew dumped fuel after take-off?
choices: They had to mitigate against the risk of fire and therefore empty the fuel tanks as much as possible.
After take-off, it is a normal procedure to dump some fuel in order to reduce pollution.
They made a mistake: According to normal procedures, the aircraft should have landed with all the remaining usable fuel.
They had to reduce the aircraft's mass in order to safely land below the maximum landing mass.
ALW.answer: They had to reduce the aircraft's mass in order to safely land below the maximum landing mass.

ALW.question: For arriving aircraft transfer of control to the TWR may occur:
choices: After the aircraft has vacated the runway.
When the aircraft is in the aerodromes vicinity and the approach and landing may be completed with the ground in sight or in uninterrupted VMC.
At some agreed point or level.
ALW.answer: When the aircraft is in the aerodromes vicinity and the approach and landing may be completed with the ground in sight or in uninterrupted VMC.

ALW.question: What is the longitudinal separation minimum when 2 aircraft are at the same cruising level and when navigation aids permit frequent determination of position and speed?
ALW.answer: 10 minutes.

ALW.question: DETRESFA may include the situation where:
choices: No communication has been received from an aircraft within a period of 30 minutes after the time a communication should have been received.
An aircraft fails to land within 5 minutes of being cleared to land.
An aircraft fails to land within 5 minutes of being cleared to land or where the fuel on board is considered to be exhausted.
The fuel on board is considered to be exhausted.
ALW.answer: The fuel on board is considered to be exhausted.

ALW.question: What is the shortest distance in a sequence for landing between a Heavy aircraft preceding a Light aircraft?
ALW.answer: 6 nm.

ALW.question: When ATC is equipped with and using PSR, at what distance from the end of the runway may a pilot expect that his aircraft can be identified?
ALW.answer: 1 nm.

ALW.question: Above flight level FL 290 the vertical separation minimum (VSM) shall be:
Which of the following Annexes to the Chicago Convention contains international standards and recommended practices for air traffic services (ATS)?
ALW.answer: Annex 11.

ALW.question: ATFM is implemented:
choices: At all ATSUs as the primary means of ground-ground communication.
For airspace when and where traffic demand at times exceeds the defined ATC capacity.
In all busy or complex airspace.
ALW.answer: For airspace when and where traffic demand at times exceeds the defined ATC capacity.

ALW.question: If, while in the approach sequence, you want to hold for a weather improvement:
choices: You are not permitted to disrupt the approach sequence. You are committed to making the approach, even if only to go-around at the MAPt.
ATC will approve your request but you may lose your place in the approach sequence and be required to re-route to an adjacent fix or even back to the top of the holding pattern.
ATC will approve your request but you may lose your place in the approach sequence and have to orbit until you are at the back of the queue.
ATC will approve your request, you will retain your place in the approach sequence but may be required to re-route via an adjacent fix.
ALW.answer: ATC will approve your request but you may lose your place in the approach sequence and be required to re-route to an adjacent fix or even back to the top of the holding pattern.

ALW.question: The acronym ADS means:
ALW.answer: Automatic Dependent Surveillance.

ALW.question: The advantage of dividing airspace into upper and lower regions is that:
choices: IFR and VFR flights can be separated into the 2 regions. (VFR in lower airspace IFR in upper airspace).
UIRs allow for a separate set of rules to be applied to high-flying traffic which doesn't deviate much from their designated tracks.
UIRs allow traffic to fly VFR in this relatively uncongested airspace.
UIR to limit the number of FIRs and control areas (CTAs) through which aircraft have to operate in upper airspace.
ALW.answer: UIRs allow for a separate set of rules to be applied to high-flying traffic which doesn't deviate much from their designated tracks.

ALW.question: When making a non-precision approach, what is created when an operating limit is added to an Obstacle Clearance Height (OCH)?
ALW.answer: Minimum Descent Height (MDH).

ALW.question: The segment which occurs between the IAF and IF is:
ALW.answer: The initial approach.

ALW.question: According to ICAO 8168, regarding omnidirectional departures, what should you expect?
choices: Sectors to be flown with no navigation aids.
Sectors to be avoided with no navigation aids.
Sectors to be avoided with no ATC service.
Sectors to be departed with no ATC service.
ALW.answer: Sectors to be avoided with no navigation aids.

ALW.question: In cruise flight, what should the altimeter indicate?
choices: Altitude in and below the transition layer.
Altitude when cruising at or below transition altitude.
Flight level in and above the transition layer.
Height or altitude above the transition altitude.
ALW.answer: Altitude when cruising at or below transition altitude.

ALW.question: The primary area of an instrument approach segment is:
choices: A defined area symmetrically disposed about the nominal flight track in which full obstacle clearance is provided.
The first part of the segment.
The outside part of the segment where the obstacle clearance increases from 0 ft to the appropriate minimum.
The most critical part of the segment where the minimum altitude should be kept very carefully.
ALW.answer: A defined area symmetrically disposed about the nominal flight track in which full obstacle clearance is provided.

ALW.question: Approach procedures - Circling. The visual contact with the runway is lost on the down-wind leg, while circling to land following an instrument approach. You have to initiate a go-around:
choices: If you have other visual cues of the aerodrome environment, continue with visual ground contact.
Make an initial climbing turn towards the runway and initiate the missed approach.
Make a turn of 90 degrees towards the runway and try to regain visual contact.
Turn towards the runway, maintain altitude and request ATC instructions.
ALW.answer: Make an initial climbing turn towards the runway and initiate the missed approach.

ALW.question: Which of the following best describes the transition altitude?
choices: The altitude at or above which the vertical position of an aircraft is controlled by reference to heights.
The altitude at or below which the vertical position of an aircraft is controlled by reference to flight levels.
The altitude at or below which the vertical position of an aircraft is controlled by reference to altitudes.
The altitude at or below which the vertical position of an aircraft is controlled by reference to pressure altitudes.
ALW.answer: The altitude at or below which the vertical position of an aircraft is controlled by reference to altitudes.

ALW.question: The purpose of altimeter setting is:
choices: Provide horizontal separation and clearance during all phases of flight.
Provide vertical separation and input for SSR ground facilities during all phases of flight.
Provide vertical separation during all phases of flight.
Provide horizontal separation during all phases of flight.
ALW.answer: Provide vertical separation during all phases of flight.

ALW.question:
You are on an IFR flight executing a circling approach. You must not descend below the MDA until:
1. You have the landing threshold in sight.
2. Visual reference has been established and can be maintained.
3. The required obstacle clearance can be maintained and a landing can be made.
The combination of all the correct answers is:
What is the FAP?
choices: It identifies the beginning of the intermediate approach segment of an instrument approach procedure.
It is the point of intersection of an electronic glide path with the applicable DA/H in APV or precision approaches.
A point in space on the final approach track where the intermediate approach altitude/height intercepts the nominal glide path/microwave landing system (MLS) elevation angle.
It is designed to place the aircraft on the localizer or the MLS azimuth specified for the final approach track.
ALW.answer: A point in space on the final approach track where the intermediate approach altitude/height intercepts the nominal glide path/microwave landing system (MLS) elevation angle.

ALW.question: When passing over a hold fix, you fly a left turn onto heading 090. You maintain track for a specified time, and then perform a second left turn to intercept the 270 inbound radial of the same hold fix. After flying over the hold fix for a second time, you perform a right turn and continue tracking around the hold procedure. What sort of entry procedure is being described?
ALW.answer: Parallel.

ALW.question: Manual on Simultaneous Operations on Parallel or Near-Parallel Instrument Runways (SOIR) (ICAOs Doc 9643) provides:
ALW.answer: Guidance material.

ALW.question: Which of these provisions are correct for a VFR-flight in Class E airspace?
choices: Service provided: Traffic Information as far as practicable; ATC Clearance: required.
Service provided: Air Traffic Control Service; ATC Clearance: required.
Service provided: Air Traffic Control Service; ATC Clearance: not required.
Service provided: Traffic Information as far as practicable; ATC Clearance: not required.
ALW.answer: Service provided: Traffic Information as far as practicable; ATC Clearance: not required.

ALW.question: A turning departure involves a turn of more than 15. However, straight flight is assumed until at least
While taxiing, you receive from the control tower: a series of red light flashes. You:
choices: Must move clear of the landing area in use.
May continue to taxi to the take-off area with extreme caution.
Must return to your point of departure.
ALW.answer: Must move clear of the landing area in use.

ALW.question:
An aircraft operated on, or in the vicinity of, an aerodrome shall whether or not within an ATZ (select correct statements):
1 - Land and take-off into the wind unless safety, the runway configuration, or an air traffic consideration determines that a different direction should be used.
2 - Observe other aerodrome traffic for the purpose of avoiding collision.
3 - Conform with or avoid the pattern of traffic formed by other aircraft in operation
4 - Make all turns to the right, when approaching for landing or taking-off unless otherwise instructed.
When flying IFR outside controlled airspace:
choices: You are only ever provided with a flight information service.
You must maintain a listening radio watch.
You need not maintain a listening watch.
You must maintain a datalink connection with ATC.
ALW.answer: You must maintain a listening radio watch.

ALW.question: You are on an IFR flight in airspace where radar is NOT used in the provision of air traffic control. You are experiencing a complete radio failure and were unable to report your position at the last compulsory reporting point. You shall maintain the last assigned speed and level, or minimum flight altitude if higher, for a period of how long after failing to report your position over the compulsory reporting point?
ALW.answer: 20 minutes

ALW.question: To an aircraft on the ground, a flashing red light means:
choices: Return to starting point on the aerodrome.
Move clear of the landing area.
ALW.answer: Move clear of the landing area.

ALW.question: An intercepted aircraft indicates that a designated aerodrome is inadequate for landing by:
choices: Overflying the runway with the landing gear up and then executing a sharp breakaway manoeuvre.
Raising its landing gear and flashing its navigation lights while passing over the runway in use at a height between 1000 ft and 2000 ft and continuing to circle the runway in use.
Raising its landing gear and flashing its landing lights while passing over the runway in use at a height between 1000 ft and 2000 ft and continuing to circle the runway in use.
Lowering landing gear (if fitted ) showing steady landing lights and following the aircraft
ALW.answer: Raising its landing gear and flashing its landing lights while passing over the runway in use at a height between 1000 ft and 2000 ft and continuing to circle the runway in use.

ALW.question: An IFR-rated pilot is performing a flight between two European aerodromes 100 NM apart. The weather conditions are VMC during the flight. According to SERA (Standardized European Rules of the Air), under which rules can the flight be performed?
ALW.answer: VFR or IFR.

ALW.question: What is the minimum flight altitude for VFR flights permitted over towns, settlements and populated areas?
choices: 500 ft within a radius of 1NM of the aircraft position.
The altitude which permits the aircraft to land safely in the event of an engine failure.
1000 ft within a radius of 8 km of the aircraft position.
1000 ft above the highest obstacle within 600 m of the aircraft position.
ALW.answer: 1000 ft above the highest obstacle within 600 m of the aircraft position.

ALW.question: An in-flight event occurs in which the crew need to use emergency oxygen for 5 minutes. Under EU 996/2010 this is classified as:
ALW.answer: A serious incident.

ALW.question: An aircraft's registration mark is assigned by:
choices: A Ministry of Transport and Ministry of Defence in the registering state.
The State of Registry or a common mark registering authority.
ALW.answer: The State of Registry or a common mark registering authority.

ALW.question: According to PART-FCL, class ratings are established for Single Pilot Single Engine Aeroplanes not requiring a type rating. These may include, for example:
choices: All types of single-pilot, single-engine aeroplanes fitted with a turbojet engine.
Any other type of aeroplane if considered necessary.
Microlights having fixed wings and movable aerodynamic control surfaces acting in all 3 dimensions.
ALW.answer: Touring Motor Glider (TMG).

ALW.question: The aircraft commander and others are empowered to prevent criminal acts and penal offences on-board. To assist in making this restraint, the commander may:
choices: Authorise or require the crew to act. Authorise or request passengers to assist.
Manoeuvre the aircraft so as to overthrow a disruptive passenger.
Use the cockpit fire axe to threaten or subdue a disruptive passenger.
Require the crew to act, but has no authority to empower passengers to act.
ALW.answer: Authorise or require the crew to act. Authorise or request passengers to assist.

ALW.question: Unaccompanied baggage to be carried by air shall be cleared under the procedures applicable for:
choices: accompanied baggage, or under another simplified customs procedure distinct from that normally applied to cargo.
cargo when covered by a traffic document.
cargo but the requested customs clearance documents provided by airlines shall be completed by the passenger prior to shipment.
cargo but shall be not subject to any kind of declaration forms.
ALW.answer: accompanied baggage, or under another simplified customs procedure distinct from that normally applied to cargo.

ALW.question: A Boeing 737 suffers a catastrophic engine failure on take-off. Under EU 996/2010 this __________ classified as an accident.
ALW.answer: is not

ALW.question: According to the ICAO definition, if an aircraft is missing or is completely inaccessible:
choices: This is classified as an incident.
This is classified as an accident.
This is classified as a serious incident.
This is classified as an uncertainty phase.
ALW.answer: This is classified as an accident.

ALW.question: When establishing security at an airport, what are the objectives (general principles) with regard to ICAO Annex 17?
choices: Each Contracting State shall have as its primary objective the safety of the general public in all matters related to safeguarding against acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation.

Each Contracting State shall have as its primary objective the safety of passengers, crew and ground personnel in all matters related to safeguarding against acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation.

Each Contracting State shall have as its primary objective the safety of passengers, crew, ground personnel and the general public in all matters related to safeguarding against acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation.
Each Contracting State shall have as its primary objective the safety of passengers and crew in all matters related to safeguarding against acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation.
ALW.answer: Each Contracting State shall have as its primary objective the safety of passengers, crew, ground personnel and the general public in all matters related to safeguarding against acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation.

ALW.question: Safeguarding civil aviation against acts of unlawful interference. This objective is achieved by a combination of measures and human and material resources' this is a definition of:
ALW.answer: Security.

ALW.question: After landing, while taxiing the landing gear sinks into a hole. No person gets injured, but the aircraft sustains structural failure, which delays the departure. Which of the following correctly describes the situation and following action:
choices: This is an accident. The crew must follow the procedure relevant to this case.
This is a technical incident. Since there is no person injured and the flight is terminated, a damage report has to be made out for the respective insurance company.
