The aircraft, its flight, and the passengers and crew it carries.
The flight crew, the cabin crew and the operator.
ALW.answer: The aircraft, its flight, and the passengers and crew it carries.

ALW.question: Search and rescue on the high seas is conducted:
choices: On the basis of Regional Air Navigation agreements.
These areas cannot be served by SAR.
By agreements of the ICAO committee.
By agreements of the EASA committee.
ALW.answer: On the basis of Regional Air Navigation agreements.

ALW.question: A Certificate of Airworthiness shall be issued by a Contracting State on the basis of satisfactory evidence that the aircraft complies with the design aspects of the appropriate airworthiness requirements. Who issues the Certificate of Airworthiness?
ALW.answer: State of Registry.

ALW.question: The light shown by an Aerodrome Identification Beacon of a land aerodrome shall be flashing, giving the aerodrome identification by Morse Code. The colour of this light is:
ALW.answer: Green.

ALW.question: You__________ manoeuvre of a section of runway marked with large white arrows.
ALW.answer: May

ALW.question: A double white cross displayed horizontally in the signal area indicates that:
choices: Special precautions are needed while approaching for landing on the runway in use.
The aerodrome is being used by gliders and that glider flights are being performed.
This area is unfit for the movement of aircraft.
Special precautions must be observed due to the state of the taxiways.
ALW.answer: The aerodrome is being used by gliders and that glider flights are being performed.

ALW.question: Which part of the AIP contains a brief description of areas and/or routes for which a meteorological service is provided?
ALW.answer: GEN

ALW.question: ICAO Annex ______ provides guidance on the calculation of declared distances (TORA, TODA, ASDA, LDA).
On the final approach, how many red lights should you see when following the glide path defined by a PAPI?
Runway edge lights are
ALW.answer: Fixed lights showing variable white.

ALW.question: In addition to the elements of the integrated AIP and maps/charts etc which other information is given to crews before flight as part of the PIB?
choices: The QNH, transition altitude, SPS and current temperature and dewpoint.
A summary of NOTAMS (which may be in plain text) and other urgent information.
Essential decode tables for any NOTAMS and ASHTAMs provided.
ALW.answer: A summary of NOTAMS (which may be in plain text) and other urgent information.

ALW.question: In the aerodrome reference code' the second code element identifies:
choices: The maximum width of the aircraft's wing.
The maximum wing span and maximum outer main gear wheel span.
The maximum length of the fuselage.
ALW.answer: The maximum wing span.

ALW.question: What is the most important factor leading to the effective rescue in a survivable aircraft accident?
choices: Number of fire fighters in attendance.
Number of fire extinguishers on the aircraft.
Number of fire engines in attendance.
ALW.answer: Training received.

ALW.question: Permanent changes to the AIP are published as:
ALW.answer: Amendments.

ALW.question: NOTAMs are distributed via:
ALW.answer: The Aeronautical Fixed Service (AFS).

ALW.question: Which of the following statements is true?
choices: The apron is part of the movement area.
The hangars are part of the manoeuvring area.
The apron is part of the manoeuvring area.
The terminal is a part of the manoeuvring area.
ALW.answer: The apron is part of the movement area.

ALW.question: How shall the bearing strength for an aircraft with an apron mass equal to or less than 5700 kg be reported?
choices: As the actual mass on the day.
As the actual tyre pressure on the day.
As a maximum allowable mass and maximum allowable tyre pressure.
As the actual weight of the aircraft on the day and tyre pressure on the day.
ALW.answer: As a maximum allowable mass and maximum allowable tyre pressure.

ALW.question: The last __________ m of the approach lighting array, if elevated, must be frangible.
What is a 'barrette'?
choices: A high obstacle near the runway and/or taxiway.
A frangible structure on which approach lights are fixed.
A CAT II or III holding position.
3 or more ground lights closely spaced together to appear as a bar of lights.
ALW.answer: 3 or more ground lights closely spaced together to appear as a bar of lights.

ALW.question: ASDA (Acceleration Stop Distance Available) is:
choices: The length of the take-off run available plus the length of the clearway.
The length of the runway plus the length of the RESA (if provided).
The length of the take-off run available plus the length of stopway (if provided).
The length of the take-off run available plus the length of stopway and clearway (if provided).
ALW.answer: The length of the take-off run available plus the length of stopway (if provided).

ALW.question: The height of signs near runways or taxiways should be kept to a minimum to:
choices: Provide clearance for propellers and engine pods.
Prevent damage to aircraft or vehicles.
ALW.answer: Provide clearance for propellers and engine pods.

ALW.question: A 'stopway' is:
choices: A defined rectangular area on the ground at the beginning of the take-off run available prepared as a suitable area in which an aircraft can be stopped in the case of an abandoned take-off.
A defined rectangular area on the ground at the end of the take-off run available prepared as a suitable area in which an aircraft can be stopped in the case of landing.
A defined rectangular area on the ground at the end of the take-off run available prepared as a suitable area in which an aircraft can be stopped in the case of an abandoned take-off.
A defined rectangular area on the ground at the end of the landing distance required, prepared as a suitable area in which an aircraft can be stopped in the case of an abandoned take-off.
ALW.answer: A defined rectangular area on the ground at the end of the take-off run available prepared as a suitable area in which an aircraft can be stopped in the case of an abandoned take-off.

ALW.question: For the aeroplane for which the taxiway is intended, the taxiway designer assumes that on a taxiway curve the:
choices: pilot will oversteer and the cockpit will NOT follow the centre-line markings.
width of the taxiway is decreased on the inner curve.
width of the taxiway is increased on the outer curve.
cockpit of the aeroplane will remain over the taxiway centre-line markings.
ALW.answer: cockpit of the aeroplane will remain over the taxiway centre-line markings.

ALW.question: Which colour paper is used in the Aeronautical Information Circulars (AIC) for safety related topics?
ALW.answer: Pink.

ALW.question: An obstacle-free rectangular area on the ground at the end of the runway which is the same width as the associated runway and is centred along the runway’s centreline is known as a:
ALW.answer: Stopway.

ALW.question: Within the Annex to the ICAO convention that specifies dimensions of aerodromes is a specific dimension given for the approach light system for CAT I ILS. What should be the length of this approach light system?

Which of these acronyms corresponds to the following definition?
A special NOTAM series notifying, by means of a specific format, an important change for the aircraft operations, due to volcanic activity, a volcanic eruption or a volcanic ash cloud.
ALW.answer: ASHTAM

ALW.question: What is the minimum distance (in metres) that the clearway must extend either side of the runway centreline?
High intensity obstacle lights should be:
ALW.answer: Flashing white.

ALW.question: What can you omit from a position report with a reliable SSR Mode C?
ALW.answer: Flight level or altitude.

ALW.question: An in-flight change from IFR to VFR takes place:
choices: Only on the initiative of the aircraft commander.
As instructed by an air traffic control unit.
At the clearance limit, irrespective of the weather conditions.
When the aircraft is leaving controlled airspace during VMC.
ALW.answer: Only on the initiative of the aircraft commander.

ALW.question: When an arriving aircraft is making a straight-in approach, a departing aircraft may take-off in any direction which is at least 45° from the reciprocal of the direction of approach:
choices: Until 3 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.
Until 10 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.
Until 2 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.
Until 5 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.
ALW.answer: Until 3 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway.

ALW.question: What Information is to be passed by ATC before taxi:
choices: The runway in use, the surface wind velocity (in °M), and the QNH.

The runway in use, the surface wind velocity (in °M), the QNH or, if requested, the QFE, the air temperature (for turbine-engine aircraft), the runway visibility if less than 10 km or the RVR if appropriate and the correct time.
The runway in use, the surface wind velocity, the RVR and the QNH. Other information is provided just before take-off.
The runway in use, the surface wind velocity (in °M), the QFE, the air temperature (for all aircraft types), the runway visibility if less than 10 km or the RVR if appropriate and the correct time.
ALW.answer: The runway in use, the surface wind velocity (in °M), the QNH or, if requested, the QFE, the air temperature (for turbine-engine aircraft), the runway visibility if less than 10 km or the RVR if appropriate and the correct time.

ALW.question: When 'Secondary Surveillance Radar' (SSR) is not available, for radar identification ATC may request the pilot to execute one or more heading changes of:
ALW.answer: 30° or more.

ALW.question: According to ICAO Doc 8168, for parallel runway operations, what is the maximum intercept angle when vectoring an aircraft towards the ILS localiser?
During a standard SRA, azimuth instructions are passed:
ALW.answer: Every 2 km (1 nm).

ALW.question: Milano approach, BIGJET 337 HEAVY over UNDAP", the aircraft's correct callsign is:
ALW.answer: BIGJET 337

ALW.question: The EAT has to be transmitted to the pilot as soon as practicable, when the expected delay is:
ALW.answer: 10 minutes.

ALW.question: The alerting service is provided by:
choices: Flight information centres, area control centre and any ATSU provided a service to the aircraft.
ALW.answer: Flight information centres, area control centre and any ATSU provided a service to the aircraft.

ALW.question: According to international agreements, wind direction shall be adjusted to the local variation and given in degrees magnetic:
choices: In upper wind forecast for areas north of lat 60° north or 60° south.
On the request from a meteorological watch office.
When the local variation exceeds 10° East or 10° West.
ALW.answer: Before landing and take-off.

ALW.question: In case of an emergency a pilot needs to act in a correct way. All the avionics are out and contact can not be established with ATS. What level might the PIC choose to signify that something is wrong?
choices: 500 ft difference from each flight level 1000 ft apart.
1000 ft difference from each flight level 1000 ft apart.
2000 ft difference from each flight level 1300 ft apart.
1000 ft difference from each flight level 500 ft apart.
ALW.answer: 500 ft difference from each flight level 1000 ft apart.

ALW.question: Aerodrome traffic is:
choices: All traffic on the manoeuvring area.
Traffic flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome.
All traffic on the manoeuvring area and aircraft flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome.
ALW.answer: All traffic on the manoeuvring area and aircraft flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome.

ALW.question: A flight information service in which a continuously repeating voice broadcast details essential aerodrome information for arriving and departing aircraft is known as:
ALW.answer: ATIS

ALW.question: You are flying a medium category aircraft. You are approaching the airport vicinity under your own navigation, when you hear "VIR123 Heavy wind XXX runway XX cleared to land". What is the distance that you must maintain from the preceding aircraft?
ALW.answer: 5 NM

ALW.question: One of the functions of a radar control unit providing an approach control service is:
choices: To provide instructions in order to reduce separations minima, if accepted by the pilots.
To apply a reduced vertical separation of 500 ft between IFR flights and VFR flights.
To apply a horizontal separation less than 5 nm.
ALW.answer: To conduct surveillance radar approaches.

ALW.question: The standard vertical separation minimum (VSM) between flights operating in accordance with IFR, within controlled airspace, below FL 290 is:
The minimum permissible height for fuel dumping is normally:

You are the pilot in command of an aircraft subjected to unlawful interference. Due to the circumstances you are obliged to deviate from the assigned track and cruising level. It is expected that you will try to broadcast warnings and follow applicable special procedures established in Regional Agreements. If no such procedures have been established you should proceed at a level which differs from those normally used by IFR flights by:
ALW.answer: 1000 ft above FL410.

ALW.question: According to ICAO Doc 4444, when should the aerodrome control tower pass the correct time to an aircraft?
choices: At the same time when the IFR clearance is delivered.
Prior to the commencement of taxiing for take-off.
ALW.answer: Prior to the commencement of taxiing for take-off.

ALW.question: The phases related to an aircraft in emergency or believed to be in emergency are, in the increasing order of seriousness:
ALW.answer: INCERFA, ALERFA, DETRESFA.

ALW.question: An ATIS broadcast:
choices: Shall not be transmitted on the voice channel of a VOR.
Shall not be transmitted on the voice channel of an ILS.
Shall only be transmitted on a discrete VHF frequency.
Shall be transmitted on the voice channel of an ILS, on a discrete VHF frequency or on the voice channel of a VOR.
ALW.answer: Shall not be transmitted on the voice channel of an ILS.

ALW.question: In which airspace classes shall an Air Traffic Control service for all VFR flights be provided?
choices: A, B, C, D, and E.
ALW.answer: B, C, and D.

ALW.question: According to ICAO Annex 11, the lateral limits of a control zone shall extend to at least_ from the centre of the aerodrome or aerodromes concerned in the directions from which approaches may be made.
ALW.answer: 5 NM

ALW.question: After changing frequency, you should make a position report on initial contact. You must include your speed:
choices: If one has been assigned by ATC.
Whenever your altitude is less than 10 000 ft.
Whenever you are flying at less than 250 kt.
ALW.answer: If one has been assigned by ATC.

ALW.question: When in RVSM airspace between FL 290 and FL 410 the vertical separation between aircraft travelling in opposite directions is:
When making a position report, which one of these phrases is the correct way to report that you are flying at 35 000 ft on the SPS?
ALW.answer: flight level tree fife zero

ALW.question: A controlled flight operating under IFR passes a designated compulsory reporting point on the route. In accordance with ICAO Annex 2, Rules of the Air, the pilot shall report to Air Traffic Control the:
choices: heading and level, and verify the route to the next reporting point.
time, heading and level, and verify the route to the next reporting point.
ALW.answer: time and level.

ALW.question: During your initial descent towards Stuttgart airport, ATC tells you that you are 'cleared via REUTEL FIVE ALPHA':
choices: This is a clearance to fly direct to a fix called REUTEL, to be there by 5000 ft.
This is a clearance to fly one of the published SIDS for Stuttgart.
This is a clearance to land on runway 5A.
This is a clearance to fly one of the published STARs at Stuttgart.
ALW.answer: This is a clearance to fly one of the published STARs at Stuttgart.

ALW.question: What is the maximum intercept angle for aircraft being vectored to intercept the localiser for simultaneous independent parallel approaches?
ALW.answer: 30 degrees.

ALW.question: The lower limit of a CTA must be not less than:
ALW.answer: 700 ft AGL.

ALW.question: Which of the following is the correct definition of "commercial air transport operation" according to ICAO Annex 6, Part I?
choices: An aircraft operation involving the transport of passengers, cargo or mail for remuneration or hire.
An aircraft operation by a commercial operator for or without remuneration or hire.
Any aircraft operation for remuneration or hire.

An aircraft operation in which an aircraft is used for specialised services such as agriculture, construction, photography, surveying, observation and patrol, search and rescue aerial advertisement, etc.
ALW.answer: An aircraft operation involving the transport of passengers, cargo or mail for remuneration or hire.

ALW.question: Guidance material on parallel operations is provided in:
ALW.answer: ICAO’s Doc 9643.

ALW.question: What is the classification of the ATS airspace in which: IFR and VFR flights are permitted; all flights are subject to air traffic control services and are separated from each other?
ALW.answer: Airspace B.

ALW.question: A no transgression Zone (NTZ) for independent parallel approaches is:
choices: At least 1310 metres wide when the vertical separation between aircraft on adjacent approaches is less than 1500 ft.
A maximum of 610 metres wide when the vertical separation between aircraft on adjacent approaches is less than 1000 ft.
At least 610 metres wide when the vertical separation between aircraft on adjacent approaches is less than 1000 ft.
A maximum of 1310 metres wide when the vertical separation between aircraft on adjacent approaches is less than 1500 ft
ALW.answer: At least 610 metres wide when the vertical separation between aircraft on adjacent approaches is less than 1000 ft.

ALW.question: Controlled airspace extending upwards from a specified limit above the earth is:
ALW.answer: A control area.

ALW.question: A circling approach is:
choices: A visual flight manoeuvre that may be carried out as long as visual ground contact can be maintained.
A visual manoeuvre to be conducted only in IMC.
A visual flight manoeuvre to be performed when radar vectoring is available.
A visual flight manoeuvre keeping the runway environment in sight while at MDA/H.
ALW.answer: A visual flight manoeuvre keeping the runway environment in sight while at MDA/H.

ALW.question: When should the latest QNH altimeter setting for the aerodrome be obtained?
choices: When descending below the transition level.
Prior to descending below the transition altitude.
When descending through the transition layer.
Prior to descending below the transition level.
ALW.answer: Prior to descending below the transition level.

ALW.question: When you are asked to hold on a non-standard holding fix (e.g. en-route) what direction are the turns made?
choices: It depends upon the inbound holding track.
ALW.answer: Right.

ALW.question: A minimum vertical separation shall be provided until aircraft are established inbound on the ILS localizer course and/or MLS final approach track. When independent parallel approaches are being conducted, this minimum is:

That point in an instrument approach procedure at or before which the prescribed missed approach procedure must be initiated in order to ensure that the minimum obstacle clearance is not infringed. This is a description of:
ALW.answer: The MAPt.

ALW.question: According to PANS OPS Doc 8168, Flight Level zero shall be located at the atmospheric pressure level of 1013.2 hPa. Consecutive flight levels shall be separated by a pressure interval corresponding to at least __________ in the standard atmosphere.
During a circling manoeuvre you must keep in sight:
choices: All obstacles within the circling area.
ALW.answer: The landing runway environment.

ALW.question: What happens during the intermediate segment of an instrument approach?
choices: The aircraft climbs to achieve a safe height of 50 m.
The aircraft is manoeuvring to enter the arrival segment.
The aircraft is aligned with the runway and descent for landing is made.
Aircraft speed and configuration are adjusted to prepare for the final approach.
ALW.answer: Aircraft speed and configuration are adjusted to prepare for the final approach.

ALW.question: What is the transponder code used to indicate an emergency?
The optimum gradient for the final approach segment is:
By when must the Transition Level be obtained when making an approach to an aerodrome?
choices: Before commencement of the final approach.
Before commencement of the initial approach.
ALW.answer: Before commencement of the initial approach.

ALW.question: An ATS route designator comprises:
choices: A letter to denote type of airspace; a number 1–999. Additional letters may indicate the aircraft type that can use the route.
A letter to denote type of airspace; a number 1–999. Additional letters may indicate whether it is an RNAV route.
A letter to denote type of airspace; a number 1–999. Additional letters may indicate RNP requirement.
A letter to denote type of airspace; a number 1–999. Additional letters may indicate the time of availability.
ALW.answer: A letter to denote type of airspace; a number 1–999. Additional letters may indicate whether it is an RNAV route.

ALW.question: According to ICAO Pans Ops 8168 a Traffic Advisory (TA) should precede a Resolution Advisory (RA) because:
choices: TAs have the ability to create a horizontal traffic avoidance manoeuvre.
A TA must always be created before an RA.
TAs have the ability to create a vertical traffic avoidance manoeuvre.
A TA highlights the approximate position of an aircraft nearby that may become an RA.
ALW.answer: A TA highlights the approximate position of an aircraft nearby that may become an RA.

ALW.question: Independent parallel approaches may be conducted to parallel runways provided that:
choices: The missed approach track for one approach diverges by at least 20° (degrees) from the missed approach track of the adjacent approach.
The missed approach track for one approach diverges by at least 25° (degrees) from the missed approach track of the adjacent approach.
The missed approach track for one approach diverges by at least 45° (degrees) from the missed approach track of the adjacent approach.
The missed approach track for one approach diverges by at least 30° (degrees) from the missed approach track of the adjacent approach.
ALW.answer: The missed approach track for one approach diverges by at least 30° (degrees) from the missed approach track of the adjacent approach.

ALW.question: The still-air time for flying the outbound entry heading is:
choices: 1 minute below or at 14 000 ft 1.5 minutes above 14 000 ft.
1 minute below or at 10 000 ft 1.5 minutes above 10 000 ft.
1 minute below or at 14 000 ft 2 minutes above 14 000 ft.
1 minute below or at 10 000 ft 2 minutes above 10 000 ft.
ALW.answer: 1 minute below or at 14 000 ft 1.5 minutes above 14 000 ft.

ALW.question: You must operate your transponder:
choices: At all times during flight, regardless of whether the aircraft is within or outside airspace where SSR is used by the ATS.
On the occasions when ATC ask you to squawk IDENT.
When directed to do so by ATC.
Only when in controlled airspace under the direction of ATC.
ALW.answer: At all times during flight, regardless of whether the aircraft is within or outside airspace where SSR is used by the ATS.

ALW.question: When can the flight crew change the altimeter setting from 1013.2 hPa to QNH during the descent to land, when the aircraft is above the transition level?
choices: Only if it has been specified in Item 18, “Other Information”, of the flight plan.
Flight above the transition level using QNH as the reference datum is not allowed.
After approach clearance has been issued, provided that level flight above the transition altitude is not indicated or anticipated.
When the atmospheric pressure is significantly different from the standard pressure and level flight above the transition altitude is not anticipated.
ALW.answer: After approach clearance has been issued, provided that level flight above the transition altitude is not indicated or anticipated.

ALW.question: The lower limit of a CTA shall be established at a minimum height of:
ALW.answer: 700 ft above the ground.

ALW.question: A flight information region (FIR) is an airspace within which the following services are provided:
choices: A flight information service, an alerting service and advisory service.
A flight Information service and an advisory service.
A flight information service and an alerting service.
ALW.answer: A flight information service and an alerting service.

ALW.question: Towards the end of a long flight, the IAF marks the:
choices: End of the initial approach segment.
Beginning of the intermediate approach segment.
ALW.answer: End of the STAR.

ALW.question: The transition level shall be provided to the flight crew:
choices: During descent, prior to reaching the transition level.
When changing the altimeter setting from QNH to QFE.
During climb, before reaching the transition altitude.
When passing the transition altitude during descent.
ALW.answer: During descent, prior to reaching the transition level.

ALW.question: Omnidirectional departures are used:
choices: Whenever there are no obstacles in the climb-out sector.
When there are no adequate navigation aids available or, for some other reason, no track guidance is provided.
Whenever an aircraft has no navigational aids or, for some other reason, is unable to maintain track.
Whenever ATC is unable to give track guidance.
ALW.answer: When there are no adequate navigation aids available or, for some other reason, no track guidance is provided.

ALW.question: The crew of an intercepted aircraft shall immediately attempt to establish radio-communication with the intercepting aircraft or with the appropriate intercept control unit by making a general call on the frequency:
choices: 121.5 MHz If no contact can be established and if practicable, repeat this call on the frequency 282.8 MHz
121.5 MHz If no contact can be established and if practicable, repeat this call on the frequency 125.5 MHz
243 MHz If no contact can be established and if practicable, repeat this call on the frequency 125.5 MHz
121.5 MHz If no contact can be established and If practicable, repeat this call on the frequency 243 MHz
ALW.answer: 121.5 MHz If no contact can be established and If practicable, repeat this call on the frequency 243 MHz

ALW.question: Flights operating within airspace classified as G above an altitude of 10 000 ft MSL and in accordance with VFR, must observe the following weather minima:
choices: A distance from cloud: 1500 m horizontally, 1000 ft vertically; flight visibility: 8 km.
A distance from cloud of 1500 m horizontally and 1000 ft vertically and a flight visibility of 5 km.
A distance from cloud: 1 nm horizontally, 1000 ft vertically; flight visibility: 5 km.
A distance from cloud: 1 nm horizontally, 1000 ft vertically; flight visibility: 8 km.
ALW.answer: A distance from cloud: 1500 m horizontally, 1000 ft vertically; flight visibility: 8 km.

ALW.question: Other than when necessary for take-off or landing, or except by permission from the appropriate authority, the minimum height to be maintained by an aircraft over the congested areas of cities, is:
choices: 100 m over the highest man-made obstacle located within a radius of 600 m from the position of the aircraft.
1000 ft over the highest obstacle located within a radius of 300 m from the present position of the aircraft.
300 m over the highest obstacle, located within a radius of 600 m from the present position of the aircraft.
A height that will permit, in case of emergency, to land without hazard to persons or property on the ground.
ALW.answer: A height that will permit, in case of emergency, to land without hazard to persons or property on the ground.

ALW.question: TAS needs to be notified with:
ALW.answer: 5% difference.

ALW.question: What does the term "DANGER AREA' describe?
choices: An airspace of defined dimensions above the land areas or territorial waters of a State within which flight of aircraft is prohibited.
An airspace of defined dimensions within which activities dangerous to the flight of aircraft may exist at specified times.
An airspace of defined dimensions within which air traffic control service is provided to IFR flights and to VFR flights in accordance with the airspace classification.
An airspace of defined dimensions, above the land areas or territorial waters of a State, within which the flight aircraft is restricted.
ALW.answer: An airspace of defined dimensions within which activities dangerous to the flight of aircraft may exist at specified times.

ALW.question: After take-off, while climbing in IMC, ATC authorises a further climb to FL 150. Immediately after receiving this transmission your radio goes completely dead. In accordance with the communication failure procedures, you continue your climb to FL 150, which takes you 5 minutes. You must now maintain this level for at least a further _______ minutes.
When flying VFR at night at and below 3000 ft AMSL or 1000 ft above terrain, whichever is higher, you must:
choices: maintain continuous sight of the surface.
ALW.answer: maintain continuous sight of the surface.

ALW.question: The rear (white) navigation light must display through an angle of ______ degrees.
To acknowledge an ATC light signal at night you should:
choices: Flash the landing and navigation lights twice.
Respond with a steady green light.
Flash the landing and navigation lights continuously.
ALW.answer: Flash the landing and navigation lights twice.

ALW.question: When, in airspace where VFR is permitted, the PiC of an IFR destination is reached he/she:
choices: 1. Must inform the control unit ('cancelling my IFR flight'). 2. Must request and obtain clearance. 3. May request her IFR flight plan to be changed to a VFR flight plan. 4. The flight plan automatically becomes a VFR flight plan.

ALW.question: In the air, an ATC clearance may be requested:
choices: Using Mode S on the transponder.
ALW.answer: By voice communication or datalink.

ALW.question: You are flying IFR above FL 290 in non-RVSM airspace. Your track is 200 degrees magnetic. Which set of Flight Levels would be suitable?
A flight in controlled airspace is being subjected to unlawful interference, with a hostage situation. According to SERA, the pilot shall attempt to notify ATC of:
choices: the flight number, the flight time remaining, and any information about the type(s) of weapon being used.
any significant circumstances associated with the interference.
the type of aircraft being flown.
the position of the aircraft and the time in UTC when the interference started.
ALW.answer: any significant circumstances associated with the interference.

ALW.question: What must pre-flight actions for all IFR flights include?
choices: Checking the hours of operation of the briefing office.
Studying current weather reports and forecasts.
Consulting the AIP for the latest information on aerodrome charges.
Finding the most cost-effective route to the destination.
ALW.answer: Studying current weather reports and forecasts.

ALW.question: You are the Pilot-in-Command of a commercial air transport flight, operating within the European Union. Which of the following reasons may allow you to depart from the provisions of the Standardised European Rules of the Air
ALW.answer: Safety of the flight.

ALW.question: The red (port) navigation light and the green (starboard) navigation light must each display through an angle of _______ degrees.
Which phrase should be given by the intercepting aircraft to communicate that it wants you to land?
ALW.answer: You land.

ALW.question: Which of the following statements about IFR is accurate?
choices: The minimum applicable flight altitude is 2000 ft above any obstacle within 8 km.
IFR flight requires an aircraft equipped with suitable instruments and navigation equipment.
The minimum applicable flight altitude is 1000 ft above any obstacle within 8 km.
ALW.answer: IFR flight requires an aircraft equipped with suitable instruments and navigation equipment.

ALW.question: Is it possible to choose flying altitude for IFR 2600 ft AMSL?
choices: No, because lowest flight level should be at least 3 000 ft AMSL.
No, because IFR uses whole altitude numbers.
No, because IFR flight levels should be either odd or even numbers.
ALW.answer: No, because IFR uses whole altitude numbers.

ALW.question: A glider flying in VMC conditions is approaching a light aeroplane towing an object at approximately the same altitude and on a converging course. Which aircraft has the right of way:
choices: The aeroplane towing an object, regardless of its position in relation to the glider.
The glider, if the aeroplane is on its left side.
The glider, regardless of its position in relation to the aeroplane.
The aeroplane towing an object, if the glider is on its right side.
ALW.answer: The glider, regardless of its position in relation to the aeroplane.

ALW.question: The follow-me signal given by an interceptor is:
choices: A slow turn to the right onto the desired heading.
A slow turn to the left onto the desired heading.
An abrupt break-away manoeuvre consisting of a level turn of 45 degrees.
An abrupt break-away manoeuvre consisting of a climbing turn of 90 degrees or more.
ALW.answer: A slow turn to the left onto the desired heading.

ALW.question: To an aircraft on the ground, a steady green light means:
choices: Move clear of the landing area.
Return to starting point on the aerodrome.
ALW.answer: Cleared for take-off.

ALW.question: Your Class 1 medical certificate expired more than 5 years ago, if you are going to an AMC now you must undertake an:
ALW.answer: Initial Examination.

ALW.question: Holders of a pilot licence with privileges to fly aeroplanes or TMGs shall only tow sailplanes or banners when they:
choices: Have at least 100 hours of flight time and 200 take-offs and landings as PIC.
Hold the appropriate sailplane towing or banner towing rating.
Have at least 30 hours of flight time as PIC on aeroplanes.
Hold an IR in the appropriate aircraft category.
ALW.answer: Hold the appropriate sailplane towing or banner towing rating.

ALW.question: According to PART-FCL, 'instrument time' comprises:
choices: Instrument flight time or instrument ground time.
The time in IMC where the aeroplane is flown by the PIC.
ALW.answer: Instrument flight time or instrument ground time.

ALW.question: Under PART-MED, you are required to seek advice from your AeMC or AME if you:
choices: Have been suffering from any illness.
ALW.answer: Have started regularly using medicine.

ALW.question: Two of the requirements for the issuance of an ATPL(A) licence are:
choices: 75 hours of flight time in a simulator with a maximum of 30 hours in an FNPT.
250 hours of flight time in a simulator with a maximum of 70 hours in an FNPT.
100 hours of flight time ln a simulator with a maximum of 30 hours in an FNPT.
100 hours of flight time in a simulator with a maximum of 25 hours in an FNPT.
ALW.answer: 100 hours of flight time in a simulator with a maximum of 25 hours in an FNPT.

ALW.question: According to the relevant FCL requirements, the applicant for an IR shall hold a PPL including a night qualification, or a CPL, and shall have completed at least 50 hours:
choices: instructional flight time as student pilot-in-command of aeroplanes for IR(A), or helicopters for IR(H).
cross-country flight time as pilot-in-command in aeroplanes or helicopters of which at least 10 hours shall be in aeroplanes for IR(A), or in helicopters for IR(H).
instructional flight time as student pilot-in-command of aeroplanes or helicopters of which at least 10 hours shall be in aeroplanes for IR(A), or helicopters for IR(H).
cross-country flight time as pilot of aeroplanes or helicopters of which at least 10 hours shall be in aeroplanes for IR(A), or in helicopters for IR(H).
ALW.answer: cross-country flight time as pilot-in-command in aeroplanes or helicopters of which at least 10 hours shall be in aeroplanes for IR(A), or in helicopters for IR(H).

ALW.question: The demonstration of skill to revalidate or renew ratings is known as a:
ALW.answer: Proficiency check.

ALW.question: Article 31 of the Chicago Convention requires that a certificate of airworthiness must be issued to:
choices: Every aircraft engaged in international navigation.
Every aircraft engaged in aerial work.
ALW.answer: Every aircraft engaged in international navigation.

ALW.question: The First Freedom of the Air is:
choices: The right to overfly without landing.
The right to board passengers from the State where the aircraft is registered and to fly to another State.
The opportunity to operate a commercial flight with passengers on board between two States.
The right to land for a technical stop.
ALW.answer: The right to overfly without landing.

ALW.question: What corresponds with a Class B aircraft?
choices: Propeller Engines, 9 persons or more, 5700 kg or less.
Jet engines, 9 persons or more, 5700 kg or more.
Propeller engines, 9 persons or less, 5700 kg or less.
Jet engines, 9 persons or less, 5700 kg or less.
ALW.answer: Propeller engines, 9 persons or less, 5700 kg or less.

ALW.question: For loss, destruction, damage or delay of baggage the carrier is:
choices: Liable to pay a fixed amount of compensation, based on the number of bags.
Not liable to pay compensation unless the flight is delayed.
Liable to pay the level of compensation set out in the carrier's terms of carriage.
Liable to pay a fixed amount of compensation, currently 1131 SDRs per passenger.
ALW.answer: Liable to pay a fixed amount of compensation, currently 1131 SDRs per passenger.

ALW.question: Which of the following ICAO documents contain International Standards and Recommended Practices (SARPS)?
choices: Annexes to the Convention on international civil aviation.
ALW.answer: Annexes to the Convention on international civil aviation.

ALW.question: The regulatory material related to air safety and managed by EASA involves:
choices: Hard norms and soft implementing rules.
ALW.answer: Hard law and soft law.

ALW.question: How long in advance may you undertake a proficiency check for the revalidation of a class or type rating?
ALW.answer: 3 months.

ALW.question: The requirement to maintain a continuing standard of airworthiness applies to all aircraft and is the responsibility of the:
ALW.answer: State of Registry.

ALW.question: According to Article 6 of the Chicago convention, scheduled international air services may:
choices: Be operated over, but not into, any State in accordance with the 5 freedoms of the air.
Be operated over or into the territory of a contracting State, in accordance with the 5 freedoms and the terms of such permission or authorisation.
Be operated over or into the territory of a contracting State, in accordance with the 2 technical freedoms

Not be operated over or into the territory of a contracting State, except with the special permission or authorisation of that State, and then only in accordance with the terms of such permission or authorisation.
ALW.answer: Not be operated over or into the territory of a contracting State, except with the special permission or authorisation of that State, and then only in accordance with the terms of such permission or authorisation.

ALW.question: An ATPL(A) gives the same privileges as:
ALW.answer: PPL(A), LAPL(A) and CPL(A).

ALW.question: Which of the following combinations of letters may be used for registration marks?
ALW.answer: VOR

ALW.question: EASA’s primary objective is to:
choices: Create and approve hard and soft law governing civil aviation.
Establish and maintain a high, uniform level of civil aviation safety within the EU.
Control the flow of traffic at peak times in European airspace.
ALW.answer: Establish and maintain a high, uniform level of civil aviation safety within the EU.

ALW.question: Rules which supplement or amend existing law, but cannot change the basic legal elements are known as:
ALW.answer: Delegated acts.

ALW.question: Concerning the Chicago Convention of 1944:
choices: All states in the world attended.
Each state has total sovereignty over the airspace above its territory.
Only 52 nations were permitted to attend.
Each state was required to recognise the other States attending.
ALW.answer: Each state has total sovereignty over the airspace above its territory.

ALW.question: A competency based instrument rating (CBIR):
choices: Is valid for IFR in all types of airspace.
Is valid for IFR only in uncontrolled airspace.
Is not valid for instrument approaches in controlled airspace.
ALW.answer: Is valid for IFR in all types of airspace.

ALW.question: The validity and renewal of a Certificate of Airworthiness is subject to laws of the:
choices: State in which the operation takes place.
ALW.answer: State of Registry.

ALW.question: IATA's objectives are:
choices: Control the flow of traffic at peak times in European airspace.
Represent, lead and serve the airline industry.
Establish and maintain a high, uniform level of civil aviation safety within the EU.
ALW.answer: Represent, lead and serve the airline industry.

ALW.question: The objectives of ICAO were ratified by the:
ALW.answer: Chicago Convention 1944.

ALW.question: Binding legislation which specifies a high level of safety with uniform conformity and compliance is known as:
ALW.answer: Implementing rules.

ALW.question: The privileges of an ME IR extend to DH’s lower than 200 feet after training at an ATO and
ALW.answer: Passing the skills test.

ALW.question: What is the minimum rest at the home base?
What is the time interval between Recurrent training
ALW.answer: 12 Months

ALW.question: Can you Take-off when no RVR is availiable
choices: Yes, if you can determin it yourself
Yes, if your operator says so
ALW.answer: Yes, if you can determin it yourself

ALW.question: What is the time interval between operator proffeciency check
ALW.answer: 6 Months

ALW.question: When do we speak of LVR
ALW.answer: RVR below 400

ALW.question: What is the lowest approved MDH for a VOR
ALW.answer: 300 ft

ALW.question: Can you take-off after your holdover-time has elapsed
choices: Yes, if approved so by the opperator
No, you need to redo your anti-icing
Yes, if you have to take-off
ALW.answer: No, you need to redo your anti-icing

ALW.question: What is a consequence of a tailwind windshear
ALW.answer: Below the glideslope

ALW.question: Where are the flighthours and aircraft-info stored?
ALW.answer: Tech-Log

ALW.question: What concept is in focus when icing conditions exist?
ALW.answer: Clean aircraft concept

ALW.question: What is an accurate description of wet snow?
choices: Snow which, if compacted by hand, will stick together and tend to or form a snowball
Snow which can be blown if loose or, if compacted by hand, will fall apart again upon release
Water-saturated snow which, with a heel-and-toe slap-down motion against the ground, will be displaced with a splatter
Snow with a layer of water above it
ALW.answer: Snow which, if compacted by hand, will stick together and tend to or form a snowball

ALW.question: When more than one cabin crew member is required, the composition of the cabin crew shall include a senior cabin crew member nominated by:
choices: The commitee of senior cabin crew members
ALW.answer: The Operator

ALW.question: Aircraft are permitted to cross the territory of a Contracting State without landing, unless the regulations of that State require you to land for customs examination.
choices: Aircraft from another Contracting State may land at a non-designated customs airport for the purpose of re fuelling and then continue to another Contracting State.
Aircraft are permitted to cross the territory of a Contracting State without landing, unless the regulations of that State require you to land for customs examination.
Aircraft departing from one Contracting State to another Contracting State may depart from a non-customs airport provided that the destination airport has customs facilities.
Particulars of all designated customs airports shall be published by the State and transmitted to the International Air Transport Association (IATA).
ALW.answer: Aircraft are permitted to cross the territory of a Contracting State without landing, unless the regulations of that State require you to land for customs examination.

ALW.question: You may revalidate your medical certificate up to how many days before it expires?

According to the relevant FCL requirements, the applicant for an ATPL(A) shall have demonstrated the ability to perform as pilot-in-command, the procedures and manoeuvres of an aeroplane type certificated for:
choices: the carriage of passengers at night.
a minimum crew of two pilots under IFR.
a minimum crew of two pilots plus a flight engineer.
ALW.answer: a minimum crew of two pilots under IFR.

ALW.question: An IR is valid for 1 year. It must be revalidated within the months ____ immediately preceding its expiry date.
Which body of ICAO finalises the Standard and Recommended Practices (SARPS) for submission for adoption?
ALW.answer: The Air Navigation Commission.

ALW.question: The flying training for an applicant for a CPL(A) integrated course shall comprise:
choices: a total of at least 200 flying hours, of which up to 10 hours for the entire course may be instrument ground time.
a total of at least 200 flying hours, instrument ground time not provided.
a total of at least 150 flying hours, of which up to 5 hours for the entire course may be Instrument ground time.
a total of at least 150 flying hours, instrument ground time not provided.
ALW.answer: a total of at least 150 flying hours, of which up to 5 hours for the entire course may be Instrument ground time.

ALW.question: A member of the flight crew being under the influence of psychoactive substances:
choices: can undertake his function only if not acting as pilot flying.
can undertake his function only if the impact of the substances on the human performance is minor.
shall not undertake his function, taking into consideration that human performance is impaired.
shall not undertake his function if he acts as pilot-in-command for that flight.
ALW.answer: shall not undertake his function, taking into consideration that human performance is impaired.

ALW.question: The privileges of an ATPL(A) allow the holder:
choices: To act as pilot in command of aircraft engaged in commercial air transport and to exercise all the privileges of the holder of an LAPL, a PPL and a CPL.
To act as pilot in command for commercial operation.
To exercise all the privileges of the holder of a LAPL, a PPL, a CPL and ATPL-H.
To act as pilot-in-command in any aeroplane engaged in operations other than commercial air transportation.
ALW.answer: To act as pilot in command of aircraft engaged in commercial air transport and to exercise all the privileges of the holder of an LAPL, a PPL and a CPL.

ALW.question: Class 1 medical certificates are initially issued by an AeMC. Subsequently, they can be revalidated and renewed by
choices: Either an AeMC or by an AME.
ALW.answer: Either an AeMC or by an AME.

ALW.question: According to ICAO Annex 8, a Certificate of airworthiness shall be renewed or shall remain valid, provided that the State of Registry shall require that the continuing airworthiness of the aircraft has been determined by periodical inspection at appropriate intervals having regard to lapse of time and type of service or alternatively:
choices: Provided that the aircraft owner has the necessary maintenance facilities.
By means of a system of inspection, approved by the Operator, that will produce at least an equivalent result.
Provided that the aircraft has NOT sustained any type of damage.
By means of a system of inspection, approved by the State, that will produce at least an equivalent result.
ALW.answer: By means of a system of inspection, approved by the State, that will produce at least an equivalent result.

ALW.question: Which restrictions apply to licence holders aged between 60 and less than 65 in commercial air transport?
choices: Multi-pilot crew only and the other flight crew member has to be a Captain.
No restrictions if the other crew member ls younger than 40 years.
Multi-pilot crew only and the other flight crew member must be younger than 60 years.
ALW.answer: Multi-pilot crew only.

ALW.question: ensure _________ that regulations are introduced and are applied fairly and uniformly.
ALW.answer: Implementing acts.

ALW.question: When an aircraft has sustained damage, the aircraft shall be allowed to resume its flight, if the:
choices: State of Design and the State of Manufacture inform the State of Registry that the aircraft is still airworthy.
State of Registry, the State of Design and the State of Manufacture consider that the aircraft is still airworthy.
State of Registry considers that the damage sustained is of such nature that the aircraft is still airworthy.
State of Manufacture informs the State of Registry that the damage sustained is of a nature such that the aircraft is still airworthy.
ALW.answer: State of Registry considers that the damage sustained is of such nature that the aircraft is still airworthy.

ALW.question: You have received holding instructions for a radio fix. The published holding procedure is: all turns to the right, 1 minute outbound, inbound MC NDB 052°. You are approaching the fix on an inbound Magnetic Track 232°. The appropriate entry procedure is:
ALW.answer: Either offset or parallel.

ALW.question: What is the transponder code used to indicate unlawful interference?

When independent parallel approaches are being conducted to parallel runways, and when vectoring to intercept the ILS localiser course, the vector must allow the aircraft to be established on the ILS localizer course:
choices: At least 3.0 nm prior to intercepting the ILS glide path or specified MLS elevation angle.
At least 1.5 nm prior to intercepting the ILS glide path or specified MLS elevation angle.
At least 2.0 nm prior to intercepting the ILS glide path or specified MLS elevation angle.
At least 2.5 nm prior to intercepting the ILS glide path or specified MLS elevation angle.
ALW.answer: At least 2.0 nm prior to intercepting the ILS glide path or specified MLS elevation angle.

ALW.question: Which answer best applies to the Final Approach Fix (FAF)?
choices: It signifies the end of the Initial Approach Segment.
It signifies the end of the Arrival Segment.
The optimum distance for locating the FAF from the runway threshold is 5 nm.
It signifies the beginning of the Final Approach Segment.
ALW.answer: It signifies the beginning of the Final Approach Segment.

ALW.question: You must not descend below MDA/H until you:
choices: Visual references are established and can be maintained throughout, and you have the landing threshold in sight, and the required obstacle clearance can be maintained and you can position to land using normal descent rates and bank angles.
You have both thresholds in sight and can maintain MDH while clear of cloud and in sight of the ground.

Visual references are established and can be maintained throughout, or you have the landing threshold in sight, and the required obstacle clearance can be maintained or you can position to land using normal descent rates and bank angles.
You have both thresholds in sight and can maintain MDA while clear of cloud and in sight of the ground.
ALW.answer: Visual references are established and can be maintained throughout, and you have the landing threshold in sight, and the required obstacle clearance can be maintained and you can position to land using normal descent rates and bank angles.

ALW.question: The design of approach procedures is constrained by:
choices: The level of ATC control available in the initial approach.
The accuracy of the approach aids.
ALW.answer: The accuracy of the approach aids.

ALW.question: In a holding pattern, the standard turn is:
choices: 20° of bank or rate one turn, whichever requires the lesser bank.
20° of bank or rate one turn, whichever requires the greater bank.
25° of bank or rate one turn, whichever requires the greater bank.
25° of bank or rate one turn, whichever requires the lesser bank.
ALW.answer: 25° of bank or rate one turn, whichever requires the lesser bank.

ALW.question: The altimeter sub-scale setting to obtain elevation when on the ground is known as:
ALW.answer: QNH

ALW.question: Commission Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 applies:
choices: To all types of commercial and non-commercial operations.
ALW.answer: To all types of commercial and non-commercial operations.

ALW.question: ATS airspace in which IFR and VFR are permitted and aircraft may receive a flight information service if requested, is classified as:
ALW.answer: Class G.

ALW.question: IFR and VFR flights are permitted, all flights are subject to air traffic control service and IFR flights are separated from other IFR flights and from VFR flights. Also VFR flights are separated from IFR flights and receive traffic information about other VFR flights. What is the classification of this ATS airspace?
ALW.answer: Airspace C.

ALW.question: The vertical distance of a level, a point or an object considered as a point measured from mean sea level (MSL) is:
ALW.answer: An altitude.

ALW.question: The minimum obstacle clearance in the primary area of the initial approach segment for an instrument approach procedure is at least:
What aircraft equipment is required for parallel runway ILS approach operations?
choices: precision approach and PBN approach capability.
ALW.answer: precision approach capability.

ALW.question: When using Mode S without having filed a flight plan:
choices: Use the company's flight designator as the identification.
Use the aircraft’s registration as the identification.
ALW.answer: Use the aircraft’s registration as the identification.

ALW.question: ATS airspace where IFR and VFR flights are permitted, where all flights are subject to air traffic control service and are separated from each other is classified as:
ALW.answer: Class B.

ALW.question: Flight levels are defined as pressure altitudes above:
choices: The level of the lowest useable flight level.
ALW.answer: The 1013.25 hPa pressure datum.

ALW.question: An airport provides two parallel runways where one is used for departures only and the other one is used for departures and approaches. What type of operation is this?
ALW.answer: Semi-mixed

ALW.question: When radar identification of aircraft has been achieved, the radar controller shall:
choices: Request the pilot to squawk ident for identification.
Inform the aircraft only when identification has been achieved by using primary radar.
Inform the pilot that his aircraft has been identified before issuing instructions, based on the use of radar.
Only communicate with the pilot when work load permits.
ALW.answer: Inform the pilot that his aircraft has been identified before issuing instructions, based on the use of radar.

ALW.question: You receive an IFR en-route clearance stating: 'Clearance expires at 0920'
choices: The take off clearance is expected at 0920.
If not airborne before 0920, a new clearance has to be issued.
After 0920 return to the ramp and file a new flight plan.
ALW.answer: If not airborne before 0920, a new clearance has to be issued.

ALW.question: Aircraft may be cleared to maintain a specified vertical separation when both are climbing or descending, provided that:
choices: Both are visual with each other.
The trailing aircraft is visual with the leading aircraft.
ALW.answer: Both agree to do it.

ALW.question: At larger airports, some air traffic services usually handled by the control tower may be transferred to:
ALW.answer: An apron management service.

ALW.question: An aircraft is in the descent and has been receiving instructions from ATC to make adjustments to its horizontal speed. At what distance from the threshold, on the final approach, must the PIC expect to stop receiving these instructions to control the speed?
ALW.answer: 4 NM

ALW.question: Which of the following statements is true?
choices: Aircraft on an instrument approach have priority to land once they have passed the FAF.
Landing aircraft, in the final stages of their approach, have priority over aircraft departing from the same runway.
Aircraft conducting a visual approach have priority to land over aircraft conducting an instrument approach.
Departing aircraft have priority over aircraft landing on the same runway.
ALW.answer: Landing aircraft, in the final stages of their approach, have priority over aircraft departing from the same runway.

ALW.question: When it becomes apparent that an aircraft is in difficulty, the decision to initiate the alert phase is the responsibility of the:
choices: Flight information centre or area control centre.
ALW.answer: Flight information centre or area control centre.

ALW.question: A Special Air Report must be made when:
choices: Experiencing severe icing or severe turbulence.
An unruly passenger is on board.
The ETA changes by more than 10 minutes.
ALW.answer: Experiencing severe icing or severe turbulence.

ALW.question: 1 minute separation may be used between departing aircraft if they are to fly on tracks diverging by at least:
ALW.answer: 45° immediately after take-off.

ALW.question: Which class or classes of airspace don't require separation between IFR flights?
choices: All classes except Class A and Class B.
ALW.answer: Class G.

ALW.question: Radar vectoring, wherever possible, is carried out at a height which:
choices: Lets the aircraft descend below MSA.
Allows the aircraft to maintain own separation.
ALW.answer: Minimises GPWS alerts.

ALW.question: What do you report during an IFR flight in cruise when passing a reporting point?
choices: Flight level, time and verify next reporting point.
Aircraft identification, position, time, flight level, next position and time over ensuing significant point.
Aircraft identification, position, time, flight level, heading, next position and time over ensuing significant point.
ALW.answer: Aircraft identification, position, time, flight level, next position and time over ensuing significant point.

ALW.question: Significant changes in the conditions in the take-off or climb-out must be given to a departing aircraft:
choices: Once the aircraft is safely airborne and climbing.
ALW.answer: Without delay.

ALW.question: To avoid confusion, how are transition altitudes set at two aerodromes located close together?
choices: A single TA is used, which is the lower of the two if calculated separately.
A single TA is used, which is the higher of the two if calculated separately.
ALW.answer: A single TA is used, which is the higher of the two if calculated separately.

ALW.question: Aerodrome traffic is:
choices: All traffic on the manoeuvring area.
All traffic on the manoeuvring area and flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome.
Traffic flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome.
ALW.answer: All traffic on the manoeuvring area and flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome.

ALW.question: An aircraft making a radar approach should be directed to execute a missed approach if no clearance to land has been received from the non-radar controller by the time the aircraft reaches a distance of:
ALW.answer: 2 nm from the touchdown.

ALW.question: The purpose of issuing speed instructions to aircraft is to ensure:
choices: The safe and orderly flow of traffic.
Control an aircraft's rate of descent.
That the ATC controller doesn't become over loaded.
Adequate vertical separation between aircraft on parallel approaches.
ALW.answer: The safe and orderly flow of traffic.

ALW.question: When using the Mach number technique the separation minimum for 2 co-speed aircraft is:
ALW.answer: 10 minutes

ALW.question: The SSR code for unlawful interference is:

An aircraft designed and manufactured in the United States of America (USA), registered and operated in the United Kingdom (UK), and having a maximum mass of 10 tonnes, crashes in France. According to ICAO Annex 13, which State/organisation(s) must be notified of the accident and by whom?
choices: The USA, the UK, and France must be notified by ICAO.
The UK must notify France, the USA, and ICAO.
The USA must notify the UK, France, and ICAO.
France must notify the UK, the USA, and ICAO.
ALW.answer: France must notify the UK, the USA, and ICAO.

ALW.question: According to the ICAO definition, an accident is an occurrence associated with the operation of an aircraft which:
choices: Takes place between the time the aircraft is in flight until such time as it lands where a person is fatally or seriously injured.
Takes place between the time any person boards the aircraft with the intention of flight until such time as all such persons have disembarked where a person is fatally or seriously injured.
Takes place between the time any passenger boards the aircraft with the intention of flight until such time as all such passengers have disembarked where a person is fatally or seriously injured.
Takes place between the time any person boards the aircraft with the intention of flight until such time as it stops engines where a person is fatally or seriously injured.
ALW.answer: Takes place between the time any person boards the aircraft with the intention of flight until such time as all such persons have disembarked where a person is fatally or seriously injured.

ALW.question: The language to be used when reporting an accident or incident must be:
choices: The language of the State of the Operator.
One of the 6 working languages of ICAO.
The language of the State of Occurrence.
ALW.answer: One of the 6 working languages of ICAO.

ALW.question: States must take adequate measures to ensure the safety of the passengers and crew of an aircraft which is subjected to an act of unlawful interference:
choices: If requested by an individual passenger.
Until their journey can be continued.
And arrange for them to return to their country of origin.
ALW.answer: Until their journey can be continued.

ALW.question: A process conducted for the purpose of accident prevention which includes the gathering and analysis of information, the drawing of conclusions, including the determination of causes and, when appropriate, the making of safety recommendations' this is a definition of:
ALW.answer: An investigation.

ALW.question: A situation wherein there is reasonable certainty that an aircraft and its occupants are threatened by grave and imminent danger or require immediate assistance' is a definition of:
ALW.answer: The distress phase

ALW.question: The ground - air visual signal code for use by survivors on the ground in order to indicate REQUIRE ASSISTANCE is:
ALW.answer: V

ALW.question: The State in the territory of which an accident or incident occurs', this is the definition of:
ALW.answer: The State of Occurrence.

ALW.question: A situation wherein apprehension exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants' is a definition of:
ALW.answer: The alert phase.

ALW.question: Isolated parking position: at least ______ m from other parking positions, buildings or public areas.

Each Contracting State should designate an appropriate authority to be responsible for the development, implementation and maintenance of a national aviation security programme. This programme should apply:
choices: Only to all international civil transport including aircraft engaged solely in the carriage of cargo.
Only to passengers and aircrew in international civil transport flights and domestic flights.
Only to passengers and aircrew in international civil transport flights.
To all international civil air transport including aircraft engaged solely in the carriage of cargo and also to domestic flights at the discretion of each member state.
ALW.answer: To all international civil air transport including aircraft engaged solely in the carriage of cargo and also to domestic flights at the discretion of each member state.

ALW.question: In accordance with ICAO Annex 13, Chapter 1 - Definitions, what is an 'incident'?
choices: Any occurrence associated with the operation of an aircraft which affects or could affect aircraft or passenger safety.
An occurrence, other than an accident, associated with the operation of an aircraft which affects or could affect the safety of operation.
Any occurrence, other than an accident, associated with the operation of an aircraft which could adversely affect the safety of any persons or property.
Any incident, associated with the operation of an aircraft which affects or could affect the safety of operation.
ALW.answer: An occurrence, other than an accident, associated with the operation of an aircraft which affects or could affect the safety of operation.

ALW.question: A crew attempts to land on a closed runway. Under EU 996/2010 this is classified as:
ALW.answer: A serious incident.

ALW.question: In passenger-carrying aeroplanes equipped with a flight crew compartment door designed to resist penetration by small arms fire, when shall this door be closed and locked?
choices: From the time all external doors are closed following embarkation until opening such doors for disembarkation, except to permit entry and egress of authorised persons.
From the commencement of pushback until vacating the runway upon landing.
From the time the cabin crew reports “cabin ready” during taxi-out, until vacating the runway upon landing.
From the commencement of pushback until top-of-climb, and again from top-of-descent to vacating the runway upon landing.
ALW.answer: From the time all external doors are closed following embarkation until opening such doors for disembarkation, except to permit entry and egress of authorised persons.

ALW.question: Which of the following items of post-flight information provided by crews might be forwarded to the AIS?
choices: Any evidence of communicable disease among the passengers of a flight which has just landed.
Hazards posed by birds or other wildlife.
ALW.answer: Hazards posed by birds or other wildlife.

ALW.question: What additional lighting is required for runways being used for take-off with an RVR of 400 m or less?
choices: Either edge lights or centreline lights.
Runway edge lights and centreline lights.
ALW.answer: Runway edge lights and centreline lights.

ALW.question: Annex 14 to the convention on international civil aviation contains SARPS for:
ALW.answer: Aerodromes.

ALW.question: Which of the following are valid configurations for aerodrome signs?
choices: Mandatory instruction signs; black background with red inscriptions.
Mandatory instruction signs; red background with black inscriptions.
Information signs; orange background with black inscriptions.
Information signs: yellow or black background with black or yellow inscriptions.
ALW.answer: Information signs: yellow or black background with black or yellow inscriptions.

ALW.question: A simple approach lighting system:
choices: Is used with an ILS CAT I system.
Is used with an ILS CAT II system.
Should extend from the runway centreline, whenever possible, over a distance of 300 m.
Should extend from the runway centreline, whenever possible, over a distance of not less than 420 m.
ALW.answer: Should extend from the runway centreline, whenever possible, over a distance of not less than 420 m.

ALW.question: The 'clearway' is a defined rectangular area prepared to:
choices: Protect aircraft during take-off or landing operations.
Permit aircraft to make a portion of its initial climb to a specific height.
Reduce the risk of damage to aircraft running off a runway.
Permit the aircraft to stop if it fails the take-off.
ALW.answer: Permit aircraft to make a portion of its initial climb to a specific height.

ALW.question: The centreline and crossbar lights of a precision approach Category I lighting system are fixed lights, showing variable intensity of which colour?
ALW.answer: White.

ALW.question: Runway end lights are:
choices: Runway end lights are fixed unidirectional lights showing red in the direction of the runway.
Alternating green and red, fixed, variable intensity, unidirectional.
ALW.answer: Runway end lights are fixed unidirectional lights showing red in the direction of the runway.

ALW.question: All runway-holding positions where operations are conducted in low visibility have fixed unidirectional red lights extending across the width of the runway. These are called:
ALW.answer: Stop bars.

ALW.question: What is the maximum time between the initial call to the rescue and fire fighting service, and the time when the first responding vehicle is in position to apply foam at the scene of accident?
ALW.answer: 180 seconds.

ALW.question: The curves of a rapid exit taxiway should be designed to allow exits speeds under wet conditions of ______ km/h where the code number is 3 or 4
RWY-side-stripe markings are required:
choices: On all precision runways and any other paved runway where the edges are indistinct.
On all grass runways where the edges are indistinct.
ALW.answer: On all precision runways and any other paved runway where the edges are indistinct.

ALW.question: The principles of pavement classification numbers (PCNs) and aircraft classification numbers (ACNs) are described by ICAO Annex 14. These numbers describe the strength of a surface and the impact an aircraft will have on a surface. Select the correct option:
choices: The ACN of an aircraft is independent of the actual weight of the aircraft and tyre pressure and is always reported for maximum weight.
An aircraft with a given ACN value may operate on a surface with a lower PCN value if certain operational limitations are met.
The PCN value must be exactly equal to the ACN value of an aircraft in order to allow for unrestricted operation of that aircraft.
The published PCN value must be equal to or lower than the aircraft's ACN value to allow for continuous and unlimited operation.
ALW.answer: An aircraft with a given ACN value may operate on a surface with a lower PCN value if certain operational limitations are met.

ALW.question: What is meant by the term 'response time', regarding rescue and fire fighting (RFF) at an aerodrome?
choices: The time between the initial call to the rescue and fire fighting service, and the time when the first responding vehicle is in position to apply foam.
The time between the observation of the accident, and the time when the first responding vehicle is approaching the scene of accident.
The time between the initial call to the rescue and fire fighting service, and the time when the first responding vehicle is leaving the station.
The time between the initial call to the rescue and fire fighting service, and the time when the first responding vehicle is approaching the scene of accident.
ALW.answer: The time between the initial call to the rescue and fire fighting service, and the time when the first responding vehicle is in position to apply foam.

ALW.question: Temporary changes of 'long duration' and information of 'short duration' with extensive text and/or graphics are published as AIP supplements. The period of 'long duration' is:
ALW.answer: 3 months or longer.

ALW.question: Which is the principal composition of a precision approach Category I lighting system?
choices: A row of lights on the extended centreline of the runway, extending over a distance of 600 m from the runway threshold and a crossbar at a distance of 450 m from the runway threshold.
A row of lights on the extended centreline of the runway, extending over a distance of 900 m from the runway threshold and a crossbar at a distance of 300 m from the runway threshold.
A row of lights on the extended centreline of the runway, extending over a distance of 420 m from the runway threshold and a crossbar at a distance of 250 m from the runway threshold.
A row of lights on the extended centreline of the runway, extending over a distance of 900 m from the runway threshold and 5 crossbars at a distance of 300 m from the runway threshold.
ALW.answer: A row of lights on the extended centreline of the runway, extending over a distance of 900 m from the runway threshold and a crossbar at a distance of 300 m from the runway threshold.

ALW.question: _________ holding positions are locations which are established at all road entrances to runways.
ALW.answer: Road

ALW.question: An aircraft is expected to land at 22:30 UTC. The airport has little traffic. When must ground lights be brought into operation?
The length of runway which is declared available and suitable for the ground run of an aeroplane landing is the:
ALW.answer: LDA.

ALW.question: What is the purpose of a red spherical sign, 60 cm wide, giving the impression that it is floating near an obstacle?
choices: Indicate a dangerous area close to the airport.
Indicate a high object with a small surface area.
ALW.answer: High-tension lines or cables.

ALW.question: ASDA' (Acceleration Stop Distance Available) is:
choices: The length of the take-off run available plus the length of the clearway.
The length of the take-off run available plus the length of stopway (if provided).
The length of the runway plus the length of the RESA (if provided).
The length of the take-off run available plus the length of stopway and clearway (if provided).
ALW.answer: The length of the take-off run available plus the length of stopway (if provided).

ALW.question: You should not expect any kind of speed control within nm of the _____ runway threshold.
